I'm mixing with CD's, mastering onto DAT. One of the big problems I
have is that i can't always be cheking my DAT levels for overload, and
when i do overload, it sounds horrible. Also, my neighbors are getting
tired of my loudness, so i figure if i compress, at least it'll seem
louder... Anyways, it's high time to get a compressor/limiter.

Anybody have any recommendations on a stereo unit that sounds good, here
are the ones i have seen in catalogs, etc.

	Alesis Nano Compressor (about $200.00)
	Aphex "Tubesessensce" compressor (???)
	Behringer MDX2100 Composer (about $220)
	Rane Mojo MC22 ($299)
	DBX 262 (about $200.00)
	DBX 166A (about $350.00)
	DBX 1066 (about $500.00)
	TC Electonics "Finalizer" (about $2000).

The last one looks awesome and can also function as a high-end A/D
unit, 5 band parametric EQ, normalizer, stereo enhancer, and lots of
other stuff, but it's about 4X what I want to spend (about
$300-500.00)...

Also, anybody recommend a store in the bay area that carries these
units so's i can check 'em out?

Subject: Re: a groovy thing bout music
Cc: Frisco Freaks <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

House/techno is surging ahead in Europe because it is becoming Disco Part II,
a huge commercialized edifice built on the foundation of an underground
music movement.  There are plenty of old-style "underground" events there,
but the scene seems (from afar, since I haven't visited) to be pushing well
along the popularization curve with all the trappings -- the DJ as star,
club culture overtaking the non-commercial scene, incorporation of house
and techno into commercials, TV and other mass media, and so on.  Some
good, some not so good in all that, I think.  Certainly it mitigates
against innovation and inquisitiveness in both the producer and listener
as far as the music is concerned.  I was buying 75% UK and European in
1993 and 25% domestic, the proportions are nearly reversed now though the
proportion of European releases is far greater.

The change in the dance music magazines from specialist to mass-market is
the biggest indicator.  I really liked Mixmag and DJ a couple years ago,
even as commercial as they were then.  Now they and Muzik and even Jockey
Slut have turned into People for Clubbers, complete with every DJ's favorite
color and pet peeves.  

I had some hope this wouldn't happen with house and techno, but frankly,
it now all seems basically inevitable.  

phred

to all you that are paranoid about the "scene" dying out...I am not
afraid...dancing will never be out of style, dancing will never lose its
magic no matter how much press you give it...maybe the "raver" lifestyle
may get a little old, but if you truly love the ritual of dancing and
losing yourself all night long... as has been happening since the dawn of
man then you have nothing to worry about...this energy is not based upon
four million peoples approval, along with camel and budweiser.
I cant say what it is about for me, maybe if you want to talk in person, I
can elaborate about the meaning of dance for ME, but I really believe that
most people here understand but, that is for all to figure out on their
own...but certainly, camel, budweiser, all the mixmags and "popular" press
dont really have a clue...maybe the individuals of the organization do,
But, once the mentality changes to money and control of the popular
opinion, the organization as a whole loses touch with the energy.

NOTHING will ever stop me from dancing!
tony rose...



> House/techno is surging ahead in Europe because it is becoming Disco Part II,
> a huge commercialized edifice built on the foundation of an underground
> music movement.  There are plenty of old-style "underground" events there,
> but the scene seems (from afar, since I haven't visited) to be pushing well
> along the popularization curve with all the trappings -- the DJ as star,
> club culture overtaking the non-commercial scene, incorporation of house
> and techno into commercials, TV and other mass media, and so on.  Some
> good, some not so good in all that, I think.  Certainly it mitigates
> against innovation and inquisitiveness in both the producer and listener
> as far as the music is concerned.  I was buying 75% UK and European in
> 1993 and 25% domestic, the proportions are nearly reversed now though the
> proportion of European releases is far greater.
> 
> The change in the dance music magazines from specialist to mass-market is
> the biggest indicator.  I really liked Mixmag and DJ a couple years ago,
> even as commercial as they were then.  Now they and Muzik and even Jockey
> Slut have turned into People for Clubbers, complete with every DJ's favorite
> color and pet peeves.  
> 
> I had some hope this wouldn't happen with house and techno, but frankly,
> it now all seems basically inevitable.  
> 
> phred
>

On Fri, 8 Nov 1996, ~^JBondy wrote:

> To some, flyers are keepsakes of times past. We can look beyond the
> obvious fact that there real purpose is to attract, but there are some 
> of the cooler underground ones with say a simple logo, black and white
> xerox with a name and a ph#. These are more like invitations, and less
> like advertisements.

My first couple of parties I went to had little or no flyering and it was 
there i picked up flyers for future raves I wanted to attend.  Being new 
to the scene at the time and not being "in-the-know", flyers were the only 
ways I knew about parties.

Now that I live in the Central Coast the people around here rely on word 
of mouth and local friends.  If a flyer pops up around here people are 
interested.  There's not much out here in the way of a rave scene so 
anything is better than nothing.  I recently distributed some flyers at 
Quest in Santa Barbra and about everyone picked one up, looked at it and 
gave it to a friend or kept it.  Hardcore ravers will drive the 3 - 4 
hours a weekend here to go to LA or SF because there is not much here. 

   Interest in the rave scene is rasing here.  There are many local dj's 
that just got their start a year or two ago and are making an impact on 
the locals about the rave scene else were.  Seismic flyered well for 
this area and pulled a great crowd.  The party went off past 6am which 
is great for this area and everyone came away with a positive 
impression and wanting more....  But there is not much more unless you 
go south or north.  If I had the time and money I would love to throrw 
a DIY and flyers would be one of the best ways to introduce new people 
to the scene.  

*I think I rambled*

As far as the tras thing you can only hope responcible peopel will throw 
there trash in the cans - providied that there are some.


  >  Sorry, I have no 
conclusion... and besides, I'm SCR, why do I keep > posting up here? ;)
> 
> JBondy
> 
Hey I post to both SCR and SFR.  It's one of the connections I have left 
to the scene - besides my mixed tapes.  :P

PS I never personally made it to Seismic in SLO but from all my friends I 
heard Thomas Micheal was sic and Kimo threw down some funky shit - over 
all the best organized/promoted party thrown in SLO county to date.
It was on a hill with two large tents -one for chill filled with 
matresses and the other the main dance area.
(I got to requset those party days off - doh!)  

There's another party schedualed for Dec 7th here and i'll post d-tails L8TR.

  PLUR,

       Austin

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Nov 10 18:06:10 1996

Received: from plastikdreams.sonoma.edu (SA-6EN38.sonoma.edu)

 10 Nov 1996 18:05:52 -0800 (PST)
Date: Sun, 10 Nov 1996 18:08:07 +0000
From: Jonas Hanning <hanning@SONOMA.EDU>
Subject: 2o12 Review [bitchy]
X-Sender: hanning@sonoma.edu
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>,
        Ola Persson <d95olape@ostrabo.uddevalla.se>
Message-id: <3.0.32.19961110180805.006faa50@sonoma.edu>
MIME-version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 3.0 Demo (32)
Content-type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

After warming up with Flouro (happytrance at its best/worst mixed by
Paul Oakenfold), we finally arrived at 2o12 around 11:30. The beats
were mesmerizing, and I immediately found my way over to the speakers
to the right (when facing the DJ booth). And for the next 5 hours, I
was unable to leave that spot. This was psychedelic trance at its best.
Maybe a little bit too soft and fluffy, but still WICKED! The last 45
minutes of these 5 hours were bouncy acid with lots of breaks, and 
definitively the best 45 minutes of the night.

Then at 4:30, 3 things happened...
1. The average BPM dropped from 145 or so to 80. We're not talking DANCE
music anymore, we're talking Fugees and 2Pac (tempowise). Slow, trippy
acid is really neat at 9-10 in the morning, but at 4:30? At 4:30 we should
get the hardest and fastest beats!
2. Someone decided to turn down the volume. And not just a notch or two,
more like 50%. It was about the same level I keep it when my roommates are
asleep. =(
3. The DJ obviously felt that he was done for the night, and started mixing
like ... well, a NON-mixed CD. I can mix better with ONE turntable.

The BPM _did_ pick up after half an hour or so, and the last hour was more
wonderful ACID MAYHEM! But the fact that there was no mixing whatsoever still
lowered the overall score.

And now it's time to bitch. If you don't want to read my bitching, please stop
reading now. =)

Still here? Ok, here goes... I go to a rave to dance to mixed music, I don't
go to a rave to jump around in a circle or watch some slender girl stand on
her head in the middle of the dancefloor (impressive, but the way she shoved
us out of the way was TOTALLY rude!) to unmixed music. I'm sorry if this is
putting down your loving SF-scene, but that's the way I feel. Don't get me
wrong though, the overall vibe at 2o12 was WONDERFUL. It's just these little
things that bug me. =)

I hope everyone had a good weekend, no matter where they went. =)

reespect, jonas
***********************************************************

*    "still listening to wax, i'm not using the cd..."    *
***********************************************************

To Tom and everyone who threw 2o12:  You all should be patting yourself 
on the back for a party well done!  The space was excellent, the banners 
and artwork were *breathtaking*.  I am SO glad to have gotten a couple of 
photos of them before some fell down (due to humidity?).

I was surprised to find  that I knew Jeremia, who was one of the first 
dj's I believe.  What a trip.  Last time I saw him, he was living in 
Sacramento helping my exboyfriend in his sound production.  He's come 
quite far!  

Then our very own "Superstar DJ" Tom (as his friends lovingly call him) 
spun a wonderful set.  The power could not keep up with Tom's great energy, 
as it cut out a couple of times.  But hey, sometimes things like that 
happen.  

Then Dutch came on after Tom and his music worked me.  That's all I can 
say.  I was by the right front speaker, too, watching Jonas and his 
glowing head, but I mostly closed my eyes and deeply tranced out for what 
seemed like hours.  Thank you for that, Dutch - I really needed that!

One more thing before I sign off.  NubChaiCircus - what is their secret 
ingredient for their magic chai?!?!  I make the stuff at home now (my 
first chai was NubChai at Burning Man) and it's just not the same!  
Theirs is ***SOOOO*** much better!  Everyone I know now is addicted to 
the stuff.  I can see it becoming the next big thing to those who are 
coffee'd out.

love,
Amy

...to Michael Clay and his stunning visuals @ 2o12.

that film traveled all over the world, capturing people in spiritual, 
ecstactic bliss during religious rituals, or just meditating by 
themselves. It was really a unifying experience for me, because I felt 
we were all participating in our own ritual as we were watching others do 
it in their way.

wouldn't looking at the positive aspects of 2012 be more betterest then
it's flip side...

have a look at the world around u ... imho we have enough of that ugly lip
side of reality

love 
ben

ps.. 2012 was the celebration of the continuty of incredible change that
lays ahead..


At 06:08 PM 11/10/96 +0000, you wrote:
>After warming up with Flouro (happytrance at its best/worst mixed by
>Paul Oakenfold), we finally arrived at 2o12 around 11:30. The beats
>were mesmerizing, and I immediately found my way over to the speakers
>to the right (when facing the DJ booth). And for the next 5 hours, I
>was unable to leave that spot. This was psychedelic trance at its best.
>Maybe a little bit too soft and fluffy, but still WICKED! The last 45
>minutes of these 5 hours were bouncy acid with lots of breaks, and 
>definitively the best 45 minutes of the night.
>
>Then at 4:30, 3 things happened...
>1. The average BPM dropped from 145 or so to 80. We're not talking DANCE
>music anymore, we're talking Fugees and 2Pac (tempowise). Slow, trippy
>acid is really neat at 9-10 in the morning, but at 4:30? At 4:30 we should
>get the hardest and fastest beats!
>2. Someone decided to turn down the volume. And not just a notch or two,
>more like 50%. It was about the same level I keep it when my roommates are
>asleep. =(
>3. The DJ obviously felt that he was done for the night, and started mixing
>like ... well, a NON-mixed CD. I can mix better with ONE turntable.
>
>The BPM _did_ pick up after half an hour or so, and the last hour was more
>wonderful ACID MAYHEM! But the fact that there was no mixing whatsoever still
>lowered the overall score.
>
>And now it's time to bitch. If you don't want to read my bitching, please
stop
>reading now. =)
>
>Still here? Ok, here goes... I go to a rave to dance to mixed music, I don't
>go to a rave to jump around in a circle or watch some slender girl stand on
>her head in the middle of the dancefloor (impressive, but the way she shoved
>us out of the way was TOTALLY rude!) to unmixed music. I'm sorry if this is
>putting down your loving SF-scene, but that's the way I feel. Don't get me
>wrong though, the overall vibe at 2o12 was WONDERFUL. It's just these little
>things that bug me. =)
>
>I hope everyone had a good weekend, no matter where they went. =)
>
>reespect, jonas

>
>Wow, 
>
>That pretty much sums up my weekend experience.   This weekend is THE reason
>why Im proud of my Bay Area scene.
>
>Although I really don't post much on reviews anymore and this is generally
>the time of parties waning until the big X-mas and New Year massives. I'd
>have to say this weekend was stellar.
>
>Friday:  after chilling @ F-8 for a while I boogied up to the Sutra Tower
>(great night, clear not too cold) B-4 heading to Smiles.  As I arrived, I
>heard the familiar "woomp, woomp. thump, thump, thump"  of a techno groove
>bumpin' from some other car.  I hooked up with some ravers there, shared
>partying experiences and spun down to a small house party that ended round
>4AM...  A few of us broke for breakfast peeled @ another house caught 3 hrs
>of sleep and then boogied down to SJ for _Discovery_.
>
>Saturday:  _Discovery_  SJ still has that House vibe goin on.  I dropped by
>Upstairs Records (Santa Clara btwn 1st and 2nd) b-4 going to _Discovery_ ,and
>chatted with one of the owners.  Not too much in techno but more of a Latino
>flavour.  Arrived @ Children's Park about 1PM.  Cool statues of bunnies and
>frogs and kittens.  Very intimate vibe and no more than 40 or so people at
>the apex....  House and house with the exception of a (goa?, electro?) other
>DJ whose genere of music I really couldn't identify... Ended on a flat note
>though, when the generator ran out of oil...
>Left the SJ vicinity 'bout 5PM and ended up hanging w/some friends till
>12-or-so deciding on which part to attend.  Ended up @ an Underground 
>
>__BLISS__ in Berkeley.  Dancing up a storm till the wee hrs. of the morning
>the vibe died out around 5AM so back to The City to watch the sunrise from
>the GG bridge.  Chilled @ another friends house in the sunset dist. and
>caught bout 2more hrs of ZZZ's.
>
>Sunday:   Entered society @ the Serrimonte Shopping Centre to pick up some
>shoes (my lil' toe bust through my last pair @ _Bliss_).  Then of to buy some
>sick tracks (dark cybertrance, very cool).  Ventured to a pals house in
>Oakland and arriving @ home in Fremont @ 6:30.  Mixing my new tracks a into
>olde King Morpheus laid claim to me @ 8PM...  Nice 11Hr sleep set and here I
>sit staring and  still feeling the afterglow of this fine weekend....
>
>I'd like to thank all those to whom I chatted with, kicked it with and
>chilled out to throughout these past 48 hrs.
>
> Shade and sweetwater,
>---Adam
>"Stay Connected..."
>

be very , very lucky. Some of you have>> >>>already heard this story. (I
think one of you sent it to me once :)>> >>>>> >>>  "The Gift">> >>>>>
>>>A young man wanted to purchase a gift for his new sweetheart's
birthday,>> >>>and as they had not been dating very long, after careful
consideration, he>> >>>decided a pair of gloves would strike the right
note: romantic, but not>> >>>too personal.>> >>>>> >>>Accompanied by his
sweetheart's younger sister, he went to Nordstrom and>> >>>bought a pair
of white gloves.  The sister purchased a pair of panties>> >>>for
herself.>> >>>>> >>>During the wrapping, the clerk mixed up the items
and the sister got the>> >>>gloves and the sweetheart got the panties.
Without checking the>> >>>contents, the young man sealed the package and
sent it to his sweetheart>> >>>with the following note:>> >>>>> >>>"I
chose these because I noticed that you are not in the habit of wearing>>
>>>any when we go out in the evening.  If it had not been for your
sister, I>> >>>would have chosen the long ones with the buttons, but she
wears short>> >>>ones that are easier to remove.>> >>>>> >>>"These are a
delicate shade, but the lady I bought them from showed me>> >>>the pair
she had been wearing for the past three weeks and they were>>hardly>>
>>>soiled.  I had her try yours on for me and she looked really smart.>>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Nov 11 10:05:21 1996

Received: from smtplink.acer.com ([204.160.139.137]) by acergw3.acer.com (8.7.3/8.7.3) with SMTP id KAA06244 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 11 Nov 1996 10:02:16 -0800 (PST)
Received: from ccMail by smtplink.acer.com (SMTPLINK V2.11.01)
	id AA847735897; Mon, 11 Nov 96 10:01:40 pst
Date: Mon, 11 Nov 96 10:01:40 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9610118477.AA847735897@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Chrysalis (Extended Rambling Included)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hit Discovery right after a whoppin spaghetti lunch at OJ's (it was local for a 
SanJosean like me).  Nice to see an outdoor, mellow production with some nice 
music, and a group of people all having a good time.  Too simple a formula.  
Just be outside on a nice day and have fun.  Had to leave after no time at all 
though... whaa.

Went for a tour of the Bay area for the benefit of my friend from LA.  Too bad I
ran out of time for the MOMA... I wanted her to see the giant multimedia potato 
from hell.  Went to band practice, they were all drunk when I got there.  It 
went on forever.

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>Actual Chrysalis Review Here<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

Finally left for Chrysalis around 1:00.  Picked up Phil and Kate after they were
stranded at the map point, which really put a positive tilt on everything (Phil 
admits to being an alien, Kate just has a great accent, both were FULL of 
energy).

Got there at two.

Found out I missed Deak's set.  I like Deaks because he spins like I drive.  
Hectic, spazzy, and spins his wheels sometimes coming around corners.

EconoRaver Victory...
$1 water bottles and free fills at the fountain thingy... nice to find after a 
$15 ticket.  You can make a profit on $1 water.  I think the vegan fruit 
smoothies were $2 bucks.  Nice for the budget raver.

Had to take care of freshly out of box newbie from LA (Lesly says big hi to 
everybody she met this weekend BTW).  E hit a little hard for the uninitiated 
one.  Had fun telling funny stories at whisper volume all night to cheer her up.
 She felt a lot better as the morning came, and I took her to the chill room to 
dance to a great morning set from whoever it was *sorry* (thanks for showing us 
those morning clouds John).  I will never hear "What's going on" by Marvin Gaye 
the same way, a definite compliment to whoever was spinning around 6:30am 
for keeping the groove with the crowd.

On the Main Room...
There's a part of me that honestly wishes that trance dj's would play something 
other than trance in their sets.  Two sets in a row I heard nothing but hard 
trance being played, and it seems like there's more that can be done.  I've 
heard some DJ's mix it up stylewise, and those are the sets I walk (or crawl) 
away from feeling like I've finished a journey.  If it's the same sounding music
at the same speed with the same 4/4 kick drum, how could it be going anywhere?  
It was also very steamy/hot/funky in there, on account of 100 groovers, no vents
and one fan.

Anyway, the night was a bittersweet kind of beautiful, and it's great to see the
sun after a long night of helping keep somebody sane and comfy.

As I we left, somebody was found who had overdone it, apparently on Ketamine.  
My heart goes to her brother, who was outside and scared, and to her, hoping 
that all goes well.  Other than that, I guess there's little I can say or do 
except hope.  To everybody who does chemicals, be careful.

Peace,
AndyW

Raving + Having to be at work @ 7am = Narcoleptic Mondays

ZZZZZzzzzzz.....

From: "Thompson. Jim" <jthompson@arkons.lmsc.lockheed.com>
To: sfraves - send mail to list <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: My last word (Money isn't the problem, Money isn't the solution)...
Date: Mon, 11 Nov 1996 09:57:00 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.993.5
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

My major point is not that the well-off are paying too much in taxes,
it's that
the way the tax load is DISTRIBUTED results in a built-in bias toward
more
government.  The fact that some citizens taxes are increased to benefit
other citizens is what  cannot be justified - it's merely one group
taking money
away from another, whether they can "afford" it or not.  A perverse side
effect
of increased government spending is that taxes on ALL citizens tend to
increase.  If you dropped income taxes to zero on low income earners,
they
would still be groaning under the weight of all the sales taxes,
property taxes
(which they pay indirectly when they rent), car registration "fees",
road tolls,
etc.....


jim thompson - CUBE ROOT FACT AXON INFO GRID DATA FATE

     it seems kinda funny that a couple hundred years ago (give or take a

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: My last word (Money isn't the problem, Money isn't the solut
Author:  "Thompson. Jim" <jthompson@arkons.lmsc.lockheed.com> at ccsmtp
Date:    11/11/96 9:57 AM


My major point is not that the well-off are paying too much in taxes, 
it's that
the way the tax load is DISTRIBUTED results in a built-in bias toward 
more
government.  The fact that some citizens taxes are increased to benefit 
other citizens is what  cannot be justified - it's merely one group 
taking money
away from another, whether they can "afford" it or not.  A perverse side 
effect
of increased government spending is that taxes on ALL citizens tend to 
increase.  If you dropped income taxes to zero on low income earners, 
they
would still be groaning under the weight of all the sales taxes, 
property taxes
(which they pay indirectly when they rent), car registration "fees", 
road tolls,
etc.....
     
     
jim thompson - CUBE ROOT FACT AXON INFO GRID DATA FATE

Hey kids!

Thanks to all who made it to the Gateway party Saturday.  Thanks for the
review Andy.  Here are some random comments...

At 6:01 PM -0000 11/11/96, Andy Wyszkowski wrote:
>Found out I missed Deak's set.  I like Deaks because he spins like I drive.
>Hectic, spazzy, and spins his wheels sometimes coming around corners.

Yes, Deaks moves wax like a well greased hive...  =)  There were a number
of comments that Deaks shouldn't have spun first, but one, I love that
someone has to get the cogs turning, and who better than Ernie?  Second, I
feel it was pretty fair consulation that he spun for 2hrs. and 20min.  =)
Anyone wishing to hear more of Ernie Deaks should consider the Pro Soy
event "Wyrd" on the 23rd.  (BSP:  I'll be spinning in the morning, as well.)

>EconoRaver Victory...
>$1 water bottles and free fills at the fountain thingy... nice to find
>after a
>$15 ticket.  You can make a profit on $1 water.  I think the vegan fruit

Yeah, probably enough to cover gas from CostCo to the party and back.  =)

>those morning clouds John).  I will never hear "What's going on" by Marvin
>Gaye
>the same way, a definite compliment to whoever was spinning around 6:30am
>for keeping the groove with the crowd.

Joe Rice and Brad were spinning in the morning.  I believe it was Brad that
spun MG.  My kind of guy...=)

>
>On the Main Room...
>There's a part of me that honestly wishes that trance dj's would play
>something
>other than trance in their sets.  Two sets in a row I heard nothing but hard
>trance being played, and it seems like there's more that can be done.  I've
>heard some DJ's mix it up stylewise, and those are the sets I walk (or crawl)
>away from feeling like I've finished a journey.  If it's the same sounding
>music
>at the same speed with the same 4/4 kick drum, how could it be going
>anywhere?
>It was also very steamy/hot/funky in there, on account of 100 groovers, no
>vents
>and one fan.

I can't comment on the music you like or don't like.  All I know, is that
it was consistent, and pounding, and there were a lot of people loving
it...I think the best way to make an impact, is to get involved.  If you
like sets where DJs mix it up, lead by example.  I'm not saying this to
sound harsh, or be an asshole.  It's just that everyone has their taste and
style.  Have you ever watched Minor Minor spin?  Dude, that cat is working
the Rane so hard.  It's amazing!

As for the heat, that's an issue with the venue.  The sound was too loud on
the street to open windows.  There's really not much you can do there.  I'd
love to hear your ideas.  Consider this, however:  There needs to be foam
on the windows for sound proofing, there are power limitations, and there
are two small openings into the main room.  A sound system can't build
vents in the space, can't force people not to dance there, and there was
more than one fan.  Heat is a part of the dance studio, much as it was a
part of Acme, and Komotion, and King Street, and....  It's something that
comes with the territory.  The third room wasn't officially ours to use,
and we risked a lot to let peopel chill in there, but I allowed it to help
let people get a breath of fresh air.

>As I we left, somebody was found who had overdone it, apparently on
>Ketamine.
>My heart goes to her brother, who was outside and scared, and to her, hoping
>that all goes well.  Other than that, I guess there's little I can say or do
>except hope.  To everybody who does chemicals, be careful.

She's okay.  It was GHB.  I think she may have taken some K, but it was
mostly a GHB thing.  She woke up yesterday and is alright now.  I agree,
Andy, people have got to be careful of what they take.  That stuff is a
promoter's nightmare.

Anyway, thanks again folks, it was a fun little party.  =)

Love
Tony

P.S.  How about that chill space?  Man, with the laser hitting the crystal?
Brilliant!

Greetings all!
I did have a rather hectic weekend .... all good though!
I was in L.A. friday nigth and went to the wicked party and had a great 
time. Doc Martin and Garth rocked my world ( my part of the world that 
digs house anyway). An excellent set by Stefan in the other room. He 
platyed the most eclectic set I've ever seen anyone play before. Cool.

Drove back up here after a few hours of sleep so that I could follow my 
heart and go to 2012. 2012 was one of those things that I JUST HAD TO BE AT!
It was sublime! THank you Jason, Lauren, Tom etc. for everything. The 
good folks at Nubchai circus kept me going for a long time with their 
excellent chai, fruit, and most importantly phat love vibe in everything 
they did.
Excellent music all the way through. I was having too good a time and 
digging on that pure energy in the room to notice any of the sound 
malfunctions that I've been reading about. 
Got to meet tons of really aware people! 
In essence, I have never felt at home with the vibe as I did with 
everybody at 2012. I will be there all the way for anything these 
guys do next.
The enormous group hug , Om session, and spontaneous hugs all night 
reinforced the essence of Goa for me.

Thank you all for being there and making it one of the 
most special nights of my life.


Until next time
Peace and Love
Dhiren

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Nov 11 13:03:38 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id NAA28661; Mon, 11 Nov 1996 13:03:38 -0800 (PST)

Received: (from simitzis@localhost) by netcom17.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id NAA00892; Mon, 11 Nov 1996 13:03:29 -0800
Date: Mon, 11 Nov 1996 13:03:29 -0800
From: simitzis@netcom.com (Steve Simitzis)
Message-Id: <199611112103.NAA00892@netcom17.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: my weekend of fruit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


This weekend was insane. I stayed awake for 34 hours, went to four
parties, and had an incredible time (despite the fact that I was
sick). This weekend was a blur in every sense of the word, so here's
a whirlwind review of each party:

- Cyborganic

Most of you probably hadn't heard of this, since it was private party
at the Cyborganic offices. There was techno and jungle in the
basement, though not that many people were dancing. Weird Blinking
Lights played, which brought back some of my tweakier memories of
Burning Man. Talked to some friends, ate some fruit, and left.

- 2012

This was the party to be at last night! The people involved with 2012
did a *beautiful* job of decorating the space, probably the best use
of the D7 warehouse that I've seen yet. Todd's blacklight art made yet
another appearance, and many other banners and glowing things in the
Mayan theme covered the walls.

I caught most of Tom and Dutch who spun some excellent psychedelic
trance. The music was so good that I was almost tempted to stay and
discontinue my party hopping (some of the people I was party hopping
with decided to stay, though).

The vibe that they created at 2012 was amazing. It just goes to show
you what happens when a few ravers get together with all of the energy
and positivity that they can gather to throw their own party. Not
big-wig rave promoters, not business people after the "rave market";
just plain good folks who want to share an evening of music and
celebration.

And of course, Nub Chai :) was there, those wonderful people who made
Chai such a special part of my life. So I drank a lot of Chai, talked
to some friends, ate some fruit, and left.

- Gateway (Chrysalis)

I came here around 4:30/5-ish. I'm glad I went - I was able to see
many friends that I had seen at the other two parties. I came just in
time to see Greg spin, which was nice; he was spinning exactly the
kind of music I was in the mood for. He ended (or what I thought was the
end) his set was a nice mellow song that wound everyone down.

But then he decided to sneak in one more...pretty hard and
thumping. It was just enough to get me pumped up for the next party :)
After that, the music ended for the night, so I talked to some
friends, ate some fruit, and left.

- CCC

While at 2012, I had heard of a CCC party that was a mere block away
from my house; so why not? Okay, it was 7am, but I was sure they would
keep it going until at least 9am.

So I arrived at party number four. And looking around, all I saw were
remains of a wonderful night. I have loved CCC events since Burning
Man, but unfortunately there were too many other things going on this
weekend for me to have gone to this one in its entirety.

They finished the morning with some beautiful spiritual ambient music,
but still very much with a Goa feeling. I ate some fruit, and left,
feeling grounded and energized.

- Other stuff

After all of the celebration, fruit, and Chai that I absorbed, I had
too much energy in me to even think about sleeping. So I spent the
entire day, mostly wide awake and happy doing things. After much
prodding from people ("you should sleep you crazy fool!") I finally
forced myself to go to bed later on that night...simply an insane
weekend :)

Too bad there was no Sunset! I was definitely up for that!!!

- Gripe section

I have a small gripe/request that relates to map points. Frequency 8
is not the best location to use for a map point, especially when the
party is downtown (ie. SOMA). For people who are already coming up
from the South or East Bay, this might not present a problem.

But for those of us who are local to San Francisco, it can be somewhat
difficult. I would like to ask promoters to please try to keep map
points within 8 or so blocks of the party, and at the very least have
the map point and the party on the same bus line.

Thanks; I know of others who have this gripe, and I thought I would
present it here for consideration/flaming :)

- Future plans

Hopefully, we'll see some of you tonight at our crazy pre-Mad dinner
party. Or if not, at Mad :)

Steve

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Nov 11 13:15:14 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id NAA00139; Mon, 11 Nov 1996 13:15:14 -0800 (PST)
Received: from wired.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with ESMTP id NAA00126; Mon, 11 Nov 1996 13:15:09 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [204.62.132.181] (megalon.hotwired.com [204.62.132.181]) by wired.com (8.7.6/8.7.3) with ESMTP id NAA03929; Mon, 11 Nov 1996 13:14:49 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v0300781caead44be8f9a@[204.62.132.181]>
In-Reply-To: <199611100233.SAA27966@netcom8.netcom.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

To: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>,
        "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
From: Brian Benitez <benitez@hotwired.com>
Subject: Re: anybody recommend a good quality compressor/limiter
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 6:33 PM -0800 11/9/96, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
>I'm mixing with CD's, mastering onto DAT. One of the big problems I
>have is that i can't always be cheking my DAT levels for overload, and
>when i do overload, it sounds horrible. Also, my neighbors are getting
>tired of my loudness, so i figure if i compress, at least it'll seem
>louder... Anyways, it's high time to get a compressor/limiter.
>
>Anybody have any recommendations on a stereo unit that sounds good, here
>are the ones i have seen in catalogs, etc.
>
>	Alesis Nano Compressor (about $200.00)
>	Aphex "Tubesessensce" compressor (???)
>	Behringer MDX2100 Composer (about $220)
>	Rane Mojo MC22 ($299)
>	DBX 262 (about $200.00)
>	DBX 166A (about $350.00)
>	DBX 1066 (about $500.00)
>	TC Electonics "Finalizer" (about $2000).
>
>The last one looks awesome and can also function as a high-end A/D
>unit, 5 band parametric EQ, normalizer, stereo enhancer, and lots of
>other stuff, but it's about 4X what I want to spend (about
>$300-500.00)...

Stay away from the Alesis, it's nasty... TC Electronics is high end stuff,
if you can afford it it's the best thing on the list.

The Behringer is a good unit (they operate by making knock-offs of better,
higher priced gear - I think this one's based on an Aphex), as is the Aphex
Tubessence. I think this goes for about $200-300??? Aphex makes great
stuff, definitely have a listen to that one. If you're in the market for
something a bit pricier (but not as much as the TC), try out an Aphex
Compellor, or one of the other Aphex high-end dynamics processors - they're
well worth the money, the sound great and add a lot of warmth to the sound.
(If you're primarliy looking for something to keep overloading your DAT for
mastering, you may even want to check out their Dominator II Limiter -
absolute brickwall limiting that sounds great even at limiting levels of 15
dB or greater). I also have used the dbx 1066 and 166A and find them to be
good - the 1066 is a nice unit with lots of control over the dynamics, you
need to be careful and know what you're doing with this one. The other dbx
units have fewer controls and are easier to set up and get a good sound out
of.

Dunno about the Rane, but they generally make good gear. Also check out the
Drawmer DL 241 for about $500, nice compression unit that's easy to use.

Try out Leo's on Van Ness (or in Oakland on Telegraph) if you want
demonstrations of this stuff... Cutting Edge in SF is a good place to buy
but they don't have a lot of stock on hand to test with.

It sounds to me like your application is more limiting than compression.
Most compressor/limiters have a fairly puny limiting section - often one
"peak stop" knob. If this is truly what you need it for - keeping a DAT
from clipping - and you're not interstied in general compression, I'd
seriously consider getting a dedicated limiter instead. There's not many on
the market, but you might find that you'll have more precise control and
better sound out of something that's designed to do that job exclusively.

--
. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
Brian Benitez                    Audio Engineer, HotWired
benitez@hotwired.com             http://www.hotwired.com/
. . . . . . . . . . (415) 276-8416. . . . . . . . . . . .

they're a fungus. And hey, alcohol is a naturally occurring substance (sure
people make it), but it's a natural process of fruit of wood fermenting. . .
is that a drug? What about nicotene, it isn't made by man (well not really)
it's a chemical that's in tobacco leaves, another naturally occurring plant,
is nicotene a drug? What about peyote (however it's spelled), or morning
glories, or tenactl (I think that's right), or other naturally growing
substances that are used for certain spiritual enhancement?

        Now a question for you all: Is whatever not a drug unless you use it
as one?
   At what point is use and abuse seperated?

may be a plant, but it's so mutated for strength or whatever that's it's not
natural anymore. Like nature made hydroponic green bomb weed. . . yeah. . .

I haven't seen no reviews on 2nd Chakra!
 I'm not much of a poet but: Roses are red and violins are brown. At 2nd
Chakra. Well EVERYBODY got down!
 I am probably the only person in the world that has to blow of nurmorous
bad vibes every Saturday night. But I had a blast at this party! NEXUS has
got it together big time.
 I stayed in the chill room for like three hours when I got there. E'in
tornadoes! They were playing some realy fun music in there. Everyone was
move from side to side just having a great time! Kinna like on that movie
Grease Lightning. How everyone on there was always boogyin down together...
 But check it out. Sence I love to whine so much n all...  Check it out. 
My friend Luciana went with me last night.. And we were kicking it in the
chill room fer quite awhile nStuff.. It felt so good to just lay there and
chill yanno?
Well I finally talked her into getting off her ass, so we could go dance.
And on the way to the main room we held hands (most likely becouse Luciana
didn't want every guy hitting on her on the way there). 
 But all the people you may have heard me talk about before. Well they were
trippin! I heard:
"Check it out! He has a girlfriend!!!"
"What the...  Now I am really confused"
"Who is she.." <snobby>
And alot of other things, some flattering, some just plain rude "Bla, bla,
bla." anyways.
 Well. I care about Luciana alot. And I would like to be with her. But she
likes tall guys, buff guys, brunets, tan. And alot of other things I am
none of. Even though I feel she likes me too...  I still think about
thoughs things. So I think we would be better off just friends becouse of
her standards nAll..

 Later on while we were dancing (apart) <--- You know.. To be honest. I
have trouble dancing in contact with women to "techno"..  It just don't
click.  I used to be the master at the Hip Hop clubs.. But I have no
practice slow dancing to Jungle, sorry.  =[   Anyways.. While we were
dancing. I saw this guy with a hat just like the one she whore at the last
ravE. I wanted her to have one. So she went up to the guy and borrowed his
hat. Then she came back and told me she was going to dance with him for
awhile. Ok..  Cool. I seem to dance better alone anyways right?
 Well while she was dancing with him. Thoughs people.. GOD! They thought I
let her slip away (maybe I did)  So I hear things like:
"What an idiot! She took off"
"What? Your mom won't let you have sex tell you get out of high school?"
"Check him out. He is leaving alone"
And much, much more funny Stuff......
Whats up with this?  Why do people care so much about my sexual prefrence
and status? What is so special about me? So I am the only person at the
ravE, not seen kissing some girl? I doubt that.  And um it's not that I
don't wanna kiss no girls.. I realized that girls did not have the koodies
along time ago. Lemme tell yea.. And I have already had my share of good n
bad relationships.
 Most people seem offended that I don't talk to them (heard it).  But they
don't talk to me either.. Well.. Only behind my back.. Sheeesh how rude
huh..

Got to get back to work though..
Cami. I sent a letter to the rave page at work. But I don't see it on
here..  I was looking for you.. I lost all my current HDD stuff..  My drive
stopped spinning. And everything for the last month or so that was not
backt up. GONE!
So E-Mail me.....


Jeff

Received: from niles.com (niles.com [157.22.229.1]) by zocalo.net (8.7.5/8.7.3) with ESMTP id NAA09622 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 11 Nov 1996 13:57:07 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [157.22.229.127] by niles.com
 with SMTP (Apple Internet Mail Server 1.1b2d4); Mon, 11 Nov 1996 13:57:03 -0800
Message-Id: <v02130514aead4e65b5de@[157.22.229.127]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 11 Nov 1996 13:57:28 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: peter@niles.com (Customer Service)
Subject: Let me tell you about the kind of guy I am (a love story)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Friday night, my homeboys tried to talk me into checking out a rave in San
Francisco, but I had other plans.

See, sometimes on Friday nights I get in the mood to hop in my IROC and
sliiiiiide on down to the Sound Factory to check out the score, if you
catch my drift.  And having a bunch of your homeboys hanging around when
you're looking for love just ain't the bus I'm lookin to ride.

So once I had myself looking all fresh in my new Gucci loafers, black 501's
and my P.I.M.P. t-shirt, I jumped in the ride, dropped the pedal to floor,
and let the house beats  pump out the trunk, tossing empty Colt 45's out
the window, just to let everyone know what time it was.  Cause that's the
kind of guy I am.

Johnny was working the door down at the Sound Factory, and he don't like me
coming around these days, on account of my reputation on the dance floor.
I guess all the boys there start fussing and pouting when I'm macking the
ladies, so ole' Johnny finally had to put a stop to it.  But  twenty bills
and a fresh pack of Marlboros in his breast pocket was an easy cure for his
bouncer blues, and soon enough I was saddling on up to the bar to scope out
the freshies.

Well, wouldn't you know it, over there in the corner, dancing atop the
speakers, was the finest, tightest-jeans wearing score I had seen.  And lo
and behold, she, too was wearing a shirt that said P.I.M.P.!

"What's this?" I asked myself, freaking my way across the floor with a Bud
in my hand.  "Ain't nobody can pimp the pimp!  Ain't nobody can play the
playa!"

So I climbed onto the speakers to get to acquaint myself with my heavenly
doppelganger, this denim-wearing shadow of my psyche.  A Jungian fantasy in
the making, with potential eroticism and psychological metaphors far
greater than in Basic Instinct!  Be I her darkness, or she mine?

So what I did was, I went up to her and said, "Hey, baby, ain't your name
'Damn'?  'Cause that the first thing I thought when I seen you."  Then I
proceeded to come to familiarities with her.

Together, we tweaked with the tweakers, freaked on the speakers, and
circle-danced for hours as only lovers could, but when the time came for me
to work my charms and ease her on back to my crib, she protested,  "Oh no,
Boomerang, that wouldn't be right."

"Damn,"  I said,  "You better check your crossfader, baby, 'cause you're
spinnin' two different records at the same time, if you catch my drift.
You're playin' "Let's Get Busy" on one turntable and "Uh-Uh No Way" on the
other, and that's a bad mix, baby.  I swear, I'm not trying to Mac on you
or nothing.  I was just thinking you could come on back for a glass of wine
and a little massage.  I just wanna get to know you better, on a mental
level. 'Cause that's the kind of guy I am."

"Well, if it's platonic, I guess,"  she said finally, and next thing I
knew, we were jamming across the bridge to my pad.

I pulled the old trick on her about "just a massage", but once I had Otis
Redding on the radio and a little bit of wine in her, she couldn't help
succumbing to the boomerang charms.

Afterward, though...oh, man, let me tell you about afterwards.

I sat up on the edge of the bed, and started crying like a baby.  It was
weird--one minute I was balling, the next minute I was bawling.  It didn't
make no sense to me.  Usually when I get all emotional on the ladies, it's
to get something juicy.   I said, "Shoot, baby,  I don't know why I done
you like this.  I brung you back here, took advantage of you, pimping you
and macking you like you was an object.  Shucks, I didn't even tell you I
got a girlfriend."

She said, "Aww, now don't you worry, Boomerang.  What you did to me ain't
so bad.  Plenty of people done worse things than what you done to me."

I began to feel a little better.  I wiped away my tears and said,  "Yeah?
People done worse than what I done to you?"

"Sure.  Hey, take me, for example.  I knew I had warts when I met you!"

Hey now,
Chai is actually the Hindi word for "tea"...personally the chai I've had most
places outside goes way overboard on the cinnamon and clove, but that's just my
opinion...what exactly is in Chai depends on who's making it (or perhaps what
part of India they are from)...I think the stuff that is sold at cafes etc
usually has ginger, cinnamon, cardamom, clove...and is boiled with milk.  Of
course, there's tea in it also :o)

My fave way to make it...all my friends really dig it...boil up some water in
a teapot, throw some cardamom seeds and a cinnamon stick in there, you can 
add maybe one or two cloves and a bit of ginger if you like...when it boils
add some black tea (even lipton teabags are fine, or get your fave black
tea)...put it in, let it boil for maybe a minute, take it off the heat, let it
brew for just maybe 2-3 min, pour, add milk and sugar.  There!  Your very own
homemade chai, and you didn't have to go to a cafe to have it!! ;)
some people use half milk and half water and boil it all up.  your tastes may
vary.
that's probably more info than you wanted, but oh well :^)
I love chai, it's the first thing I ever learned how to make :-)

namaste ;)
shamini

> HI ALL,
> 	Does any one wish to elaborate on Chai Tea?
> I keep hearing about how positive it is, and I'm very curious.
> 				VERTIGO

At 9:03 PM -0000 11/11/96, Steve Simitzis wrote:
>But for those of us who are local to San Francisco, it can be somewhat
>difficult. I would like to ask promoters to please try to keep map
>points within 8 or so blocks of the party, and at the very least have
>the map point and the party on the same bus line.

Hi!

So, once again, I find myself saying, "Please offer suggestions."

Here's the scenario:

You need a place, about 8 blocks from 150 Folsom.  It has to be open until
2am, it has to be safe and secure, and it can't be just some public area
for there will the the transfer of thousands of dollars over the course of
the night.

Next, find me one of those 8 blocks from 24th and Mission.

Any suggestions welcome.

(We'll make fine promoters out of you all, just you see...=)

Tone

P.S.  The planning of a party can be very difficult.  What happens, most
times, is you have to rely on the resources that are available.  The ideal
party would have a map point 8 blocks from the party, or even better, 8
blocks from everyone going to the party.  ;^)  But that can't happen.  As
it happens, the record stores most willing to provide the wonderful service
of playing map point happen to be on upper Haight Street.  That's just the
way it is right now, in the underground rave scene in San Francisco.  I'm
sure that will change with time.  Most of the promoters I know would be
very happy to hear that you've unearthed a more centrally located, safe,
secure, cheap map point.  Peace!  =)

that was my first rave in over a month, and boy that was the BEST, most
RAD, experience in my whole 3.5 years of raving!!!  If anyone was at 2012
they should know me.  I was walking arround to everyone, and I do mean
everyone, saying hi and seeing how they were doing, asking if they were on
E, and if they weren't I told them they should be.  I was on 2.5 hits of
it.  The E at that party was killer.  The music was even BETTER, the
screens were very RIGHT ON!!!!!!!  The envionment there was sooo positive,
friendly, happy place to be.  I didn't realize how much I missed the rave
community until Sat. night, I felt sad when the party ended, there was soo
much positive energy from everyone there that they shouldn't have broken up
the party.  I can't wait until Friday, 4 days until I go to Famtasia, not
sure where I am going on Sat.  Any suggestions?????? 
P.S.
Highlight of the night:
some of my friends and I were smoking out near the speakers, and I looked
down and someone dropped us off food and water and I no one in our group
saw the person.  Who ever that was I am going to find them, and give them
the biggest happy raver hug I can give! 

Rave on,

THERE IS NO REASON IN THE WORLD that water should cost $2.
Anyone and their uncle can go to Costco (considering that they are a
member) and by boxes of 24 of those little guys for $4.69.

With tax, that's about $5.  with a $24 dollar income, you're makin'
about twenty bucks per box.  that's over 75% profit margin.  To anyone
that knows anything about business and retail, that's damn good.

Also, there are many people (me included) that think that free water
should be available at parties.  If you wana sell water aside from the
free stuff, that's one thing, but tryin to squeeze every penny you can
out of ravers makes me feel like a wary consumer more than a care-free
raver.  

In my opinion, the price or lack of price of water at a party makes a
big impact on the atmosphere the promoters set for their party.  Do they
want people to have fun and create an environment for people to be
comfortable, making sure that people have water, and making sure that
there is adequite ventilation, or do they just want to get people's
admission money, and then close their eyes and wait for 6 AM.

Just a few thoughts....

--adam--

Arthur Chandler wrote:
> 
>   Thanks for the info about the origin and development of house. A further
> question:
>   A couple of folks I was talking to in F8 yesterday said that the
> house-and-techno scene is "losing life" here in San Francisco...


I don't know about how the scene exists in other countries, and don't
really know much about how it is in other parts of this country.  But
the scene here will never die.  It changes, yes, and there are elements
we might not be all to appreciative of, but you can't change what other
people do or think.

You can change what you think and do.  Be positive.  Contribute to the
positive scene and make raves what you want them to be.  There are many
people raving today that were in the scene five or more years ago.  Yes
things are not the same as they were back then, but there will ALWAYS be
an underground.  No matter how comercialized the music becomes, there
will always be a cutting edge of underground that stick together and
know what positive energy is truly made of.

--adam--

     Geez,
     
     I would be really worried if we were stating opinions as fact...
     
     Suffice to say we don't know what would happen if the entire planet 
     got stoned.  They might all go to sleep, or eat all the cookies in the 
     world causing riotous economic upheaval or they might realize we've 
     all been assholes for a really long time and try to change things for 
     the better.
     
     Anything that alters perception can be considered a psychoactive drug, 
     and I KNOW pot alters perception.
     
     But I think it's a personal choice and should be a personal choice 
     without legal recourse.  If you feel it should be illegal, just pick 
     up the phone and call 911, and mention my name, President Clinton's 
     (it's not inhaling that's illegal you know), as well as the majority 
     of people on this list.  The only reason we are free to do it as many 
     of us do currently is the present ineffectiveness of drug laws.  A law 
     that cannot be enforced makes a mockery of justice.  I don't want to 
     raise my children in a place where I have to explain laws that have 
     lower mandatory terms for rapists and murderers (people who HAVE 
     committed evil against other people) than for certain types of drug 
     dealers (try to think of them as Robin Hood liquor stores that MIGHT 
     be hurting other people for the sake of this argument).
     
     If you have ever even tried illicit drugs, I'd recommend you lay off 
     being a hypocrite as well (you've opened up and told us about your 
     shroom/lsd experiences if I remember correctly).  Too many people 
     tried something a couple years back, but "know better" now.  Too bad 
     that if they'd been caught 'back then', they'd still be serving time 
     today.  Let the penalty fit the crime... oh it was no big deal... than 
     work with us on reducing mandatory drug possession penalties, not 
     badmouthing a drug that doesn't happen to fit comfortably into your 
     particular lifestyle.
     
     Fact is more people die yearly from lung cancer/heart disease as a 
     result of cigarettes than all illicit drug od's and drug related 
     accidents combined.
     
     Source:(http://www.drcnet.org/)
     
     :)
     
     You decide what's right to do with your own body and mind... oh wait, 
     you can't... the law won't let you.
     
     Peace,
     AndyW

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: overpriced H2O
Author:  trance@slip.net at ccsmtp
Date:    11/11/96 3:31 PM


THERE IS NO REASON IN THE WORLD that water should cost $2.
Anyone and their uncle can go to Costco (considering that they are a 
member) and by boxes of 24 of those little guys for $4.69.
     
With tax, that's about $5.  with a $24 dollar income, you're makin' 
about twenty bucks per box.  that's over 75% profit margin.  To anyone 
that knows anything about business and retail, that's damn good.
     
Also, there are many people (me included) that think that free water 
should be available at parties.  If you wana sell water aside from the 
free stuff, that's one thing, but tryin to squeeze every penny you can 
out of ravers makes me feel like a wary consumer more than a care-free 
raver.  
     
In my opinion, the price or lack of price of water at a party makes a 
big impact on the atmosphere the promoters set for their party.  Do they 
want people to have fun and create an environment for people to be 
comfortable, making sure that people have water, and making sure that 
there is adequite ventilation, or do they just want to get people's 
admission money, and then close their eyes and wait for 6 AM.
     
Just a few thoughts....
     
--adam--

From: ~^JBondy <jbondy@worldsite.net>

MIME-Version: 1.0
To: TGARCI02@ccsmtp.farinon.harris.com
CC: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: overpriced H2O
References: <287D3B50.1825@ccsmtp.farinon.harris.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

It's really not that hard for the promoters to pay for water and give
it away. We are filling up old gallon jugs with the 25cent vending
machine water, and giving it away at Elevation. It may not be evian, but
it's non-tap, and its good.

 I figure that 20 gallons will be enough for around 300 people, and
that's a cost of a whopping $5. Ouch! ;?) And to think that we're only
charging $5 to get in. So one person comes through the door, we've made
our money back.

 We're also making coffee all night long, and giving that away too.
Didn't cost us that much either. Bought a brand new 100cup coffee
machine for $30, 5 pounds of starbucks coffee for $10, and that'll be
more than enough for our tribe of Elevators. So that's another $40. So,
we need another 7 people to walk through the door to make that money
back.

 Now you come to a differnet problem. CUPS! now you have to go out and
buy cups, and then people will leave them somewhere else, and everytime
they want more water, they want a new cup. So, that's kinda tricky. So
you buy 300 cups, and go through them very easily. But, for an outdoor
venue, lots of people bring their own bottles, and hold on to them
throughout the night, eliminating the cup crisis.

 Then we've got fruit and bread. Spent $40 on that, so we need another 7
people to come. So to get paid back for all of that stuff, we need 15
paying guests....sounds a little too easy huh?  Well, it is.

 Promoters need to think of the people more often, and think of what
they are giving to them. Albeit, getting big name dj's can cost a lot of
cash, but if you use locals who aren't charging $500 a set, you'll be
ok.


 Where am I going with this? A lot of promoters want to gouge you at
every angle, and it's immediately accepted by most ravers. It seems fair
to you at the time, but when you go to an event where things like water
and fruit are free, you know that you're getting a lot more than what
you paid for.

 I'm happy in knowing that I am giving something to the people that come
to the party, and not scamming all of their cash away from them. I'm a
raver like everyone else, but I look at other events, and see what I
would want to be different, and act accordingly.

Demand Free water!!!

JB)ondy
Elevation2  Nov 16th
714-224-9779  elevation@party.net

Hi. A couple people responded to me who were interested in getting 
involved with KZSU, so I'm going to post some general info here.

It's really a great organization with a lot of 
crazy-knowledgable people -- I've learned a lot about music from working 
there.

We have organizational meetings once per quarter, where we invite anyone 
who's interested to come out, apply for a spot in our (free) DJ training 
class, and find out about working around KZSU. The next org. meeting is 
scheduled for Wednesday, 8 January, at 7:30, location TBA, but somewhere 
on Stanford Campus. If you can't make it to that meeting, or if you want 
to get involved ASAP, come down to KZSU on a Monday night (staff meeting 
night), and I can introduce you to some people and hopefully get you 
working. ( Did I mention that to have a show at KZSU, one has to do at 
least 15 hours of work at the station per quarter... work includes 
reviewing music, writing public service announcements, alphabetizing the 
music library, recording promotional stuff, contacting clubs, etc.)

For your reference, most of this information is available on the web at:

	http://www-kzsu.stanford.edu/join.html

Any more questions, please let me know, and I hope to see lots of you at 
our meeting in January.

dj radon

On Mon, 11 Nov 1996, Andy Wyszkowski wrote:

> As I we left, somebody was found who had overdone it, apparently on Ketamine.  
> My heart goes to her brother, who was outside and scared, and to her, hoping 
> that all goes well.  Other than that, I guess there's little I can say or do 
> except hope.  To everybody who does chemicals, be careful.

	This is something I am torn over. On the one hand, I believe
people should be able to do what they want with their bodies. On the
other, making the promoters of a party deal with your overdose or your
friend's overdose is totally out of the question. One of the things that
most people who eat scheduled substances complain about is that it is my
right to do with my body what I what (something I totally agree with).
Yet with that statement is implied or should be implied as long as I am 
not hurting or demanding things of other people, would that be a fair 
assumption of what we mean?
	When someone overdoes it, one necessary places themselves on the 
help of ours (unless you pass out in a corner, and come back to without 
breaking things or before that party ends and clean up has occured and 
the owner wants the space back...). This becomes a problem when those 
whose responsibility the overdoer becomes do not want the responsibility, 
such as the EMS people who get to hear "I don't know" to questions of 
dosages and the like so they can figure out how to handle the situation. 
This problem becomes even larger in the current state of affairs because 
when a call is made to EMS, a police officer is also dispatched and 
depending on the beliefs of the officer, a stink could be raised and 
parties could be hassled more or it will be viewed as just what is was 
someone either fucking up or being irresponsible either in not knowing 
their dosages or combining too many things together.
	I guess my anger as it is, stems from those who knew the girl
paniced (ok, I can see that happening, but is that an excuse?). Gateway
called an ambulance to help the girl because helping the girl was their
first concern (I don't think anyone there had much experience with k and
GHB induced unconsciousness nor should they be required to be). Because of
that concern, there was the possiblity that they will NEVER be able to
throw another party without police sercuity, searches on entry and the
like.
	When we are in circles of people who use illecit substances, we
can become repsonsible for our friends and here was a case where people
were not prepared for that responsiblity. I hope they either will be in
the future, will better educate themselves, or will stop doing illecit
substances (but I suppose there is the consideration that one does not
know exactly what they are prepared for until they get there). I work in
an industry where people immediately believe a speech like this assigns
blame, but I am not interested in assigning blame because I don't know
this situation, I leave that to the people involved, and hopefully they
will be able to deal with whatever went wrong and not just point a finger
at someone else.  This is a cold hard opinion of mine - people exceeding
their limits and leaving themselves to the responsiblity - of which this 
was an example - is one of the LARGEST reasons I believe drugs remain 
illegal (that is based on everyone believing one cannot be trusted with a 
choice which is based on their conceived ideas that those who chose this 
obviously fucked up and since those who fucked up are the only examples 
of people have that a decision on a certain choice, it seems they always 
tend to believe that that same decision will result in the same end for 
ANYONE who makes that same type of decision)...
	I think people should be allowed to experiment with their 
consciousness and continue to alter or enhance it as they see fit, but 
with that goes the responsiblity of doing such.

dave

Ok buddie. . . heregoes. . . 

        Do you actually think that such of a depressant is safe out on the
streets with sooo many drug abusers and stupid people out there? 

        Sure, you probably think that marijuana is as safe as water but only
in small amounts. Don't mix weed with anything else, or else you will end up
hurt or in an accident somewhere. I smoked pot a lot, my friends smoke it
even more. The funnies thing I see while my buds are driving is when they
sit at an intersection and forget where they are for a second. Also, most
weed gives you a phat let-down afterwards, you almost have to go to sleep. 

        Too many people would be smoking it before school: You can't learn
when you're high on pot, you have a very slow reading speed, and your
attention span isn't much worth mentioning either.

        People at work will be stoned out of their minds: Would you want
some loaded guy to put your car together? Or would you rather have a bunch
of stoned guys build a room for your new home? Work will decrease sooo much
that the re-cycle rate for employees will be exceptionally high.

        Would you want to be out on the freeway in traffic with most
everyone around you smoking joints, swerving into your lane and cutting you
off cuz they couldn't move out of the way in time? Or what about following a
kid  who's already sparked a couple and he slams into the car in front of
him, and before you can react (because you never saw his breaklights) you
slam into him?

        I know this os exaggerated, but it's true, and it WILL happen. The
only people I know who want marijuana legalized are people who obviously
smoke too much or are under educated. But hey, isn't more than half of this
country?

        I don't really think that making kids addicted to an x-drug would be
a good Idea, and yes, they will become addicted, since it's legal and all,
why not?        

        That's just what I think. . . 

Aryck

> My major point is not that the well-off are paying too much in taxes, 
> it's that
> the way the tax load is DISTRIBUTED results in a built-in bias toward 
> more
> government.  The fact that some citizens taxes are increased to benefit 
> other citizens is what  cannot be justified - it's merely one group 
> taking money
> away from another, whether they can "afford" it or not.  A perverse side 
> effect
> of increased government spending is that taxes on ALL citizens tend to 
> increase.  If you dropped income taxes to zero on low income earners, 
> they
> would still be groaning under the weight of all the sales taxes, 
> property taxes

On Mon, 11 Nov 1996, Guillermo Lemus wrote:

> 	Does any one wish to elaborate on Chai Tea?

My recipe as given by Brian from Harbin:
1 cp of soy milk or cow milk
1 cp of water(if you use soy milk)
cardamon, cinnamon, clove, fresh ginger, and gotu kola(optional) to taste.
2 tblsp of sugar
2-4 teabags of black or green tea

add all ingredients but tea and heat over medium-high until milk foams on
top. <breathe> (that really is in the recipe!)  Add tea and turn down heat
allowing the tea to brew for 3-5 minutes. <breathe>  ENJOY!

Yes Adam, the water often is overpriced.  But I think it's time to share 
a different perspective on the subject.

On Mon, 11 Nov 1996, Adam Mednick/philip diaz wrote:

> THERE IS NO REASON IN THE WORLD that water should cost $2.
> Anyone and their uncle can go to Costco (considering that they are a
> member) and by boxes of 24 of those little guys for $4.69.

**The price was $1.00 for the same bottle at Gateway.  Consider:  the 
people selling the water take the time and energy to go and buy the water, 
then they carry it all over the place, up stairs, etc. then spend the night 
selling it because too many fucking ravers have yet to figure ou t that they 
need to take care of themselves!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  Grow up people.  
Bring your own fucking water, pretend every party is Burning Man.

> With tax, that's about $5.  with a $24 dollar income, you're makin'
> about twenty bucks per box.  that's over 75% profit margin.  To anyone
> that knows anything about business and retail, that's damn good.

** So two people work their butts off and make a couple hundred dollars
usually with some proceeds going to the party.  

> Also, there are many people (me included) that think that free water
> should be available at parties.  If you wana sell water aside from the
> free stuff, that's one thing, but tryin to squeeze every penny you can
> out of ravers makes me feel like a wary consumer more than a care-free
> raver.  

** What is it going to take, a two by four made out of X?  Not every 
venue has running water, major renegades seldom do.  I for one will not 
drink water SOMA, period.  Also, where does it say that the people who 
put on parties have to 'take care of you?" They are busting their asses 
in ways beyond most raver's comprehension to make these parties happen.  
If you smoke or take E, then be fully responsible and carry in your own 
unopened water.  If they don't allow unopened water in, find another party.
For the latter is always a sure sign of greed.  

> In my opinion, the price or lack of price of water at a party makes a
> big impact on the atmosphere the promoters set for their party.  Do they
> want people to have fun and create an environment for people to be
> comfortable, making sure that people have water, and making sure that
> there is adequite ventilation, or do they just want to get people's
> admission money, and then close their eyes and wait for 6 AM.
> 

**The ravers are ultimately responsible for whether or not a party goes 
off.  e.g. all of the free tasty water in the solar system isn't going 
too make a party positive energy happen if everyone is on speed. 

If the promoters sell it at too high a price, pick other parties. 
If the venue is a toxic, fire trap, don't go back and let them know why.

**I must consume a minimum of .5 gallon of water at every party I 
experience, just for my health.  I grow weary of having to say no to 
sharing the water I carry..also and lastly, I have no medical insurance 
and I can't afford the risk that sharing water with strangers carries.
In 1993 I had bronchitus four times.  I was raving about three times per 
week for one year and shared my water often, any connection?

Please Adam, teach everyone you know to carry their own water into 
parties and recycle those bottles afterwards.   Lastly there is a 
an even greater ability too let go at a party knowing that 'you' 
have taken care of all of your needs. 


~~peace
Maureen (many of you have met me recently in connection with the raving 
alien sculpture (I created for all of us) from Gateway at Burning Man)

filtering.  The sender field was:

  Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com

>of DRUNK guys build a room for your new home? Work will decrease sooo much
>that the re-cycle rate for employees will be exceptionally high.
>
>        Would you want to be out on the freeway in traffic with most
>everyone around you DRINKING, swerving into your lane and cutting you
>off cuz they couldn't move out of the way in time? Or what about following a
>kid  who's already DRANK a couple and he slams into the car in front of
>him, and before you can react (because you never saw his breaklights) you
>slam into him?
>
>        I know this os exaggerated, but it's true, and it WILL happen. The
>only people I know who want marijuana legalized are people who obviously
>smoke too much or are under educated. But hey, isn't more than half of this
>country?
>
>        I don't really think that making kids addicted to an x-drug would be
>a good Idea, and yes, they will become addicted, since it's legal and all,
>why not?        

There are so many skewed statements here that it's not worth picking 
apart.

The problem with most chemical abuse is not the chemicals themselves.  
Have we not learned from our (recent) history that the solution to 
chemical abuse is not prohibition, but education and social 
responsibility?

Plus, you're only arguing about marajuana, completely ignoring hemp and 
all of its benefits and uses: fast growing crop, can grow in many soils, 
parts can be used for fuel, threads, paper, oils, food, etc, cheaper than 
lumber, infinitely renewable, etc, etc.

And I think you have a lot of nerve for, among other things, calling 
members of the SFRaves list "under educated".  YOU appear to be the 
uneducated one here.

I would have loved to have seen this thread follow a gentle tone, but 
right out of the gate, it's a series of assertions of right and wrong, 
instead of a friendly exchange of information.  There must be a better 
way.

deeje

>DILBERT'S LAWS OF WORK 
>  
>  
> If you can't get your work done in the first 24 hours, work nights. 
>  
> A pat on the back is only a few centimeters from a kick in the butt. 
>

> promoted. 
>

> done and what you're going to do. 
>  
> After any salary raise, you will have less money at the end of the 
> month than you did before. 
>  
> The more crap you put up with, the more crap you are going to get. 
>

> clipboard.

> will happen to you the rest of the day.

> hour.

> supposed to be doing.

second.

+
Are you implying you travel in a car with people who are so stoned that they 
forget where they are... brilliant.  I don't promote irresponsible use of 
any drug.

 Also, most weed gives you a phat let-down afterwards, you almost have to go 
to sleep. 

+
Totally subjective information.  I used to enjoy waking up to a bowl every 
once in a while, without the need to immediately go back to sleep.  I've 
noticed in my own experience that green pot with white crystallized hairs 
(as opposed to red or brown hairs) tends to not have the 'burn out' many 
people associate with marijuana.
     
        Too many people would be smoking it before school: You can't learn
when you're high on pot,

+
Passed AP physics and chem in my junior year with the highest grade in 
the class.  Did book reviews for the school paper.  Pot was a daily thing 
for me back then.  If you can back it with data from somewhere fine... 
otherwise cool it with the subjective arguments.  You're not going to 
convince anybody with data that only makes sense to you.

 you have a very slow reading speed, and your attention span isn't much 
worth mentioning either.

+
I personally don't feel that is true.  Are there any studies you have 
proving this?
     
        People at work will be stoned out of their minds: Would you want
some loaded guy to put your car together?  Or would you rather have a bunch 
of stoned guys build a room for your new home?

+
Have you ever met a real construction worker?  I live with two.  Many of 
them do enjoy the occasional spliff.  Do I think it should be openly 
tolerated in the workplace... no.  It should be treated in a manner similar 
to an alcoholic beverage.

 Work will decrease sooo much that the re-cycle rate for employees will be 
exceptionally high.

+
Recycling is good.  And no, I have not noticed higher turnover in employees 
who indulge.
     
        Would you want to be out on the freeway in traffic with most
everyone around you smoking joints, swerving into your lane and cutting you 
off cuz they couldn't move out of the way in time?

+
No, I'm not asking for legalization of irresponsible behavior.

Or what about following a kid  who's already sparked a couple and he slams 
into the car in front of him, and before you can react (because you never 
saw his breaklights) you slam into him?

+
This could happen from sleep deprivation, or changing a station on the 
radio.  Once again, I don't advocate driving under the influence of 
ANYTHING.
     
        I know this os exaggerated, but it's true, and it WILL happen. The
only

+
I agree that it's exaggerated, but I don't agree it's true.

 people I know who want marijuana legalized are people who obviously smoke 
too much or are under educated. But hey, isn't more than half of this 
country?

+
How about people who think synthetic fabrics are harmful to the environment, 
or people who feel it brings them closer to God (as a few religions do), or 
people who want healthier alternatives to petroleum, or even a return to 
natural hemp rope.  Or how about somebody who is bulimic or has AIDS, or 
somebody who just wants to get high once a year or so?  Or enjoy jazz from 
another perspective or use it to alter their perception of arts or 
philosophy.  So Aryck, am I ... uh... undereducated?
     
        I don't really think that making kids addicted to an x-drug would be
a good Idea, and yes, they will become addicted, since it's legal and all, 
why not?        

Alcohol, Robotussin, Cigarettes, Nitrous Oxide... the junkies are not 
exactly rolling in the streets.  Legal drugs do not pose much of an 
additional threat.  Many physicians consider alcohol much more dangerous 
than marijuana or ecstasy (keep in mind they're starting to believe ecstasy 
and marijuana MIGHT cause minor brain and organ damage in large amounts, 
whereas it's a know fact with alcohol).  I think it's the 'criminal' aspect 
of illicit drugs that causes the most expense to the American people.  We 
don't need gun toting dealers.  To get rid of them, get rid of their source 
of income.  We don't see Budweiser and Miller pushers in the street causing 
problems by shooting at each other over turf wars...

In addition, the legality of a drug has little affect on it's usage.  While 
I agree there would be an increase in use of marijuana, it would not be too 
significant.  During prohibition, it is estimated by many historians that 
alcohol use INCREASED, due to the youth embracing the speakeasy culture of 
open sexuality, irresponsible behavior, a romantic respect for the 
gangsters and a disdain for the religion and morality being pushed on them 
by their parents.
     
        That's just what I think. . . 
        
        +
        I respect your opinion, but not your disregard for the facts.  I find it 
        difficult to appreciate your endorsements of psylocybin mushrooms and 
        lsd when you have such a negative view towards tolerance or legalization 
        of marijuana.  I'm not asking you to smoke it, but you seem really 
        opposed to it, and I find that rather hypocritical.  I understand it's 
        not for everyone, but there are hundreds of people in jail for doing 
        some of the things you claim to have done.  Nobody belongs in jail for 
        possessing drugs, especially for the lengths of time some of these 
        people are in for.
        
        (take a look at http://www.paranoia.com/drugs/war.on.drugs/casualties/)
        
        In addition, the War on Drugs has had serious negative effects on people 
        who don't even touch drugs.  The list of unconstitutional searches and 
        seizures goes on and on.  I hope this doesn't go on forever, because the 
        longer it goes on, the more normal people will think it is.  We need to 
        understand freedom again.
     
Aryck
