______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Re: overpriced H2O
Author:  Maureen Garrett <mh2o@well.com> at ccsmtp
Date:    11/11/96 10:06 PM


     
Yes Adam, the water often is overpriced.  But I think it's time to share 
a different perspective on the subject.
     
On Mon, 11 Nov 1996, Adam Mednick/philip diaz wrote:
     
> THERE IS NO REASON IN THE WORLD that water should cost $2.
> Anyone and their uncle can go to Costco (considering that they are a 
> member) and by boxes of 24 of those little guys for $4.69.
     
**The price was $1.00 for the same bottle at Gateway.  Consider:  the 
people selling the water take the time and energy to go and buy the water, 
then they carry it all over the place, up stairs, etc. then spend the night 
selling it because too many fucking ravers have yet to figure ou t that they 
need to take care of themselves!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  Grow up people.  
Bring your own fucking water, pretend every party is Burning Man.
     
> With tax, that's about $5.  with a $24 dollar income, you're makin'
> about twenty bucks per box.  that's over 75% profit margin.  To anyone 
> that knows anything about business and retail, that's damn good.
     
** So two people work their butts off and make a couple hundred dollars 
usually with some proceeds going to the party.  
     
> Also, there are many people (me included) that think that free water
> should be available at parties.  If you wana sell water aside from the 
> free stuff, that's one thing, but tryin to squeeze every penny you can 
> out of ravers makes me feel like a wary consumer more than a care-free 
> raver.  
     
** What is it going to take, a two by four made out of X?  Not every 
venue has running water, major renegades seldom do.  I for one will not 
drink water SOMA, period.  Also, where does it say that the people who 
put on parties have to 'take care of you?" They are busting their asses 
in ways beyond most raver's comprehension to make these parties happen.  
If you smoke or take E, then be fully responsible and carry in your own 
unopened water.  If they don't allow unopened water in, find another party. 
For the latter is always a sure sign of greed.  
     
> In my opinion, the price or lack of price of water at a party makes a
> big impact on the atmosphere the promoters set for their party.  Do they 
> want people to have fun and create an environment for people to be
> comfortable, making sure that people have water, and making sure that 
> there is adequite ventilation, or do they just want to get people's
> admission money, and then close their eyes and wait for 6 AM. 
> 
     
**The ravers are ultimately responsible for whether or not a party goes 
off.  e.g. all of the free tasty water in the solar system isn't going 
too make a party positive energy happen if everyone is on speed. 
     
If the promoters sell it at too high a price, pick other parties. 
If the venue is a toxic, fire trap, don't go back and let them know why.
     
**I must consume a minimum of .5 gallon of water at every party I 
experience, just for my health.  I grow weary of having to say no to 
sharing the water I carry..also and lastly, I have no medical insurance 
and I can't afford the risk that sharing water with strangers carries. 
In 1993 I had bronchitus four times.  I was raving about three times per 
week for one year and shared my water often, any connection?
     
Please Adam, teach everyone you know to carry their own water into 
parties and recycle those bottles afterwards.   Lastly there is a 
an even greater ability too let go at a party knowing that 'you' 
have taken care of all of your needs. 
     
     
~~peace
Maureen (many of you have met me recently in connection with the raving 
alien sculpture (I created for all of us) from Gateway at Burning Man)

I was wondering if anyone was interested in playing a little story game. I
can't remember what it's called but it goes like this.

Whoever wants to play, email me and I'll put you on a list. By 8am
Weds,which well be the cut off time to enter,  I'll send the list to
everyone who replied, that way we keep it off SFRaves. What will happen
next is I will write a sentence no less then 5 words. Then I will send it
to the next person on the list, then they will had a sentence to that. And
so on. Then the person at the bottom (which will be me) will send the final
story to everyone that's playing.

I use to do this along time ago and we came up with some really crazy
stories. I know it a little childish, but it could be fun.

So if your interested let me know. At 8am tomorrow Weds, I'll send the list
of people out to all that wants to play then I'll send off the first one to
whoever is next on the list. By only doing it one at a time, no one will
know the outcome until it's all done. On friday, I'd like to have it all
done and sent to everyone that played.

Tim (knucklehead)

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

On Tue, 12 Nov 1996, jaw's wrote:

> >there is no justification for letting people starve in the street. i don't
> >care how much of a slacker someone is, how uneducated they may be... being
> >penniless when there are people rolling in money on the other side of town
> >is a misery no one should have to endure.
> 
> is there any justification for allowing an animal to starve in the forest?
> or is it a part of a natural evolutionary cycle in which some beings go
> hungry and others find food?


	just to play devil's advocate:
	
	human's are not *simply* animals in a forest. is not one of the
things commonly considered setting us apart from animals our capacity to
reason and move beyond mere instinct (not to say that most of us *do*
act rationally--these things only work in theory). sure, starvation is
"natural" in the animal kingdom, but no matter how much you believe we are
animals, there are some very obvious aspects of our existence that set us
apart from other species. 
	
	i do, however, think there *are* arguments to be made for not
helping *all* the poor and the hungry (how do you decide who is poor and
hungry, anyway--i could use a sandwich right now).

	glad i could stoke the fire...


stan

			nothing else.

Subject: NRR: (Humour) The Darwin Awards
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>The Darwin Awards


The annual honor given to the person who did the gene pool the biggest
service by killing themselves in the most extraordinarily stupid way. 

 Last years' winner was the fellow who was killed by a Coke machine which
toppled over on top of him as  he was attempting to tip a free soda out of it.

And this year's nominee is: The Arizona Highway Patrol came upon a pile of
smoldering metal embedded into the side of a cliff rising above the road at
the apex  of a curve. The wreckage resembled the site of an airplane crash,
but it was a car. 

The type of car was unidentifiable at the scene. The lab finally figured out
what is was and what had happened. It seems that a guy had somehow gotten
hold of a JATO unit (Jet Assisted Take Off - actually a solid fuel rocket)
that is used to give heavy military transport planes an extra 'push' for
taking off  from short airfields.  He had driven his Chevy Impala out into
the  desert and found a long, straight stretch of road.

  Then he attached the JATO unit to his car, jumped in, got up some speed
and fired off the JATO! The facts, as best could be determined, are that the
operator of the  1967 Impala hit the JATO ignition at a distance of
approximately 3.0  miles from the crash site. This was established by the
prominent  scorched and melted asphalt at that location. 

The JATO, if  operating properly, would have reached maximum thrust within
five seconds, causing the Chevy to reach speeds well in excess of 350 MPH,
continuing at full power for an additional 20-25 seconds. The  driver, soon
to be pilot, most likely would have experienced G-forces usually reserved
for dog-fighting F-14 jocks under full afterburners, basically causing him
to become insignificant for the remainder of the event. 

However, the automobile remained on the straight highway for about 2.5 miles
(15-20 seconds) before the driver applied and completely melted the brakes,
blowing the tires and leaving thick rubber marks on the road!

He then became airborne for additional 1.4 miles and impacting the cliff
face at a  height of 125 feet, leaving a blackened crater 3 feet deep in the
rock.

 Most of the driver's remains were not recoverable; however, small fragments
of bone, teeth and hair were extracted from the crater, and  fingernail and
bone shards were removed from a piece of debris believed to be a portion of
the steering wheel.

"A beautiful picture of a racing car"

seemed like people kindof tuned it out at that point.

Thus, some humor for the cynic and self-flagellant in us all.

Hi there.

My name is Jonathan McCleery. aka. DJ Flyte. I am a DJ from Vancouver BC
and I am currently looking for DJ work all over the world.  If you are a
promoter and would like a free demo tape, email me at jonathan@axionet.com

I've played a wide variety of music ranging from hard house to trance over
the past five years.  I've spun in all the major clubs in the Vancouver
area including, Graceland, Mars, and the Red Lounge.  I have also done a
lot of gigs on the party circut. The most recent being a party called
Spooky, and the club Graceland, for Halloween.

My new tapes "network and footwork" are also for sale at Bassix in Vancouver.

Thanks for your attention.

I hope to talk to you soon.

Have to pipe up here and say that Jon is one of the *nicest* djs I have 
ever met!  He drove down from Vancouver to spin at a party we threw in 
Eugene, it ended up getting busted in the middle of his set (which was an 
amazing set) and he was very relaxed about the whole thing.  We went and 
had a very nice lunch the next day and he and friends turned out to be 
just absolutely beautiful!

So get Jon down here, you won't regret it!

love drenalin

ps He even played stuff off of DAT that was his own music, very nice 
touch to his set.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Nov 12 23:41:59 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id XAA19512; Tue, 12 Nov 1996 23:41:59 -0800 (PST)
Received: from mh1.well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with ESMTP id XAA19508; Tue, 12 Nov 1996 23:41:55 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [206.15.69.62] (sf1-ppp62.well.com [206.15.69.62]) by mh1.well.com (8.7.6/8.7.5) with SMTP id XAA01831; Tue, 12 Nov 1996 23:41:44 -0800 (PST)

Message-Id: <v01510104aeac6893953e@[206.15.69.11]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 13 Nov 1996 00:53:52 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: leftjab@well.com (leftjab)
Subject: "Crystal-bliss" review
Cc: aditya@mh1.well.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

gateway raves have been my talismanic experiences in the scene, and I knew
that this past saturday night would be another.  i noticed immediately it
was exactly eleven months after my first rave, the chrysalis at the acme
last december, and it was definitely time to reflect, and not just on rave
living -- last wednesday I received word from the boss that the recent
downsizing infection was spreading to my position (although I get paid
until the end of the year, get the full support of the office in my job
search over the next two months, and don't have to work during this time
period [really]).

i hadn't raved hard since charity, and it was time to again, although my
new love susan was unfortunately away.  i was a little worried that 2o12,
CCC & other events would keep some familiar faces away, and although that
was a little bit true, i was repeatedly amazed at who showed up, including
unexpected newbie friends.  finally carin (the woman on crutches who
introduced me to the scene last year) hobbled in at 2:30, and i could feel
the thread reaching back to my first rave, with many people who i met for
the first time 11 months ago still grooving.

this weekend reminded me again how much energy goes into this, as I was
there early to help Todd set up his amazing butterfly prints and stayed
after a bit for the clean up.  the flyer i saw didn't bill the event as
"chrysalis" (the sfr calendar did), but there was no denying the two walls
of psychedelic butterflies (if you liked Todd's 2o12 work, you shoulda seen
the ambient room).  the ambient room was breathtaking.  it was great seeing
maureen's welcoming alien again. there was a crystal suspended in the air
in the center of the room by gossamer cloths hanging from all four corners
of the room, and this thin red laser focused from the floor up to the
crystal.  there was also a beautiful effect at the chill room altar, with a
big buddha statue clutching a crystal, onto which a trippy pink light was
shining from over the buddha's shoulder in such a way that it appeared that
the crystal was glowing from within ... you had to look hard to see where
the light was coming from.  crystal-bliss at chrysalis ...  and i'm a
sucker for all the dance floor lights as well ...

oh, and the music in both rooms ... deaks going off, alex filling in for
ethan and keeping it going, minor minor & john carel turning the dancers
into sweaty mush, and I can't describe greg's closing set at all.  reza,
dave, clare, rob, joe rice & brad all filled out the beautiful ambient
space gracefully.

the momentum of the party carried me through about 2 1/2 hours of the
cleanup, and even getting stuck in that massive Bay Bridge traffic jam
didn't bum me out (i turned around at treasure island and drove the long
away through marin back to north berkeley).

regarding the latest "overdoing it":  the gateway folks have had some bad
luck recently, with the woman who passed out from her ketamine/misdosage of
GHB combination this weekend, omar's accident at burning man, and a couple
of other incidents earlier this year.  they've always reacted to these
situations professionally, with their concern for the health of the
partygoers more important than the ramifications for gateway.   i've heard
that the woman was fine, and the people who run the space are cool.
nonetheless, I hope that people who do indulge do so a bit more
intelligently.  people shouldn't want to get fucked up so much as to rely
on someone else's opinion about what (and how much) drugs they put in their
bodies.

there was a good vibe in the air saturday night, and i hope everyone else
shared some

leftjab

Dear SFRavefriends,

	This thread ties in nicely with Dave Bayer's recent post about
not letting your use of illicit drugs become a problem for others at
parties.
	It really boils down to a question of who is responsible for whom
in society.  Do we have an obligation to help each other out when we're in
trouble?  I don't have a clear answer to this one.
	I will say this however:  Humans are different from other
animals in that we (most of us, anyway) are upset by suffering, and would
like to do something to end it.  However we also (most of us, anyway)
understand that sometimes just giving a person what they are pleading for,
whether it's money, food, a smoke, a new video game system (if you have
kids) isn't necessarily going to either (a) make them happier, or (b)
solve the underlying problem -- in fact it may make it worse.
	Furthermore, as humans, we tend to have a well-developed sense of
self.  Except for sexual submissives and U.S. Marines (a little humor, ha 
ha, don't flame me), we usually resent being told what to do.  When people
try to force us to do something, we resist, or if given no choice, we
perform in less than an ideal manner.
	My conclusion from all this is that to be effective, help must
fulfill these two conditions:

	(1) It must not simply make it easy for the person(s) being helped 
	    to continue the behavior pattern that led to their needing
	    help in the first place, and
	(2) It must not be forced (either directly or by law), but must be
	    given voluntarily.
	
Hope this helps,	;)
				<<< Starchild >>>

Neither here nor there, but as a note, I've found it interesting that the
last couple times I showed my design portfolio to suits, the one thing that
always sparks conversation is the rave flyers. They don't know a damn thing
about raving, but they always see those "crazy flyers" that rarely seem to
follow any criteria of "good design" around and they just can't figure out
how we can afford to go to such extent for "just a party."
Oh yeah, incidentally, finding one of these crazy colorful little flyers is
literally what first got me into this house we call rave.
:)
-StEvEo
P.S. For anyone interested in the history of party flyers, check out a book
called Design After Dark by Cynthia Rose, and if you know of anything, let me
know. Lastly if anyone ever thinks of tossing their collection, or even has
just a stack, I may be glad to purchase or trade records, etc. for them.

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

             <v0300781eaeaed8ae9ca3@[204.62.132.173]> 
Date: Wed, 13 Nov 96 10:33:27 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



>>there is no justification for letting people starve in the street. i don't
>>care how much of a slacker someone is, how uneducated they may be... being
>>penniless when there are people rolling in money on the other side of town
>>is a misery no one should have to endure.
>
>is there any justification for allowing an animal to starve in the forest?
>or is it a part of a natural evolutionary cycle in which some beings go
>hungry and others find food?

Last I checked, the hungry animal could freely forage for food, freely
cross any land in order to get food, and not risk arrest for
trespassing or theft. Only a sick/injured animal, or a whole population
facing overgrazing/drought/ecological disaster would find itself
"starving in the forest"....

Even when you take animal territoriality into account, most animals
driven out of a territory can find somewhere to go. Unfortunately for
humans, this is not the case. Fact is "we" treat wild animals better
than a large percentage of the underclass -- where are our "wild human 
sanctuaries" ; how come you never hear of a "save the humans" campaign?

Unfortunately, given that every square inch of land is owned by
somebody, fenced by somebody, and we have police/legal structures that
strongly enforce these private property rights, one ends up with
starving people on the street. They have nowhere else to go, and no
means by which to sustain themselves. If these people had a place to
rest their heads, soil to grow their food or graze their animals, I
very much doubt they'd be starving in the street.

So the better question to ask is where does privatized land, private
property, and a system that prevents people from being able to sustain
themselves unless they're willing to rent out their bodies as
slave-labor in order to obtain food/lodging -- where the hell does that
fit into your "natural evolutionary cycle"??

I would love to see what happens to people spouting such economic
darwinism crap if they actually existed in nature, wild, and without
the police/state there to enforce their hoarding of property and means
of sustenance. If this were a "natural" system, I could just get myself
a big gun/knife/club, barge onto your property, and claim it for
myself. And unless you could better defend yourself, you'd either find
yourself dead or you'd have to retreat.

In fact, I'd venture to say that we've badly disrupted the natural
evolutionary cycle through our ability to unfairly enforce the hoarding
of private property. I find it rare that those that actually have the
state protecting their property holdings are actually more fit than 
those that are enslaved to work on that property in exchange for their
rights to exist and thrive on said "private" property.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Greetings fellow Elevators!

 We're almost there, and I notice tons of you adding "see ya at
Elevation" to the end of your posts. (Wow... I didn't think you guys
really cared ;?)) That's really cool. We had such a great time last
August, and the vibe was perfect.

 Anyway... We're going to be posting the directions to the site on
Friday as opposed to Thursday. There's been an influx of rumours going
around that everyone is going to be there so, I really would suggest all
SCR, SDR and SFR people to get there early, and start the vibe flowing
right! Also, if you are setting up a tent, make sure that you get there
around 9:00, and that way you won't have 400 people stepping all over
you while you're trying to do your thing.

 *The road up to the actual site is completely paved, so we wont have to
do the 4by thing that we did last August. (that was a wreck huh?) Also,
the designated parking areas will be very close to the actual rave camp,
so getting back to your car for whatever reason won't be an ordeal.

*There will be porta potties, so please use them.* 

 Also, since the onslaught of forest fires has once again risen, all
mountain areas are NOT permitted to have wood or coal bruning fires. I
know, that would've been really fuc*in cool, but we've got to follow all
rules put forth to ensure that we can have our fun out there again.
However, if you have a gas burning stove and you want to cook some food,
that is permittable.

 There will be tons of trash cans around the area with the words "Trash
Can" painted on the side in huge letters, this way making sure that we
are not "forced" to throw any garbage on the ground. Please obey all
concientous thoughts about the environment while Elevating, it really
does matter. Pack it in, Pack it out....

 Also, be prepared to experience chills. It may be a little cold out
there. Last weekend, it was in the mid 50's at night, so make sure to
dress in layers, and bring warm stuff with you. We will have some
blankets and other goods on hand, but bring warm stuff anyway. 

 Also, NO FLYERS PLEASE. This is an outdoor event, and flyers have a
tendancy to blow away in the wind, leaving unmistakable traces that a
rave was there. This makes us look really bad, and will be a definate
way of telling the rangers and the land owners that we are not
responsible and don't care about the environment. I know that I'm
preaching to the wrong crowd, and that SCRs are educated and
responsible,  but as long as we tell people that we know not to flyer
the area, everything will be ok.... if you are caught with flyers, you
shall be stripped naked, painted pink and hung upside down in front of
the dj's for all to see. ;)

 That's about it for now. So, I'll post the directions on Friday, and
you can call 714-224-9779 on saturday, and elvation@party.net on
saturday as well.

 I can't wait to see all of you there- This is going to be a great
weekend!!!! Up in the mountains with all of our SCR friends and family!
(oh yeah, and you SFRs and SDRs too!)

-Over

JB)ondy



(if you have any questions, email me privately...)

             <199611131920.LAA10592@shellx.best.com>

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

Precedence: bulk

> What's the point?
> ...
> And what, pray tell, is "consumerism"?  The act of consuming?  And can you 
> honestly say that people will cease to consume for one day?
> 
> Uh huh... right....
> 
> I don't know.  I'm not casting stones, really, but I just don't get it.  
> What's the point?

The point is that (in case you having noticed from the last election),
voting is completely ineffective because our system no longer even has
the slightest resemblance to a democracy. It's straight-up plutorcracy
and your vote *ALWAYS* comes in second place after corporate dollars
dictate the way things will be (c.f. propositions 211, 214, 216, 217).
This is especially so given multinational/mega-corporate control of the
mass-media that is used to shape public consensus, telling people how
to think, which values are applicable to make themselves happy, and
even defining happiness and success for us.

So given that, the average man/woman has one response to this
sick&decaying consumerist "moneyocracy" that many of us are forced to
participate in whether or not we want to -- vote with your dollars.
Especially w/ the christmas season coming up, and with the "boycott"
day being the biggest shopping day of the year, you really have a
chance to spread your message -- spread it and make it HURT!

BOYCOTT CHRISTMAS!  Go ahead and party, do something creative and fun
with your family (get toghether and cook a killer meal, decorate the
house, spend QUALITY time with your children, etc). Instead, "they"
have us worrying about giving loads of uneccessary consumer items to
our friends and families, while we sheepishly thank people for buying
us crappy gifts that we don't want, need, or even have place to put. 
Meanwhile, the media has us brainwashed into thinking we'd be horrible
antisocial creeps if we don't want to join-in a season of frenzied
waste, where we significantly fill our landfills with unrecyclable
goods, buy our children carcinogenic plasticene baubles that they grow
bored with almost instantly (Like gifts can replace the care,
friendship, love and attention that children  really need!)

And most importantly, we all go significantly into debt during the
Christmas season -- the system loves our debt as the banks can profit,
and our employers can more easily put the screws to the worker who now
needs that pointless job even more than ever. 

At least in the Jewish tradition, before Judaism got polluted with
keeping up with the joneses (Christians), Chanukah was not a holiday
filled with waste. Gifts consisted of candies and "chanukah gelt"
(money) which children could use as they need, to buy items they
wanted, even life necessities. But now Christianity-culture has made
this aspect of Jewish culture seem like this is a bad thing (usually
mouthing the usual racist crap like "oh that stingy jew" behind our
backs...) Personally, i'd rather give a family member in need money
during the holiday season and let them get something they really need.

So go ahead and party down during christmas, but ask yourself whether
the materialism they want you to participate in is really the key
to your happiness.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
==When yer swimming in a creek and an eel bites your cheek, that's a moray!==

                      Subject:                              Time:  1:04 =
PM
  OFFICE MEMO         new to the list!                      Date:  =
11/13/96

hey people,
i'm new to the list.  got on about 3 weeks ago.  mostly to just find out =
what was happening now in the rave scene and where the cool parties were. =
 but in addition to that i lurked onto some very interesting discussions =
re: raves, vibes, politics, race, etc.  the politics/race thing got =
pretty intense but some very intellegent stuff came out from many  people =
and i learned a lot from it.  i've always felt that ravers would be the =
ones to enlighten, sensatize and mellow out this uptight world we live =
in.....and show it how to dance!
actually, i haven't raved in while but was there when the scene first =
dropped in on SF about late '89-'90.  i went to just about every toon =
town, full moon, wicked, mr floppy's and everything in between for the =
next 3 or so years.  some of the greatest times of my life took place =
meeting people, dancing my ass off and sweating like crazy in the most =
content blissful daze at rave parties (a few hits of "e" always helped =
too).  the energy level at raves was something i have never experienced =
before or since but around '93 i just dropped out.  the vibe and energy =
had changed at these parties and it seemed that alot of people i knew =
where letting drugs take a really negative hold on them.  so i dropped =
out, cleaned up and moved out of the city.  i didn't want to move to far =
away though (i live in oakland).  i like being close to SF.
i tried partying at the other club scenes only to be disapointed; hip =
hop, alternative shows, gay clubs, etc.   and for the most part they were =
all just pick-up spots where the last thing anyone wanted to do was make =
a friend.  and the last thing i wanted to do was waste a good drug trip =
on a dull party.
so i was totally releived to find out through sfraves that the scene was =
still alive and kicking and that SF is still the place to be.  my only =
problem right now is transportation.  i live near lake merritt in oakland =
and don't have a car.  (violins please) it's been months since i've been =
to a good party and just let loose and danced.  hopefully there's some =
cool, friendly east bay ravers out there with car space who wouldn't mind =
sharing some of it with a dude who has no problem with gas money and =
usually has a joint on him.  if so, i'd love to hear from any of you.  my =
number is: 510-834-5305.
bye
david b.

To: mayer@netcom.com (Niels P. Mayer)

Neils wrote:
> 
> BOYCOTT CHRISTMAS!  Go ahead and party, do something creative and fun
> with your family (get toghether and cook a killer meal, decorate the
> house, spend QUALITY time with your children, etc). Instead, "they"

Hey!  Maybe even... go to Church!?!

> 
> At least in the Jewish tradition, before Judaism got polluted with
> keeping up with the joneses (Christians), Chanukah was not a holiday
> filled with waste. Gifts consisted of candies and "chanukah gelt"
> (money) which children could use as they need, to buy items they
> wanted, even life necessities. But now Christianity-culture has made
> this aspect of Jewish culture seem like this is a bad thing (usually
> mouthing the usual racist crap like "oh that stingy jew" behind our
> backs...) Personally, i'd rather give a family member in need money
> during the holiday season and let them get something they really need.

The best thing about the commercialization of Chanukah is the fact that it's not
even one of the most important of the Jewish holidays, but "they're" attempting
to make it thus.  On the other hand, I guess it's less disgraceful to make a
mockery out of a festival of remembrance than the birth of one's Lord and
Saviour...

I remember when I was a kid, a lot of my Christian friends would bitch and envy
(and usually toss in an epithet or two) over the mistaken notion I and the other
Jewish kids got a horde of gifts every night for eight nights, eight times as
many as they themselves got.  Some actually wished that they had been born
Jewish (even though they generally didn't like our culture in most other
respects).  And a lot of the Jewish kids that celebrated Chanukah with only
the gathering of family, the lighting of candles, and the giving of small gifts,
woke up to the fact that _they_ were getting shafted.  I can only wonder what
parents must put up with this time of year.

And I  can only guess at the orgasmic waves of euphoria that passed through the
corporate world when they realized that they had an untapped segment of the
population that happened to have a gift-giving holiday that occurred near
Christmas.  It's too bad that this was the route to inclusion for us. 

I myself love to give gifts to my family and loved ones.  And yes, Chanukah (for
me) is a convenient time to do this (all the family is together).  And there
is nothing wrong in theory and in (limited) practice with holiday marketing.
But it is sickening to watch the inundation, no, the assault of marketing-
driven bullshit at this time of year (worse than Easter...)  To see all
the "BUY BUY BUY" propaganda thinly veiled as holiday spirit on TV, radio, in
schools, stores, etc. (reminds me of the movie They Live :)...  To look at the
toy departments of stores, trashed, with shit all over the floor, by shoppers
who couldn't give a shit about anybody but themselves, bitching at each other,
bitching at the store clerks, who often bitch back (while the exec's are on
vacation)...  F**k when I worked retail, I worked 60 hours the week leading
up to Christmas, at two jobs, and I have NEVER seen so many unhappy, bitter,
selfish, angry people.  (Of course to be fair I met a few of the most angelic
people at that time too..) Holiday Spirit?!?!?!?!?

Shit, oops, sorry about the rant, I think I just needed to vent a bit.

Back to topic.  I don't think a boycott day would work.  But I think everyone
should boycott the bullshit, for their own sanity and integrity,  and not buy
into the madness.

Sorry,
-mike

> =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

> =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Haha that's funny!  I feel better now :)

  The Humanities Department at San Francisco State University will be
hiring a new person whose speciality is music. One of the three finalists
is Hillegonda Rietveld, a British writer who has written extensively on
the rave scene(s). She will be presenting a talk at SFSU entitled:
 
  SPECTACULAR DISAPPEARANCES: CONSUMPTION OF HOUSE MUSIC ON THE DANCE
                FLOOR, SUBJECTIVITY AND THE GAZE

  The presentation will go from 4:30-5:30, Monday, November 25, in
HUMANITIES 213 (southwest side of campus). 
  To read one of her pieces on house music, check out:

        http://www.gold.ac.uk/difference/rietveld.html

  I'll be there. Hope that some of you/us can make it too. Bring her a
flyer, an SFR button, or anything you like (if you want to) to make her
feel welcome.

Subject: Clip on GHB on Hard Copy
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com

Okay, on my way to the Simpsons last night, I passed by the channel that
had the intro to Hard Copy or some such bullshit show like that and saw
they were going to do a piece about GHB.

It was the most ridiculous thing I have ever seen.  Sadly, it focused on a
young woman in Texas who went to a country line-dance club and apparently
somone slipped GHB in her drink, or so they think (the show ended by saying
that after interviewing at least 100 people that were at the club, they
still have no leads).  She went home, after complaining of a headache, and
never woke up.  Her uncle said that he was convinced "someone slipped GHB
into her drink" and that "people should be very afraid."  "You should never
leave your drink unattended.   You can't trust anyone."

They showed where she used to play volleyball in her backyard, her grave
site, her bedroom.

That's it!

Now, what's missing here?  Um, like, they never once mentioned what GHB is.
Never ever even so much as gave ANY indication of what they were talking
about.  It was ridiculous.  As close as they got was to show a vial with a
piece of tape on it, and GHB handwritten on it.  Then they showed a cap
full of a liquid being poured into a Coke or something.

Be afraid, people, be very afraid....

Tony

While renewing my membership to KALX recently (remember to support community 
radio!!), I inquired as to why I hadn't heard DJ Seth's excellent 
Thursday Night techno show ("Aurora Borealis") lately.

In true community form, it turns out KALX shows get rotated off the schedule 
after a year to make room for others who want to broadcast.

But, I was told, there is now no other show featuring techno on KALX!!  
As we all know, our music is truly underground and we cannot find the 
real stuff on commercial mainstream radio.

I think this is a sad loss... and kind of strange that an often cutting-edge 
public radio station does not play this music.  I love KALX but if they 
aren't playing techno, who will??

continually turning the dial in Berkeley,
Nancy

Dear Arthur,

Is this her "job-talk?"  

The title of this sounds very academicky.  I think this is
supposed to be where she shows her academic credentials to the whole
dept., which then will debate (formally and informally) whether or not to
offer her a job.  

Is this talk open to the public?  

I would be chicken to go  there as a "raver" just because it might somehow
influence their decision on whether to give her the job.

My own personal experience is that hiring decisions in academia are hotly
debated, and I just can't imagine that (even humanities)
professors would think much of a raving lifestyle - except a topic for
academic study.  Maybe.

I mean,...the title of this talk is really formal.  It kind of
makes me think she is under pressure to convince her
(academic) audience that her topic isn't frivolous.  Or that she herself
is going to be a serious colleague- and that she won't be out partying all
the time, having lots of fun, taking E now and then, and basically making
everyone else jealous because she's having so much fun being a professor
of raving, instead of Chaucer, or whatever.

But of course, my apologies if these worries are obnoxious to you in any
way.

Enjoy,

Ann

Rebecca Klassen wrote:
> 
> I hadn't seen Baraka before and I am glad that I got the opportunity to
> at 2012.But what was up with the chick de-beaking
> scene? and the factory farm?and then the homeless Brazilian kids,
> and the natural gas burning at oil drilling?
> It was suddenly very sobering and I wasn't even on drugs. Would hate to
> see that on acid! Whew! 8(
> Last place I expected to see those issues appear on the big screen!
> seemed like people kindof tuned it out at that point.
> 

  Since I'm the one who often shows Baraka I thought I might chime in here...
You are right to notice that the film has not only some wonderful spiritual
images but also shows some of the "other side of the coin".... but then it
is my belief that balance is in order... so much of our life is out of
balance... males not balanced by females... blacks not in balance with white...
rich out of balance with poor.... and so on....

Here is where people begin to disagree...

  Some people think raving is only about "happy, happy joy joy" images and
everything shown at a rave should reflect this... these people often
critize the showing of any negative images what so ever. Everything should
be fantasy or Sesame Street and reflect a child like innocense. While I don't
completely object to this view, upon reflection I think if I were to completely
support such a position it would be too much like M. Anntonette saying "let 
them eat cake.". That is, if ravers only party and totally ignore the more serious
aspects of the world - we become merely consumers of the "good life" without at
least reflecting upon the more serious aspects of the world. This is of course,
my opinion, and yours may differ. Some people have told me raving is an escape
from all that serious stuff and besides they see enough of that every day so I
should show only totally positive stuff... others actually like a bit of "grit
in their eyes" for balance....

  So on the whole I balance my images fairly carefully but do throw in some stuff
that is frightening ( Tim Curry as the Legend Devil for example ), some funny stuff,
some technology, some fantasy, some nature and so on... most feel I do achieve a
good balance and I strive to do so. Also I try to be mindful of strong drug states
and leave the Texas Chainsaw Massacre at home ;-) but then I do like to play with
images a bit... and don't shy away from images that are moving or thought provoking
even though they are not perhaps totally positive....

  Hopefully I succeed in some small way of pleasing most of the people most of the
time which really is the best that can be hoped for....

 Visually yours,

  Mike

 PS The chicks are having the part of their beaks that they fight with cauterized 
or branded so they won't peck and hurt each other. The beaks are NOT being removed.
But then those are images of how chickens are raised so we can have our chicken
dinners.... we sure have moved a long way from societies who worshiped and respected
the things they eat - we no longer even care to see the process.


-- 
     Mike Clay      meclay@ix.netcom.com    (415) 572-8971
**** Alone and Ecstatic a young rainbow learns to levitate. ****

 hour, he WENT OFF about how much he learned from watching the screens.

 in life will go away and we wont have to deal with them. Yet, at a 
 gathering where consciousness and community are the main focus, maybe its 
 not such a bad idea to confront so musch of the attrocities of the world,

 countries. The argument that it was probably a bit much for those on 
 acid, etc, is very true, and that's why I told mike to turn it off, but

 unpleasant to watch, but I bet its a hell of a lot more painful to 
 experience first hand. Its a tough issue, and I agree completely with 
 your points. Im just torn, bucause I think the issues are important.  :)

Well, there's no reason to think the rave as a culture phenomenon any
less worthy of serious research than anything else.  A lot of the
popcrit stuff in adademia is really atrocious, but some of it has real
insights.  In the UK, especially, where raving and clubbing are much
more pervasive parts of the society, and have resulted in very serious
political consequences like the CJA, I'd think there is quite a bit that
would be amenable to serious academic inquiry.

There are even testable hypotheses, like Arthur's own about the progression
of audiences for musical styles from dance-oriented to stationary listening
(pardon the simplification).  

My friend Rebecca Adams, a sociologist in North Carolina, did several years
of quite serious field study in the Grateful Dead scene, including some
innovative work involving participant observation study-groups with her
students.  Yes, it was fun, but it was also serious work as the resulting
papers (and even a PBS show) indicated.  

And San Francisco, of all places in the States, would be the best place
for this kind of research to occur.  I for one am interested in the relatively
rapid pace of change in the "underground dance music" scene, and what it now
represents for participants at various levels.  

Of course, all of this can be tossed aside in the typical pomo shite that
passes for much academic research on popular culture.  But as someone whose
degree in anthropology resounds with the idea that "if there's cultural
smoke there's cultural fire," you bet I'd argue a case for some serious
academic research in "rave studies."  And it better come with an equally
serious component of participant observation, or it will end up with the
same stale and incorrect results that often occur when studies are done
only from secondary sources.

So, if Professor Rietveld gets the job, we should make sure she gets to
experience the F&F/Gateway/Sunset/etc. part of the scene as well as Cool
World :)

phred

I took a look at Rietveld's piece noted by arthurc, it's quite good once
you get beyond the usual genuflection at the Altar of Semiotics (with the
obligatory Barthes, Foucault and Baudrillard references).  The piece
basically focuses on both the way a DJ uses records to create a set which
has meaning as a "text" (the universal Good Thing in the world of semiotics)
and the importance of active participation (and a loud enough sound system,
heh :) as the audience "interprets" that text.  Although she pays the usual
homage to the Barthian idea that the listener or reader of a text creates
its only real meaning, the paper shows the practicality of the view that
both the DJ and the listener "create" that meaning -- and indirectly,
of course, the composer of each recording used.  One of the areas I would
find interesting is how a non-producer DJ (someone such as myself) as
opposed to those using their own productions (Frankie Knuckles or
Frankie Bones, for example) deals with the contraints on their assembly
of the "text" and how that works in conjunction with the audience.

Oops there I go again, now you know why I left academia before theory
rotted my brain.  And I can just hear Frankie Bones yelling, "It ain't
about no mothafuckin TEXT!  Get up and DANCE!!!"  Such are the ironies
of Real Life vs. the world in Academe :)

Anyway, it seems that Hillegonda Rietveld has written a book called
"This Is Our House," published last year, but I could find no further
information on the Web about it.  Has anyone seen it?  I'd also be
interested in reactions to her talk . . .

Working on tenure track for Professor of DJ,

phred

                        Harmony Productions Presents

                           <<< FREAKY PEOPLE >>>

      Dj's:   Trent - Minor Minor - Brandon - Brian Flip - Greg =)

                   (408)486-9591           (415)263-4885

        The party will be in San Francisco, at a new space (for Harmony,
that is). There are a limited amount of tickets availible for this one
-about 400... You will be able to get tickets at a map point on the night of
the party. There will be free water as well as $1 bottles. You can bring
your own water, but it has to be sealed (with it's original seal not
broken). (We are trying to avoid any and all GHB related problems. Please
respect our requests, as they will benefit you in the long run.) If your
bottle's original seal has been broken then we cannot permit it inside the
building. Thanks in advance. =)

        For this party we are asking that you come dressed in your funkiest,
craziest, scariest and freakiest costumes. Getting dressed up doesn't mean
just scary costumes, it can be anything! Just be original! But we do
encourage it... as if you come to the map point (and the party) dressed up,
you will get a discounted ticket into the party. (Originality of the
costumes are subject to promoter's judgement ;)   Anyways, the admission is
$15, or $10 with a costume. So get dressed up and have some fun! 

        There is a long running curse put on the Harmony family... Our first
Harmony party was on "Friday the 13th." With all of the bad luck in the
world, we got busted four times! Now, we are trying to break this curse with
a totally beautiful party. So it should be something!! Hope to see you there!!!

        Also, we hope to see everyone out this weekend at Omar's "A Wrinkle
in Time" party. He is totally happy the we are putting this together for
him, and wishes he could come. But he knows that he can't, so he sends all
of you his love, and thanks you for the support!

Peace, love and harmony to all!!!

Greg =)

In the explanation of a joke, something is usually lost...usally the humor...

but, then again, there may be some more serious points worth considering...


>Jeff Berman wrote:
>
>>> In the interest of making a point about the need to reduce the
>>> rampant consumerism in the Western World, please pass the word:
>>>
>>>     Planetary BUY NOTHING DAY
>>>
>>>     November 29, 1996
>>>
>>>     A 24 hour moratorium on consumer spending
>>>
>>>     PARTICIPATE BY NOT PARTICIPATING!
>
>
>What's the point?  I don't see how not buying anything affects anything.

...it's like: go on a diet... ya know, don't pig out for a day...you are
acting by not acting, eh???

If
>this was a day like "Buy Stuff Packed In Ecologically Friendly Materials
>Day" or "Buy Only From Companies That Haven't Committed Heinous Crimes
>Against Humanity Day" or something like that, I could see participating, but
>simply buying nothing?
>Yeah, right...

hmm...you gotta open your mind a little...this is not about politically
correct consumerism... I mean, are <<eco-friendly>> mass merchandizers
good? or is the notion of  "eco-friendly" massive amounts of mass
merchandized stuff kind of ironic/oxymoronic/just plain moronic...


>
>And what, pray tell, is "consumerism"?  The act of consuming?
>
>Uh huh... right....

My non_expert definition might be:

consumerism is a characteristic of advanced capitalistic society which is
created by social status <symbols> being givin to "stuff", whose possession
is deemed advantageous to attracting the attention/respect? of his/her
peers which can then be leveraged to gain social status/sexual
favors/friendship?/conversation ...etc. c0nsumerism society is marked by
the social reality of attention, and the deprication of character
development and appreciation of "non-conformist" individuals <<ie, those
without stuff>> who never receive the attention/love/friendship? of the
most socially significant individuals, and hence suffer from stunted
personal growth/social acceptance, which as it eventually becomes
intolerable, leads to the inevitable devotion of resources to the
aquisition of stuff...

individuals and peer groups certainly evolve sucessfully nevertheless-- but
even these exceptions <in a consumerism based world>> are marked by uneven
quality and certainly shunned by the consumerist majority,as they are
ignored for reasons concerning lack of common cultural values...if not
ignored due to outright philosophical disdain/ subliminal labidinal ennui
<ie lack of that lusciously shallow lascivious gloss, that emanates from
shiny new things>

that's consumerism in IMHO

 And can you
>honestly say that people will cease to consume for one day?

Now this is a good point, as the definition of consume is certifiably broad
enough that it is inevitably a characteristic of some very necessary daily
activity... but certainly this was a word which existed before the "ism"
was added, and I for one would not object to any "consuming" of resources
that takes place beyond the bounds of the "ism" outlined above!!

>
>I don't know.  I'm not casting stones, really, but I just don't get it.
>What's the point?

Consumerist pshycological profiles...hmm...probably not all that
contemplative, probaly impulse driven by superficial social relations,
trendy short attention span types, herd menatalities...

Kinda antithetical to my style,
But you all tell me, is this +++ or  very raver-like...??

point is: depth of character requires strenght of character, and the
habitualized psychological patterns of consumerism types , IMHO, is not a
strong type...the first step is to break the habit+mindless repetitivenss
... to make these actions once again choices, and to put into perspective
the role of these choices in the development o f our individual character
and the character of our societies and sub-cultures as a whole...and
hopefully to develop characters strong enough to develop depth...

so taking a day off from the culture of consumerism is probably a  +++ mind
opening day well spent, the first step toward a new realty created by you
and your peers, not by Madison avenue ...

>>>>mission aborted due to short attention span ;)>>>>>>>>

donning asbestos

:>
qsip


You know, there are many people in the country today who, through no
fault of their own, are sane.  Some of them were born sane.  Some of
them became sane later in their lives.  It is up to people like you
and me who are out of our tiny little minds to try and help these
people overcome their sanity.
                                           -- Monty Python

From: Austin Woffington <awoffing@tuba.aix.calpoly.edu>
To: I_wanna_Dance! <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Cc: Austin Woffington <exodus@earthlink.com>
Subject: It's great what house music can do (pesonal story)
Message-Id: <Pine.A32.3.91.961114011819.83194B-100000@tuba.aix.calpoly.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I recently went to a house party on Sunday here in SLO.  My friend Mike 
and Abraham were both spinning and they invited me so I thought i'd check 
it out.  My roommate and I showed up at 10 figuing there would be a bunch 
of drunk college students but great music.  

This was mostly true.  Everyone was some what unfriendly-very cliquey.  
My roommate wanted to go but the music abe was spinnin was cool so I 
wanted to stay.  No one was dancing and some people wanted to put on some 
CD's and turn the tables off.  I mingled and got bored so mike and i and 
this girl I met just started dancing and groovin around.  The keg went 
dry soon after and I figured everyone would leave as usual.  

So wrong I was.  Mike got up and started spinning some fast break and 
house and everyone started to get into it .  No one left and there was no 
beer left and suddenly there were 20 people in the living room gettin' down!
Wow.  Abe and I started cheering and people responded.  I talked to many 
who had never even danced to house before and they were loving it.  A 
nother keg rolled in but it didn't matter people were having a great 
time - asking were they could here more of this crazy phat dance music.

I stayed till 3.30 am dancing and having a great time.  One of the 
funnest nights I've had here.
And now I have a caravan of 8 people coming with me to LA this weekend.  
Some newbies and some new found raver friends.  Anyone know Porcha or 
Jordan or Claire?  neways I had a great time.

This weekend I'm plannig on going to Ron D Core and Thee-o's birthday 
party on Friday and then Oz and/or Evolution 2 on Saturday.  Hope all are 
having a supa week

          I love this music!

PLUR,

       Austin

        ------------------(   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )-----------------

On Wed, 13 Nov 1996, Nancy Shaw wrote:

> While renewing my membership to KALX recently (remember to support community 
> radio!!), I inquired as to why I hadn't heard DJ Seth's excellent 
> Thursday Night techno show ("Aurora Borealis") lately.
> 
> In true community form, it turns out KALX shows get rotated off the schedule 
> after a year to make room for others who want to broadcast.
> 
> But, I was told, there is now no other show featuring techno on KALX!!

Unfortunately, my show did expire a couple months ago, but there are
definitely other dj's to check out who play a certain amount of
techno/ambient/jungle.  Try Alice on Fridays from 3-5:30pm or Nommi on
Sunday nights from 9-midnight.  There is also a budding jungle dj
named Stareyes wandering the late night hours.  And if all goes well,
there will be a permanent techno/ambient specialty show every Sunday night
from midnight to 1am, where we will feature guest dj's weekly.  So it may
be a bit hard to find, but techno still exists at KALX.  Keep your ears
peeled, hopefully I'll have new show soon as well.

take it easy,
Seth

check out the KALX website: oms1.berkeley.edu/KALX

>habitualized psychological patterns of consumerism types , IMHO, is not a
>strong type...the first step is to break the habit+mindless repetitivenss
>... to make these actions once again choices, and to put into perspective
>the role of these choices in the development o f our individual character
>and the character of our societies and sub-cultures as a whole...and
>hopefully to develop characters strong enough to develop depth...
>
>
>

from the pb-cle-raves mailing list:::::

>Date: Wed, 13 Nov 1996 21:28:45 -0500 (EST)
>From: Christopher Newton <hannibal@bu.edu>

>Ok kids.. for all you analogue freaks out there, I have discovered what 
>might be the most insane program ever.  It's called "RubberDuck", and it 
>is basically a fun little virtual tb-303 for PCs.  Some kids from Germany 
>developed it, and let me just say that it sounds incredibly realistic.
>
>You can generate up to 14 pages of acid lines on it's built-in sequencer, 
>mess around with the attacks and slides for each note, then REAL TIME 
>screw with the modulation, the overdrive, the cut-offs, u name it.  Plus, 
>u can set the sequencer to run your pages randomly, creating a totally 
>insane and constantly changing acid frenzy.  It has to be seen to be 
>believed.
>
>The US mirror site is awfully slow (around 815k, but slow throughput) but 
>believe be it is well worth the download for those who want to play 
>around with the sounds but don't have the cash to drop on an actual bass 
>line or other gear.  
>
>This is the download of the century, IMHO.
>
>German site:
>
>http://www.waste.uni-essen.de/d-usion
>
>US Mirror site:
>
>http://www.students.uiuc.edu/~gruschow/rubduck.dip

>It came through pretty quick for me -- you can find it at
>http://pantheon.yale.edu/~sklar/dj/rubduck.zip if the uiuc one is
>still slow.

Hey everyone. . . I'd just like to thank Sho, Joe, and all those
other guys for that bad-ass party tonight (last night). I had even more fun
at this one than the last one. I met more people, talked to more people, and
danced more than before. As usual (I guess) everyone there was cool. There
were no crazy people this time, there were just people dancing, sitting, and
listening.

        I got there a bit too early (about 20-30 mins before the equipment).
I wish I could've helped out with the stuff but everyone was soooo stressed
and in a major rush cuz they were running late. I kinda felt useless just
sitting there as everyone ran back and forth setting things up.

        Once the music started, they started letting people in. Immediately
people started boogying down to those funky beats ala SHO. I have to say
though that I really didn't like the piano music too much, I liked Joe's set
the best. But that's just the type of guy I am.

        It kinda depressed me to see one really sad girl. I tried to cheer
her up, but it was like she was half dead or something. She was sober, but
she was trying to explain to me that it was just a bad time for her. Worse
yet, her friends never showed up.

        There was a pretty cool guy. I forgot his name, but I forget most
everyone's name. He was dancing with his flowers and his jackets, he was
care-free. That was cool. He was a really spiritual man, in fact, he told me
about how he is a spiritual healer. 

        I've never seen sooo many people with their tongue pierced. . . 

        It got a little crowded for about 30 mins, then it cleared pretty
good and there was room for whatever you wanted to do.

        Kinda last minute stuff, like the black lights. I know you guys are
in a hurry, but NEVER leave home without your Duct Tape. 1,000,000,000M uses.

        I really liked the party. I can't say it enough. But I was expecting
to see Leslie, and she wasn't there. But I see Joe, and Sarah, and J Wiley,
and a chick named Olivia, and another named Shugah, Mike, and a guy named
Ojo, and some others who's names have temperarily been bassed out of my
mind. Hey to all of you people I met and spoke to. 

        Can't wait till next time. My sister agreed to go with me.

Thanks!

HUGZ2ALL

Aryck


--QQbpmy22685.847804339/relay6.UU.NET--

Subject: Water problems solved. . .
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Ok, I gots me and Idear. . . Go to your local dirt bike dealer, but
a camelbak water storage thingamajigee (or something similar), and strap it
on. You can usually fit a lot of water in one, and they're pretty
concealable as a small pack under your shirt or jacket. I've been searched,
but they never feel my back (well, not my back back). It's a good idea, and
it's probably work. Just don't abuse the idea. They have tubes which can
connect to your helmet for those long endurance rides where you can't really
take out a bottle and drink from it. 

Aryck

On Thu, 14 Nov 1996, Aryck wrote:

>         Ok, I gots me and Idear. . . Go to your local dirt bike dealer, but
> a camelbak water storage thingamajigee (or something similar), and strap it
> on. You can usually fit a lot of water in one, and they're pretty
> concealable as a small pack under your shirt or jacket. I've been searched,
> but they never feel my back (well, not my back back). It's a good idea, and
> it's probably work. Just don't abuse the idea. They have tubes which can
> connect to your helmet for those long endurance rides where you can't really

drugs, not a 40 of Maddog, but plain 'ol life sustaining water.

Precedence: bulk

Jondabomb wrote:

>My 85 year old Grandpa just left from a ten day visit from Pennsylvania. I
>was sick the whole time he was here, except for like the last two days...
>When he left just now he ws crying. It dawned on me that I might never see
>him again, and he was thinking that too... It just tore my heart up
>inside.... I'm sorry for posting this, but I just had to tell someone....Or
>Something like that... Uhhhh, I feel really shitty right now...

Just before my grandmother died, I got the feeling that, if I didn't go see 
her soon, I might not get the chance.  I made the right move by making 
immediate arrangements to visit her.  A few months after my visit, she died. 
 You can't stop death, but you can enjoy life as much as possible while it 
lasts.  I'd suggest making frequent phone calls, asking him questions about 
his life, his childhood, what life was like when he was young, his views, 
his memories of his parents and grandparents, etc.  Write it all down.  Get 
a tape of him if you can.  I managed to secretly record my grandmother 
singing some old songs to me, and I cherish that tape more than you can imagine.

Much happiness and fond memories,

S

> I thought this would be an appropriate time to start a discussion 
>     about the number 23, which was never really covered by sesame street, 
>     but seems to be, well, very chaotic.  anyone have anymore background 
>     on the significance of 23?

twen ty three (twen' te thre') n. 1. a cardinal number, 20 plus 3.  2. a 
symbol for this number, as 23 or XXIII.  3. a set of this many person or 
things.  -adj. 4. amounting to 23 in number.

-From The Random House Dictionary of the English Language (the unabridged 
edition)

                       ____                     ____
                                  !E.A.C!       
                       Electronic Artists Collective
                       ____     *Astronout*     ____

     Disclaimer:
     Read the message below the Reply Separator... mine makes no sense 
     without it.  It might not even make sense with it.  Is sharing weird 
     thoughts always like this?
     
     =)
     
     I supposed it's fair... It's my fault.  About ten years ago, I was in 
     detention staring at the graffiti on my desk and thought to myself: 
     THERE COULDN'T BE ANYTHING MORE PATHETIC THAN ETCHING THE VAN HALEN 
     LOGO INTO A PUBLIC HIGH SCHOOL DESK.
     
     I now admit to having been proven wrong by the fates and time.  
     Addidas never came out with "Eruption"... Nike doesn't even have a 
     drummer...
     
     What the fuck.
     
     Ironic that if those kids that graffiti that stuff lived in Indonesia 
     or Tibet or Malaysia, they might not have time to scratch logos on 
     desks because:
     
     Many schools lack resources like teachers, desks, etc...
     
     They'd still be at the Nike shoe factory because they didn't finish 
     their quota for the day.
     
     They are too illiterate to accurately remember the wording and logo 
     because the United States actually does benefit from keeping other 
     countries in the poorhouse by keeping them in civil wars (funded with 
     our hard earned drug dollars even), undereducated and working in 
     manual labor fields.
     
     Sorry.
     AndyW
     
     Does anybody else ever realized how spoiled we are... I'm not saying 
     stop complaining, because it can get better, but stop and marvel every 
     once in a while at how much we have.  I think I'm still in afterglow 
     from Chrysalis... did anybody else notice how good the vibe got in the 
     morning?

I've heard rumors that "A Wrinkle in Time" is going to have
Stella Luna performing, so I'm seriously thinking about
making it there.

How about "Freaky People" on December 13th.  Any chance of
Stella Luna there?

> Dj's:   Trent - Minor Minor - Brandon - Brian Flip - Greg =)

And I can't say I'm up on the DJs these days.  What can
these folks be expect to spin?

Hardcore is a definite minus for me.  Jungle (or
tribal... anyone remember tribal?) would be a definite
plus.  

Though actually, what would be a big plus is
"stuff-I've-never-heard-of-before-and-would-have-a-
hard-time-classifying".

By the way, as for "Buy Nothing Day" and all that.  A friend
of mine has just started working at Global Exchange, a
non-profit organization that among other things sells
various "ethnic" hand crafts from around the world with the
idea of funneling more of the money to the ethnic-folks and
less of it into the profit margin.  They would be seriously
bummed if they didn't do some decent business this holiday
season.  

(They've got a few locations, one is in SF on 24th Street in
Noe Valley, another is in Berkeley, I think on College near
Claremont.  It's a good place to get some decent drums, if
you feel like joining in with Stella Luna...)

I was gone most of the week, so there might be stuff missing.  Lotsa stuff
got sent in though, so there's plenty to choose from.  Recombinant continues
for the next couple days, Basics is on Saturday, and the SFR BBQ.

I checked out Goldie's Metalheadz and James Lavelle's That's How It Is
in London at the beginning of the week.  Way good stuff - busy crowd,
lotsa beats!


                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi
    
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Thursday, November 14th - Asphodel Records presents Recombinant
   DJ Spooky that Subliminal Kid, Sub Dub, We, Byzar, Granular Synthesis
   (Austria), the Invisible Scratch Pickles, The X-Men, Cheb I Sabbah,
   Steve Roach, guests.
   8:30pm-, 21+, $15. 174 King St., SF. 415.522.7380
   
   Thursday, November 14th - _Cargo_
   Chris Lum, Rasoul, Buck, Marilyn Bull.
   9p-, 21+, $5. Jelly's, Pier 50, SF.
   
   Friday, November 15th - _Famtasia_
   Tony, John Howard, Jonathan, Sin, Boomerang Fidget, Judge, Rob Doten,
   Tom, others.
   Only 200 tix, presale only from Primal Records and Housewares
   $12. 510.559.2529
   
   Friday, November 15th - _Rise Above It_
   Laron, Preston, Chris Lum, Mei-Lwun, Soulstice featuring Jamalski.
   $10. 150 Folsom St, SF. 415.709.0770
   
   Friday, November 15th - Asphodel Records presents Recombinant
   DJ Spooky that Subliminal Kid, Sub Dub, We, Byzar, Granular Synthesis
   (Austria), the Invisible Scratch Pickles, The X-Men, Naut Humon
   conducts the ISO Orchestra, guests.
   8:30pm-, 21+, $15. 174 King St., SF. 415.522.7380
   
   Friday, November 15th - Rebel Alliance and Elliptical Sound presents
   _Genesis_
   Traditional ambient drum and bass, down tempo free form, bass breaks,
   and beats!
   Ocean, Niel, Sam (Earth), Markus, Juules, special guests.
   10pm-3am, 21+, $5. 2007 16th St, SF.
   
   Saturday, November 16th - _BBQ & Beats III_
   Alex (Soto), Noah Ruiz, Micron, BioJeff, Tom, Myster-E/Mars.
   some food will be provided, but you're encouraged to bring some to
   share
   12noon-9pm, All ages, Free. 415.974.4357
   
   Saturday, November 16th - _Rhythm and Sound_
   turntablism mixology
   curious (la), noel, abstract, stareyes, sean andrews.
   a monthly drum and bass excursion
   415.322.5800x247
   
   Saturday, November 16th - Basics
   Tony, Josh, Jeno, Solar, Phil Smart.
   $415. 415.905.9629
   
   Saturday, November 23rd - Pro-Soy presents _Wyrd (we - urd)_
   Deaks, Maya, drenalin, John Carel, Rich, Sig/Tina, Moshce, Cloud,
   drenalin, Tony Rotundo.
   415.635.6815
   
   Friday, November 29th - _Ubiquitous_
   Carlos, Simon, Pete Avila, Rick Preston, Ghost, R.K.Tech, Frank Nitty,
   Pat Allen, Dutch, Spun, Alonso, Larry Live, Friction (TX), Shiloh,
   Henrik, Jaz, Liquid, David Michael, DRC.
   Free. Sacramento. 916.491.1944 415.263.0695 510.806.8588 408.881.0615
   
   Saturday, November 30th - _Tribal Funk 3 year birthday party_
   Utopia, Garth, Tony, DJ Dan, Mark Farina, guests.
   9pm-7am, . 415.905.4476
   
   Saturday, November 30th - Space Children presents Be Here Now
   a journey through the sacred life
   J Saul Kane, A Guy Called Gerald, DJ Hyperactive, Twerk, Dutch,
   Radley, DRC, Cesar, Consciousness Lab Ambient Sound Research, Jonah
   Sharp, Abstract, Beyond Race, Darkhorse, The Cyclops.
   Visuals by Multimedia Meltdown.
   Fire Dancers & Blowers\\\Snake Goddesses\\\Free Love
   415.273.1622
   
   Friday, December 6th - NU-S.A.L.T. Productions presents _Argon_
   Rig-A-Tony, Carlos Campos, DLX, Simon Apex, Rockit, Dennis.
   Limited quantity $7 presale tix available.
   Sacramento. 916.499.7417
   
   Friday, December 13rd - Harmony presents _Freaky People_
   come and celebrate the spirit of superstition
   Trent, Minor Minor, Brandon, Brian Flip, Greg.
   $10 with a costume.
   limited # of tickets (400)
   $15. sf. 408.486.9591 415.263.4885
   
   Saturday, December 14th - _Candyland_
   Simon, Carlos, Ghost, Josh, Liquid, Jazz-e, Kwashi, Spinner,
   Tripnotix, Jin, Nam.
   Visuals by L.S.D., Square one.
   free candy all night
   
   
   Tuesday, December 31st - Cool World presents _Planet New Year Festival '96_
   415.979.4543 408.235.1077
   
   Saturday, January 18th - Ghostribe / Underground Urban Guerrillas
   presents Acid Breaks
   Kelly Reverb (Dallas), Donald Glaude, Barry Weaver, Carlos, Ghost,
   Frank Nitty, Tripnotix, Preston, Moshe, Pat Allen, Boomerang Fidget,
   Glo Worm, Sean Andrew, Foster.
   Visuals by L.S.D, Lumitech..
   presale tix on sale December 1st.
   415.273.1474 510.433.7181 408.881.0632

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday morning 9am-11am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench. Varied techno sub-genres, noise, spoken word, world
       music. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

On Thu, 14 Nov 1996, Thompson. Jim wrote:

> 
> 	We used to have "Buy Nothing" days - every Sunday!
> 
> 	Perhaps those in favor of government control of our
> 	behavior would like a return to those days - to "protect"
> 	us from crass commercialism of course!

	No one said anything about government control here. No one is 
proposing to "protect" anyone from "crass commericalism", or at least I 
have not gotten that feeling from any of the posts I have read. 
Commericalism has by and large convinced a hell of a lot of people that 
they need shit for some reason that they really do not need. Ok, maybe it 
was not commericalism, but somehow, people started to believe that the 
amount of pointless shite that you never use is one way of proving just 
how good a person you are. Some of us don't think that way, and not 
necessarily because we are excluded from the game, but because the game 
holds nothing for us except being shitty to other people for no reason 
that holds any importance to me, while making someone else able to smirk 
while they think "those suckers out there sure are silly...".
	Maybe those who are out there proposing BOYCOTT day are really 
super secret CIA type operatives, planting subversive thoughts so the 
real hearty Americans can look down on us who had so little brain power 
as to be lead astray from what life is really all about - things like 
progress and buying things. With everything telling everyone who watches 
TV or drives down the freeway or wanders about in public places that they 
need a new set of Sony super-improved ultra bass fluxation with a 
response of 10hz VR-7594669 headphones, I do not think one or two people 
asking people to think about why they would be giving those to their 
"loved" ones or friends is bad.

dave

Hoo boy, gotta add a word to this one...

>BOYCOTT CHRISTMAS!  (snipped out multiple paragraphs on wasteful and
>meaningless giftgiving)....


I happen to love giving gifts, including at Christmas ... whether it costs
a nickel at a yard sale or $500 at a jeweler, if it's been chosen with
love, care, thought and individuality, a gift is a tangible way we show
people that we care about them.

I remember gifts that I've given, and gifts that I've received, and I
cherish many of those gifts years later, because they remind me of the
person who cared enough about me to give it.

Boycott crappy needless mindless stuff, sure, but planning out giftgiving
is one of the greatest pleasures I know!

Leslie

     23 : Two score plus 3
     
     
     The Roman numeral 23 has much signifigance in the modern world.
     
     23 is the exact number of apostles that Jesus had (incluing Jesus 
     himself and adding 10 to allow for historical innaccuracies)
     
     If you reverse the numbers that make up the number 23 you get the 
     number 32. There are no known 32-day months in the roman calender. 
     This surely has wide reaching karmic implications which we are only 
     now beginning to comprehend.
     
     Jesus Christ was allegedly 23 when he died (allowing + or - 10 for 
     historical variation (please see 1. above))
     
     Today is the 14 of Novemeber. If we add 14 and 11 we get 25. If we 
     subtract 2 from 25 (2 being the average number of arms,legs, eyes and 
     ears attached to the average human) we get 23. Spooky, huh ?
     
     It is considered good luck in certain parts of Lithuania to wear size 
     23 plaid pants on the night of a new moon. 
     
     If we omit ABC from the popular song "Now I know my ABC" we discover 
     that there are in fact 23 letters in the alphbet and not 26 as may of 
     us have been brainwashed into beleiving by a system which places no 
     value on freedom of thought. 
     
     At the moment there is a  "real" version of a popular cartoon called 
     101 dalmations. But it is a little known fact that Walt Disney had 
     originally planned to call the cartoon "23 Dalmations" as he had a 5 
     year old grandson who would reach that very age in 18 years time. 
     
     23 is the age which I would have reached on my most recent birthday 
     had I been born a year later.
     
     Well thats all for now, I hope all 23 of you enjoy reading the above.
     I have to run to catch the 23 bus to 23 23rd avenue in time for the 
     23:23 (11:23) meeting of the 23 club.
     
     wibble, wibble

Ah, I am Max Vision, 23, neuromanic to the core.  23 is obviously my 
favorite number.  I know a perhaps too much about it.  From Illuminatus to 
cyberpunk fiction to my everyday life, I KNOW.  So greetings from all three 
points of the triangle... and have a nice day!

number 23 and it's significance, email me or something, I may post more info.

At 03:49 PM 11/14/96 -0800, you wrote:
>> I thought this would be an appropriate time to start a discussion 
>>     about the number 23, which was never really covered by sesame street, 
>>     but seems to be, well, very chaotic.  anyone have anymore background 
>>     on the significance of 23?
>
>twen ty three (twen' te thre') n. 1. a cardinal number, 20 plus 3.  2. a 
>symbol for this number, as 23 or XXIII.  3. a set of this many person or 
>things.  -adj. 4. amounting to 23 in number.
>
>-From The Random House Dictionary of the English Language (the unabridged 
>edition)

is in SF on Haight between Masonic and Central.

to avoid incurring the $3 you-waited-too-long tax.
