>a camelbak water storage thingamajigee (or something similar), and strap it
>on. You can usually fit a lot of water in one, and they're pretty
>concealable as a small pack under your shirt or jacket. I've been searched,
>but they never feel my back (well, not my back back). It's a good idea, and

i'll vouch for the camelbak. they're awsome. i've got one, i don't wear it
all the time, but when i do it's the handiest little thing of all time.
plus, having that tube hanging into my mouth all night entertains all the
kiddies on e.. ;)

regarding sneaking it in: i took mine to a kundalini once and got in with
it, even though they were taking everyone's water bottles away. i wrapped
up the bladder and stuffed it inside the pack part; when the security guard
looked in, she said "wierd, i've never seen one like that before" - she
thought it was some crazy bong and let me in with it. =)
-brendan

OK, it is not suppose to rain where the BBQ will be, only partly cloudy. So
here is what I would like everyone to do. If we all think and believe
positive thoughts and believe it will NOT rain tomorrow, it will NOT rain.
I'm a strong believer of, if you think and believe in something strong
enough it will actually happen. So if we all think positive then it will go
off great.

An example of this is when I did a BBQ for my company it was raining during
the week and was supposed to rain the day of the BBQ. Well, they didn't
want to cancel it and It could go inside with the BBQ undercover. I just
started to believe that it wasn't going to rain, as well as everyone else
hoping for no rain and low and behold it didn't rain. It was actually a
nice day.

The BBQ will be in the same place as the last 2 other ones. Believe it or
not the weather forecast is different in that area then SF and further
north like Napa Valley. Chances are, there is a slight chance of rain in
Northern CA near Napa, but at Pt. Molate (San Rafael) it is only going to
be partly cloudy.

So lets all think NO RAIN and get ready to have a great time. I will have
tarps ready in case we have some negative vibes brewing in our mist. I will
update the Voicemail after 11pm (NEWS). If the News say Yes rain then I
will postpone the BBQ, if they say Only party cloudy or SLIGHT chance of
rain, then it is still a go for the BBQ because I'd like to think Slight
means NO.

So call the Voice mail about 11:30pm tonight or before you head to the BBQ
on Saturday.

415-974-4357


NO RAIN,


Tim (knucklehead)

From: Max Vision <vision@mpath.com>
Subject: nrr: 23
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Wow the response was more than I expected! :)
I've got to tell you guys, that since I opened a new pack of underwear and
the sticker said, "Inspected by #23", my life has never been the same.  (I
swear on my existence that this really occured!!)  Basically I'm going to
echo out some of the explanations I've heard so everyone can see what other
people said, but I also want to note some things I've seen.  
Twenty Three years of life, and here is what I've learned.  There are a lot
of things that are coincidence, and there are a lot that are blatent and
intentional.  Like in FringeWare Review #2, on the cover
(http://www.fringeware.com/cgi-bin/cat), note Bruce Sterling's portrait on a
23 dollar bill.  Or in Max Headroom, Network 23.  Or countless references in
hundreds of scifi and cyberpunk works, both print and movies.  By far the
strongest single meaning that I can convey to people who wonder, is that
it's a subcultural ICON.  It's a recurring reference in cyberpunk genre,
both fiction and nonfiction.  You'll see it referenced in phrack, people's
handles (ahem, ghost23 speaking)... it's like anime is to raves.  Or more
accurately, what 420 is to the subculture.  420 raves, 23 cybertek.  Ah but
there is a reason that number evolved to be the one.  (Unlike 2600 which is
a frequency)

Here are some emails I received on the matter, most reference I knew about
but I'll just list them all here for everyone:

>i've always wondered about people different interpretations of 23, the way
>i interpret is seperate 2 to 3(to be free) then add 2+3=5, number of man,
>and take 2^3 + 3^2 =17, or one 7, a number of worldwide mystical
>significance. Too me it was of the pattern numbers like 7, that is worked
>over by many people into an image of something?
Yes, it's a thought meme.  A sort of subcultural virus that some find
enjoyable :)

>The number 23 - extremely significant.  My Grandfather, a gypsy, had a
>curse put on him that his two sons would die at fifty five (23 + 32) and
>be buried on their wives birthdays.  Sure enough, they both died at 55
>and were buried on their wives birthdays.  Sucked. 
Ack.. sorry to hear it, see there is a reason people have respect for this
number, some reason that even gypsies (probably without computers) are keen on..
(I'm assuming it was a gypsy who did the cursing also?)

>Since I was made aware of it's 'significance' it has appeared, often
>prophetically, in many different circumstances and situations.
>But then this could just be heightened awareness/perception of the number.
>i.e. If it was the number 42, would you see that everywhere,
>or if you have a certain make/color of car, you always spot many more of
>the same.  I don't know much about it, but 23 seems to have a lot of
>caballistic (sp: kabal?) links.
>Also lots of mentions in The Illuminatus Trilogy (see below).
>Father + Mother each contribute 23 chromosones.
>23 Skidoo
>2+3=5 (Law of Fives)
>2/3=0.666 (numer of the beast recurring)
Yep, the Illuminatus may be a significant contributer, and at least a
provocateur.  The law of fives was my first non-cyberpunk intro to 23.

>it IS the NINTH prime number, you know.
>http://www.teleport.com/~ingebret/23.html
Thanks for the link, many of these are coincidence type occurances, but
those are fun too!

So in a nutshell, despite it's origins, 23 is a subcultural icon reoccuring
in raving, hacking, cyberpunk, and other cultures.  Hey, even Michael Jordan
knows what's up :)

hehe

Have a cool day!
Max

___________________________________________________

                                 Geekerata                (A UNIX Analog
of Desiderata (Max Ehrman, 1927))                   (mainly as addressed
to a network process)                            Badri Krishnamoorthy
                           badri@srtc.com-----Route placidly amid
channel noise and network failures,And remember what throughput there
may be in executing all alone.As far as possible, without overflowing
bufferBe on communicative terms with all processes.Broadcast your data
quietly and clearlyAnd listen(2) to others.Even to the null and the
unreachable,They too have their requests.Avoid long and argumentative
sessionsThey are burdensome to the ether.If you compare your priority
with others'You may become vain or bitterFor always there will be
greater and lesser processes than yourself.Enjoy your CPUtime as well as
your idletime.Keep cognizance of your portmapper, however low-levelIt is
a constant port in the changing mappings of the network.Exercise caution
in your execution,For the kernel is full of traps.But let this not blind
you to what swap space there is;Many channels strive for high
bandwidths, and everywhereComputing is full of parallelism.Be yourself.
(Check with getpid(2) frequently)Especially do not forge NFS file
handles.Neither be cynical about sockets,For in the face of all
congestion and delaysThey are as powerful as STREAMS.Take kindly the
influx of new requests,Gracefully re-prioritizing the older ones.Nurture
support of check-points to rollback from sudden crashesBut do not thrash
pages due to imagined pagefaults:Many core dumps are born of bus error
or segmentation faults.Beyond a nominal consideration,Be nice(1) to
other processes.You are a child in the kernel spaceNo less than the
daemons and the device drivers,You have a right to execute here.And
whether or not it is apparent to youNo doubt the kernel is crashing,
though it shouldn't.Therefore be at peace with your programmerHowever
geeky you think s/he is.And wherever your read(2)'s and recvfrom(2)'s,In
the noisy communication channels of the network,Keep a valid (void *)
buf available in your address space.With all its stopped jobs, missing
arguments and broken pipes,It is still a UNIX shell.Be
backward-compatible.Strive to be up and running always.
"Stay Connected..."

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

From: Thompson. Jim
Subject: Re: We Used to Have Buy Nothing Days - EVERY SUNDAY!!!


Actually, I totally agree with you!  There used to be "Blue Laws" that
prevented stores from being open on Sunday.  The idea was that there
was to be at least ONE day a week that was to used for introspection,
religious activity (albeit Christian), family time, etc without the
constant
drumbeat of worldly concerns....

I'm not advocating a return to Blue Laws but there HAS  been something
lost in our headlong rush away from all things spiritual.....

        jim thompson - cube root fact axon info grid data fate

From: Dave Bayer
To: \SFRaves\
Subject: Re: We Used to Have Buy Nothing Days - EVERY SUNDAY!!!
Date: Thursday, November 14, 1996 6:18PM



On Thu, 14 Nov 1996, Thompson. Jim wrote:

>
> 	We used to have "Buy Nothing" days - every Sunday!
>
> 	Perhaps those in favor of government control of our
> 	behavior would like a return to those days - to "protect"
> 	us from crass commercialism of course!

	No one said anything about government control here. No one is
proposing to "protect" anyone from "crass commericalism", or at least I
have not gotten that feeling from any of the posts I have read.
Commericalism has by and large convinced a hell of a lot of people that
they need shit for some reason that they really do not need. Ok, maybe
it
was not commericalism, but somehow, people started to believe that the
amount of pointless shite that you never use is one way of proving just
how good a person you are. Some of us don't think that way, and not
necessarily because we are excluded from the game, but because the game
holds nothing for us except being shitty to other people for no reason
that holds any importance to me, while making someone else able to smirk
while they think "those suckers out there sure are silly...".
	Maybe those who are out there proposing BOYCOTT day are really
super secret CIA type operatives, planting subversive thoughts so the
real hearty Americans can look down on us who had so little brain power
as to be lead astray from what life is really all about - things like
progress and buying things. With everything telling everyone who watches
TV or drives down the freeway or wanders about in public places that
they
need a new set of Sony super-improved ultra bass fluxation with a
response of 10hz VR-7594669 headphones, I do not think one or two people
asking people to think about why they would be giving those to their
"loved" ones or friends is bad.

dave

[ to sfraves list ]

 Unfortunetly, I won't be able to make it out to anything this weekend.
I did want to mention a Pt. Molate/Friends and Family story that may
have a bearing on tomorrow's BBQ & Beats picninc party:

 Many months ago , FnF decided to do an outdoor party at Pt. Molate. 
Come the day of the party, the weather reports were very bad, but, with
all optimism, Ethan decided to go ahead with it.

 And, yes , it did rain some on us, but not as much as areas north
and south of us. Looking to the west, you could see the clouds parting 
at Mt. Tamilpias , heading either north or southward, leaving only
a little percipitation for the Richmond/Pt. Molate area. As if the weather
was giving us a special dispensation!

 So, hey, it could happen again! Especially if the wind is coming from the 
ocean (west).

 Good luck and good partying, y'all!

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

a little more number theory...:-)

:2 is prime, 3 is prime, 
:2 and 3 are the third and fourth numbers in the fibbonacci sequence(see
stars below)
:2 succesive numbers in the fibonacci sequence also give the WORST running
time for the extended Euclidean algorithm
:2+3=5 which is both the prime that follows 3 and the fibonacci number
that follows 3
: 3 - 2 = 1 and 2 - 3 = -1 showing distinct dualistic properties
:the number 23 is a member of the natural numbers, the rational numbers as
well as the reals 
:lim (e-->infinity) (23 + 1/e ) = 23 relation with infinite forces

* * ** *** ***** ******** *************
Tony Rose
UC Berkeley CS
http://www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~trose
"hmmm hhmmmm good"

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Fri, 15 Nov 1996 12:27:54 -0700
To: Scott Wade <SWade@bronson.com>
From: Rhea Gossett <rhea@xinet.com>
Subject: Re: Invisible Scratch Pickles
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Yeah, I went to the Recombinant show last night.  The Pickles were really
interesting, I thought, really good.  Only two or three people dancing
off & on (one of them me!), way in the back, big empty space in the room's
center, all the rest of the people crowded tightly around the turntables,
looking on.  I couldn't blame 'em at all - I would have liked to get
close enough to see exactly what they were doing with their equipment!

The Pickles came on in the "small" room, my guess is around
11:00 or 11:20 ??   Played till about 12:00 or 12:15...then someone
else came on, started up some visuals on 4 big screens....I was
into it at first, but then the visuals turned horrifying (staccato
loopings & warpings of a woman's head, mouthing along with a high-pitched
vocally sound, all of it super-fast, sound-level increasing....then
the woman's head seeming to morph into a white-eyeballed, fanged
grimace....sped-up, jerking like a evil retching puppet head, repeated
across all 4 screens).

I ended up leaving - sound levels had increased to the point of actual
ear-pain, even though I was wearing thick foam earplugs....I'd
put my hands over my ears, turned away from the screens, thinking
I'd "wait it out," then I decided that was stupid & I could just
plain leave.

The visual images were startling & repulsive to me in a way that's really
hard to explain...if you go & you see it, or, if anyone else reading this
was there last night, write me back & tell me what you thought, as I'm still
not quite sure what my opinion of it is. They seem to have been shooting for
a "noise/terror" effect, and they achieved it, but to good, bad,
or indifferent ends, I can't say...

It did not seem like a night for dancing.  When I arrived around
10:30, the crowd was sparse - only a couple people were dancing in the
main room, to Cheb i Sabbah, and some other folks with tons & tons &
TONS of computers & keyboards & software.  Then everyone headed for the
small room to check out the Pickles. But then, I left at 12:30, so the
dancefloor may have improved once people got out of the habit of facing
the stage, looking for something to see.

If anyone goes tonight (it's still at King Street, same folks +/- one or
two special guests), I urge you to please, please BRING EARPLUGS !!!!
I have started to get in the habit of wearing ear plugs at raves for the
last 2 years now, and I can say that this was the loudest sound I have
encountered in those 2 years at least.

I'm kicking myself for fleeing in pain without even trying to communicate
this to someone "in charge" last night....maybe no one was on the dance
floor 'cause it was too tough to handle the volume from the speakers at
such levels??

Bonus-that-tipped-the-evening-from-neutral-to-downright-positive:
I was handed a flyer announcing a new(?) gig for DJ Charlotte!
It's going to be Wednesday nights, at the Up&Down club (I think -
can't check this, since the flyer's at home, in my jacket pocket).
If I remember right, it's called "feminine PHAT"  !!

See you there, and good luck at Recombinant!!

Rhea

>on the Pickles and DJ Spooky...possible set times?
>

Subject: Marijuana Gets Own Internet Site
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 1996 12:40:51 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

      BERKELEY, CALIF. - The Associated
                               Press via Individual Inc. : One week after state
                               voters approved the use of marijuana for
                               medical reasons, a group has set up an Internet
                               site with an order form for potential
                               customers. 
                                      - Web browsers can choose from ``B
                               grade imported'' to ``AA grade California
                               green'' at the new site of the Berkeley
                               Prescription Cannabis Growers and Buyers
                               Club. 
                                      - ``The victory of (Proposition 215) has
                               allowed us to come out of the closet,'' said Ted
                               Tuk, temporary director of the 10-year-old
                               group. 
                                      - ``We've always been an informal group
                               of disabled people helping each other obtain
                               marijuana, but now we can be more out front
                               about it,'' Tuk said. 
                                    - Proposition 215 legalized the cultivation,
                               possession and use of marijuana for health
                               reasons. However, it is still illegal to sell or
                               distribute marijuana, and growing it is a
                               federal crime. 
                                      - Tuk's group does not seem to care, but
                               police do. 
                                      - ``Along with supplying and selling
                               marijuana, which are felonies, I imagine you
                               could cook up something extra for using the
                               Internet,'' said Berkeley police Sgt. Michael
                               Stafstrom. 
                                     - The attorney general's office declined to
                               comment on the group's offer, saying the law
                               has left things ``murky.'' 
                                      - Tuk, who is prepared to go to jail, said
                               eventually the Web site will only be available
                               to club members, who must have a doctor's
                               permission to use marijuana. 
                                      - ``I don't want people trying to order
                               marijuana without the proper authorization,''
                               he said. ``I'm really trying to do this in keeping
                               with the proper spirit of Prop 215.'' 
                                      - ^___= 
                                      - The marijuana Internet site can be
                               found at http://www.dts.org/BRXCGBC/ 
                                      [11-14-96 at 17:58 EST, Copyright 1996,
                               The Associated Press]

     Shameless Plug for a Product I Love (well.. not LOVE...)
     
     I wore my Camelback (I have a groovin little deluxe model with extra 
     pouches.. perfect for hiking, MTBiking, etc) all night at Freedom, and 
     people just dug it.  It keeps water really cold all night long if you 
     fill it with ice cubes, and you can dance like a freak without having 
     to put it down, because it's comfy.  I don't think of it in a 
     smuggling way, but a convenience way... plus it makes no trash and 
     sorta promotes that "SoCal Desert Raver Survivalist Just Lived Through 
     Nuclear Winter But I'm Still Happy and Dancing" look.  Look for me 
     wearing it outdoors next summer!
     
     Is anybody else getting really hyper about this weekend?  See you all 
     at uh.. um... Wrinkle in Time.  And BBQ & Beets (not my favorite veg, 
     but I do have some borsht occasionally) where it is NOT GOING TO RAIN.
     
     I know it's not going to rain, and I'm very confident of this fact.  
     So confident that I will NOT bring the top to my trusty raving 
     companion, the 87 Suzuki Samurai convertible.  Everybody say happy 
     100,000 miles... it just kicked over last night (didn't actually see 
     it though :( ).  My car is now officially Kelly Blue Book worthless... 
     or damn close at least.
     
     I think I need to get my blood sugar checked.
     
     Peace Beautiful People!
     AndyW

Subject: Terence McKenna's "Food of the Gods"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     
     Hi all,
     
     
     I finally finished reading this book (on Bart) last night and I have 
     to say Terence gets very excited in the final chapter when he 
     basically comes to the conclusion that DMT & other hallucinogens 
     represent the escape door out of the psychic and environmental mess 
     that we humans have embroiled ourselves in at the end of the of the 
     20th century. 
     
     Of particular interest to me and I suppose to readers of the list was 
     his observations on the whole DMT experience. He talks of beings akin 
     to "tykes at play" that one becomes aware of when in this state which 
     he likens to entering a parallel universe. He also makes reference to 
     an entity called "the wholly other" and...wait for it...Aliens !
     
     I'm aware that the alien thread may have come up before on the list 
     before but I find the associations very interesting and wonder does 
     anyone out there have any first or second hand experiences similar to 
     Mr McKenna's ?
     
     Or which McKenna books would you recommend I read next ?
     
     Nanu nanu,
     
     COH

From: Adam Guevara <aguevara@rely.com>

Subject: Terminology of our kind...
Date: Fri, 15 Nov 1996 16:01:39 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.994.63
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I thought this might be a bit interesting...


To be in the "scene"  one has to be down with the right sayings  it
seems whatever we wish to call ourselves become out dated in 5-7 yrs and
we reinvent...

40's   Cats

50's   Beatnecks, bohemians

60's   flowerchildren, hippies

70's   Dudes, chicks

80's    Ravers, Friends

90's     Scenesters, partygoers

I stumbled upon this when I was conversing w/ a newbe and she commented,
"whoa,  you've been a scenster for a while!"
Me:  "Scenster?  Is that what they call ravers nowadays???"
Her:  "Raver?  yep you're old school all right..."


Hmm.   I guess new terms pop up everywhere, eastcost goers calls Jungle
-Drum and Bass-

I hear that jungle dancers be referred to as junglists.
Trance goers are called Trancers (or tranceheads)

Has anyone else noticed this???

keeping a finger on the pulse,

---Adam
"Stay Connected..."

Before letting yourself get too excited about entering parallel universes
or meeting aliens through the use of psychadelics I highly recomend
reading some john lilly, check out this link...at first it may seem that
he is coming to the same conclusions, but you really gottsa get to the end
before he really draws his hypothesis together..

http://www.rain.org/~lili/DrJohnLilly/metaprog.html
if you read this let me know what you think...

Tony Rose

     profits from Proctor & Gamble products went to a satanist group. The 
     compamy logo (check it out on the side of products) depicts a 
     half-moon and seven star motif. Maybe they have since removed it, but

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com

the problem of private ownership of property is directly related to the
excessive population of the human species.  there are too many humans on
this planet and that is why we can no longer freely forage for food and
neither can the other animals with which we share this planet (being
confined to a park hardly counts as free) (and animals that violate the
park bounds are often killed, like the mountain lion in marin last month).
by the way, over-grazing is caused when the animal population becomes too
large for it's territory which is the case with humans and is why some
people should die of starvation. the reason you never hear of a "save the
humans" campaign is because we are doing fine, unfortuneately we are
killing pretty much everything else living on this planet in the process.
when i think of what we've done to this planet i'm ashamed to be human.

just another primate, jennifer

ps.  i don't own any land, but if you show up at my door with a big bazooka
and threaten to blow my head off if i don't give you all my stuff, well you
can have it!  i don't really give a shit about stuff or property.  life is
what matters.

pps. has it occured to you that agriculture enslaves plants?

>>is there any justification for allowing an animal to starve in the forest?
>>or is it a part of a natural evolutionary cycle in which some beings go
>>hungry and others find food?
>
>Last I checked, the hungry animal could freely forage for food, freely
>cross any land in order to get food, and not risk arrest for
>trespassing or theft. Only a sick/injured animal, or a whole population
>facing overgrazing/drought/ecological disaster would find itself
>"starving in the forest"....
>
>Even when you take animal territoriality into account, most animals
>driven out of a territory can find somewhere to go. Unfortunately for
>humans, this is not the case. Fact is "we" treat wild animals better
>than a large percentage of the underclass -- where are our "wild human
>sanctuaries" ; how come you never hear of a "save the humans" campaign?
>
>Unfortunately, given that every square inch of land is owned by
>somebody, fenced by somebody, and we have police/legal structures that
>strongly enforce these private property rights, one ends up with
>starving people on the street. They have nowhere else to go, and no
>means by which to sustain themselves. If these people had a place to
>rest their heads, soil to grow their food or graze their animals, I
>very much doubt they'd be starving in the street.
>
>So the better question to ask is where does privatized land, private
>property, and a system that prevents people from being able to sustain
>themselves unless they're willing to rent out their bodies as
>slave-labor in order to obtain food/lodging -- where the hell does that
>fit into your "natural evolutionary cycle"??
>
>I would love to see what happens to people spouting such economic
>darwinism crap if they actually existed in nature, wild, and without
>the police/state there to enforce their hoarding of property and means
>of sustenance. If this were a "natural" system, I could just get myself
>a big gun/knife/club, barge onto your property, and claim it for
>myself. And unless you could better defend yourself, you'd either find
>yourself dead or you'd have to retreat.
>
>In fact, I'd venture to say that we've badly disrupted the natural
>evolutionary cycle through our ability to unfairly enforce the hoarding
>of private property. I find it rare that those that actually have the
>state protecting their property holdings are actually more fit than
>those that are enslaved to work on that property in exchange for their
>rights to exist and thrive on said "private" property.
>
>=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
>==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
>=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

>	human's are not *simply* animals in a forest. is not one of the
>things commonly considered setting us apart from animals our capacity to
>reason and move beyond mere instinct (not to say that most of us *do*
>act rationally--these things only work in theory). sure, starvation is
>"natural" in the animal kingdom, but no matter how much you believe we are
>animals, there are some very obvious aspects of our existence that set us
>apart from other species.

every species is different, that is the point in dividing them up.  the
argument that humans are especially different and therefore better and more
worthy of this earth than other animals is a product of the christian
religion, and i believe it to be false.  it is this very reason which sets
us "apart" that has given us this erroneous belief.  there is no apart.  we
are all in this together.  if there were no other living beings but humans,
we would die, we depend on other species for our life, it's a system and we
are just a link in it.  a damn weak link too.

ravers!
it's been a long time, my friends.
this is shalom, also once known as disssolve. i bid a teary and very =
temporary goodbye to the sfraves family when i moved to korea last =
winter. i've been teaching here ever since - repaying loans, learning =
about this culture, living a loveable life - giving and receiving PLUR =
to and from those whose minds and lives are inconcievably different from =
my own.=20
i could write volumes, but i won't - not now, not here. instead, i'll go =
straight to my main question:=20
do any of you know anything about raving in east asia? especially, about =
raving in korea? i've found zip, nothing happening in seoul, and i'm =
starved for even a little taste of what i once feasted on in the bay =
area.=20
that's my first question. here's my second:
i'm flying back to the bay area for the christmas/new year's week, and =
of course, i want to rejoin our dancetribe. i want to sweat, to pant, to =
paint my muscles and face and feet and hands with heat, with power, =
with...
i digress, as always.
to rejoin the tribe: my fingers lose the keys with giddiness at this =
point.
to pant, to sweat, to digress again and again and to forget about =
digressing and thinking and doing this or not doing that, to worship =
with the movements of my body the mysterious everything surrounding us, =
to praise the rising sun with the  shining sweat of my ancestors...=20
to...
to loose my language, to lose my language, to learn the flaming language =
of those dancing around me... to end my long fast.=20
what am i looking for?
for a rave with heart, with PLUR, with people who aren't afraid to dance =
the rhythms of their own heart. i was englightened at harmony a few =
summers back - is that absurd to write? perhaps, but that's what i felt. =
i want to do it again. i want to give and receive. i want to share. i =
want to celebrate. and i don't want to stop for commercial breaks.
can any of you help me?=20
i'm so far away, typing as i am in seoul, but i feel as close as any of =
you are to each other. i feel as though i've returned to my tribe, even =
though most of you probably have no idea who i am.=20
i'm shalom, and i'm back.=20
that's all.=20
i'm borrowing a friend's account, so i won't be able to respond to =
responses promptly, but i will get them, if you send them within a few =
days.=20
thank you, all.
i can't wait until the time that i'm able to dance beside you.
i can't wait, and yet i must.=20
i can't wait, but i will...

shalom
"wisdom tells me i am nothing,
love tells me i am everything,
and between the two, my life flows."
        - swami ?

 Some folks have been criticizing my description of "a little percipitation"...
 
>  Wait, it rained some Larry? at FnF? NO,No I was driving to Pt. Molaite in
> *hail*. But, all of us crazy-ass ravers just kept on going, probaly
> because the music was so good that fateful afternoon/evening.
>                                           Reagan
> 
> On Fri, 15 Nov 1996, Larry Ching wrote:
> > .... 
> >  Many months ago , FnF decided to do an outdoor party at Pt. Molate. 
> > Come the day of the party, the weather reports were very bad, but, with
> > all optimism, Ethan decided to go ahead with it.
> > 
> >  And, yes , it did rain some on us, but not as much as areas north
> > and south of us. Looking to the west, you could see the clouds parting 
> > at Mt. Tamilpias , heading either north or southward, leaving only
> > a little percipitation for the Richmond/Pt. Molate area. As if the weather
> > was giving us a special dispensation!

 Well, I still say that Pt. Molate got less than the rest of the SF Bay
area that day. And, yeah, it was more than "a little" , especially with the
cold later that day.

 My standard of "rain" is conditioned by growing up in Hawaii, where what
we got at Pt. Molate qualifies as "heavy drizzle".

 Have fun and good luck you guys!!!

On Thu, 14 Nov 1996, Leslie Ayres wrote:

[SNIP]

> I happen to love giving gifts, including at Christmas ... whether it costs
> a nickel at a yard sale or $500 at a jeweler, if it's been chosen with
> love, care, thought and individuality, a gift is a tangible way we show
> people that we care about them.
> 
> I remember gifts that I've given, and gifts that I've received, and I
> cherish many of those gifts years later, because they remind me of the
> person who cared enough about me to give it.
>
> Leslie

Right on!  And, you don't have to get gifts for people at Xmastime.  How
many times do you see something and think, "So-and-so would LOVE that!"?
How many Xmases do you end up getting something for that same person just
because you have to?  Well, put the two together! 

I don't even wait for Xmas to give it to them.  My friends all know that I
don't follow the same holiday schedule as everyone else, and most of them
don't, either.  It's totally fun to surprise people with "that perfect
gift."  It's even more of a surprise (and, therefore, more FUN!) if they
aren't expecting a gift.

Who needs the tension of watching someone open a gift on Xmas morning,
knowing that no matter what it is they will say, "Oh, I love it!"?  (To
which you respond with, "I'm really glad.  I like the present that you got,
me, too.  We'll be friends forever!" (Can you detect my antagonism 
toward Disney-style interactions?) ) <grin>

Anyhow, 'nuff on that.

Has anyone gone to the San Francisco Shopping Center on the day after
Thanksgiving?  It's one of my holidays.  I don't ever buy anything, but I
love to go and look at the faces of the people who are following the
routine.  The look like they are working in a morgue.  They are rude to
each other, and seem agitated.  And the best part... There are thousands of
them!  It's so FUN!

Okeedoke!
Have fun!
.:blossom

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sat, 16 Nov 1996 15:06:10 -0800
To: "Ciaran OHara" <ciaran.ohara@CCMAIL.AirTouch.COM>
From: natural@sirius.com (natural)
Subject: SELLING REKKIDS !
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>
>
>     Anyone got any vinyl for sale ?
>

        You betcha!

        I am currently thinning out my collection and have about 800-1000
pieces for sale. Nothing very recent though. Lots of 90-92 breaks and ravey
techno. Lots of '91 rare Italian 'party music' (pianos, breaks, cheesy
vocal samples). Quite a few UK progressive things from 92-93. The odd
british promo/white label and some weird and wacky one offs. There may be
more to come as I haven't finished sorting through the whole collection.
        To make it easier for people to view, they are housed at 678 haight
street (a new CD and vinyl boutique called Faster Bamboo), the # is
415.255.8973, ask for Wade.
        Good Luck

        Jon Williams

Oh my gosh! This sucks! I bought tickects for Famtasia, and I could 
swear that it was Saturday night. I was getting so excited to go and 
then I saw messages saying that they were going to Famtasia and then 
Wrinkle on Saturday. I ran and checked the tickets, they didn't say a 
date, so I cheked all the other messages to find out that I missed it!
Do you know how horrible this is? 
I haven't gone to a rave forever, and I really really needed to go to 
one this weekend, you don't know how bad. Now I don't have enough money 
to go to A wrinkle in time AND I had told my friend it was on Saturday, 
too. So now there goes her money and she's pissed. AHHHHH! 
On top of that my friend hit another car when he was driving mine and 
broke a tail light and put Huge dent in it. 
I really need to go to a rave, I'm going to try to beg it out of my 
mother to send me some.Good luck, it's not likely!
Oh well.
-k

     The last time the Chemical brothers played here (the Trocadero) I had 
     been planning on going for ages. My friend Damien bought the tix a few 
     days b4 the show and gave me mine when we met up in the Mad dog in the 
     fog. I put it in my pocket and found it at work (In Berkeley) the next 
     day.
     
     So...I put it into a drawer in my desk so that it would be safe.
     Friday the day of the show comes around and I'm talking to folks at 
     work about this show I'm going to at the Trocadero.
     
     I get a ride home with a workmate's girlfriend and then the 
     realization hit me like a ton of bricks that said ticket was not on my 
     person but instead tucked away in a drawer in a securely locked 
     building all the way back over the bay bridge.
     
     Doh !

	id AA848203021; Sat, 16 Nov 96 19:42:57 PST
Date: Sat, 16 Nov 96 19:42:57 PST
From: "Ciaran OHara" <ciaran.ohara@CCMAIL.AirTouch.COM>
Message-Id: <9610168482.AA848203021@CCMAIL.AIRTOUCH.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Best of SF (4 Ravers)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     Hello everybody :
     
     I posted this questionnaire a while back with the intention of 
     collecting and posting the results as soon as was possible. For a 
     number of reasons to numerous to mention (i.e. laziness) I have not 
     gathered the info together until now. The replies ranged from the 
     "exxcellent idea"  type to one who basically told me get a life. He 
     subsequently recanted (having seen the error of his ways) and sent his 
     replies to me.
     
     
     I have to say that the amount of replies was not huge. But I've always 
     felt it's quality not quantity that counts. So if any of you feel 
     misrepresented by the results don't blame me, I can only go by those 
     that forwarded their opinions to me.
     
     I received a request from the *alleged* administrator of a French 
     mailing list and record label - F communicatios - asking my permission 
     to translate and use the quesstionnaire in his/her country and of 
     course I agreed.
     
     Special thanks to Ozymandias G. Desiderata, Andre Lucerno and David 
     Lowe for their detailed replies.
     
     If you feel that your "best of.." was not represented E-mail me for 
     the questionnaire.
     
     Peace,
     
     
     Ciaran O'
     
     
     
     
     1.Anyone bought any good cd compilations lately (all genres)? 
     
     
     loop Records compilation.
     "Subtropic" album by Homebrew, Reflective records
     Trip hop test Part 2
     V/A - Platinum Breakz (Metalheadz) -- jungle V/A - Tech Steppin' 
     (Emotif) -- darkstep jungle
     V/A - Virus Volume 2 (ACV / HotTrax) -- dark housy techno V/A - 
     Synewave New York (Kickin' / Synewave) -- hard techno
     
     2.What's on your playlists ?
     
     Hybrid/Loop Missile Lable.
     Rollerskate Skinny - Horsedrawn Wishes (Warner Bros) -- psychotic pop 
     Catherine Wheel - Like Cats and Dogs (Mercury) -- power pop 
     Muslimgauze - Veiled Sisters (Soleilmoon) -- mysterious ambient
     Leo Anibaldi - Void (RePHLeX) -- darqambient
     Robert Armani - Spectacular (ACV) -- hard techno / hard house DJ 
     Sprout - Freq of Nature (Sub Freq) -- dark techno
     The Cardigans - First Band on the Moon (Mercury) -- fluffy pop 4D - 
     Hidden (Labworks) -- dark gritty acidcore
     Kinesthesia - Empathy Box Remixes (RePHLeX) -- weird electro 
     everything by Underworld
     
     3.Any good RR books/literature that you feel is too good to keep to 
     coh> yourself ? Inquiring minds (i.e. me) want to know.
     
     The Acid House, Ecstacy, Mirabou stork nightmares, Trainspotting by 
     Irving Welsh
     Orion, by Masamune Shirow (absolutely beautiful Japanese comic)
     The Temporary Autonomous zone by Hakim Bey.
     
     
     4.Best free dance magazine ?
     
     XLR8R
     Resonance (out of Washington) OR
     
     5.Best commercial dance magazine (domestic) ?
     
     URB
     
     6.Best commercial dance magazine (imported) ?
     
     DJ (UK)
     Muzik (UK)
     The Wire 
     Jockey Slut 
     Generator
     
     7.What are your favorite clothes stores ?
     
     Thrift stores.
     
     8.What are your fav music stores ?
     
     SF: Soundworks, Tweekin, BPM and Aquarius Records (music w/ guitars) 
     
     Berkeley: Rasputin's, Amoeba, and Mod Lang
     
     9.Best place for a beer (and dance music) ?
     
     MAD, The Top
     
     10.Best place to go after the party's ended ? who said "home" ? 
     
     The ananimous answer seems to be Home to sleep or with warm, fuzzy 
     people to hug, sleep or  shower with...
     
     11.Best place for used dance records/cds ?
     
     Open Mind Records on Divisadero
     Streetlight, 
     Reckless records on Haight 
     
     12.Best radio station for house/techno/dub/trance ?
     
     KUSF, KCRW
     
     13.Best natural high ?
     
     Love. (Need anymore be said ?)
     
     Dancing for 8 hours straight to really good music, preferably while 
     wearing a shit-eating grin. It helps if all of my friends are there, 
     too. A close second is _spinning_ for eight hours in front of my 
     friends while wearing a shit-eating grin.
     
     Hugs/kisses

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Nov 16 21:21:41 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id VAA10972; Sat, 16 Nov 1996 21:21:41 -0800 (PST)
Received: from netcom16.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id VAA10965; Sat, 16 Nov 1996 21:21:37 -0800 (PST)
Received: from localhost (mayer@localhost) by netcom16.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id VAA29980; Sat, 16 Nov 1996 21:21:32 -0800
Message-Id: <199611170521.VAA29980@netcom16.netcom.com>
To: "jaw's" <jen@hotwired.com>
Cc: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>, geoffw@v-site.net,
        jack@twaxx.com
Subject: Re: You show me your facts, i'll call them irrelevant (nrr) 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Fri, 15 Nov 96 20:12:13 PST."
             <v03007826aeb2e910c9f1@[204.62.132.173]> 
Date: Sat, 16 Nov 96 21:21:27 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>the problem of private ownership of property is directly related to the
>excessive population of the human species.  there are too many humans on
>this planet and that is why we can no longer freely forage for food and
>neither can the other animals with which we share this planet (being
>confined to a park hardly counts as free) (and animals that violate the
>park bounds are often killed, like the mountain lion in marin last month).
>by the way, over-grazing is caused when the animal population becomes too
>large for it's territory which is the case with humans and is why some
>people should die of starvation. the reason you never hear of a "save the
>humans" campaign is because we are doing fine, unfortuneately we are
>killing pretty much everything else living on this planet in the process.
>when i think of what we've done to this planet i'm ashamed to be human.

I think the system would like you to believe that overpopulation is the
problem, and that the current way of doing things is "a natural means
by which organizations/people can increase their efficiency by 
concentrating on their specialties, thereby capturing economies of
scope and scale". Unfortunately, in all this focus on efficiency and
economy, we are also setting up a system which artificially inflates
the cost and attainability of "natural resources" by hoarding them, by
creating artificial demand for them, and then limiting those that can
attain them to those that have money or excesses of other tradeable
hoarded resources.

	As a side-effect of this system, we regularly have farms that
	THROW AWAY milk, cheese, grains, and other foodstuffs simply
	because giving it  away to those in need would actually
	decrease the artificially inflated costs at which these goods
	are sold. Certainly, part of this excess food is given to
	foreign countries as foreign aid, but only if the agribusiness
	can sell their excess to the government (aka US taxpayer
	subsidies of US mega-agribusinesses). The food we produce and
	throw away could be used to feed a majority of the hungry
	people on earth, if it weren't for agribusinesses bottom lines
	(and the cost of transportation). There is enough for
	everybody, you are believing in their myth to think that in
	order for you to be happy/fed/housed, someone else needs to be
	homeless and starving.

	As a side effect of this system, restaurants in the USA
	regularly THROW AWAY enough food to to easily feed all the
	homeless people on the streets.

	As a side effect of this system, people can actually LIVE
	by scavenging the WASTEPRODUCTS of our consumer society
	(cf, dump-scavenger societies in India, Brazil, etc).

So no, I totally and completely disagree that "world hunger" and
"homelessness" are a result of overpopulation. I reject your implicit
beliefs that the human race must suffer their plight because they've
lost some "survival of the fittest" race. Their plight stems 100
percent from greed and hoarding of natural resources, which is a
pollution upon the natural order of things. Please note that the only
reason why i'm bringing "natural" up is because you bring up the
concept of starvation as natural, while not noting that we've set up a
completely unnatural system and are then expecting to use social
darwinism as an "out" to expliciate the suffering we've created as
"natural").

Finally, although I believe overpopulation *IS* a problem, you'll note
that none of the power structures that are promoting hoarding and greed
are doing a single thing to diminish overpopulation. The Catholic
Church still decrees that birth control and abortion is a sin;
Christian groups pressure governments and voters  around the world to
not promote birth control in public schools; they pressure mothers
seeking abortions to carry their babies to term (but never actually
provide the full financial/educational support for these unwanted
babies). And they apply vicious political opposition against
organizations that promote population control and sustainable growth.
(It is "natural" for a population to seek means to control it's growth
-- why then are we so hell-bent on overpopulating the planet, and why
are our governments sponsoring/protecting those that seek to hinder
population control?).

The reason for all of the above is simple -- it's the same reasoning
that goes into the hoarding mentality that creates value/wealth by
creating artificial defecits. By creating excess humans that cannot
adequately feed/sustain/educate themselves, you've automatically
created a "slave" class that you can abuse, exploit, and underpay as
subsistance workers. After all, wealth cannot be created "in a vacuum"
-- you have to have poor people to  compare your riches to, and you
have to have a desparate class of people working for the rich at
inequitable wages in order for those at the top to be able to
accumulate more than their fair share of wealth. (and by "slave" --
note that we've managed to finesse those old-fashioned shackles and
leg-irons -- it's been conveniently replaced by "clean" shackles in the
form  of $$$, loans, rent, health-insurance-payments, auto-insurance
payments, as well as government mandated IRS, child-support, and 
alimony payments (of course, you get to see the real shackles if you
happen to disobey da massa on the latter)).

Me? I'm just another house-nigga workin' on the plantation... But don't
worry about me so are you!

--------------------
At 10:33 AM -0800 11/13/96, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
>>>there is no justification for letting people starve in the street. i don't
>>>care how much of a slacker someone is, how uneducated they may be... being
>>>penniless when there are people rolling in money on the other side of town
>>>is a misery no one should have to endure.
>>
>>is there any justification for allowing an animal to starve in the forest?
>>or is it a part of a natural evolutionary cycle in which some beings go
>>hungry and others find food?
>
>Last I checked, the hungry animal could freely forage for food, freely
>cross any land in order to get food, and not risk arrest for
>trespassing or theft. Only a sick/injured animal, or a whole population
>facing overgrazing/drought/ecological disaster would find itself
>"starving in the forest"....
>
>Even when you take animal territoriality into account, most animals
>driven out of a territory can find somewhere to go. Unfortunately for
>humans, this is not the case. Fact is "we" treat wild animals better
>than a large percentage of the underclass -- where are our "wild human
>sanctuaries" ; how come you never hear of a "save the humans" campaign?
>
>Unfortunately, given that every square inch of land is owned by
>somebody, fenced by somebody, and we have police/legal structures that
>strongly enforce these private property rights, one ends up with
>starving people on the street. They have nowhere else to go, and no
>means by which to sustain themselves. If these people had a place to
>rest their heads, soil to grow their food or graze their animals, I
>very much doubt they'd be starving in the street.
>
>So the better question to ask is where does privatized land, private
>property, and a system that prevents people from being able to sustain
>themselves unless they're willing to rent out their bodies as
>slave-labor in order to obtain food/lodging -- where the hell does that
>fit into your "natural evolutionary cycle"??
>
>I would love to see what happens to people spouting such economic
>darwinism crap if they actually existed in nature, wild, and without
>the police/state there to enforce their hoarding of property and means
>of sustenance. If this were a "natural" system, I could just get myself
>a big gun/knife/club, barge onto your property, and claim it for
>myself. And unless you could better defend yourself, you'd either find
>yourself dead or you'd have to retreat.
>
>In fact, I'd venture to say that we've badly disrupted the natural
>evolutionary cycle through our ability to unfairly enforce the hoarding
>of private property. I find it rare that those that actually have the
>state protecting their property holdings are actually more fit than
>those that are enslaved to work on that property in exchange for their
>rights to exist and thrive on said "private" property.

--------------------

Let's talk rain - let's talk the night of Connection II, Berkeley Marina,
the rain starting around 5am and continuing until the end, coming down
heavy enough that Moonpup was showing folks how the needle of the record
player left waves on the standing water on the records as they played...
and a turntable-denching failure in the tarps is recorded lovingly on
the tapes of the party, too.

I think you all will enjoy this... 

>Perhaps difficult enough for adults to define, this question received
>some interesting responses from those of a younger generation...
>
>What Exactly Is Marriage??
>-  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -
>
>"Marriage is when you get to keep your girl and don't have to give
>her back to her parents"
>         -Eric, AGE 6
>
>"When somebody's been dating for a while, the boy might propose to
>the girl. He says to her, 'I'll take you for a whole life, or at
>least until we have kids and get divorced, but you got to do one
>particular thing for me.'  Then she says yes, but she's wondering
>what the thing is and whether it's naughty or not. She can't wait to
>find out."
>         -Anita, AGE 9
>
>How Does a Person Decide Whom to marry??
>-  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -
>
>"You flip a nickel, and heads means you stay with him and tails means
>you try the next one."
>         -Kelly, AGE 9
>
>"My mother says to look for a man who is kind....That's what I'll
>do....I'll find somebody who's kinda tall and handsome."
>         -Carolyn, AGE 8
>
>Concerning the Proper Age to Get Married.
>-  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -
>
>"Eighty-four Because at that age, you don't have to work anymore,
>and you can spend all your time loving each other in your bedroom."
>         -Carolyn, AGE 8
>
>"Once I'm done with kindergarten, I'm going to find me a wife"
>         -Bert, AGE 5

>
>"They were at a dance party at a friend's house. Then they went for a
>drive, but their car broke down...It was a good thing, because it
>gave them a chance to  find out about their values."
>         -Lottie, AGE 9
>
>"My father was doing some strange chores for my mother.  They won't
>tell me what kind."
>         -Jeremy, AGE 8
>
>What Do Most People Do on a Date??

>

>gets them interested enough to go for a second date."
>         -Martin, AGE 10
>
>"Many daters just eat pork chops and french fries and talk about
>love."
>         -Craig, AGE 9
>
>When Is It Okay to Kiss Someone??
>-  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -  -
>
>"You should never kiss a girl unless you have enough bucks to buy her a
>ring and her own VCR, 'cause  she'll want to have videos of the
>wedding."
>         -Allan, AGE 10
>
>"Never kiss in front of other people. It's a big embarrassing thing
>if anybody sees you....If nobody sees you, I might be willing to try
>it with a handsome boy, but just for a few hours."
>         -Kally, AGE 9
>
>The Great Debate: Is It Better to Be Single or Married??

>         -Anita, AGE 9

>don't need that kind of trouble."
>         -Will, AGE 7

From: pauly <pauly@x-radio.com>
Subject: (BSP) x-radio
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings:

We have just finished adding another enhancement to x-radio.  Now,
visitors to the site can generate a playlist based on a particular music
genre.  The playlist will consist of (somewhat) random tracks taken from all
the titles we have in that genre.

In addition, a single RealAudio metafile is created for the entire playlist,
which means that listeners will not have to keep returning to the  site to
select the next track in the list.  Instead, all the tracks will play
through sequentially.  Listeners can use their RealAudio players to move
forwards and backwards through the playlist (try pressing PgUp and PgDn in
the RealAudio player).

Now it's easier than ever to tune in and hear the latest in underground music!

peace, love, unity, respect
pauly


p.s. this was a recommendation from one of our visitors!  please continue
making great suggestions like this one!
_____________________________________________________ x-radio _____
_______ http://www.x-radio.com/x-radio/ ___________________________

wow what a GREAT weekend!
	I started out at Famtasia where I met so many beautiful people and 
heard some equally beautiful music! the party was great, even though the 
floor got a little muddy, it was ignorable compared to the wonderful 
time my friends and i had! Jonathan's set was great, kept me on my feet 
even though I'm getting over (another?) cold. the positive attitude i 
had was shared by EVERYONE to an ultimate degree (or so it seemed). :> 
this party had great potential, and it SOARED! seeing Eric walking 
around waving and smiling at everyone never ceased to make me smile :>
	I missed the BBQ, somehow I ended up rideless, but I heard it went 
off.. a little rain never hurt anyone, right? then, we went to get 
tickets for Wrinkle in Time, which was sold out by then (we arrived 
LATE), but nevertheless we hopped right back into the car and drove to 
150 folsom and joined the junglists at rhythm and sound. the music was 
loud, hectic, and fucking great. curious's set was a little too trancey 
at times for my mood, but everyone else seemed to LOVE it, and who am I 
to complain? ;> i'm glad we ended up there, jungle never ceases to make 
my body move and set my mind free.I ran into a few people who had been 
raving since Famtasia (hell yea!) we left early, exhausted and 
exhilirated of the great weekend we had. Doesn't rain feel FANTASTIC 
after a night of dancing? 
	I met a # of SFravers, it's good to finally put a face to the name :> 
*waves* ad *smiles* to Eric, Mike, Micron, Leslie, and everyone else out 
there. and MAJOR props to all of you who actually stayed up and did 
Famtasia, BBQ & Beats, and Wrinkle In Time/Rhythm and Sound. Hope you're 
all asleep right now, catching up so you don't get sick! :>
I guess next on the list of things to do for me would be Audio Impact.. 
Take care !
Lara
-- 
              (sk3)
      [ J U N G L I S T ]
. . . wishing on a star . . .

Dear SFRavefriends,

	This is not quite a timely follow-up, I meant to send it off
earlier, but it got shunted into my "postponed messages" file and
overlooked...

My computer tells me that on Thu, 7 Nov 1996, leftjab shared (in part):

> even with respect to income, the u.s. now has the most uneven income
> distribution amongst the richest industrialized nations (this wasn't the
> case 20 years ago), and the highest level of child poverty.  

	This is somewhat dubious, since the government keeps redefining
the poverty level.  Also the way it is currently calculated, they do not
take into account non-monetary assistance such as food stamps, public
housing, etc.
	It is clear that many people are still poor however, including
children, and in my view it is absolutely criminal that the government be
taking any money from them *at all*, in the form of sales tax, social
security, or any other form of witholding.  When you're trying to get by,
you need every dollar.
	Instead of worrying about raising taxes on the rich, let's lower
taxes on the poor and middle class where it will do some good.  Or can't
the government get by on less than $1 trillion a year?

Much love,
				<<< Starchild >>>

Received: from [205.231.222.64] (vbarr.isinc.insignia.com) by mvgate.isinc.insignia.com (5.65c8/UK-2.1.ISL) with SMTP
	id AA29390; Mon, 18 Nov 1996 06:29:23 -0800
X-Sender: knucklehead@mail.domain.net
Message-Id: <v02130502aeb5adba2c77@[205.231.222.64]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: knucklehead@club.net (knucklehead)
Subject: A Drenched Thank you
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, I really don't know what to say! I let better judgement get clouded.
O'well, After we got the circus tent up the party went off, there were 200
people there having a blast. It my have rained but the giant circus tent
was big enough for the 200 people that was there and it was awesome. Then I
woke up from slipping in the mud and hitting my head on a tree and go,
"Damn where did the tent go!", Where did all those people go"  And reality
set in.


I just want to thank those hardcore people out there that came out to
B&BIII. I know I shouldn't of had it, but if the people that did showed had
an ounce of fun, then I'm happy. I also want to thank the DJs that ventured
out there and spun. All of you did a GREAT job. Alex, Thanks for dealing
with your time slot. Dan(Micron) Thanks for coming out and spinning. Loved
your set. This DJ from Switzerland came and spun for us, Dj Ramtin or
something like that. BioJeff for showing up and giving us another wonderful
set.

And to Noah Ruiz, the man that stuck by me all day and helped out with
everything as well as Chris and James that came with him. You didn't only
have a great set, but you were alot of help too. I think I'll be going out
in the SBay alittle more if you spin out here. I loved your set.

I at least hope the people that did come had an ok time. I want to thanks
all the SFRavers that helped out and came out to this wet and wild BBQ.

I do promise that the next BBQ & BEATS will go off and there WILL be a
clear sky and warm weather.

Thanks,

Tim (knucklehead)


P.S. Terry, it takes 7 ravers to put up a tarp, and only 3 to setup sound
in less then half the time it took to set up the tarp. That was tooooo
funny. I swear I'm going to put that together and mark every single pole.

Good Morning Everyone!!!!!! =)

Well, what a weekend!  I must say I had my share of water this weekend! =)

Tim, thankyou for a good time and all the food you provided.
We all did the best we could under the conditions.  I met new friends
(alex,terry,micron,leslie,branka,Ethan,all the people there tring to put up
the tarp, I forgot so many names, sorry!)  I had a blast and would do it
again in a heart beat!

While I was spinning I was looking at the rain and the bridge and water and
was just thinking how wonderful this all was, and it made me so happy no
matter the mud and rain.  I had a great time setting up, and the tearing
down was a bit messy, but James, Tim, Chris and I were all pretty happy
when it was all packed!=)

Alex,Micron and Biojeff were great!  You guys played some killer tunes!!! =)

Thanks Ethan for the sound system!  It sounded great!

To all the people whoes names I forgot I'm sorry!  But thankyou for coming
up and saying hello!

Everybody have a good day!

Noah Ruiz =)

p.s. How many ravers does it take to put up a tarp????? =)

Just have to say the rave scene in Santa Barbara is like a child in a
storm - trying to run out into the rain is difficult in this little
newly wed, nearly dead paradise.  Thanks to Mo & Sam of SOMA and others,
the kids are splashing in the puddles - smiles to them for gettin' it
goin'.

But damn if I can't wait to get outa'her and dance exxxstatically in the
rain of the SF scene.  Left Chi-house scene four years ago and my body
aches to move. 

Lookin' future wise to SF.

see the stone float.

seestone

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Nov 18 11:02:08 1996

Message-Id: <2.2.32.19961118184352.0068a320@ix.netcom.com>
X-Sender: ascend@ix.netcom.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 2.2 (32)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 1996 10:43:52 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Harmony!!! <ascend@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: "Harmony's Comeback!?!?!?"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello again,

        Well, after reading this thread, I figured I should respond...

        Over three years ago, Harmony was thought of by a few certain
people. Over the years, different people have joined our family to help, as
well as left us. This includes some of the main organizers of the "Harmony"
parties. I am the only organizer in the collective who has consistantly been
there and helped with every Party since the beginning. (except my B-Day ;) I
have worked closly with several different people organizing the parties we
have done, but when we do an "Anniversary Party," it's the only party out of
the whole year that the original organizers are all working together. This
was always something special to us, and that is what makes the anniversary
parties so interesting. There are a lot more people involved with a lot more
ideas and creativity, so we can make them a lot bigger.

        But, as we all grow up, some of us gain responcibilities and move on
to do different things. The original "Harmony Crew" is really not coming out
anymore, nor are some of them putting in the time and energy it takes to put
on a "Harmony" size event. We also feel that it is kinda funky to throw an
anniversary party for a collective like Harmony, when half the people in the
collective won't be there. It's kinda like a family reunion, with only half
of the family wanting to go. Our goal in Harmony was to put on events that
we would want to go to, and that we would be able to produce... together.
But as it seems right now it's getting harder and harder to get everyone
together. There are many reasons for this. As I said above, some of them
(organizers) are gaining responcibilities in their lives that take up their
time, some don't like the direction that Harmony Productions has gone, and
some are just plain and simple burnt out. These are all very valid reasons.
So it was voted on, and decided that the 3 year anniversary party would be
the last "Harmony" party. (maybe forever, maybe not, we'll see what road
life leads us down) 

        Now as far as this "comeback." Like Pengo said, "Don't call it a
comeback, we been here for years!" I fully intend on throwing all the
parties I can for all of you ravers. It's what drives me right now.
Although, it might not look like it, I do have a lot of fun promoting our
parties. Harmony parties are a special place for us. We can all come in good
spirits and party our asses off together. Celebrating the peace, love,
positivity, and most of all the harmony in our lives! So, now I am now
working with one of the best crews I think Harmony Productions has ever had,
and I don't see how we can stop now! (I wish I could name all of you, as you
know there are too many of you guys! But I love you anyways!) The parties to
look for from us are, (as most of you know) "Beautiful People", "Hunny", "A
Wrinkle in Time", "Free Harmony on the Beach", and the newest one "Freaky
People" (a dress-up Beautiful People party). There is much more to come in
the future from Harmony Productions, but as far as the original "Harmony",
it's debatable...

        I hope this clears some of the confusion... Smile!

Peace, love and harmony to all!!!

Greg =)

>Wrinkle in Time", "Free Harmony on the Beach", and the newest one "Freaky
>People" (a dress-up Beautiful People party). There is much more to come in
>the future from Harmony Productions, but as far as the original "Harmony",
>it's debatable...
>

>Date: Mon, 18 Nov 1996 10:43:52 -0800
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
>From: Harmony!!! <ascend@ix.netcom.com>
>Subject: "Harmony's Comeback!?!?!?"
>Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
>Precedence: bulk
>
>Hello again,
>
>        Well, after reading this thread, I figured I should respond...
>
>        Over three years ago, Harmony was thought of by a few certain
>people. Over the years, different people have joined our family to help, as
>well as left us. This includes some of the main organizers of the "Harmony"
>parties. I am the only organizer in the collective who has consistantly been
>there and helped with every Party since the beginning. (except my B-Day ;) I
>have worked closly with several different people organizing the parties we
>have done, but when we do an "Anniversary Party," it's the only party out of
>the whole year that the original organizers are all working together. This
>was always something special to us, and that is what makes the anniversary
>parties so interesting. There are a lot more people involved with a lot more
>ideas and creativity, so we can make them a lot bigger.
>
>        But, as we all grow up, some of us gain responcibilities and move on
>to do different things. The original "Harmony Crew" is really not coming out
>anymore, nor are some of them putting in the time and energy it takes to put
>on a "Harmony" size event. We also feel that it is kinda funky to throw an
>anniversary party for a collective like Harmony, when half the people in the
>collective won't be there. It's kinda like a family reunion, with only half
>of the family wanting to go. Our goal in Harmony was to put on events that
>we would want to go to, and that we would be able to produce... together.
>But as it seems right now it's getting harder and harder to get everyone
>together. There are many reasons for this. As I said above, some of them
>(organizers) are gaining responcibilities in their lives that take up their
>time, some don't like the direction that Harmony Productions has gone, and
>some are just plain and simple burnt out. These are all very valid reasons.
>So it was voted on, and decided that the 3 year anniversary party would be
>the last "Harmony" party. (maybe forever, maybe not, we'll see what road
>life leads us down) 
>
>        Now as far as this "comeback." Like Pengo said, "Don't call it a
>comeback, we been here for years!" I fully intend on throwing all the
>parties I can for all of you ravers. It's what drives me right now.
>Although, it might not look like it, I do have a lot of fun promoting our
>parties. Harmony parties are a special place for us. We can all come in good
>spirits and party our asses off together. Celebrating the peace, love,
>positivity, and most of all the harmony in our lives! So, now I am now
>working with one of the best crews I think Harmony Productions has ever had,
>and I don't see how we can stop now! (I wish I could name all of you, as you
>know there are too many of you guys! But I love you anyways!) The parties to
>look for from us are, (as most of you know) "Beautiful People", "Hunny", "A
>Wrinkle in Time", "Free Harmony on the Beach", and the newest one "Freaky
>People" (a dress-up Beautiful People party). There is much more to come in
>the future from Harmony Productions, but as far as the original "Harmony",
>it's debatable...
>
>        I hope this clears some of the confusion... Smile!
>
>Peace, love and harmony to all!!!
>
>Greg =)
>
>
>
Peace, love and harmony to all!!!

Greg =)

First, I am DYING to hear more about Wrinkle in Time.  Will someone PLEASE
post a descriptive review to satiate my curiousity?!!  I had planned on
going up until about 3 pm on Saturday when I made a change of plans.  Did
the virtual reality machine go off?  How were the three different rooms?
I couldn't be there, but I'm dying to hear about it.

Second, I just caught a news report about cops being able to search your
car for drugs.  The State Supreme Court or a State Judge (wasn't clear on
this) ruled that when the police stop you for whatever they may ask you if
they can search your car.  You can *voluntarily* allow this, but they
*cannot* make you.  However, they *do not* have to tell you you are free
to go.  So, you may not actually know you don't have to let them search
your car.  Supposedly, this is to allow you to *voluntarily* choose to let
them search.  I didn't catch the whole story, so if anyone knows anything
further, please elaborate.

-KaySEE


p.s.  I had a great weekend, went to a bar and was reminded just how warm
raves can be.  Man, that will teach me for *even* thinking raves have
attitude.  Just goes to show you how you can take things for granted.
People can't even try to be friendly unless they are picking up on you.
There's nothing like a reality check to make you appreciate something all
the more!! 

There was this moment when the dj put on some songs (was a
hip-hop bar) that everyone loved and started screaming about.  There was
this psuedo-semlance of a *slight* vibe.  And I grabbed my friends, who
were really enjoying this part, and told thim that this is nothing
compared to the best raves and maybe even the worst.  I was hoping
they'd actually listen to me and I could get them to go more frequently.
Yeah, right! :)

and live life.  My father wants to thank you all for supporting me, and
when he gets better I'm
going to take him to an event and have you all meet him.  I think he would
like that!  Would you all like to meet him?  He started crying when I told
him about all your support and how you all asked about him on Saturday!

I can't express how I feel right now!  I want to cry from enjoyment and
stress.  I thought that this whole situation would cramp my style spinning
at BBQ & BEATS, but I used it to my advantage.  That set I did out there in
the rain is dedicated to my father and my family.  I transferred all that
energy towards my set.  I hope you all enjoyed it!

Once again thank you all for your support!  After meeting all of you at BBQ
and Beats I feel much closer to you all.  There is one person I would like
to give a phat thank you to, and thats Branka!!!!  Thank you so much!  =)

In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSI.3.95.961118112702.27128A-100000@value.net> from "KaySEE" at Nov 18, 96 11:46:40 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Precedence: bulk


A Wrinkle in Time was fun.  At the studio, they had the same room they
usually use for dancing decorated with lotsa blacklight friendly Winnie
the Pooh and Tigger posters.  The music had a lot of energy and the whole
time I was there the dance room was a bouncing frenzy.  I especially like
the lighting in this room.  Usually I don't notice lighting effects too 
much, but in this room whoever was controlling the lights was really keeping
it interesting.  They had 3 smaller intellabeam above the dj that they
strobed onto the crowd.  Some people may have found it irritating, but
personally, I thought it was really cool.  The effect was totally hypmotizing.
Then they would stop those lights and flood the room in blacklight for
awhile.  Then they would scan their other intellabeams...  Basically,
a whole lot of eye candy.

The regular chill room was closed off and they had the other 3rd room
setup for Stella Luna, Ran's gear and Rick&co's ambient setup.  I like
these chill rooms where they pretty much just leave things open for
ravers to display their talants.  

The crowd was on the younger side, but these are definatly kids who "get
it" and extend great energy and vibes.  There is just no way you could
get the sort of energy that was brewing in the dance room without the
18-and-younger ravers.  Several of my 20-something friends who were there
commented about the giggly, "I'm on e are you let me tell you all about
because I'm *so cool*" scene... no big deal... those kids all seemed to
stay in big groups so you could avoid them if you wanted to.  I met
some kids who were truly beatiful and that seemed to offset the other
vibes.  

I think a lot of my 20-something friends wonder if these kids get raving,
or if they are just there to get trashed on drugs.  Well, there is definatly
a fine line between the two!  All I can say is this, the recreational
rave drug experience is really something that can overshadow anything else
at a party, the music, the vibe, ect.  With new people coming into the
scene all the time, you can't expect young people to immediatly identify
with the spirituality of dancing and music AND the drug experience all at
once.  Give them time... these drugs do, in fact, become boring after awhile
and those who really love the experience will strive to achieve it in
other ways besides drugs exclusively.

Anyway, I really hope this event raised some money for omar.  I am sure
the vibe alone was healthy for him, but some material compensation is always
good too.

-troy

ps:  Any of you on socal-ravers reading about their Elevation II party this
weekend?  It seems that insanely great parties are becoming the norm
all over california... hooray for net.ravers!

On Mon, 18 Nov 1996, KaySEE wrote:

> First, I am DYING to hear more about Wrinkle in Time.  Will someone PLEASE
> post a descriptive review to satiate my curiousity?!!  

ok...ok here goes...the party was incredible, It was so great to get there
early help set up and see the whole thing come together...before I knew
it...five minutes till lights out!...holy lights out batmen! how did that
happen so fast...there were two rooms, the main room and the chill room,
the main room was set up spectacular...highlights are the "pyramid from
hell" black light set up, and the manequin with butterfly wings and a
disco ball spinning in her hands, I actually spent very little tim ein the
dance room this time, usually this is the ONLY place Iam at...dancing my
booty off...but this time...not sure why...maybe the mushies had something
to do with the fact that I spent most of my time int the chill room going
woooaoaaa!!
	Speaking of the chill room...DAMN!!!! that room was SET UP!!! I
cant even begin to give it justice with words...
the sights: on one whole wall one BIG wall was divided in half on one half
there was a HUGE projection of the new 64 bit nintendo with super mario
brothers...it was RAD!!!! you could go over and play on the other side of
the room and it was projected onto this huge screen. Then the other half
of the wall was a normal projection which played various animantions
throughout the night. The entire space was covered with harmony flowers
and fuzzy trees and cool glowing banners...and the black
lights...damn...there were alot!
	the sounds: As I made my way into the chill room once it had got
going...I was initially going to get some water before havoc set loose in
my mind...thinking to myself as Im on the dance floor...tony...you had
better get some water soon, cuz tyour not gonna wanna deal with it very
shortly! So im ...working... my way to the water fountain and somehow
ended up in the chill room loolking for a quiet corner FAST! and i hear
this crazy tribal deumming with guitars and stuff...I cant quite describe
it but it was very powerful, I think...(this could be distorted!) what I
saw was this guy with big sticks and about 3 or 4 bongo drums BANGING the
crap out of them! WOW!!! thump thudda thumpthump thudda thu thuda thu
thudda thu thump THUMP...things get kinda fuzzy after this, I was goin
hella deep...C-labs  played some incredible soothing sounds for my tender
mind, and pengo let me make play his VR game...which I finally got the
hang of...that thing is really cool!
	Well, that is my attempt at a verbal description of a beautiful
evening...I hope it helps! love to ya's

tony rose...:P


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Nov 18 13:41:50 1996

Received: from Feynman.tenetwork.com (feynman.tenetwork.com [10.10.2.99]) by yam.tenetwork.com (8.7.6/8.7.2) with SMTP id NAA12576 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 18 Nov 1996 13:35:16 -0800 (PST)
