Date: Mon, 18 Nov 1996 14:43:13 -0800
From: Pengo <Pengo@ten.net>
Reply-To: Pengo@ten.net
Organization: Pengo Productions
X-Mailer: Mozilla 3.0 (Win95; I)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: How the Virtual Reality went...
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I was really afraid that things would go wrong with the Virtual Reality
Machine at "Wrinkle in Time". Silly me! It was a totaly awsome
expierence!! Not only for the people that used it but for me, it was an
amazingly educational expierence!!!

Early on during the party, I had 'Descent', which is a neat looking but
complex flying game. Descent was cool but because of it's complexity, it
was difficult to aproach for people. Then I put on a much simpler game
called 'Ascent', that was nothing more than the player jumping from rock
to rock over a river (lava?). This game however totaly changed the was
people used the VR machine!! Instead of just one person using it,
someone would use the helmet to look around while another person
'jumped' for them. Then people started passing it between them,
teaching  each other how to play and expierencing the "inner-world" more
as a group!! Ascent was also very cool after the whole house was high,
because myself or someone else would be able to move the person around
in the VR world while they just sat back and tripped out!

We really were fortualte to have a VR machine there at all, becuase mine
decited not to work on Saturday (doh!). But fortunatly, I was able to
barrow a friends. I still want to bring my original system to a party
because it does offer a much better experience. What I *really* hope to
do it bring 2 or more VR machines and have people interact within the VR
world!!! (Food for thought: This doesn't necessarily have to be at the
same party! Hmmmm...)

One final note: For thoes of you that really had a blast with it, send a
quick 'Thank You' note to my friend who let us use it. His email is
jeffk@tenetwork.com (And if it made your acid trip peak, thats cool but
leave that out of the letter ;)) Let's hope he lets me barrow it
again!!Thanks to thoes of you (you know who you are!) who helped me out
Sat night!! It was a blast!!!

-=Pengo=-
Blake "Pengo" Merriam
TOTAL ENTERTAINMENT NETWORK
www.ten.net

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Nov 18 13:59:15 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id NAA01115; Mon, 18 Nov 1996 13:59:15 -0800 (PST)
Received: from netcom17.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id NAA01105; Mon, 18 Nov 1996 13:59:10 -0800 (PST)
Received: (from simitzis@localhost) by netcom17.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id NAA24870; Mon, 18 Nov 1996 13:59:08 -0800
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 1996 13:59:08 -0800
Message-Id: <199611182159.NAA24870@netcom17.netcom.com>
From: Grumpy the Raver <simitzis@netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Wrinkle in Time - a cure for rave burnout
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Wrinkle in Time was the beginning of something different. 

I felt not so much that I was at a "rave", but more of an underground
festival of art, sound, music, and technology. Never before have I
danced to trip-hop above a virtual reality lava pit. Or watched a
party get propagated on the Internet. Or feared the "little green men"
as Stella Luna jammed in front of Mario.

I spent a serious amount of time in the ambient room, where I finally
had a chance to hear the often talked about Stella Luna (that I missed
at the Harmony 3-year). Although I'm not a big fan of the guitar and
music that features guitar, they were doing something that was far
beyond being a "rock band". So ambient sounding, that sometimes I
thought I was hearing synthesized music.

Consciousness Lab came on afterwards, and played some really nice
ambient/IDM style music. As always, I look forward to seeing techno
being produced live; there's not enough live techno acts at parties.
Later on, some down-tempo trip-hop type sounds were spun, though a
couple of jungle tracks were mixed in. It was sort of strange hearing
jungle played quietly on a sound system, but whatever! :)

I didn't spend enough time in the the main room to hear anyone's set
straight through, but it sounded like Minor Minor was kicking ass as
always. And Trent was spinning some great sounds. Unfortunately,
though I was too occupied to hear the rest of the main room, which was
probably just as well (it was about a million degrees in there!).

Visually, the party was much different than the last few Harmony
parties I had been to, probably due to new props and banners (which
were very well done) and other things like projection screens with
computer graphics and video games (!).

I'm just really happy that there are groups like Harmony that are
doing something interesting with their parties. There have been enough
warehouse drugfests over the years; now it's the time to do something
artistic and creative with the scene. As always, thanks again to all of
the people involved with Harmony for their energy and for helping to
put together something that means so much to so many people.

Steve

--
Steve Simitzis | simitzis@netcom.com saturn5@cyborganic.net | "Hup!" - R. Crumb

This weekend while I was at my dads house and listening to the radio, something 
I haven't been doing very often, live 105 played an orbital song.  I was totally 
surprised and am not sure if live 105 playing orbital is a good thing or a bad 
thing.  As my dad was dancing around the room to it I started thinking it was 
good that orbital was getting the exposure I believe they deserve but also 
thought it was a crime they were being given exposure on such a poseur station 
as live 105.  Not to say that all live 105 listeners are poseurs because I know 
when I lived in the East Bay it was the only halfway decent radio station I 
could get, and I am not a poseur, but I don't beleive the station plays music 
just because they like but of course because they can possibly get some new 
listeners and money.  NOw I lost the point I was trying to make, but I just 
wanted to mention the orbital situation because it just makes me confused as to 
why a radio station such as live 105 would play a song totally out of its 
listeners main interests such as orbital or underworld.  Eagerly awaiting 
comment.

			hugs and kisses,
				Megan         Czefir

haphazard collection of ravers that get together to properly wind down

there or be talked about! 

This weeks dinner is at a great vegetarian place in Chinatown!

vegetarian dim sum. Brown rice available, and also has pastry/takeout
counter.  (They promised that their entrees were in the $5 range!)

Date: Mon, 18 Nov 96 15:00:59 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9610188483.AA848364668@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, Aryck <mxman@illuminati.heald.edu>
Subject: Re: Aryck's Theories of Expanded concious learning technique
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I wrote this a long time ago... and I never sent it.  You don't have to read it,
but I read your opinion so I figured it would be healthy...

XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX

My Take...
     
Fluffy Green Buds
I've noticed it takes the unique and beautiful in a person and makes it stand 
alone.  I love what pot does for most people.  I'm not a big fan of people 
who get too stoned to walk, but in functional amounts... I'd say some of the 
most thoughtful moments of my life could be somehow attributed to pot.  
Marijuana is also a family of highs, and not just one buzz.  Most people 
claim significantly different effects between brown and green strains for 
example.
     
SHROOMS
Mushrooms had a similar effect on me as acid, plus that quivering body rush. 
 To be honest, I'm not the biggest fan.  Only did it a couple times a long 
time ago.  Too little and it just made me jittery and feel like I ate some 
bad Mexican food... too much and God is arguing with your brain and crossing 
wires.  Try mescaline.  That's the sprit trip... I've heard peyote is even 
better.
     
ACID
It's as weird as you are.  As for how clearly you think on it, you want to 
be careful in general with drug-inspired thought processes.  I recommend 
taking an approach of "anything I decide is correct tonight I will ponder 
again tomorrow".  This keeps you from rash behavior and also prompts you to 
learn more form the experience.
     
MDMA
I don't think E covers anything up unless you're doing it for that purpose.  
I think E has helped me wade through some really bizarre shit.  In 
smaller/medium doses (I know a lot of 2 and 3 hitters out there), it has 
amazing effects on your perception of emotions, both remembered and current. 
 For me it does to my heart what acid did to my mind.  Ecstacy has a certain 
regressive quality that prompts many users into exploring roles we perhaps 
should have left behind long ago.  Many people find extraordinary amounts of 
pleasure and solace in hugging teddy bears or talking like children.  It's 
healing, and I'm glad it happens.  It's as fake as you percieve it to be, 
but too many people feel the same way.  As for the girl who thought she was 
a beauty queen, she is only as bad as those guys who think they're robots or 
mackdaddies from hell (wait... I think I've been there).  I think it sucks 
that most men can't admire a woman for being just beautiful without wanting 
to "have" her.  I wouldn't blame her for wanting to feel pretty for a little 
while with no strings attached.  I've been there myself.
     
AndyW
     


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Nov 18 17:05:12 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id RAA21562; Mon, 18 Nov 1996 17:05:12 -0800 (PST)
Received: from acergw3.acer.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with ESMTP id RAA21553; Mon, 18 Nov 1996 17:05:04 -0800 (PST)
Received: from smtplink.acer.com ([204.160.139.137]) by acergw3.acer.com (8.7.3/8.7.3) with SMTP id RAA21161 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 18 Nov 1996 17:01:43 -0800 (PST)
Received: from ccMail by smtplink.acer.com (SMTPLINK V2.11.01)
	id AA848365864; Mon, 18 Nov 96 17:01:29 pst
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 96 17:01:29 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9610188483.AA848365864@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: I think I like you all...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     I got invited by a SF-Raver to a party that didn't exist apparently... 
     THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU.
     
     Location:  Non Existent
     Time:      10pmFriday-7amSaturday
     
     Music:     Rich House, some Goa, even ambient on the floor.  The house 
     was great.  I'm not a big house maven, but good music played off a 
     good crowd never fails to put a smile on my face. The goa was good for 
     the party, but it seemed less fresh than it used to... it's probably 
     me.
     
     Chill room was luscious... music, vibe, everything in line.  Too bad 
     it was a little small considering the demand.
     
     Started out with drum circle outside, and a vibe that was soo damn 
     positive.  Chimed in for the last couple jams and for the first time 
     in a while I felt really connected to the other drummers and the 
     people sitting in the middle of the circle at the fire making slight 
     vocal noises and clapping, snapping and rubbing hands together to add 
     to the magic, wooden, driven sound.  Went inside to start the event 
     with a toning exercise.  Damn damn.  Felt sooo good to get out some of 
     that energy.  Even thought I physically felt like I'd been hit by a 
     bus (bad chemical choice earlier in the day), I couldn't help but 
     elevate to the party's level.  Managed to stay amazingly coherent, 
     bright eyed and bushytailed throughout the evening.  Met divine 
     wonderful people all night long, as well as getting a chance to sit 
     back and talk forever with some familiar faces.  Ahhhhh.  Hope they 
     have another one like this soon.  From some of the morning's neighbor 
     related events, these may be in jeopardy  Hope not.  It was really 
     amazing.
     
     Found my car marginally defaced.  Too disgusting to mention to the 
     entire list, but not exactly what I was planning on seeing.  I feel 
     bad for mentioning it now.  Suffice to say some people have done 
     things in my car I haven't done.
     
     Went back sleepy, and crashed with friends in Berkeley through the 
     morning.
     
     Saturday:
     Tim, the BBQ king, reigns supreme (or is that rains?).  BBQ and Beats 
     III was too fun.  Although I'm glad not every party has rain and a 
     vibe of *I love the freaks that would gather outside in the rain to be 
     with other freaks that would gather in the rain*, it was something I 
     almost needed.  A perfect cap to help me through another bout of 
     wondering if this is something I still love or fell into and am stuck 
     in.  I LOVE THESE PEOPLE.  Yes Yes Yes!!!  First and foremost.  
     Partied  everybody out, as well as getting partied out by everybody.  
     The spirit was all about giving, and sharing.  Really liked the view 
     through the fog and rain.  Sorta melancholy and industrial... but the 
     fact that we gathered to be together in this made it strangely 
     beautiful.  I also liked all the DJ's I heard during my short time 
     there (about two hours), and I caught all of Micron's set... which was 
     most tasty.  Good records, good intentions, and good technique.  Sorry 
     if I talked anybody's head off.
     
     Tim, stop apologizing... it was REALLY GOOD (you scared me with that 
     electric shock in the rain thing btw).  I ate well, danced freely and 
     met some new faces.  Look at the bright side... no sunburn or 
     heatstroke!
     
     And finally:
     
     Wrinkle in Time
     Got to the map point... just a little sign that said "Sold Out".  
     That's how I felt... sold out.  Whaaaaa.  Then I remembered an 
     overheard ancestral memory about the location.  Do I dare guess... 
     only other party was Basics (I'm assuming that was an east bay party), 
     and I figured I'd shoot down the street and give the imaginary Wrinkle 
     in Time location a shot.
     
     Pay dirt... I got to the location and was welcomed by Terry, who I'd 
     finally met just earlier that day.  Hello!  More nice people up the 
     stairs.  Hello!
     
     The hallway to the mainroom was clogged with people.  Usually I'm 
     somewhat pleased to be crushed by thousands, but this wasn't the case. 
      People were bumping into, stepping on, and dishing out dirty looks.  
     All without apology or a grin to let me know their intentions were 
     better than their balance.  Is the planet getting sucky?  Had I become 
     jaded after a solid weekend of supremely good will...
     
     Well, no.  As little as a half an hour later, I started to mellow out. 
      Met up with some wonderful people in the relaxo room, and zoned out 
     to Stella Luna for a while.  Greta got her hand stepped on, and that 
     jerky didn't apologize either.
     
     BE NICE YOU ALL!!!
     
     I finally start just grounding myself and realizing that I was in the 
     midst of some really good people and probably concentrating on the few 
     buttheads.  So I relaxed for about a half an hour more.  I got a 
     little hungry and atE a little something to tide me over.
     
     At about 3:00 am the somEthing came over me right about as I had made 
     peace with the notion that my perception was playing more of a part in 
     my enjoyment of the event than the actual event... *WHAT TIMING!*  
     I'll just leave it with... I was wearing a striped black and white ski 
     hat and brown overalls, really stoked and giving as much energy as I 
     could to this party.  I'm so glad for Mike, Moshe, Greta, Libby, Jay, 
     Melanie, Micron, Susan, EPaul, Wayne, Maggie, Renzo, Rick, Shawna and 
     friends (massive gratitude), Mike Migurski (happy birthday to you and 
     the girl who got B'dayd right after you in the hallway), Matt (arch 
     hug meister), SJDRS,SFR & Harmony, Tim, Burger King, Jason, Diana, 
     JohnK, Omar (hope you got the wave, stay strong) and a cast of 
     thousands coming into my life and I into theirs.
     
     I had a really good weekend (I can't seem to remember one to compare 
     it to at this point).  This means we're 2/7's of the way there.  If we 
     had days like this everyday...
     
     Peace,

Hi everyone!  =)

 Gads! I'm still tired! Well as most of you know the party went off BIG 
time! We actually opened the doors and had the music start on time. As I 
was coordinating the ambient room (and performing) I didn't have much of 
a chance to enjoy the main dance floor but I did get a chance to boogie 
to Deaks which is always fun.

 I gets to the party spot at about 3:30 and starts on the ambient room. 
Once again the room was put together with love from a lot of dedicated 
volunters. You folks were all tremendous!! Esoecially in my mind were, 
Tony Rose, Anthony and Mack (the knife ;), Martin, Carrie (on 
decorations:), and of course others whose names escape my tired brain.

 Huge props to Tim for the doggie bag from BBQ & Beats!! :) also to David 
from InSight Lighting who delivered the tasty morsel.

 I really am thankful to the performers in the ambient room that night. 
There was a lot of last minute changes and everyone worked hard to cope. 
I'm happy to say everyone got their alloted time and more for a few 
(including the surprise DJ at the end who got to play one song ;)

 Props to Rick Riffle from Conciousness Lab Ambient Research Group (did I 
get that right?) and their DJ who filled in at the beggining--great 
sounds!!, Bonnie and Shom (great stuff folks!), Stella Luna who once 
again were over the top and melted what was left of my brain AND huge 
thanks to Dave Baer who provided sound and to Rob from Gateway who 
helped tracked down that annoying buzz (sorry Dave ;).

 The design for the ambient room was not quite where I wanted it but 
folks seemed to enjoy it. It was very crowded but the vibe in there was 
super good all night long!! Me (and the rest of Harmony actually) owe a 
big thanks and phat hug to Rebecca Love Cardennis for providing me with 
away to get my equipment home on Sunday. Due to transportation problems I 
did not have a ride for me and all my gear (a lot of stuff!) and Rebecca 
appeared out of the blue with a friendly smile and phat van. YOU ARE 
F*CKING AWESOME!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

 Thanks also to her friend Heather who brought Rebecca to her first rave 
(Harmony 3).

 Thanks to Greg for a phun party!!  =) Thanks to Pengo for the VR 
machine!! Thanks to Brandon for his smart bar. Thanks to Brendon (sp?) 
for video!!! =) Thanks for the Wrinkle Cam. I hope Omar saw me wave to him.

 However the folks who stayed to help clean up were the most awesome! 
Thank you!!

 THANKS TO ALL OF YOU WHO CAME AND HELPED TO SPREAD THE VIBE!!  =)



peace y'all,


Ran @ Dionysus Dreams
                               (Namasate)
                                  /
                            -=*=-/
                              ~

Subject: RAVE LIT - re: Terrence McKenna's "Food of the Gods"

I think anyone into the Rave scene should definitely read "Brave New
World"
by Aldous Huxley (1935).  Aside from the almost Shakespearean use of
language,
the book is a description of a futuristic society where everyone stays
happy
on "soma" and goes to tribal dance/religious sex ceremonies....

	"A half gram for a half-holiday
	One gram for a week end
	Two grams for a trip to the gorgeous East
	Three for a dark eternity on the moon"

     and

	"Feel how the greater Being comes
	Rejoice and in rejoicings die
	Melt in the music of the drums
	For I am you and you are I"

	- Aldous Huxley (1935)


        jim thompson - cube root fact axon info grid data fate

From: "Thompson. Jim" <jthompson@arkons.lmsc.lockheed.com>
To: sfraves - send mail to list <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: The Economy of Nature, the Nature of Economy  (NRR)
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 1996 09:32:00 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.993.5
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


When I was in college - before I fell from grace and entered engineering
school -
I took an ecology course (part of the botany program) whose textbook was
entitled "The Economy of Nature".  The book made it clear that
eco-systems
and economic systems are VERY similar in their behavior.  Increases in
food supply (lowered costs of products) leads to increases in population
(demand for products, increase in business activity) leading to
subsequent
decreases in population as populations/demand outstrips supply (costs
rise,
business retrenches).

Man's intervention in eco-systems is analogous to government
intervention in economic systems.  You can increase the amount of one
crop/
product but at the expense of bio-diversity/efficiency of the system as
a whole.
Picking one crop/product to grow/protect increases the supply OF THAT
PARTICULAR crop/product but at the cost of lowering the OVERALL "wealth"
of the eco-system/economic system.

It turns out that what is most efficient  for the system as a whole is
NO
INTERVENTION AT ALL.


I realize that there can be exceptions to the general rule above (look
at goverment investments in computers, networking, etc)
(also one can argue that some interventions in eco-systems CAN increase
them - for example diverting a river that would flow into a salt flat
to instead flow into crop land) but as they say :

"Generalizations are GENERALLY true".....


        jim thompson - cube root fact axon info grid data fate
        ::: ..::.  ....:  ::::.::::::     .       ....::... ::
        .:..:::::  ....:::.....::.:::::::::..     .. :..:::::
        .:.:..:.. ..:  ...::::..:. . ...:: : .... :........:.:
        .....  ::...   .:::::::    ...:::: ...  :..... ..::...
        :::..:::....:: .:......::..   :::::.::         ::.....

>>. "AMP" is a
>>                               showcase for new bands that have embraced
  >                             the latest techno sounds, such as Prodigy,
>>                               Chemical Brothers, Underworld and Future
  >>                             Sounds of London. "AMP" is like nothing
   >>                            you've ever seen or heard before on MTV.

Its interesting to see the perspective on whats considered nu bands 
when all these guys have been hooning around for five years or so
at least . Prodigy had a succession of gimmick singles in the charts
, Chemicals used to be Dust Brothers and were around remixing
quite early on and F.O.S are into their third or fourth album courtesy
of Sony . They are all great bands , ( well U/World is , the Prodigy
nearly are , the Chemicals are not really a band and FOS is an
ambient studio project ) , but not new . These guys are the big boys
but only the tip of the iceberg .
Shut up Freud .
Ok

atb
Freud

Club Alien
Red Beard Recordings

has been great and I cant wait to get over and see it all for real , which
hopefully will be next month .

appreciated....
  Keep it up guys , keep it up !

This is to let anyone interested know what's up with the "sfr" cabin trip
III.

Some might recall, last year, about 27 sfravers went up to a big ol plush
cabin in tahoe and had a really really good time. 

This weekend, there will be another one, with some of the same people and a
lot of new people. The organization of this has gone smoothly so far, except
for the fact that the annoucement/invite never got to the list. After sending
out the first invites to last years goers, and a group of close friends, the
35 spots filled up quickly, we're actually overfilled as far as cabin
occupancy goes.

Another sfraver pointed out that perhaps it shouldn't be called the SFRaves
Cabin Trip because of this, I had to agree. Furthermore, this was never
approved by Brian or any of the others gracious souls that provide us with
this forum. Though undoubtedly, it was their initial dream of this list that
made these trips possible!

Nevertheless, I'm stil very excited about this weekend, and I would love to
see more sfravers joining us at least for snowboarding/skiing on saturday.
(we'll probably go to kirkwood, I will announce on thurs.)

Once again, the cabin trip is full as of now. If you would seriously be
interested in future cabin trips, or you would like me to take your name and
# down in case we have a few people drop out within the next couple days
(possible), send a brief email with your name and ph# to SFouRcabin@aol.com
(sorry can't change the addy name this time around).
Lots o love,
StEvEo
P.S. I would certainly love to see more of these gigs like bbq & beats, cabin
trips, (how about a houseboat trip?). It doesn't take a "production company",
or the motive of profit to throw a party. I think everyone has probably said
"Hey, this would be a great place to throw a party." Well do it! And don't
forget to put me on the invite list, and the volunteer list! :)

Subject: A Wrinkle in Time

Loved it!
One of the top three ambient rooms I've ever been in....thus I spent 98% of
the night there.  Interactive technology being made available to the guests
of the party really has an effect I believe.  I had never experience VR, and
thought it was really fun......and I had also never played that super duper
nintendo extraspecialerific what ever it was either.  I had no idea what I
was supposed to be doing with it, but it was fun to make mario run around
and stuff and trip on the graphics.  It was too hot and crowded for me in
the dance room so I spent less than 10 minutes of the entire night in there.
Same with the halls.  I only ventured out of the amb space when I had to for
what ever reason.  Loved all the music played in the ambient room, and had
fun playing the song I wrote last week for Omar.  Eric and I had a blast
playing our set, and I got to hear a new song he just made for the first
time.  I was really stoked on it.  Sometimes it's good not to
practice....adds an element of suprise :)  The jam session with Randy and
Steve(?)  was cool as well.  The only thing the amb room was missing was
carpet or comfortable seating....which really adds to the ambience if
available.  

Thanks Harmony for the wonderful party, and the opportunity to play our
tunes.  See ya at the next one.

Rick

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

SteveO was the organizer, same as last year.  He took it off of the list to
avoid the scheduling nightmare that occured last year.  He just posted
something about it this morning.  He had good intensions, and I know he was
planning to give an open call to the list, but he wanted to contact the
people who went last year, and those he knew would send thier checks right
away.  Once he did that, it filled up almost instantly.  There was no chance
to post openly to the list.  I'm sure there will be more of these throuout
the snow season, and I'm hoping that the next one will be strictly first
come first serve and what not.  I've been pondering the idea of looking for
a really big space that could accomodate 100 or more so we could do it big
time, but these are only thoughts at this point.  100 people with 100
different checks....needed in advance is a massive undertaking that I don't
know if I'm ready for.  If you can, meet us up on the slopes for some
snowboarding on Saturday.  Steve's going to post something to the list about
it later in the week.

Rick

[ to sfraves ]

 Has anyone tried the 3MU freeware emulation of the TB-303 ? It's 
described at this URL:

http://www.modeemi.cs.tut.fi/~jams/3MU/

 and the source and binaries ( for DEC Alpha, Sun Sparc, Amiga, and Linux )
are at:

http://www.modeemi.cs.tut.fi/~jams/3MU/download.html

 as are some great sounding example files ( sun .au files; mono 8-bit 8kHz 
 mu-law ).

 I downloaded and uncompressed the source , but all the comments are
in Finnish! And the developers stress that it's a beta version still.
But, like I said, the samples sound great!

Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

PS - Any other software synths out there that folks would recommend? I'd prefer
     something that works on a Mac, but mention PC based ones too. I've 
     already heard about PC-303 via this list.

This probably has nothing to do with the letter but I just thought I should 
use it as an excuse to say something ;)

luv
Pab

Andy Wyszkowski wrote:
> I wrote this a long time ago... and I never sent it.  You don't have to read it,
> but I read your opinion so I figured it would be healthy...

> Fluffy Green Buds
> I've noticed it takes the unique and beautiful in a person and makes it stand
> alone.  I love what pot does for most people.  I'm not a big fan of people
> who get too stoned to walk, but in functional amounts... I'd say some of the
> most thoughtful moments of my life could be somehow attributed to pot.
> Marijuana is also a family of highs, and not just one buzz.  Most people
> claim significantly different effects between brown and green strains for
> example.

It makes sense...I myself personaly have not taken that much of it. But I do have to say that
some makes me feel as if I were happily tired (kinda like if I was high on Sugar) and some of it
makes me feel sick. I dunno ( I guess it depends on what you get doesn't it? )... 
Anyhow, I just wanted to say that personaly I don't like calling it 'pot' or 'marijuana'...

how about calling it "PIZZA" :) 
						
> SHROOMS
> Mushrooms had a similar effect on me as acid, plus that quivering body rush.
>  To be honest, I'm not the biggest fan.  Only did it a couple times a long
> time ago.  Too little and it just made me jittery and feel like I ate some
> bad Mexican food... too much and God is arguing with your brain and crossing
> wires.  Try mescaline.  That's the sprit trip... I've heard peyote is even
> better.

I agree. 
The first time I took shrooms I was doing "Pizza" as well (I guess you would call it Pizza with Mushrooms) ;)
so I didn't really know what was what... but I do know that I felt extra hyper and was dancing to no music. 
(odly enough) the second time I did shrooms (leftovers from the week before) I didn't do too much, I was at a 
Mozart Symphony and it was sooo boring I decided to eat the shroom I had in my backpack. After that I went to
a dance club and started to trip. No hallucinations or anything but I do believe that I was thinking everyone 
was an alien and I was shooting them with my pager...and I also remember hiding under the tables at the club.
(Obviously a very ambarrasing experience ;P). I did feel like if I had eaten some bad food or something... but
the feeling went away withing a day or so.
 
> ACID
> It's as weird as you are.  As for how clearly you think on it, you want to
> be careful in general with drug-inspired thought processes.  I recommend
> taking an approach of "anything I decide is correct tonight I will ponder
> again tomorrow".  This keeps you from rash behavior and also prompts you to
> learn more form the experience.

I didn't do that much Acid...but the little I did I loved. Once again I did it at
a club (no comments please ;P) I didn't hallucinate (or I really can't say if I did)
but I do remember the place being lit up, a lot of color, a lot of lights, everyone
was happy, I was happy and hyper, I was dancing, chatting, I was having a lot of fun...
but then, it all disappeared. :o(

> MDMA
> I don't think E covers anything up unless you're doing it for that purpose.
> I think E has helped me wade through some really bizarre shit.  In
> smaller/medium doses (I know a lot of 2 and 3 hitters out there), it has
> amazing effects on your perception of emotions, both remembered and current.
>  For me it does to my heart what acid did to my mind.  Ecstacy has a certain
> regressive quality that prompts many users into exploring roles we perhaps
> should have left behind long ago.  Many people find extraordinary amounts of
> pleasure and solace in hugging teddy bears or talking like children.  It's
> healing, and I'm glad it happens.  It's as fake as you percieve it to be,
> but too many people feel the same way.  As for the girl who thought she was
> a beauty queen, she is only as bad as those guys who think they're robots or
> mackdaddies from hell (wait... I think I've been there).  I think it sucks
> that most men can't admire a woman for being just beautiful without wanting
> to "have" her.  I wouldn't blame her for wanting to feel pretty for a little
> while with no strings attached.  I've been there myself.

E ! E! I would have to say that "E" has been the most wonderful thing I've ever taken.
it made me feel like a baby (and talk like one for some odd reason) and it made me feel
really good. I did it at "Wrinkle in Time" my first 'party' and my first time on "e". I really
really enjoyed it. It was as if  it had taken a 'mask' away from me..it was just me and myself.
I was happy, nothing was wrong, I talked to everyone, it made my day completely. It was just
great... and I agree with you about the men who can't admire a woman for being pretty without wanting to have 
her. but then...I find women gorgeous withouht wanting them...the reason (nevermind it).

Anyhow, maybe I should add one more little thiny to this list...since its something I tried with some
white-trash friends of mine ;o) (just kidding guys).

MINI-THINS:
Some funky pills you can buy at the liquior store they are meant for those who have ashtma or whatever
and they open up your brochial cavity or whatever.. (I'm not a doctor guys ;P) Anyhow,
just wanted to say what I experienced with it...

I took about 6pills...(which is good enough you don't really need more) and what I felt was tingly. My
entire body felt really really tingly.. my hair felt like as if it was 'flying' you know, like 'static'.
it was a nice feeling... I also noticed that touching other people, petting things, etc felt really really 
nice. me and my friends were petting each others legs and arms all night.. and cuddling and such it felt 
very very nice... it does kinda have two effects though...if you sit and enjoy the high you feel tired as if 
you were high on 'pizza'...yet if you stand and walk around or dance you get hyper...weird effect. but nice.

here comes the bad part...
After I came down...I completely felt like SH*T for the next 2 days... it was hell. the feeling it just 
horrible. It made me feel sick..really sick kinda nauseous but not really (and that doesn't make sense does 
it) it was just not nice. I guess I would have to do 'em again to really describe it better ;) the bad feeling 
could also have been lack'o'sleep :o.

Anyhow...that was fun :)
love to allz 
Pab

PS: Oh my god, hope Eric doesn't read this.. ;)

From: David Ginsberg <ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: Terence McKenna's "Food of the Gods"
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I don't think we should let ourselves get levelled off and beaten down
by the possibility that these experiences are 'subjective,' as if this
somehow discounted them.  I always try to remember that experiences
like these are profoundly transformative and indicative of a psyche in
the process of transformation and growth...the "hero's journey" that
Joseph Campbell talks about is something that is found in all cultures
from all times and the postmodern encounter with aliens may be just our
incarnation of this universal, human-transformative process.  Often
times this process is one of learning how to reach out with love rather
than recoil in fear.  I can certainly relate to that myself.  Shamans,
poets, great thinkers, musicians, lovers-these are co-created with
experiences like those McKenna and Campbell talk about, and I'll be the
first to stand up and defend anything which creates more of these,
whether or not it stands up to the (dubious) scrutiny of 'objective
analysis.'  


What is reality?  Is it what you live, or is it what someone else tells
you it is?  I'd opt for the former.  I think what is real are the
phenomena of our existence.  Therefore, I think there was no reality
before I was born, and that there will be none after I'm gone.  Reality
is what happens in between those two portals, and that includes dreams,
visions, religious experiences or whatever phenomena I encounter as I
live.  I believe that imagination is key to transformation on personal,
tribal and societal levels, and I also believe that our age's
pre-occupation with rational empiricism is anathema to imagination. 
This world IS enchanted.  We all know it everytime we come together at
a great gathering like F&F or Harmony.  I know it when I spend time
alone in the wilderness.  And as children I think we all knew it too,
before indoctrination into consensus reality...which I see as nothing
other than the lowest common denominator among the phenomena of human
existence.  We owe ourselves more than that. 


Chaos theory (http://www.ccs.fau.edu/ccs.html) and non-Cartesian
Cognitive Science
(http://www.cogs.susx.ac.uk/users/ronaldl/noncartesian.html#exis),
especially the work of Walter Freeman (http://sulcus.berkeley.edu/)
point toward this existential-phenomenological conception of reality,
and to a non-reductionist, post-Cartesian way of doing science itself,
one which eliminates the Cartesian objective/subjective distinction and
the air of superiority which one encounters among many of its
practitioners and adherents.  Fractals surround us in nature and in the
music we rave to, in who we are as part of our culture and in art and
mathematics.  All this points to a holism, one which must be taken at
face value and one which might resist rational explanation.  I think
we're only beginning to understand the connections between art and
science, and partly because we are begining to see them I think the
future holds great hope for the re-enchantment of the world.  It's all
up to us as individual members within our communities to be true to the
phenomena of our experience and to live our lives accordingly, and to
stand up to what 'they' say and stand apart from what 'they' do when
appropriate.


Quote of the day:


<fontfamily><param>Palatino</param><smaller>To be yourself, in a world
that tries, night and day, to make you just 

like everybody else - is to fight the greatest battle there ever is to


fight, and never stop fighting. -E.E. Cummings</smaller></fontfamily>


Embrace the chaos

We are fractal

Believe


-David

Abraham Lincoln and John F Kennedy...

* Lincoln was elected into congress in 1846, for Kennedy it was 1946.
* Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Kennedy in 1960.
* They both lost a son during their presidency.
* They were both killed during their presidency.
* They both died on a Friday in the presence of their respective wives.
* Lincoln was shot at the Ford Theater, Kennedy was shot in a Ford Lincoln.
* Their succesors were both named Johnson (Andrew and Lyndon), and they were
  born on 1808 and 1908, respectively.
* Lincoln's killer John Wilkes Booth was born in 1839, Kennedy' killer Lee
  Harvey Oswald was born in 1939.
* Both gunmen were assassinated before they were tried.
* After shooting Lincoln at the theater, Booth hid in a wherehouse. Oswald
  shot Kennedy from a wherehouse and hid in a theater.
* Lincoln's secretary, whos name was Kennedy, told him not to go to the
theater.
  Kennedy's secretary, whos name was Lincoln, told him not to go to Dallas.
* The names Kennedy and Lincoln both have seven letters. The successors names
  both have thirteen letters. The killers names both have fifteen letters.

To: SFRAVES@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Sad(nRR) story about Grandpa
References: <199611142204.OAA25982@shellx.best.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

SDream wrote:
> 
> Jondabomb wrote:
> 
> >My 85 year old Grandpa just left from a ten day visit from Pennsylvania. I
> >was sick the whole time he was here, except for like the last two days...
> >When he left just now he ws crying. It dawned on me that I might never see
> >him again, and he was thinking that too... It just tore my heart up
> >inside.... I'm sorry for posting this, but I just had to tell someone....Or
> >Something like that... Uhhhh, I feel really shitty right now...
> 
> Just before my grandmother died, I got the feeling that, if I didn't go see
> her soon, I might not get the chance.  I made the right move by making
> immediate arrangements to visit her.  A few months after my visit, she died.
>  You can't stop death, but you can enjoy life as much as possible while it
> lasts.  

I have never had someone close to my die.  After Charity <October 4>  I
got in touch with Omar's mom to make arrangements to give her the money
we raised for her.  As the situation were, I arranged to meet her at the
hospital and get the opportunity to see/ say hi to Omar.  I didn't know 
Omar too well before burning man.  I had talked to him on numerous
occasions, but I can't say that he was a close friend of mine.  I did,
however, after seeing him at the hospital get to talk at length with his
mom.  She and I talked and/or cried for over an hour after I had said my
good byes to Omar.

My point is this:

The whole experience of talking with Jolene (Omar's mom) and visiting
Omar was an overwhelmingly sobering experience.  You know, we all, and I
do mean EVERY one of us takes what we have for granted.  Our life, our
health, our well being.  The only way we can ever come to truly
appreciate anything is if we loose it or are threatened with loosing
it.  We all go out and party all night and take all kinds of drugs and
do all kinds of crazy things (well some of us do anywayz), and we all
think that we are immortal, but we ignore the fact that something
drastic could happen to any one of us at any time.  It might not be our
fault.  It might not be preventable.  It might not be predictable.  But
it could happen to you, and it could happen to me.  

So should we all lock ourselves up in our homes and close the blinds and
never go outside cuz we might get hurt?  No, of course not.  However:::
Take time today, to tell the people you love how you feel.  Call your
parents.  Call your grandparents.  Call your sister or your brother. 
Call your friend that you haven't talked to in a couple of years.  CAll
them all and tell them just that you love them.  Because when or if
something happens, You will be saying to yourself< "I never told them
how I really felt.  If I could only have five minutes more... etc."  


After I got back to my car at Omar's hospital, I just laid my head down
on the stearing wheel and cried.  I cried like I haven't in a very long
time.  After I had got home and told my friends how Omar was (they were
all asking)  I went to the house of an old friend I had not been close
to in a long time, but still and always will have a close place in my
heart.  I told her that I love her.   I then went to my parent's house. 
They were just finishing a late dinner.  I told them that I love them
and that I thought they did a great job of providing me with the
adequite tools for conquering the world.  I then went to my grandparents
house.  They weren't home, but I broke into their house and stuck a note
on their fridge that said: "I love you both very much... your grandson
Adam".  

Appreciate what you have... Tell those people in your life that you love
them.  Cherish every moment of your life as if it were your last.  Only
then will we begin to understand what is truly important in our lives. 
It's not the posessions, the cars, or the daily mundane stuff that fills
up 99% of our lives.  The truly important things in life are those who
love you, and those who you love.  

I've said my piece.

Peace, Love, Unity and Respect, everybody.

--Adam--

>that?  Any outright kids?  And how bout the oldest?  I'd be curious to see
>what our real age-span is.
>
I have often wondered the same thing.  A lot of people I see at parties look 
awfully young but I just attribute that to poor lighting and youthful genes.

I tried to subscribe for six months before my 16th birthday but somehow could 
not spell subscribe right (this from a spelling bee winner, huh! it was 
frustrating) and so, consequently could not subscribe.  I finally figured out my 
spelling error a little after my 16th birthday, but that was two years ago so 
I'm sure I am no longer among the youngest.

				world peas,
					Megan        Czefir

I thought this was a little more creative than the typical chain letter so I 
thought I might share it with you all.  

_______________________________forwarded text________________________________
http://www.ultranet.com/~krs/pinky.txt
Pinky:	Gee Brain, What are we going to do tonight???

Brain:	Same thing we do every night Pinky, try to take over the WORLD!

                                    ,.   '\'\    ,---.
                                    |  \\  l\\l_ //   |
                                    |  \\/ `/  `.|    |
      /~\\            //~\      | Y |   |   ||  Y |
       |   \\          //  |       |  \|   |   |\ /  |
       [    ||         ||   ]         \   |  o|o  | >  /
       ] Y  ||        ||  Y          \___\_--_ /_/__/   Narf!

       |   >'          `<            `--(______)----'
       \_ (/~`--____--'~\)            U// U /
         >-__________-<_-'         / \  / /|

            \___/__\___/              `.`' /   [
             /__`--'__\                    |`-'    |
          /\(__,>-~~ __)                |       |__
       /\//\\(  `--~~ )                 _l       |--:.
       '\/  <^\      /^>                |  `   (  <   \\
            _\ >-__-< /_              ,-\  ,-~~->. \   `:.___,/
            (___\    /___)           (____/    (____)    `---'

 Pinky and the Brain need your help.  In order for them to take over the
 world, you must send this letter to at least five other people. While
 they are reading this message Pinky and the Brain will be tying their
 shoe laces to the chair, and soon the entire population will be stuck at
 their computers.  If you do this simple task for the Brain he may spare
 you after his conquest.
.


<----  End Forwarded Message  ---->

------->Kiss someone you love when you get this letter and make magic. With
love, all things are possible. This paper has been sent to you for good
luck. The original is in New England. It has been around the world nine
times. This luck has been sent to you.
You will recieve good luck within four days of recieving this letter and you
must, in turn, send luck. This is no joke, send NO money. Send copies to
people you think need luck. Don't send money as fate has no price. Do not
keep this letter. It must leave your hand within 96 hours. A Pan Am officer
recieved $470,000. Joel Elliot recieved $70,000 and lost his wife because he
broke the chain. While in the Philippines,Can Walch lost his wife six days
after recieving this letter, he failed to circulate the letter. However,
before her death, he recieved $7,775. Please send 20 copies and see what
happens in four days. The chain comes from Venezuela and was written by Saul
Anthony Degroup, missionary from South America. Since the copy must tour the
world you must make 20 copies and send them to friends and associates. After
a few days, you will get a suprise. This is true. Even if you are not
superstitious. Do note the following. Constantine Dias recieved the letter
in 1953. He asked his secretary to make 20 copies and send them out. A few
days later he won the lottery of $2,000,000.
Cario Banddit an office employee, recieved the letter and forgot it had to
leave his hands within 96 hours. He lost his job. Delan Fairchild recieved
the chain, and not believing, threw the letter away. Nine days later, he
died. In 1987, the letter was recieved by a young woman in California. It
was faded and barely readable. She promised herself that she would re-type
the letter and send it out, but she put it aside. She was plagued with
various problems. The letter did not leave her hands within 96 hours. She
finally re-typed the letter as promised and got a new car. Send NO money. Do
not ignore this letter. It works.

        Saint Jude<------------------


I hate these damn chain letters. And I don't believe in them at all, but for
those of you who do, this may mean something to you. I'm actually against
organized religion, and therefor I'm against this pushing of beliefs on
others, forcing them to spread the word of an idiot. 

        I'm sending this just for your enjoyment, laugh. . . funny huh???

Luvyall

Aryck

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Nov 20 03:07:13 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id DAA07726; Wed, 20 Nov 1996 03:07:13 -0800 (PST)

X-Sender: star@pluto
To: David Ginsberg <ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
cc: Tony Rose <trose@uclink2.berkeley.edu>,
        Ciaran OHara <ciaran.ohara@CCMAIL.AirTouch.COM>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Objective & subjective reality
In-Reply-To: <v03007803aeb80e085c82@[128.32.192.224]>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.961120013924.8319E-100000@pluto>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Dear SFRavefriends,

	My comments are interspersed with David's below...

My computer tells me that on Tue, 19 Nov 1996, David Ginsberg shared:

> I don't think we should let ourselves get levelled off and beaten down
> by the possibility that these experiences are 'subjective,' as if this
> somehow discounted them.  I always try to remember that experiences
> like these are profoundly transformative and indicative of a psyche in
> the process of transformation and growth...the "hero's journey" that
> Joseph Campbell talks about is something that is found in all cultures
> from all times and the postmodern encounter with aliens may be just our
> incarnation of this universal, human-transformative process.  Often
> times this process is one of learning how to reach out with love rather
> than recoil in fear.  I can certainly relate to that myself.  Shamans,
> poets, great thinkers, musicians, lovers-these are co-created with
> experiences like those McKenna and Campbell talk about, and I'll be the
> first to stand up and defend anything which creates more of these,
> whether or not it stands up to the (dubious) scrutiny of 'objective
> analysis.'  

	I'm all in favor of transformative experiences, but that doesn't
mean that everything someone experiences therein should be taken with the
same sense of assurance with which one greets the news that one's car has
been towed.
	After listening to a long soliloquy by Terrence McKenna at the
Shamen concert at the Warfield in '94 (?), I realized that he makes a
great sample, but very little sense.
	I'm a poet and a lover, and I aspire to be a great thinker and
maybe a musician someday -- does this mean I should ignore the knowledge
humans have gained about reality and the way the world works over
countless generations, and my own empirical experience, in favor of
believing someone who tells me they were recently abducted by aliens?

> What is reality?  Is it what you live, or is it what someone else tells
> you it is?  I'd opt for the former.  I think what is real are the
> phenomena of our existence.  Therefore, I think there was no reality
> before I was born, and that there will be none after I'm gone.  

	If Dave is right, we better all hope he has a long, long life
ahead of him.

> Reality
> is what happens in between those two portals, and that includes dreams,
> visions, religious experiences or whatever phenomena I encounter as I
> live.  

	I guess it depends how you define reality.  That's a tricky one.
If I dream that I meet David and have a conversation with him, I believe
that the dream was real for me, but not real in the sense that actually
meeting him somewhere for a cup of coffee would have been real.  I don't
expect him to remember it the next day, because it never happened for him,
only for me.  If something happens inside my mind and is perceptible only
to me, I think we need to draw a division between this event and others
which are external to me.  Calling them both "reality" as if there were no
difference between them only serves to muddle our meaning and weaken
language as a tool for communication between people, imho.

> I believe that imagination is key to transformation on personal,
> tribal and societal levels, and I also believe that our age's
> pre-occupation with rational empiricism is anathema to imagination.

	Tell that to someone like Isaac Asimov!
 
> This world IS enchanted.  We all know it everytime we come together at
> a great gathering like F&F or Harmony.  I know it when I spend time
> alone in the wilderness.  And as children I think we all knew it too,
> before indoctrination into consensus reality...which I see as nothing
> other than the lowest common denominator among the phenomena of human
> existence.  We owe ourselves more than that. 

	I hate arguing against romantic ideas, because I'm a romantic
myself despite believing in a common reality.  But there's no Santa Claus
in the sense in which Virginia asked the question (there's not really a
man who spends Christmas Eve flying around in a sleigh delivering gifts)
even if he can be said to exist in the spirit of human generosity on some
level.
	We have the subjective ability to experience the world as a
magical, enchanted place, and I'm sure glad we do, or life would be rather
boring.  But acknowledging a common reality can be wonderful as well.  It
allows us to have beautiful experiences together, instead of just on our
own.  If we can't even achieve consensus on reality, how can we hope to
achieve consensus on anything else?

> Chaos theory (http://www.ccs.fau.edu/ccs.html) and non-Cartesian
> Cognitive Science
> (http://www.cogs.susx.ac.uk/users/ronaldl/noncartesian.html#exis),
> especially the work of Walter Freeman (http://sulcus.berkeley.edu/)
> point toward this existential-phenomenological conception of reality,
> and to a non-reductionist, post-Cartesian way of doing science itself,
> one which eliminates the Cartesian objective/subjective distinction and
> the air of superiority which one encounters among many of its
> practitioners and adherents.  

	This air of superiority may also be found among many people who
profess that there is no such thing as reality.  Even when you allegedly
don't believe in right and wrong, correct and incorrect, it is
surprisingly easy to talk as if there is no possibility but that you are
right, as I discovered while having a dicussion similar to this with an
ex-girlfriend.  8)

> Fractals surround us in nature and in the
> music we rave to, in who we are as part of our culture and in art and
> mathematics.  All this points to a holism, one which must be taken at
> face value and one which might resist rational explanation. 

	Why must this be taken at face value?  Isn't it part of the beauty
of humanity that we are constantly curious, seeking to fully understand
and grasp the wonders with which we come into contact?
	Sometimes I get the feeling that there is a hope among many that
certain "mysteries of life" will continue to defy rational explanation.
But this is a needless hope -- individually, most of us will never
understand the workings of an internal combustion engine, let alone the
nature of the universe, so why begrudge the possibility of that knowledge
to humanity as a whole?

> I think
> we're only beginning to understand the connections between art and
> science, and partly because we are begining to see them I think the
> future holds great hope for the re-enchantment of the world.  It's all
> up to us as individual members within our communities to be true to the
> phenomena of our experience and to live our lives accordingly, and to
> stand up to what 'they' say and stand apart from what 'they' do when
> appropriate.

	Quite so.  But I maintain that one of these appropriate times is
when someone like Terrence McKenna claims that the world is ending in
2012.  But if we make the language mallable enough, of course he could be
corrrect -- just like if we say that Santa Claus exists, black is white,
night is day, there is no racism today, and driving a BMW is the key to
happiness, we could be correct too -- if we use imaginative definitions.
	The reality of having different subjective experiences of the
same reality shouldn't blind us from recognizing that that reality
exists, even if none of us see it quite the same.  
	PLUR stands for peace, love, UNITY and respect. Where's the unity
if there's nothing real to experience together?

Much love,
				<<< Starchild >>>

On Tue, 19 Nov 1996, Jonas Hanning wrote:

> Sorry about this one, I just think it's pretty spooky... ;)
> 
> reespect and love, jonas
> 
> Abraham Lincoln and John F Kennedy...
> 
> * Lincoln was elected into congress in 1846, for Kennedy it was 1946.
> * Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Kennedy in 1960.
> * They both lost a son during their presidency.
> * They were both killed during their presidency.
> * They both died on a Friday in the presence of their respective wives.
> * Lincoln was shot at the Ford Theater, Kennedy was shot in a Ford Lincoln.
> * Their succesors were both named Johnson (Andrew and Lyndon), and they were
>   born on 1808 and 1908, respectively.
> * Lincoln's killer John Wilkes Booth was born in 1839, Kennedy' killer Lee
>   Harvey Oswald was born in 1939.
> * Both gunmen were assassinated before they were tried.
> * After shooting Lincoln at the theater, Booth hid in a wherehouse. Oswald
>   shot Kennedy from a wherehouse and hid in a theater.
> * Lincoln's secretary, whos name was Kennedy, told him not to go to the
> theater.
>   Kennedy's secretary, whos name was Lincoln, told him not to go to Dallas.
> * The names Kennedy and Lincoln both have seven letters. The successors names
>   both have thirteen letters. The killers names both have fifteen letters.
> 
>

A couple people have had to drop out on this weekend's CABIN/RAVE/SNOWBOARD
trip, so it looks like there will be 3-4 spots that have opened up afterall.
A portion of the original invite is below (sorry so long). PLEASE be sure to
read it all and make sure you will be able to go, if you're definitely up for
it, reply as shown at bottom to SFouRcabin@aol.com, asap. Since there are
only a couple spots, so I can't guarantee anything. Sorry for the confusion.
************************************************
Some might recall last spring's CABIN TRIP.  I believe it was common
consensus among the goers, that it went well, very well, very VERY well. From
Moonpup's 10 hour set in his birthday suit, to the communal dinner, to
tribalistic toning in the spa, to a wonderous performance by RE.  This was a
weekend of participation, family, and undescribeably good vibes.
Well it's an even bigger & better space, and with your help, more smiles,
more toys, more music, more love.
There is a catch.  Because this is a kind of "project", rather than a party,
It requires your participation, input and help. The bottom of this letter
tells how to get signed up, but it important to read this whole post, it
contains everything you need to know about The CABIN TRIP.
*************************************
*"What is it?": A weekend of fun, friendship, music, etc. at a massive cabin
in the mountains
*"Where is it?": So. Lake Tahoe (mountaneous, very woody, has a big big
beautiful lake, & possibly some snow. It's about 3 Hrs from the bay area)
*"When is it?": It looks like wknd of Nov. 22nd is going to work best for
most of us.  If I get a huge response that contradicts this, it might change.
 The fun will last the entire weekend.
*"Whos going?" Last Years group of 27 was incredible. Each person filled a
role essential to the whole. Most of us had never met, yet relationships
formed that remain growing today, (e.g. the one with the most special person
in my life right now).  Nevertheless, each experience should be lived in the
present for what it is. I hope to see as many new faces as familiar ones.
 1st invites go out to last years cabin goers (SFRavers), and a small list of
very special sfravers & other friendlies that are just born to be
cabin-goers. (See the "To:" field of this post) Also anyone who gets this is
of course welcome to invite your kin. After a week, if not filled, I'll send
an open invite to the list (sfraves) for remaining spots.  IMPORTANT, see
"Well sign me up" to guarantee a spot. 
*"A Cabin Eh?":  Last year we had a 2600 sq ft, 3 story home with a lakeview,
a huge living room. a rec room with a spa and a sauna, and was remodeled in a
lovely suburban nordic viking motif.  This years spot is a 5 bdm 4,000 sq
foot beauty, spa, game room (w/pinball,pool table, etc), solarium, massive
sun deck, view, intercom, yadayadayada. There will be a sunny "study room"
for your inconvenience.

*"MUSIC?":  Rick riffle is coordinator of sound/music. If you would like to
spin or have equip to bring let him know [rdriffle@ucdavis.edu]. The line-up
will be loose at best, but pleasure for your ears guaranteed.

*"YEAH BUT HOW MUCH?": It should be around $25, that includes pitching in
some $ for DAT tapes

"WHAABOUT FOOD?": Pot luck for Sat night dinner, aside from that, bring what
you need & some to share. There's a safeway nearby. 

"BUT WHAT ON EARTH WOULD WE DO FOR FUN? 
OUTDOOR: If my prayers are answered it will snow like mad and we'll be
boarding, skiing, sledding, making snow angels.
INDOOR: Duh.  Rave rave rave, hot tubbing! rave rave rave, fireside family
dinner!, rave rave rave, build bed sheet forts!, rave rave rave, twister!,
rave rave rave, and then of course there's my favorite multiple person indoor
sport...   pillow fights!;) Be sure to BRING ANYTHING you can to add to the
fun; games, toys, art, drums, synths, etc.
"WHAABOUT THE WEATHER?": It's bee raining up there, but there will be snow at
higher elevations. Having chains would be a very good idea but probably not
necc.

"WELL SIGN ME UP!"
Please try to give as definite of an answer as soon as possible. Look at your
calender, and have anyone you would like to go look at theirs.  Once you've
decided you really want to go, and can afford it, then reply (-text) to
SFouRcabin@aol.com, dont hit reply to this message. Be sure and include the
following info in the following order:

ANSWER    EMAIL (NAME)    PH#    ME+# ppl you'ld like to go(name(s) After
that, let me know if you would like to help or contribute in any department

This is a SAMPLE RESPONSE:

>>ABSOFUCKINGLUTELY YES!   steveosac@aol.com (Steven D. Ogden)   510.802.5777

board and would love to sign up for bathroom duty!<<

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Nov 20 09:52:13 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id JAA11935; Wed, 20 Nov 1996 09:52:13 -0800 (PST)
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with ESMTP id JAA11917; Wed, 20 Nov 1996 09:52:04 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [128.32.192.224] (ch051.Chance.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.192.224]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.6/8.6.12) with ESMTP id JAA21286; Wed, 20 Nov 1996 09:51:50 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v03007800aeb8df71908f@[128.32.192.224]>
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.3.95.961120013924.8319E-100000@pluto>
References: <v03007803aeb80e085c82@[128.32.192.224]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 1996 09:44:34 -0800
To: Starchild <star@sfsu.edu>
From: David Ginsberg <ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: Objective & subjective reality - and respect
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Good morning everyone, my comments, like Starchild's, are interspersed.

At 3:07 AM -0800 11/20/96, Starchild wrote:
>	I'm all in favor of transformative experiences, but that doesn't
>mean that everything someone experiences therein should be taken with the
>same sense of assurance with which one greets the news that one's car has
>been towed.
<snip>
>	I'm a poet and a lover, and I aspire to be a great thinker and
>maybe a musician someday -- does this mean I should ignore the knowledge
>humans have gained about reality and the way the world works over
>countless generations, and my own empirical experience, in favor of
>believing someone who tells me they were recently abducted by aliens?
>
My point was certainly not to elevate "subjective experience" above "the
knowledge humans have gained about reality," and it should be clear from
what I wrote that I wouldn't recommend you believing in (whatever that
means) someone's report of their alien abduction - my point is simply that
you shouldn't discount YOUR OWN experiences, too which I'd add I don't
think you should flat out deny those of others.  I don't deny the
usefullness of science (or I wouldn't be studying it), but at the same time
I recognize that science yields just one type of knowledge - which cuts
linear paths into something nonlinear and will always be incomplete and
contradictory (Starchild I suggest you read some Kuhn!) - and that there
are other ways of knowing which may not stand up to the requirements of
objectivity which science strives for but which may nonetheless be valuable
in their own right and in some cases (those where it involves meaning) may
even take precedence over scientific knowledge.
>
>	I guess it depends how you define reality.  That's a tricky one.
>If I dream that I meet David and have a conversation with him, I believe
>that the dream was real for me, but not real in the sense that actually
>meeting him somewhere for a cup of coffee would have been real.  I don't
>expect him to remember it the next day, because it never happened for him,
>only for me.  If something happens inside my mind and is perceptible only
>to me, I think we need to draw a division between this event and others
>which are external to me.  Calling them both "reality" as if there were no
>difference between them only serves to muddle our meaning and weaken
>language as a tool for communication between people, imho.
>
Of course there are distinctions between dreaming of doing something and
doing something.  This is trivial and uninteresting.  But to think that
only what is objectively verifiable is real denies the reality of colors
(there is NO objective baisis for measuring color, not wavelength, not
reflectance, not brightness, not some amalgam of them - none, and this is a
problem for your point of view Starchild).  Of course you're free to accept
that there is nothing such as color, and just think in terms of some
objectively quantifiable variable like reflectance, but the candlefeet of
the light reflecting off a sheet of white paper in the moonlight is lower
than that off a charcoal piece of paper in daylight, yet you and I would
both agree that the paper is white.  It's difficult to get beyond the
Cartesian dualism we've inherited.  We talk in terms of "inner" and
"outter" and it all makes perfect sense.  But what I'm saying is that when
you're true to the phenomena of your experience, you might find it
difficult to make such distinctions.  You see, meaning appears to be
embodied in the brain in the form of what we're now calling attractors, and
the patterns which arise when the cortices settle into basins of attraction
express relations between the organism and its milieu.  These relations are
not inner and they're not outter...they are holistic, and this is what we
are and this is what reality, most primordially, can mean.  This meaning
structure, this set of potentialities for action, is the basis of
intelligibility and as such is prior to objective knowledge.  Sure, science
is getting at something, but how we see it and what it means to us is based
upon this background of understanding which we get as we act in the world
and become enculturated.  I'd even grant that in some cases maybe science
is finding truly objective facts about the universe - "carving nature at
her joints" - but I also think we'd never know for sure.  It's difficult to
get beyond Cartesian dualistic thinking...such thinking has become embedded
in our language over the past 400 years and we use such language on an
everyday basis, but such thinking leads to all sorts of conundrums like
mind/body, realism/irrealism, inner/outter, all of which can be avoided by
sticking close to the phenomena.  When you use the term reality Starchild,
I think you have something like the universe in mind.  But ask
yourself...on the basis of what do you understand that universe and was it
there before you understood it, and if so, in what sense?  What does it
mean to say that something IS?  And can anything BE without the being for
whom it appears as a phenomenon?  Does being make sense if you use the term
this way?  And how would you propose to separate being from intelligibility?
>
>> This world IS enchanted.  We all know it everytime we come together at
>> a great gathering like F&F or Harmony.  I know it when I spend time
>> alone in the wilderness.  And as children I think we all knew it too,
>> before indoctrination into consensus reality...which I see as nothing
>> other than the lowest common denominator among the phenomena of human
>> existence.  We owe ourselves more than that.
>
>	I hate arguing against romantic ideas, because I'm a romantic
>myself despite believing in a common reality.  But there's no Santa Claus
>in the sense in which Virginia asked the question (there's not really a
>man who spends Christmas Eve flying around in a sleigh delivering gifts)
>even if he can be said to exist in the spirit of human generosity on some
>level.
>	We have the subjective ability to experience the world as a
>magical, enchanted place, and I'm sure glad we do, or life would be rather
>boring.  But acknowledging a common reality can be wonderful as well.  It
>allows us to have beautiful experiences together, instead of just on our
>own.  If we can't even achieve consensus on reality, how can we hope to
>achieve consensus on anything else?
>
I'm not sure why you wrote this.  I'm certainly not arguing against
consensus reality or saying that we should ignore it - far from it, as
should have been clear from my closing comment "to stand up to what 'they'
say and stand apart from it when appropriate".  I'm simply saying that as
the lowest common denominator we shouldn't make it (or anything you or I or
anyone else says) our god, that we should remain open to the possibility of
a richer, fuller existence, and most of all that we should be true to
ouselves in the sense of honoring the phenomena of our experience.
>
>	Sometimes I get the feeling that there is a hope among many that
>certain "mysteries of life" will continue to defy rational explanation.
>But this is a needless hope -- individually, most of us will never
>understand the workings of an internal combustion engine, let alone the
>nature of the universe, so why begrudge the possibility of that knowledge
>to humanity as a whole?
>
I agree completely with the first sentence and study science because I
think it does uncover something which the "new mysterians" would like to
believe will remain concealed.  As far as complete and certain knowledge, I
think it's impossible because each domain of science (or any other way of
knowing) is cutting a linear path through something with more dimensions
than that.  Each gives a perspective on the whole, but only a perspective.
>
>> I think
>> we're only beginning to understand the connections between art and
>> science, and partly because we are begining to see them I think the
>> future holds great hope for the re-enchantment of the world.  It's all
>> up to us as individual members within our communities to be true to the
>> phenomena of our experience and to live our lives accordingly, and to
>> stand up to what 'they' say and stand apart from what 'they' do when
>> appropriate.
>
>	Quite so.  But I maintain that one of these appropriate times is
>when someone like Terrence McKenna claims that the world is ending in
>2012.  But if we make the language mallable enough, of course he could be
>corrrect -- just like if we say that Santa Claus exists, black is white,
>night is day, there is no racism today, and driving a BMW is the key to
>happiness, we could be correct too -- if we use imaginative definitions.
>
I agree here too.  Of course the term 'world' in our language signifies a
cultural phenomenon.  We say the world of sports and the world of politics
and the world of art.  We talk about possible world and the world of Greek
theater and the world of the 21st century.  World means something like
domain, not the rocky wet planet we stand upon, and this is important to
keep in mind when trying to understand what McKenna is talking about.  I've
read several of his books, and I think he's certainly on the lunatric
fringe, but his stuff about the end of the world comes from Mayan culture
and the world for the Mayans is the human cultural world, just as it is for
us.  It may be that the world of these last 400 or so years is coming to an
end - every other world has - this only history will tell.  But he's
certainly not talking about armageddon or the end of everything in some
Christian sense.
>
>	The reality of having different subjective experiences of the
>same reality shouldn't blind us from recognizing that that reality
>exists, even if none of us see it quite the same.
>	PLUR stands for peace, love, UNITY and respect. Where's the unity
>if there's nothing real to experience together?
And the reality which we can come to consensus on shouldn't blind one to
richness of the phenomena of one's own existence, nor should it be used to
diminish or demean those phenomena for others.  Where's the peace and love
without RESPECT?

with respect,

-David


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~ ~~~ ~~ ~ ~
David Ginsberg
Student of Neurophenomenology and the Human Condition
University of California, Berkeley
ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu
<http://www.geocities.com/athens/2001>
....................................
You are never given a wish without also being given the power to make it
true.  You may have to work for it, however.  -Richard Bach
~ ~ ~~ ~~~ ~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

You know...If I never see another chain letter again, it wouldn't be soon 
enough.  Why pollute a list with such garbage?  I don't want to 
participate in that crap.  If you receive one and really feel like 
sending it to someone, just send it to people you know -- not to me!

I'm sure other people feel this, but I just had to say something.  This 
list has a high enough volume that I have a hard time keeping up with it 
(too busy).  Stuff like this has NOTHING to do with raves, but is far 
beyond an NRR label.  It really has no social or political relevance.  I 
really think it has no place on this list.

Blah, blah, blah,
- Dre

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Nov 20 11:49:53 1996

Received: from dfw-ix8.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id LAA25753; Wed, 20 Nov 1996 11:49:40 -0800 (PST)
Received: from 199.35.221.211 (sdx-ca6-19.ix.netcom.com [199.35.221.211]) by dfw-ix8.ix.netcom.com (8.6.13/8.6.12) with SMTP id LAA15266; Wed, 20 Nov 1996 11:48:26 -0800

lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu wrote:
