 with SMTP (Apple Internet Mail Server 1.1b2d4); Wed, 20 Nov 1996 11:59:04 -0800
Message-Id: <v02130509aeb91219790f@[157.22.229.127]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 20 Nov 1996 11:59:34 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: peter@niles.com (Customer Service)
Subject: So There I Was,      <NRR>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

So there I was, hanging out in Leicester Square, waiting on Nigel and
Beanbag to show up.  I was broke and hungry and cold, and to make matters
worse, my drawers were soaking wet from the rain.

Nigel had told me to meet him at the pub because he had some information
about a kid named Truffles who was in the tank in Holland.  Truffles was
busted for some passport problem, and he'd left 20,000 Es in a locker at
the ferry terminal in Rotterdam.

Nigel had the scoop on the locker number, and he was going to tell me how
to pop the door open and snag the Es before Truffles got out of the tank.

So it was pouring rain when Nigel and Beanbag show up, and we go inside the
pub for a warmer and to talk about the crime.

"Please don't go along with this stupid plan, Boomerang!"  Beanbag tried to
tell me.  "Truffles never did anything to hurt you.  Why should you go all
the way to Holland to pinch a bunch of Es from someone who's never done
anything to you?"

Beanbag wasn't too hip on the idea, she had all these wonderful things to
say about karma and respect and what she's learned on the rave circuit.
But me and Nigel, we're incoorigible hooligans, right nasty bastards when
you think about it.  Besides, we both know that raves aren't about nothing
but scoring money and Es and maybe a bird to bring home to the sack.

So when Beanbag started putting up a fuss, Nigel told her to cram it and
sent her up to the bar for 3 pints.  While she was gone we got down to
business:   Truffles had left Amsterdam with 20,000 Es, and stuffed them in
a locker at the ferry port in Rotterdam, just to keep it cool while he was
waiting for the boat back home.  Well, he ran into some trouble with the
coppers, and when his passport didn't check out,  they stuck him in the can
for a couple of weeks. He'd called home for help, and pretty soon word got
around about the Es in locker number 715.

Since I was broke, Nigel told me to beat it on down to the dockyards and
get to guffing with one of the sailors, see if I could swing a ride across
the channel to Rotterdam in the hold of a boat.

Nigel, nasty poof that he is, didn't have the decency to lend me 10 quid
for carfare down to the docks, so I had to nick a motorbike from Covent
Garden, which I properly rolled into the Thames when I was finished with
it.

Down at the docks, I got to chatting with a lad named Bill,  he was a
rugged old meathead, teeth all rotten from snorting too much nitrate.  The
old lunk worked on one of the boats, said he could stow me in the hold and
take me over to Rotterdam.  All he wanted in return, he said, was was a
little bit of company now and again.

Well, it wasn't until my first night in the hold that I figured out what he
meant by "company".  I'd got to thinking he wanted to guff it up about
football scores and such, but on no, my friends.  Bill showed up in the
hold that night, eyelids a-fluttering and ready for company.  I put up my
dukes and was ready to fight my way through hell and high water, but old
Bill threatened to yell for the captain and if I didn't loosen up.

Let me tell you, friends, I went through five days of hell, being tossed
about by the waves during the day, and tossed about by old Bill at night.
The man was a frightful savage, committing the most uncivilised acts
imaginable on my poor body.  I'm not much of a softy, but by my third day,
I was in tears at the very thought of my next visit from Bill.  Sometimes
got to thinking I should have listened to Beanbag when she warned me about
karma and all that happy bollocks.

My only consolation was the promise of those 20,000 Es in locker #715.
20,000 Es could last me quite a long time,  and thinking about ripping off
that poor sop Truffles made my suffering manageable.

On the fifth night in the hold of the rusty old vomit-bucket, the door
swung open and I braced myself from another onslaught from sailor Bill.
Instead, there in the door, was the Captain himself.

"Keeping company for that scalawag Bill, are ya, lad?"

"Please, sir,"  I begged.  "Don't send me back to London.  I need to get to
Holland by the end of the week.  I have important business there, and Bill
promised me a ride."

"Holland, eh?  Ahh, that old pirate!"  the captain smiled knowingly.  "I
supposed he neglected to mention that this here vessel is a charter barge
running up and down the River Thames!"

>I think we're only beginning to understand the connections between art and
>>science,

hey everyone,

 I noticed that this came up once or twice recently, so

if anyone is interested there is a very worthwhile book called "the artfull
eye" (Oxford U. Press) which is brand new and very, very good (IMO) and it
is right on this subject.

 It specifically is all about understanding art, has cool sections about
"chemical dreams", is pretty readable (at least on comparison to most books
published by universities... ).

The authors are world class cognitive scientists who are really insightful
into a wide spectrum of neat stuff <<like aesthetics/ cognitive science/
art history/episomology/psychology/psycho-pharmacology>> and teach you all
about the vision+your brain+how its wired +  how & why it does what it
does...

so, if your interested in that sort of thing, check it out...

+ tell me how you like it (and if it does anything for your CArtesian anxiety!)

I bought mine at COdy's in Berkeley (telegraph at haste/510 845 7852)


:)

qsip


PS. has anyone out there read a book called "the red queen"? I think its
about darwin + evolution

     seestone-
     
     i suggest if you really want to find the perfect job that you invest a 
     little time and effort into reading "Think and Grow Rich" by Napoleon 
     Hill.  There is a chapter specifically aimed toward people trying to 
     get the perfect job.  
     
     Don't focus on whether there's an opening or not, focus on what you 
     can GIVE.  Companies are always looking for a person who knows their 
     own personal strenghts and weaknesses, becuase there are SO FEW.  As 
     far as dress codes with blue-situs and tyedies, many big companies are 
     loosening up their dress code.  Hey, I can even wear my ADIDAS tm  to 
     work at Harris-Farinon!:)
     
     Going by Napoleon's model, which I believe includes preparing a brief 
     to present to the company, you should be able to go to ANY company, 
     big or small and get the job you want.  My advice to you is to start 
     researching companies that you want to work for to find out if you 
     really want to work for them or not.    
     
     help this hopes!
     
     fogdeep
     cc:  anyone who wants to put their life in their own hands...

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

Looking for housemates for a 3 BR/2 Bath house in San Carlos, which is
about 15-20 minutes south of San Fransisco.
Look at all these great features:
- About 2000 square feet.
- Nice Hillside location
- Wood deck
- Backyard
- Extra family room (music listening/computer room?)
- 2 (possibly 3) car garage
- and lotsa storage!

I am a software engineer at Apple Computer, and a budding DJ. I have used
to do radio shows on KFJC where I would spin an ambeint mix, and did live
events. I also play drums and guitar occaisonally, and would be wanting to
have parties once in a while (not too often; I'm no party animal or
anything). If there is enough interest, I may work on putting wiring in for
a shared Internet connection. Obviously, I would only do this if the costs
were split by everyone.
I would prefer professionals in the computer/technical fields of any
gender, race, age, etc. However, I would like people who also are into
alternative/experimental music since this is what I listen to:
ambient/techno/dub/psychedelia/whatever. Also, anyone with a a sampler or a
pair of Technics SL-1200's gets special brownie points!!
No flakes or drug abusers!! If you fit in this category, I do not want you.
But the bottom-line is I am looking for anyone who is responsible and easy
to get along with.

Available December 5. Hurry!

Rent will be $675/month + last + security deposit.
Contact Doug at 408-974-5913 or 408-972-9177. Or reply to this email.

doug

> Anyone here ever hear of a European musician/artist/group
> called "Bjork" (pronounced bee-YERK)?  Where can their
> music be had?  Not sure if she/they can be called house
> music or rave-related, but from what I have heard, it 
> is possible, since it really thumped.

Bjork is a singer from Iceland. Before her solo career
she was with the Sugarcubes. She's really big in Europe now.
If she ever makes it to the West Coast, don't miss her concert.
For me, she's one of the best on stage.
There's a lot of information on the www about her. Check out: 
http://www.yahoo.com/entertainment/music/artists/bj_rk
(a lot of links)
I don't know how to call her music style. It's a mix
of a lot of styles. 


Thomas

>>Anyone here ever hear of a European musician/artist/group
>>called "Bjork" (pronounced bee-YERK)?  Where can their
>>music be had?  Not sure if she/they can be called house
>>music or rave-related, but from what I have heard, it=20
>>is possible, since it really thumped.
>ahh, Bjork..........the love of my life!!  Formerly of the SugarCubes. =20
>She's got two CD's out : Debut and Post.  I think she's married (or=20
>engaged) to super jungle star Goldie.

This annoying Icelandic vocalist is INDEED at least engaged to Goldie (who
opened for her during her last European tour), and rumours circulated early
this summer about her being pregnant.
As far as her music goes, it's not really house or rave-related in original,
however she chose to have big names from the house/techno scene (David
Morales, Todd Terry, LFO, Towa Tei, and a few others) remix most of her back
catalogue earlier this year. Most of the mixes were released as "extremely
limited promos", but still sold in stores like Wherehouse and Virgin. Can we
say "CASH RULES EVERYTHING AROUND ME"? Anyway, LFO did a pretty good job on=
=20
Hyperballad, and if you like Bj=F6rk AND house/techno I suggest you check it=
=20
out. =3D)

reespect, jonas

quoth Jeff
>
>   I am looking for them SL-1200's...  
> I need prices & Addresses/Links.. Anywhere in the world.
> Under 300 would be a dream come true right?

Good luck. I searched long and hard for 1200s at that price; but, 
everyone seemed to want $400. I did once hear of a pair with carts and 
Gemini Scratchmaster for $650 but I didn't have any money then. 

I ended up buying new at Guitar Center. I was able to weasle them down to 
$450 after I told them that Az-Iz had quoted me that price (they did) and 
that I was going to be in LA the next week anyway (i wasn't.) Guitar 
Center gave me the old "let me check with my maneger" line, and insisted 
that $450 was below their cost; love that price matching policy. 
Surprised the hell out of me, when the poodle haired rock'n'roll guys 
came up with the best price.

On Tue, 19 Nov 1996, Pablo Beck wrote:

> and I DID infact hear about a driver'candy-flipping'. I wasn't sure wether
> it was true or not and
> I in no way tried to make fun of the tragedy.

	I did not jump on your post because I felt you were making fun of 
a tradegy. Instead because it was another circulation of rumors. The 
driver was not found to be candy-flipping. I know some of what was found 
but I do not think I am suppose to say anything because I may be called 
as a witness.

	The reason I do not like hearing the story change (although that 
may be inevitable) is more because with the change in story, the facts 
get lost and people forget what happened, or those who were not there 
hear so many different stories, all of the stories are written off as 
rumors. Does anyone know why the jeep rolled off the road when Malachy 
was hurt back when Come-Unity was started? I do not know the reason, but 
I have heard stories from people I trust enough to think they wouldn't be 
talking out of their ass on the subject. Might we benefit from knowing? I 
really do not know. From my experience, issues like this do not change 
people's lives enough - they do for a short time, but over the haul, we 
easily slip back into our comfortable lives.
	Someone talked about telling people they love them now instead of
later... And I look at that and ask why that isn't done regularly, or why
people are acting in such a way that it NEEDS to be communicated. I can
understand telling one's family that because that whole growing up thing
can create a huge gap between family members. Anyway, back to my point.  I
see as temporary stress relief or the individual, but what good is it
going to do unless the underlying problems are fixed?
	Someone wrote that I (since I am part of EVERY one) take my life
for granted, that I take having people around for granted, and that at the
end of the day I must think I am immortal because of the way I act. Yet,
it is the very reason that I am mortal, that at any moment I might be
wiped out or possibly worse might come back totally different even through
no fault of my own, that I dance; it is the energy that wells up from
inside of me from those sources which makes me like the gabber I used to
spin and hopefully will again soon.

dave

you guys much since my life just escaped being sucked down the toilet :)

i've moved in with a DJ who spins mostly ambient which is nice after a 
frantic day at work :)  what a relief to be away from that insane loser i 
WAS living with!

Last weekend i attended an amusing little event in a mansion in Victoria 
... the organizer was this sleezy cheeseball who looked like Michael 
Bolton.  *shudder*  marvelous music, massage tables, nice visuals, fresh 
fruit, and NO VIBE AT ALL!! *sigh*  at least the music KICKED.  someone 
played a great prog. house version of Roadhouse Blues around about 4am 
... and also right about then it begane to SNOW!  so we all built a 
snowman.  it was fun.

But i still miss all of you and realllllly hope to make it back down 
there by late spring/early summer .....

pounce

>I was just wondering if anyone out there could hook me up with a list of
>CD's Mark Farina has put out. I bought Mushroom Jazz cause I liked the
>cover and fell in love with the CD. One of my buddy's said he had one
>out called Seasons, but a list would be greatly appreciated.

I recently picked up "Seasons One" used at R******s Records on Haight
St for about $9.95. It's out on Domestic Records, distributed by
Moonshine Music, c. 1996.

this is mostly mellow 125 BPM "house" music, nothing to write the
mothership about, but generally "nice" and "pretty"... My favorite cuts
are:
	Downtime by Paper Music
	Past by RMA
	Nu Slow Dub by Tranquil Elephantizer

i don't know what you'd call this kind of music Chicago House, Nu Groove?
Something like that. Might as well make up a name for it so you can
sound all erudite dancing about architecture and talking about music.

Greetings from Tapei!

I guess in order to make this rave related, I have to relate an unusal
experience: The airline actually played Banco De Gaia which was a trip.
Also Dead can Dance.... nifty..

Tapei:

Very lush countryside, very muggy. The highways are in *much* better shape
than in Ca. The city looks like a giant Oakland, unfortunately the bad
parts... lots of ramshackled hi-rise tenaments. Very high density. 

Thousands and thousands of.... scooters. This must be the scooter capital
of the world, they are *everywhere*

I am suprised at just how "U.S. friendly" it is(lots of signs in English,
a lot of the inhabitants speak English.) I have also seen at least two Doc
Marten stores which is weird. Great food, great service, and instead of
napkins everyone gives you warm towels(with it being as muggy as it is you
need them.)

I am going to look for ravers,  anyone know the Chinese words for
"Harmony," or "Friends and Family?" ;-)

                                        Black Adder

Hello Everyone =)
I'm back on this list 'cos I need to stay in tune with the scene and 'cos We
at Mantra need help.
If anybody out there knows of any potential space we can use for the next
Mantra (Dec 6th) then please, please let me know. We need 2 rooms if possible
and space for up to 400-500 (maybe less) people. Any ideas?? We have
connections with the usual spaces that have been severely overused, but we're
looking for something "new" that we at Mantra haven't used before. It is so
hard to get spaces in this city - unbelievable. What's up with that?
Anyway, we have some money for a space and we have back up ideas for less
desirable places with general bad vibes floating around. If necessary we'll
just have to totally transform one of these with our magickal powers =) It's
been done before that's for sure - anybody check out Mantra at Cat's Grill
(Clementina Alley) This place took some work and so did Big Heart City, a
nasty place for the most part but we managed to transform it.
We're also looking for new fluorescent black art back drops for
trade/rent/sale if anybody has any info on that.....
Thanks for any help with all of this.
Love light and trance-formation

At 08:55 PM 11/20/96 -0800, you wrote:


{snip}
> Might we benefit from knowing? I 
>really do not know. From my experience, issues like this do not change 
>people's lives enough - they do for a short time, but over the haul, we 
>easily slip back into our comfortable lives.


Unfortunately, you are right.  This doesn't always happen, but more often
than not.

>	Someone talked about telling people they love them now instead of
>later... And I look at that and ask why that isn't done regularly, or why
>people are acting in such a way that it NEEDS to be communicated. I can
>understand telling one's family that because that whole growing up thing
>can create a huge gap between family members. Anyway, back to my point.  I
>see as temporary stress relief or the individual, but what good is it
>going to do unless the underlying problems are fixed?

This is true, but in many cases (at least for me), it helps quite a bit
to know that even though there may be problems in a relationship, that the
underlying love is the most important thing, and that it makes it worth
some of the crap that makes people grow apart.

It may also be a firm first step towards fixing the underlying problems.

FIRST - sorry I sent the last message - It wasn't done, as if you
couldn't tell.  Anyway,

At 08:55 PM 11/20/96 -0800, Dave Bayer <dlb@OCF.Berkeley.EDU> wrote:

{snip}
> Might we benefit from knowing? I 
>really do not know. From my experience, issues like this do not change 
>people's lives enough - they do for a short time, but over the haul, we 
>easily slip back into our comfortable lives.


Unfortunately, you are right.  This doesn't always happen, but more often
than not.

>	Someone talked about telling people they love them now instead of
>later... And I look at that and ask why that isn't done regularly, or why
>people are acting in such a way that it NEEDS to be communicated. I can
>understand telling one's family that because that whole growing up thing
>can create a huge gap between family members. Anyway, back to my point.  I
>see as temporary stress relief or the individual, but what good is it
>going to do unless the underlying problems are fixed?


This is true, but in many cases (at least for me), it helps quite a bit
to know that even though there may be problems in a friendship, that the
underlying love and caring feelings that you have ARE STILL THERE.

Knowing that someone loves you even though you may drive each other
apeshit once in a while can really help (at least for me) to work out
some problems.

It may also be a firm first step towards fixing the underlying problems.


>	Someone wrote that I (since I am part of EVERY one) take my life
>for granted, that I take having people around for granted, and that at the
>end of the day I must think I am immortal because of the way I act. Yet,
>it is the very reason that I am mortal, that at any moment I might be
>wiped out or possibly worse might come back totally different even through
>no fault of my own, that I dance; it is the energy that wells up from
>inside of me from those sources which makes me like the gabber I used to
>spin and hopefully will again soon.
>

Exactly - live the moment, don't vanish without sharing the love you feel.

Hope this makes sense, and sorry about the space that made me send this message
twice (well,almost).

Pat
Boulder Creek

Dear SFRavefriends,

	I'll add my voice to Andre's here -- for once, I'm in favor of
removing something from the list.  8)
	The only exception I'd make is for the truly amusing ones.
There's always enough bandwidth for levity, imho.  For the rest, if we
must endure them, could we have a new filter?  I suggest "IRR" for
"irrational."  ;)

Much love,
				<<< Starchild >>>

P.S. - If you pass on a chain letter, you are destined to be cast into
the fiery pits of hell without a toothbrush or deoderant.  Just thought
you should know.

My computer tells me that on Wed, 20 Nov 1996, Andre Lucero shared:

> You know...If I never see another chain letter again, it wouldn't be soon 
> enough.  Why pollute a list with such garbage?  I don't want to 
> participate in that crap.  If you receive one and really feel like 
> sending it to someone, just send it to people you know -- not to me!
> 
> I'm sure other people feel this, but I just had to say something.  This 
> list has a high enough volume that I have a hard time keeping up with it 
> (too busy).  Stuff like this has NOTHING to do with raves, but is far 
> beyond an NRR label.  It really has no social or political relevance.  I 
> really think it has no place on this list.
> 
> Blah, blah, blah,
> - Dre

the real logistical difficulty, as i see it, is that you have to have
containers for all that jello to chill... the jello will be very hot when
you take it off the stove, so depending on what the wading pool is made out
of, the jello might melt it :( so we might need a _lot_ of
pots/bowls/tupperware...

love,

brian

it ambient music, that should get it in the mood... ;)

This annoying Icelandic vocalist is INDEED at least engaged to Goldie =
(who
opened for her during her last European tour), and rumours circulated =
early
this summer about her being pregnant.
As far as her music goes, it's not really house or rave-related in =
original,
however she chose to have big names from the house/techno scene (David
Morales, Todd Terry, LFO, Towa Tei, and a few others) remix most of her =
back
catalogue earlier this year. Most of the mixes were released as =
"extremely
limited promos", but still sold in stores like Wherehouse and Virgin. Can =
we
say "CASH RULES EVERYTHING AROUND ME"? Anyway, LFO did a pretty good job =
on 
Hyperballad, and if you like Bj=F6rk AND house/techno I suggest you check =
it 
out. =3D)

reespect, jonas

> > Anyone here ever hear of a European musician/artist/group
> > called "Bjork" (pronounced bee-YERK)?  Where can their
> > music be had?  Not sure if she/they can be called house
> > music or rave-related, but from what I have heard, it 
> > is possible, since it really thumped.

> 
> Bjork is married to Goldie, the drum and bass kingpin
> 

Last I heard they were splitsville. 

Bjork was also the one that nut tried to send a parcel bomb to
which was supposed to have sprayed whoever opened it with acid.
Fortunately it was intercepted before it was delivered.

Bjork's remixes are in general excellent (IMHO), esp Hyperballad -
there are many many remix CDs out - you can find them at Tower,
Blockbuster, etc. There are also many many versions of the same song,
at least 8 of Hyperballad - the "Girl's Blouse Mix" is generally
regarded as perhaps the best, so look out for that. The remixes 
are much more interesting than the original source material from her 
2 albums ("Debut" and "Post"). She's geting ready to release a 
full-length CD of remixes from Post, called "Telegraph" in the 
New Year. 

- Martin  =]

Greetings and love to all of you out there! (or in there!)
I don't mean to rehash everything that's already been said about 
eLevAtion but I just had to let all you guys know how powerful it was to 
Ben, Andrew, and me.
We left the bay area at about 7 on saturday evening. Got to the campsite 
in the beautiful and generally deserted Angeles National Forest at about 
1:00. We had the supreme pleasure of meeting Jbondy (who along with the 
other organizers and volunteers did an incredible job at establishing 
the vibe and all the li'l things that make a difference!). Most of the 
people that I spoke to were surprised to know that we had driven down 
all the way from s.f.for Elevation. Hey! it was calling out to us for 
weeks via socalraves.
We walked in and found a small tent city and also Our Man In L.A. a.k.a. 
Afzal. The dj at the time was (excuse my ignorance if I'm wrong) 
Tamerlane who rocked. I do not particularly like classifying music but 
I'd be curious if anybody who was there can tell me what they think his 
set consisted of.
I also got to meet Tiffany (Hi!) The table with the free food, fruit, and 
water was sweet.
I forget the progression of dj's but the music was in the cosmic realm 
all night long. That heady mix of house, straight trance, and goa managed 
to seamlessly integrate itself into a unified whole. just the way I'd 
like my life to be. 
Saw the most divine sunrise ever. The set and setting was perfect. I 
understand exactly what Geoge Harrison is talking about in "Here Comes 
The Sun." I stood by myself watching the sun rise through the clouds and 
feeling the source working it's magic.
I was amazed at how colorfully all of you were decked out. It was 
excellent eye and mind candy. Some of you looked like you were 
ready to make the transition to pure energy right there and then.
Especially Mason and the guy with the cool bright orange pants and long
braided hair. 

Toys>>>>
Thank you for the hand warmers. Kept me going for a long time.
The silver cloth/paper that was strung from the top of the tree with the 
specks of sunlight reflecting on it was sublime.
I don't even want to start about my intense love affair with the soap 
bubble machine to the left of the d.j. Suffice it to say, we had a great 
time together.
GoodE with his camcorder provided us with some truly beautiful snapshots 
of time & space.
The goddess with the two soap bubble guns zapped us more than once with 
blasts of energy.
Speaker Kidz and Speaker Hugz>>>>>
Thank you all for your role in shaping my reality and making it a happy 
and beautiful one. I lost myself and jacked into the main matrix in a 
speaker hug with about twenty other people. T'was most powerful indeed! 
The group hug right before the group photo and the spontaneous circle 
that formed afterwards reinforced to me why we do what we do.

We'd like to thank all of you for all that you gave us. You kids know 
what's up!
Thank you Andy and Brad for spinning those rekkids and taking me to the 
moon. The last couple of records that Brad played just took me far far away.

Hi to Luciano, Jbondy, Tom, Mason, Crunch (long time no see), Tiffany, 
Audrey and all the rest of you whose names we can't remember but whose 
faces and smiles are imprinted in our heads for life and beyond!The 
portal was opened at eLevAtion 2. Keep it open, always!
LOVE, HAPPINESS, AND THE RELENTLESS QUEST FOR THE COSMIC
Bom Shanker!
Dhiren & Ben

From: "Thompson. Jim" <jthompson@arkons.lmsc.lockheed.com>
To: sfraves - send mail to list <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Imagination without Knowledge Cannot be Creative - (RR)
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 1996 09:36:00 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.993.5
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Please excuse the somewhat random structure of the following - this is
meant as a posting to SFRaves, not a term paper!


We think in terms of language.  Without advanced language concepts
one is incapable (in general) of having advanced thoughts.  Why
do we remember so little of our childhood up until the age of
3 or 4?  It is because we do not have the language skills to
make sense of our surroundings.  We can have vague rememberances
of places or events but no strong recollections because we tend
to remember (think) in terms of language concepts.  Noam Chomsky
posits that language constructs are actually "hard-wired" into
the human brain.  That is why children have such an amazing
ability to acquire language skills.

There is a latin saying "Namen est Nomen" meaning "to name is
to know".  It has been recognized for centuries that once you
put a name to something (a concept, say) you are now "conscious"
(have knowledge) of it.  A large part of learning a new subject is
learning all the definitions ("names") that go with that subject....

Your imaginings are confined to the level of your knowledge.

To emphasize imagination and creativity over knowledge and logic
is a creative dead-end.  People like to make a big deal over
"non-linear" thinking and reality, but the concept of non-linear
systems and thinking is itself a result of advanced mathematical
concepts.  People could not "see" the patterns of nature that
are fractal in nature until the mathematical concepts of fractals,
chaos and non-linearity were invented.

To have a higher conciousness (knowledge) one must first pass
through lower stages of conciousness (knowledge).  What is
conciousness but knowledge (of one's own state or of concepts
or of reality)?

To separate conciousness and creativity from knowledge and empiricism
is quite simply impossible....

To be creative at a higher level, one must have knowledge at a higher
level.



refutations gladly accepted!


        jim thompson - cube root fact axon info grid data fate

Hey Jim and all!

> There is a latin saying "Namen est Nomen" meaning "to name is
> to know".  It has been recognized for centuries that once you
> put a name to something (a concept, say) you are now "conscious"
> (have knowledge) of it.  A large part of learning a new subject is
> learning all the definitions ("names") that go with that subject....

Now while I somewhat agree with you here, I have to point out that there
are other schools of thought that say, the more you can name things,
the more separate you are from them...what do you think about that?

> Your imaginings are confined to the level of your knowledge.
> To emphasize imagination and creativity over knowledge and logic
> is a creative dead-end.  

Agreed; what you're talking about seems similar to that whole
pop psychology new agey "right-brain vs left brain" thing that is so
silly :o)

>People like to make a big deal over
> "non-linear" thinking and reality, but the concept of non-linear
> systems and thinking is itself a result of advanced mathematical
> concepts.  People could not "see" the patterns of nature that
> are fractal in nature until the mathematical concepts of fractals,
> chaos and non-linearity were invented.
 
Ah, perception is in the "eye" of the beholder?  What happens when you
transcend your senses? ;oD
And was "chaos" really invented by humans, or is it just our "language" to
partially describe a phenomenon that existed way before we did?

> To have a higher conciousness (knowledge) one must first pass
> through lower stages of conciousness (knowledge).  What is
> conciousness but knowledge (of one's own state or of concepts
> or of reality)?

It seems to me that there are at least two different parts to this
consciousness/knowledge.  One is more about particulars, and one about
generalities.  I.E.,  identification, and ?intuition? for lack of
a better word.  You know that instant where you have sort of grasped the
overall something-ness...but you can't name it just yet...but you still
know, intuit, something about it without its particulars being defined?
(Am I making sense, or am I just %o} ?)

To me the "creative" part of consciousness is more in line with this
"generality" knowledge.  Again, this is just my wee l'il opinion :o)

I guess I should go ahead and say goodbye so's that I don't waste
another posting...I'm going to India day after tomorrow :oD  
It's 90% probable that I won't have this job (this account ;) ) when I
get back, and I don't know if I'll have email access when I move to
Santa Cruz in January.  So, I just wanted to say goodbye, and tell y'all
how much I enjoyed being on this group...I hope to be in touch again,
and meet more of you folks, if not thru the list then at future parties!

hope you all have great holidays and lots of fun in advance ;),
love,
shamini

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Nov 21 12:24:12 1996

To: sfraves - send mail to list <sfraves@hyperreal.com>,
        Shamini Jain
	 <shamini@alois.icon.palo-alto.med.va.gov>
Subject: RE: Imagination...and goodbye :^(
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 1996 12:10:00 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.993.5
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

to:  Shamini Jain


Howdy!  Too bad you're leaving!  You're perfect SFRave material!  ;-)
Hope you can get back on the list when you return!


I wrote:

>> There is a latin saying "Namen est Nomen" meaning "to name is
>> to know".  It has been recognized for centuries that once you
>> put a name to something (a concept, say) you are now "conscious"
>> (have knowledge) of it.  A large part of learning a new subject is
>> learning all the definitions ("names") that go with that subject....

You wrote:

>Now while I somewhat agree with you here, I have to point out that there
>are other schools of thought that say, the more you can name things,
>the more separate you are from them...what do you think about that?

	Really?  I don't get this!  It seems to me that the MORE
	you can name things the more CONNECTED you are!
	For example, if I am in a field of wildflowers of types I have
	never seen before, it would appear to me to be just a
	jumble of leaves, flowers, colors, etc.  But once I know the
	names of all the different flowers, I can see each one as a
	separate entity, making me more "connected" to each one
	(more aware of each one).....


I wrote:

>>People like to make a big deal over
>> "non-linear" thinking and reality, but the concept of non-linear
>> systems and thinking is itself a result of advanced mathematical
>> concepts.  People could not "see" the patterns of nature that
>> are fractal in nature until the mathematical concepts of fractals,
>> chaos and non-linearity were invented.

You wrote:

> Ah, perception is in the "eye" of the beholder?  What happens when you
> transcend your senses? ;oD
> And was "chaos" really invented by humans, or is it just our "language" to
> partially describe a phenomenon that existed way before we did?

	I don't believe you can create in your mind something out
	of nothing.  Our brains work mainly by making associations
	with things we are familiar with.  The more things you are
	familiar with, the more possible associations you can make,
	 the more possible associations you can make  the more
	"creative" you can be.

	This is actually one of my "pet" interests.  Human brains
	are very poor at making "random" associations whereas
	computers are great at making (albeit pseudo) random associations
	that would not normally occur to us.  My signature is from a
	program I wrote to randomly pair 4 letter words ("fact axon"
	and "data fate" were 2 I liked!).

	I think one of the main attractions humans have to mind altering
	substances is that we believe they help us make novel
	associations.....

I wrote:

>> To have a higher conciousness (knowledge) one must first pass
>> through lower stages of conciousness (knowledge).  What is
>> conciousness but knowledge (of one's own state or of concepts
>> or of reality)?

You wrote:

> It seems to me that there are at least two different parts to this
> consciousness/knowledge.  One is more about particulars, and one about
> generalities.  I.E.,  identification, and ?intuition? for lack of
> a better word.  You know that instant where you have sort of grasped the
> overall something-ness...but you can't name it just yet...but you still
> know, intuit, something about it without its particulars being defined?
> Am I making sense, or am I just %o} ?)

> To me the "creative" part of consciousness is more in line with this
> "generality" knowledge.  Again, this is just my wee l'il opinion :o)

	I know what you're saying and agree to some extent.
	The more restrictive the conditions in which you operate
	the more restricted you are in the possible creative solutions....
	But conversely, the more "knowledge" you can bring to
	a given set of conditions, the more possible solutions you
	can create....

	You can "know" things without being able to quite put
	your finger on it.  One is not always conscious of why
	you feel something is the correct thing to do.  The problem
	with this sort of knowledge is that it is prone to error.
	You may "feel" (it's obvious, right?) that (to use a dreary
	example) raising taxes will bring in more money to the
	government.  History (and analysis) will show that this is
	not necessarily so....


        jim thompson - cube root fact axon info grid data fate

        .:..:::::  ....:::.....::.:::::::::..     .. :..:::::
        .:.:..:.. ..:  ...::::..:. . ...:: : .... :........:.:
        .....  ::...   .:::::::    ...:::: ...  :..... ..::...
        :::..:::....:: .:......::..   :::::.::         ::.....

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Nov 21 12:44:09 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id MAA01543; Thu, 21 Nov 1996 12:44:09 -0800 (PST)
Received: from starbase.starfishsoftware.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with SMTP id MAA01521; Thu, 21 Nov 1996 12:44:02 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <199611212044.MAA01521@taz.hyperreal.com>
Date: Thu, 21 Nov 1996 12:40:00 -0800
From: Roy Feague <rfeague@starfishsoftware.com>
Subject: RE: Imagination without Knowledge Cannot
To: "Thompson. Jim" <jthompson@arkons.lmsc.lockheed.com>
Cc: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
X-Mailer: Worldtalk (NetConnex V4.00a)/MIME
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


"Language shapes thought."
 It's true, and I find a lot of merit in what you are saying, up to a   
point.  To name _is_ to know, that may be true, but the inverse is not.   
 In order for language and thought to progress, it _must_ be possible to   
conceive of something new, before it is named, and then name it.   
 Otherwise language and knowledge would never grow.  So the naming and   
lingual framing is an important step in cementing a new understanding,   
and may lead to further new understanding, but there is, and must be,   
that gossamer leading rim of consciousness that extends outside of   
language; it's this elusive part, I think, that one strives to focus on   
when one talks of emphasizing imagination in efforts towards creativity.

So,
>Without advanced language concepts
>one is incapable (in general) of having advanced thoughts.
Perhaps one is less able to retain and further explore advanced thoughts,   
but it seems clear that novel thoughts must be unnamed when they are   
first conceived.

>Why
>do we remember so little of our childhood up until the age of
>3 or 4?  It is because we do not have the language skills to
>make sense of our surroundings.  We can have vague rememberances
>of places or events but no strong recollections because we tend
>to remember (think) in terms of language concepts.
I'll bet you're right.

>There is a latin saying "Namen est Nomen" meaning "to name is
>to know".  It has been recognized for centuries that once you
>put a name to something (a concept, say) you are now "conscious"
>(have knowledge) of it.  A large part of learning a new subject is
>learning all the definitions ("names") that go with that subject....
So retention and solid comprehension is aided by language.

>Your imaginings are confined to the level of your knowledge.
Woah!  This is where I think you're going too far!  :)

>To emphasize imagination and creativity over knowledge and logic
>is a creative dead-end.  People like to make a big deal over
>"non-linear" thinking and reality, but the concept of non-linear
>systems and thinking is itself a result of advanced mathematical
>concepts.  People could not "see" the patterns of nature that
>are fractal in nature until the mathematical concepts of fractals,
>chaos and non-linearity were invented.
So giving a name to this kind of thinking, "non-linear thinking", helps   
in our ability to understand and retain what it is we're talking about,   
but the name is just the result of an association of the raw,   
language-free concept, and a pre-existing concept of "non-linear".

>To have a higher conciousness (knowledge) one must first pass
>through lower stages of conciousness (knowledge).  What is
>conciousness but knowledge (of one's own state or of concepts
>or of reality)?
But consciousness does not equal knowledge.  It might seem that way, but   
I think it's an oversimplification.  At the core of it, when you strip   
away knowledge, context, environment, there is still something left of   
consciousness; I find there's a faceless, nameless, slippery core of the   
essence of a person.  And getting in touch with that, experiencing being   
on that level, I think is a goal of many who study meditation.

I expect there are lots of folks out there who've gotten in touch with   
this level through various drugs, as well!  :)   Anyone?

>To separate conciousness and creativity from knowledge and empiricism
>is quite simply impossible....
>To be creative at a higher level, one must have knowledge at a higher
>level.
Again, if you had to have knowledge and naming in advance of each new   
concept, then who would ever provide those names and knowledge?  The   
concept must come first, the naming and organization into "knowledge"   
later.

>refutations gladly accepted!
.... and gladly offered!  ;)  Your thoughts on the rebuttal?

 -Roy

From: simitzis@netcom.com (Steve Simitzis)

Subject: Audio Impact last night
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


This was my second Audio Impact (I also went to the first), and, wow,
what a _major_ improvement. When I first walked in the door, I was
happy to see that the big blue Gateway cabinets had replaced the
shrill, sound system-like torture device that they had previously. :)
The sound was just incredibly clean, which actually made it rather odd
sounding, as I'm used to hearing jungle played on ratty old systems in
party chill rooms...The distortion is usually sort of charming.

The vibe was *worlds* better than last time! I noticed that the bar
factor was very low, despite being at a bar. In fact, it was roughly
about the same as a night at Mad...which is certainly tolerable. Last
time I wrote about Audio Impact, I complained about all the weird
drunk people that would stand in my way and bump into me all
night. 

Not so last night! The level of respect for personal space was very
good, and just the overall vibe was so much more positive. The
lighting also was much more pleasant, especially since that irritating
strobe light of the first Audio Impact was no longer there...:)

Musically, things were more of the "light and bouncy" than the "evil
and noisy" type of jungle, but it was still hard enough for me to
seriously get _down_. Flux ripped it up again; he has quickly become
my favorite jungle DJ by virtue of the *incredible* variety of music
he has...

I guess my only complaint was with the MC; it was a nice touch at
times, but for the most part, it was overkill. I tend to be a music
purest; I'd rather hear the song, as it was originally intended to be
heard by the original artist. So hearing a little rasta rapping over
the music was not really up my alley.....oh well.

So last night was the perfect night of sheer jungle madness! I had a
great time, and as usual, I have post-jungle party leg syndrome :) Oh
well, I'm glad it's bi-weekly, and not weekly anymore; I don't think I
could physically handle that every week, but the tempatation would be
too great to miss it!

Steve

On Thu, 21 Nov 1996, Thompson. Jim wrote:

> To emphasize imagination and creativity over knowledge and logic
> is a creative dead-end.  People like to make a big deal over
> "non-linear" thinking and reality, but the concept of non-linear
> systems and thinking is itself a result of advanced mathematical
> concepts.  People could not "see" the patterns of nature that
> are fractal in nature until the mathematical concepts of fractals,
> chaos and non-linearity were invented.

fractals, chaos, and non-linearity were not invented. they were
discovered. mathematical models for observing and working with them were
invented. 

> through lower stages of conciousness (knowledge).  What is
> conciousness but knowledge (of one's own state or of concepts
> or of reality)?

i would say that conciousness is _awareness_ of one's own state. does
awareness=knowledge? i'm not sure. but i know that i don't necessarily
have to be able to think empirically about something in order to be aware
of it.
 
> > To separate conciousness and creativity from knowledge and empiricism
> is quite simply impossible....

i find that my emotions can exist quite apart from knowledge and
empiricism, in fact, i have had emotional-intuitive experiences that were
quite impossible to translate into thought (let alone language...), and i
know that creativity can spring from emotion without rational thought,
i've done it!

> To be creative at a higher level, one must have knowledge at a higher
> level.

perhaps what i perceive as emotion sans knowledge, you would perceive as
"knowledge on a higher level"... i have an intuition (don't ask me to talk
about it, since i don't have any knowledge of it:) that this discussion is
mostly semantic.

love,

brian


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Nov 21 13:43:41 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) id NAA00280; Thu, 21 Nov 1996 13:43:41 -0800 (PST)
Received: from melvax.sonoma.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.6/V2.0) with ESMTP id NAA00270; Thu, 21 Nov 1996 13:43:34 -0800 (PST)
Received: from 130.157.38.158 (SA-6EN158.sonoma.edu)
 by SONOMA.EDU (PMDF V5.0-7 #8366) id <01IC3YLAHWS09PNGQ3@SONOMA.EDU> for
 sfraves@hyperreal.com; Thu, 21 Nov 1996 13:43:12 -0800 (PST)
Date: Tue, 21 May 1996 13:54:19 +0000
From: ess kay three <zintsmas@SONOMA.EDU>
Subject: AUDIO IMPACT
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Reply-to: zintsmas@SONOMA.EDU
Message-id: <31A1CB0B.7227@vax.sonoma.edu>
MIME-version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Mozilla 2.02 (Macintosh; I; PPC)
Content-type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

We showed up around 11 pm and there were a handful of people standing 
around the dance floor, kinda wiggling around, a couple of em getting 
into it. my friend, who is quick to judge, almost wanted to turn around 
and leave, but since last audio impact filled up later, i assured him to 
wait about a half hour and see. Was i right or was i right? within a 
half hour, or even 20 minutes, the floor became packed with bouncy 
junglists. and YES! they were nicer this time! (i.e. people weren't 
standing in the middle of the dance floor taking up space that could 
have been DANCED in) last audio impact was full of people with attitude, 
this one was full of people who just wanted to celebrate the music.. MY 
KINDA PEOPLE!!! :>
	 i was pretty tired, so i spent alotta time sitting on the speakers 
(YES, I THINK THEY FOUND A GOOD SOUND SYSTEM THIS TIME!!) and the MC 
came up and rapped in my ear, putting a smile on my face. later on, he 
kinda sorta REALLY rewound a track that i didn't wanna hear again, but 
he made up for it by rewinding a track that i REALLY wanted to hear 
again, so it evened out. it was fun to have an MC at the party, but 
sometimes it was overkill. 
I think i got there when Abstract was playing, his set was great, as 
usual... then FLUX came on.. since the first audio impact i've noticed 
"hey he's pretty cool! and creative too!" which is a good thing.. but 
the MC's voice kinda interfered with the pure bass commin outta the 
speakers. Noel came on next, and he gets MAJOR props for dealing with 
the MC's "rewinds" an'stuff. and then flux came on again, mixed some R&B 
in with some breaks and i went "wow!" and then i was dragged home to 
face the reality of the fact that i have a midterm today. 

all in all audio impact has a better sound system, a better vibe, FREE 
water this time instead of 25 cent cups (which *is* better than $2), 
more people dancing, BETTER BETTER BETTER! i'm getting the best of my $5 
when i walk into that room to some smooth jungle and smiling faces. 
MAJOR PROPS and see ya at the next one!! 
*smiles*
Lara
-- 
              (sk3)
      [ J U N G L I S T ]
. . . wishing on a star . . .

Just a reminder that a week from today is Thanksgiving, and if you
haven't already made plans with the fam (or if you need an excuse to
get away!), then plan on a night of food, celebration, and music with
saturn5!

Here's the original message; hope to see you then! :)

--------------------

Hello! This has been in the works for a while, and it's finally time
to announce it!

On Thursday, Novemember 28th 1996 AD, please join us for:
                    Thanksgiving!!!

This will be an evening to celebrate with good food and music, and
to give thanks for the wonderful people and things that we have in
our lives. :)

This party is especially dedicated to people who (like myself) are not
originally from the Bay Area, and have no family to see... or just
can't make it out to be with their families. Why have a boring night
alone, eating Ramen? Party with us instead!!! Let's make our *own*
family this Thanksgiving!

DJ's for the night:

Mystr-E (frequency 8)
John Carel (gateway systems)
Anon (look for her at mantra :)
Warren Parker (one track mind)
Jon Logan (ambiance during dinner)

Dinner will be provided by Raw, a restaurant in SF specializing in
raw, super-energizing foods, and of course will be 100% vegan :)

Dinner and ambient music will begin around 9pm-ish, with trance music
running until 6 the next morning. The party will be in San Francisco,
and due to the size of the location, we'll have room for only about
200 or so people, so come early! :)

voicemail: 415.248.1997 (saturn5)

from your favorite happy turkey, ;)

Steve

Once again you missed Stareyes set!  She kicked things off with a really
cool set!  This is the first time I've seen her and she had a pretty cool
set!  (She's also insanely cute!)  Anyway I had a lot on my mind so you
didn't see me moving out there, but it was a cool experience.  The MC
definately overdid it, but that's the style in England, I've heard some
recordings, and over there they just go nuts with it.
I love rewinds too!
I'd like to hear more ambient/smooth jungle, mixed in with all the
hardstep, other than that, it was a perfect night.
(Lara glad to hear you could make it!)
Max

Subject: saturn5 meeting for Thanksgiving!

This Monday, November 25th will be the organizational meeting for
Thanksgiving, the first ever party to be put on by saturn5! If you are
interested in helping out (clean-up, door, etc.), providing any sort
of decoration/visuals, or anything(!!!) then please come to the
meeting :)

The theme of Thanksgiving is the notion of community and family, and
this party will be a big success if we _all_ put our creative energies
and hard work together! So if you have something to contribute, we
would love to have you as part of the crew!!!

The meeting will be at my apartment in San Francisco, which is right
off of the freeway in the beautiful South of Market area. Chai will
probably be served as well.

I haven't set the time yet, but probably later on in the evening, since I
don't get home from work until around 7:30 or so anyway...

Thanks, and hope to see you on Monday!

Steve

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Aryck <mxman@illuminati.heald.edu>
Subject: NRR: I need all your wisdom!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        See, the past week has been full of decisions for me. Right now I'm
stuck in a decision that will effect the rest of my life. I have the
oppurtunity to have a career with a multi-billion dollar company. Also,
another man, who worked for my father, says that he can get me in with a
section (soon to be whole) of the same company. 

        It's just bothering me how I have all of these things to do, and so
little time to do it. Don't you hate when you have to make a big decision
like a lifetime career in just a few days??? 

        The company will spend over $30,000 training me in a Tech. Rep. job.
After a certain time, I will recieve several raises, promotions, and I will
end up a big part in a huge company. This company, which I'm pretty sure is
supposed to be calling themselves ICON when they move into the big building
off the freeway in Oakland that Says "Better office systems". It's supposed
to be a really hard job, I'm going to have to work hard to learn a ton, plus
I have to finish 5 more months of my college and keep my A's up. I want to
continue college and I hope this job (which I most likely will receive),
will allow me enough time to do. 

        See, I guess that it was good that I got a quick start on my career.
I started college right after high school without any break (besides a
little over a month for summer). I hope I don't get severe burn out. I'm
just doing this all sooo quickly when my friends and the majority of my
peers are still just hanging with a reg job, living their youth. WOW! I
guess that I'm happy that I'll be where they wish they could be, like ten
years before they are. It's just weird how, I'm going from not having hardly
any time for myself to having almost no time for myself.

        I guess I'll get used to it. I keep thinking that it's only
temperary until I'm done at Heald, then a good portion of stress will be off
me. I have to juggle this decision, my friends, my family, my girlfriend, my
fitness, my motocross, my snowboarding, my personal time, and my social life
all at once. I know that you'll probably say that I don't HAVE to do all
that. But if I didn't do all of that, I just wouldn't be happy, and there's
no point in doing it if it won't make me better off right???

        So far, this week, even though I get up around 7:15 in the morn, the
days seem waaaaaay to short to do everything I'd like to do. They either
need to make days longer, or they need to do something else. . . 

        I guess I just have to keep my faith in myself. No one really
understands how complicated everything is for me at the moment. I know that
it can be fairly simple, but it's a big role in my life and it's required to
succeed, and I WILL SUCCEED! Did all of those people, who have made
millions, and have had tremendous success in their lives have to go through
all this? I think they did. In a way, I'm really happy, and I'm really sad. 

        I think a good recipe for life is just to take it as it comes, don't
worry abpout tomorrow, don't worry about yesterday, don't worry at all. Just
do what you do, take it one day at a time, and before you know it, you'll be
there. 

        I guess it's a good thing that my parents support me well. Although
they really have no clue in what's going on in my life, they do what they
can to help me do whatever I'm doing. Damn life's tough. But y'know? The
harder it is, the better I like it. It would be nice if everything was easy,
but then it would get all boring and monotonous. I guess that's the point right?

        I pretty much put all of this pressure on myself. My family doesn't
pressure me on anything really. They'd just like me to get a job, some type
of job, so I can pay my car insurance. It's me that makes me so complicated.
I need a vacation or somethin. But I guess that first, I have to work.

        Damn, I know, I'll work my ass off in school right now, so I'll have
less to do in the coming weeks. Hell, I have two essays that are going to be
due in one of my classes and I've easily written enough for three or four
essays that size today. I need to just chill, relax, take a couple breaths,
and get down to teh task at hand.
As long as everyone stays off my back, I probably won't snap. Right now
school is the main thing I'm looking forward to. That's good. I'm gonna have
to get a lot of sleep on the weekends since I'll probably be working from
8am-5pm, then I'll have enough time to make my way to taco bell of something
before i have to make my way to school at 6pm-10:30pm, then home to do all
of my schoolwork, my homework from my job (which is supposed to be hell of a
lot), then go to sleep for a couple hours before work the next day. WOW. . .
I didn't think it was gonna be THAT hard. It really makes you appreciate
your days off. . . Like, I'll be living on amphetamines or somethin. . . or
at least a gallon of coffee. But at least I'll be on my way. Nothings
usually ever as hard as other people make it seem. 

        I just need some words of ENCOURAGEMENT. Please no criticism. Unless
it's nice criticism.

        Thanks for letting me let off some pressure. . . 

        You all are great people!

        If you see me at a party, please give me aphat hug and squeeze some
of my worries away.

Aryck :)

I guess some of you haven't made jello squares for your kids recently 
 ;)  I might also add that I thought y'all were joking about this but 
 since the conversation is continuing here's my $.02:    You can begin 
 the hardening of jello by adding blocks of ice to start the 
 thickening.  Clear gelatin added in the dissolution phase (rather than 
 colored jello) can continue/hasten the thickening but not the color.

Lastly, I just wanna say that y'all are really sick.  :)  I've 
 created/played in mud pits,whipped cream and other sordid environments 
 and all I gotta say is you'll need a good hose or lotsa hot water.

Gullibly yours (yes, it's in the dictionary ;),
Diane

containers for all that jello to chill... the jello will be very hot when
you take it off the stove, so depending on what the wading pool is made out
of, the jello might melt it :( so we might need a _lot_ of
pots/bowls/tupperware...

it ambient music, that should get it in the mood... ;)

More stuff for anyone interested in bjork....

I just checked the bjork websense web-site (http://www.bjork.co.uk/bjork/)
(a great website, btw, with very fun links to stuff like recipes,
making string figures, and even esp (wooo)) and it appears that
the new mix album "telegram" will be out nov 25!

btw, in case anyone's running out to buy the hyperballad girl's blouse
mix, be warned it's not a stomping rave-type number - it's very quiet.
Other mixes on the main hyperballad mix cd are more lively - but pretty
much any of the mix cd's are fun. (I'd especially recommend the "big time
sensuality" mix cd - make sure you get the one with the fluke mixes). 
I'd also definitely check out telegram when it comes out.

- martin =]

From: bri@value.net (Brian Denny)
Subject: Re: objective/subjective reality (NRR)
Cc: ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu, star@sfsu.edu, shawna@ix.netcom.com,
        susanp@hotmail.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

ok, here goes...

the more i grow and learn and experience, the more i find myself having
certain beliefs about "reality."

in fact, i have two distinct, apparently conflicting beliefs about reality,
both of which would be rejected by the "scientific mainstream," -- and, in
the end, they don't conflict at all.

first belief, and very much along the lines of what some have argued here
already, is that we know nothing about reality other than what we perceive.
this is not the same as saying that there is no external reality. but i
feel strongly that if there is an external reality, i have no way of being
certain of anything about it. "all you touch and all you see / is all your
life will ever be" kind of relates to this (for me, anyway)... i've always
sort of thought this way, but it was acid that convinced me. if a few
micrograms of a substance can alter my brain chemistry so as to throw me
into an entirely different conceptual world, i have no reason to believe
that my reality is the same as anyone else's. it's just one of those things
i have to accept as unknown.

the second belief, a little bit more far-out, is that "we are all one with
the cosmic vibe." this takes a little bit of explanation although i'm sure
some of you already know what i'm talking about. the idea is that each of
us is a manifestation/thread/microcosm of a some sort of abstract
"universal consciousness"... don't get me wrong, i DON'T believe in any
sort of anthropomorphic god, nor do i believe that any of this is
"supernatural"... an analogy which i think has already been mentioned would
be fractals... each part a representation of the whole...

thus in a sense i believe that we do share a reality-- or rather, that we
are all manifestations/facets of the same reality... i'm you, and you're me
(again a la acid)...

this really does fit with the idea that there's no reality outside of my
perceptions. see, if i'm you, and you're me, and we're all the cosmic vibe,
then it becomes a moot point to ask whether my reality is the same as
yours. "i'm you and you're me" can be thought of either in terms of an
objective reality (we are literally manifestations of the same real
universal consciousness), or in terms of subjective reality (you and the
cosmic consciousness are both all in my mind, so _of course_ you're me and
i'm you and we're the vibe), and when you think about it, either way
amounts to the same thing.

i know this all sounds a bit new-agey, but the events in my life over the
past few months have been really pushing me in this direction of belief.
it's been uncanny how things keep working out as if to "show me" this
philosophy (further evidence in my own mind of the whole cosmic
consciousness idea)...

plurally, (now there's a word with about four relevant definitions :)

brian

more on 23...


Date: Tue, 19 Nov 1996 11:03:33 -0500
From: "David L. Oppenheimer" <davido@CS.Princeton.EDU>
Subject: Effects of the next cycle of solar interference 

[Source: Coming solar cycle may pose problems, AP item, 19 Nov 1996, 
PGN Stark Abstracting and Excerpting Service.]

Cycle 23 of solar interference activities is building up, and is expected to
have considerable effects on our planet around the year 2000, according to a
panel of government researchers.  (Cycle 22 was at its peak in July 1989
[see RISKS-8.38, 39 on electric currents induced in power lines, blacking
out Quebec, and RISKS-8.72 for a more detailed retrospective article]; the
strongest cycle to date was in November 1957.)  In particular, many new
industries have emerged that were not subjected to previous solar effects --
and they have not anticipated the risks to their systems and their
businesses.  Navigation and communications are considered to be particularly
vulnerable.  For information on the report, you might try contacting Air
Force Col. Jud Stailey, assistant director of the Office of Federal
Coordinator for Meteorological Services, a 13-agency panel housed in the
offices of the National Weather Service, or Ernie Hildner, director of the
National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Space Environment Center
in Boulder, Colo.

Potential problems to anticipate include damage to computers and other
electrical systems in satellites; expansion of the Earth's atmosphere,
slowing down satellites and pieces of space debris, making them harder to
track; induced currents in pipelines and other large arrays of metal;
disruption of signals for the inexpensive single-frequency global
positioning system satellites; interference with the newly developed
satellite cell-phone system; changes in the Earth's magnetic field,
interfering with signals used to direct oil drilling bits deep underground.

  [An obvious question for RISKS readers is which will have a more dramatic
  effect, Y2K or Cycle 23?  Perhaps we will have Murphy-slaw and each will
  reinforce the other on the same day!  PGN]

------------------------------

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday morning 9am-11am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench. Varied techno sub-genres, noise, spoken word, world
       music. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   

    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Hello,

On Thu, 21 Nov 1996 17:44:33 -0800, bri@value.net (Brian Denny) wrote:

>ok, here goes...
>
>the more i grow and learn and experience, the more i find myself having
>certain beliefs about "reality."
> [...the rest deleted to save space...]

Brian, I've dedicated most of my life to investigating these issues,
and I can safely say that virtually everything you've stated is
exactly right.

Furthermore, there is more truth to the "supernatural" than seems
likely - it's just different than what is portrayed in the supermarket
tabloids (just as true spirituality is different than what is
portrayed in Time magazine).

In our normal mental state, we are not aware of other levels of
reality, because we spend all our time focused on those things which
are in the physical world (passing finals, buying clothes, etc.).

It's similar to the way that the world of nature seems very remote
when one is South of Market, but seems obvious when one is out at the
Russian River....


Cheers,

Ken                         <*>
kstuart@mail.telis.org

Hey everyone,

Thanks again for another excellent night of Drum n' Bass! 

Major props to Gateway for the sound. During the night, I felt things
hiting me on the head. I went to Rob, and asked him what was up, and he
mentioned the ceiling was falling apart (yeah, right).

So I looked up, and sure enough, was hit by a piece of falling plaster!

Talk about great sound!  :)

We'll be fine tuning the sound so we don't destroy the place (unless the
management gets outta hand - always good to have a trump card in your
back pocket ;). 

As for water, it'll be free from now on. If the bartenders get funny and
try to charge you, tell someone at the door, and we'll set them
straight...;)

The crowd was better because we did 18+. It's give and take with the age
thing. All ages means we can pay the crew better, and get more people in
the door, but then there's all that annoying bullshit (like the tags)
and occasional attitudes. We'll probably keep it 18+, and work on
promoting more to pay the bills.

As for the MC, we're still experimenting. MC's and jungle can work very
well with getting the crowd whipped into a frenzy, but last night a was
a bit much. Keep up the feedback, and we'll get things sorted.

Next Audio Impact is Wed. Dec 4th. If you have any questions or concerns
about the party, please mail flux@hunab-ku.com, or call the BASS crew #
at 415-332-5800 ext 24-7

Audios!

J-

Subject: RE: Imagination without Knowledge Cannot be Creative
Date: Fri, 22 Nov 1996 09:09:00 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.993.5
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>"Language shapes thought."
> It's true, and I find a lot of merit in what you are saying, up to a
>point.  To name _is_ to know, that may be true, but the inverse is not.
>In order for language and thought to progress, t _must_ be possible to
>conceive of something new, before it is named, and then name it.
>Otherwise language and knowledge would never grow.  So the naming and
>lingual framing is an important step in cementing a new understanding,
>and may lead to further new understanding, but there is, and must be,
>hat gossamer leading rim of consciousness that extends outside of
>anguage; it's this elusive part, I think, that one strives to focus on
>when one talks of emphasizing imagination in efforts towards creativity.


I cannot disagree with many of your points.  As with any argument, I
was incomplete or incorrect on some points...

You are totally correct that you must be able to conceive of something
new without naming it, and you can conceive of things without using
language (spatial thinking, for example), but still, anything you can
conceive must be germinated from something else.  I cannot see
how the human brain can conceive of something out of nothing -
virtually all new thoughts are made of combinations of previously
known facts or even combinations of previously thought thoughts......


>>Your imaginings are confined to the level of your knowledge.

>Woah!  This is where I think you're going too far!  :)

This is a point I think we can agree to disagree on.  Again, I don't
see how the human brain can conceive of something that is outside
our realm of experience (including thoughts).  One can build a pyramid
of progressively more abstract thoughts built on lower bases of less
abstract
thoughts, but still, there must be some base of knowledge and experience
on which to begin your ascent.....


        jim thompson - cube root fact axon info grid data fate

        .....  ::...   .:::::::    ...:::: ...  :..... ..::...
        :::..:::....:: .:......::..   :::::.::         ::.....

they're the people that do that "we dress a certain way, we walk a certain
way, we talk a certain way, we create a certain way, we paint a certain
way, we make love a certain way ..." song that's on the new Mark E Quark
tape and has been on heavy rotation in Tracy's live sets lately. they also
do the "dancing around a coffee table as a form of unconscious therapy"
track that's on the new Inhuman tape.

it's not so much coffee house psedu-intellictual beatnik spoken word that
i've heard done before, but more like something i'd expect to overhear
while waiting for the bus or while standing in line at Safeway. fly
sisters kicking the awesome science. if i was to start a band up today i'd
like it to be like Mood II Swing.

But is naming the end-all to knowledge?  I disagree with this.  To name is to 
lose sight of the true nature of a thing.  A name is a representative 
association with something percieved.  Perception is forgotten when names are 
remembered. 
 
Regards, 
 
Lucas Ritting 
 
**  Futuaris Non Irresus Ridobis **

--=_ORCL_26316723_0_11919611221315450
Content-Type:message/rfc822

Date: 22 Nov 96 09:09:00
From:"Thompson. Jim <jthompson@arkons.lmsc.lockheed.com>" <sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com>
To:Roy,Feague,<rfeague@starfishsoftware.com>,sfraves,-,send,mail,to,list,<sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject:RE: Imagination without Knowledge Cannot be Creative
Return-Path:<sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com>
X-Mailer:Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.993.5
Sender:sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Transfer-Encoding:7bit
Content-Type:text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"


>"Language shapes thought."
> It's true, and I find a lot of merit in what you are saying, up to a
>point.  To name _is_ to know, that may be true, but the inverse is not.
>In order for language and thought to progress, t _must_ be possible to
>conceive of something new, before it is named, and then name it.
>Otherwise language and knowledge would never grow.  So the naming and
>lingual framing is an important step in cementing a new understanding,
>and may lead to further new understanding, but there is, and must be,
>hat gossamer leading rim of consciousness that extends outside of
>anguage; it's this elusive part, I think, that one strives to focus on
>when one talks of emphasizing imagination in efforts towards creativity.


I cannot disagree with many of your points.  As with any argument, I
was incomplete or incorrect on some points...

You are totally correct that you must be able to conceive of something
new without naming it, and you can conceive of things without using
language (spatial thinking, for example), but still, anything you can
conceive must be germinated from something else.  I cannot see
how the human brain can conceive of something out of nothing -
virtually all new thoughts are made of combinations of previously
known facts or even combinations of previously thought thoughts......


>>Your imaginings are confined to the level of your knowledge.

>Woah!  This is where I think you're going too far!  :)

This is a point I think we can agree to disagree on.  Again, I don't
see how the human brain can conceive of something that is outside
our realm of experience (including thoughts).  One can build a pyramid
of progressively more abstract thoughts built on lower bases of less
abstract
thoughts, but still, there must be some base of knowledge and experience
on which to begin your ascent.....


        jim thompson - cube root fact axon info grid data fate

Actually I think that this interaction is COMPLETELY rave related!
Development of consciousness is (for a lot of people I know in the rave
"scene") the most important reason for being involved -like minded people
and all that. Even if you don't comprehend the spiritual level of the rave
movement, it is in any case equally as important as anything pertaining to
"entertainment" (a bogus concept IMO) and definitely way more relevent than
drug discussions, which actually (should) relate with spiritual and
consciousness concerns. It's all related, ya know!

>they're the people that do that "we dress a certain way, we walk a certain
>way, we talk a certain way, we create a certain way, we paint a certain
>way, we make love a certain way ..." song that's on the new Mark E Quark
>tape and has been on heavy rotation in Tracy's live sets lately. they also
>do the "dancing around a coffee table as a form of unconscious therapy"
>track that's on the new Inhuman tape.
>
>it's not so much coffee house psedu-intellictual beatnik spoken word that
>i've heard done before, but more like something i'd expect to overhear
>while waiting for the bus or while standing in line at Safeway. fly
>sisters kicking the awesome science. if i was to start a band up today i'd
>like it to be like Mood II Swing.


FYI, Mood II Swing have been around for years, consistently putting out
solid House music. Lem Springsteen and John Ciafone are from NY, and unlike
most of their Big Apple brethren, fuse typical NY house grooves with
allsorts of other influences such as minimal techno (Maurizio etc) and
harder edged psychedelic house, making a really different sound. They are
very flexible: some of their stuff is vocal based garage (such as their
excellent mixes for Wall of Sound on Eightball -"Critical" is a classic of
the genre), some is dubby house (such as their stuff on Nitegrooves) and
some is weird and experimental (such as the record mentioned above - an EP
on NY label Groove On.) The one quoted is called "Learn to Love Yourself"
and the other tracks are excellent too. Whenever I hear people dissing on
House, Mood II Swing is one of the names I recommend them to check out.
Innovative and very modern producers worth investigating if you're into the
real stuff.
ar

Continuing the strange confluence of rave culture and student housing in 
Berkeley, this Saturday Night there is a very NRR party at our largest 
co-op, Cloyne Court.

DJs Stareyes and Abstract will be spinning jungle, as an aside.

The main attraction at the party (as far as Berkeley college parties go) 
is ska bands Skankin Pickle, Save Ferris and someone else I can't remember.

If the djs are spinning in the usual space, this is a very small dance 
area!  But maybe they'll get smart and provide a larger dancefloor.

It's five bucks.  Address: 2200 Ridge Road.  Northside of campus.
  
University Ave exit off the 80, go all the way til it runs into campus.  
Take a left, the next light is Hearst, make a right.  Next light is Euclid, 
make a left, one block up (Ridge), a right, and one block to Cloyne!

Party goes 9PM to 1AM - (it WILL end on time!)
You will also need an 18+ id
