Yes!
It was really cool. Andy you were the perfect host! Thank y'all for 
sharing time and space! It was real kickback and mellow! Andy's spinnig 
paid off big time in my reality and ben's. As we were driving home we were 
snickering to each other and going "we're going to be able to tell people 
that we had Andy W. spin for us at his house" when you're recoginized by 
the rest of the world for your artistic vision. Your set ruled. 't was 
mercurial yet there was a gossamer thin , almost invisible (inaudible? 
nay! intangible is the better word) connection between all the music 
played. I really like it 
when a collection of vastly different music maintains a pattern in my head 
and surprises me.  It was really cool to listen to 
music that was not limited to one genre due to a pigeonholing of art on 
the part of the artist. I loved the eclectic nature of the music. All of 
you out there , if you ever get a chance to see Andy W. spin, don't pass 
it up. I guarantee it will be well worth your time.

until next time,
love 
dhiren

> was cool.   Need to put together another one.

Somehow I think his brand of humor relates to this list... ;)

enjoy,
-mike

> >                         Steve Wright, On Life!
> >                      ========================
> >
> >
> >          It doesn't matter what temperature the room is, it's always room
> >          temperature.
> >
> >          I saw a sign at a gas station.  It said 'help wanted'.  There was
> >          another sign below it that said 'self service'.  So I hired
> >          myself. Then I made myself the boss.  I gave myself a raise. I
> >          paid myself. Then I quit.
> >
> >          I parked in the tow-away zone, and when I got back, the entire
> >          neighborhood was gone.
> >
> >          I once put instant coffee in a microwave and went back in time.
> >
> >          I got a dog and named him `Stay'.  Now, I go `Come here, Stay!'
> >          After a while, the dog went insane and wouldn't move at all.
> >
> >          I spilled spot remover on my dog....now he's gone.
> >
> >          I have a map of the United States, life size.  1 mile equals 1
> >          mile. It's a bitch to fold it.
> >
> >          Last year for Christmas, I got a humidifier and a
> >          dehumidifier.... I thought I'd put them in the same room and let
> >          them fight it out.
> >
> >          I woke up this morning and couldn't find my socks, so I called
> >          information.  She said they were behind the couch.  She was right.
> >
> >          Right now I'm having amnesia and deja-vu at the same time. I
> >          think I've forgotten this before.
> >
> >          In my house there's this light switch that doesn't do anything.
> >          Every so often I would flick it on and off just to check.
> >          Yesterday, I got a call from a woman in Germany.   She said, "Cut
> >          it out."
> >
> >          Cross country skiing is great if you live in a small country.
> >
> >          What's another word for Thesaurus?
> >
> >          I planted some bird seed.  A bird grew.  Now I don't know what to
> >          feed it.
> >
> >          You know how it is when you go to be the subject of a psychology
> >          experiment, and nobody else shows up, and you think maybe that's
> >          part of the experiment?  I'm like that all the time.
> >
> >          The sign said "eight items or less".  So I changed my name to Les.
> >
> >          I xeroxed a mirror.  Now I have an extra xerox machine.
> >
> >          I went to a general store.  They wouldn't let me buy anything
> >          specific.
> >
> >          When I was a kid I had a friend who worked in a radio station.
> >          Whenever we walked under a bridge, you couldn't hear what he said.
> >
> >          I have a microwave fireplace in my house...The other night I
> >          relaxed in front of the fire for the evening in ten minutes.
> >
> >          I watched the Indy 500, and I was thinking that if they left
> >          earlier they wouldn't have to go so fast.
> >
> >          I put contact lenses in my dog's eyes.  They had little pictures
> >          of cats on them.  Then I took one out and he ran around in
> >          circles.
> >
> >          I have an answering machine in my car. It says "I'm home now. But
> >          leave a message and I'll call when I'm out.
> >
> >          On the other hand, you have different fingers.
> >
> >          Some friends of mine got me a sweater for my birthday.  I'd have
> >          preferred a moaner or a screamer, but the sweater was OK."
> >
> >

hello all-

if you're actually reading this message, i'm assuming that you're a geek.

well, let me tell you: never get your filehandles confused and try to write
the contents of files straight to the directory filehandle.  i just created
a directory with 65,735 directory.  ever try to delete that (rm won't handle
it!)

well, i'm off to see if perl can fix my problem-

later-

matt

Lucas Ritting said...
>But is naming the end-all to knowledge?  I disagree with this.  To name is 
>to lose sight of the true nature of a thing.  A name is a representative 
>association with something percieved.  Perception is forgotten when names 
>are remembered. 

  If symbolism is used to replace direct experience, this is a problem.  
But symbolism is necessary to expand one's understanding of the world.  I 
believe this is clearly illustrated in child development.  The more words 
you can teach a child, the more of a framework they have in which to 
place their experiences so as to build their understanding.

"Cornering neatly, she trips up sweetly"
Matt

     I concur with my noble raver-colleague's assertation that Huxley's 
     "Brave new world" certainly paints a more hedonistic view of the 
     future in contrast to Orwell's often bleak and depressing view of a 
     future where Love itself is seen as an aberration to be wiped out by 
     the omnipresent "big brother".
     Digressing slightly, I would also recommend Terry Gilliam's movie 
     "Brazil" as a contrast to, and perhaps a superior interpretation of 
     Orwell's book than the movie "1984".

     me!"

Tom Leichardt <djtom@svpal.org> wrote:
>On Thu, 21 Nov 1996, presumed wrote:
>>   what else of huxley's is good?
>
>'the doors of perception' describes his experiences with mescalin, if i
>remember correctly - it mighta been psylocibin. this is where 'the doors'
>got their name, BTW.

And Huxley got it from William Blake.  Less well-known than Doors of
Perception, but I think even more interesting for ravers is "Heaven and
Hell."  It's another essay of ruminations on the psychedelic experience,
relating it to the bigger class of visionary and mystical experience in
general.  He goes over a variety of the many ways people have used to
explore visionary states--music and dance, different sorts of asceticism,
chemicals, contemplation (there's a bunch of stuff about visionary art that
ought to ring a bell with anyone who's ever tripped out on a big Day-Glo
mandala shining away under black light)--comparing and connecting them.  I
don't buy all his speculations--seems generally to push his metaphors too
far--but it's interesting stuff.

anarch@scruznet.com

I have not read the previous posts on this topic. don't mind me if i 
don't make sense for contributing at such a late time!

Both of your arguments are agreeable to a certain extent. Lucas' 
statement, " Perception is forgotten when names are remembered" is not 
all together true, in my humble opinion. Perception is not necessarily 
forgotten. I would percieve to see in my mind an apple if someone said 
"apple" in English or some other language. What color is the first apple 
you see in your mind? The apple I see may be yellow when "apple" is first 
mentioned. Your apple, however may be red. This does not change the fact 
that we are talking about edible fruits called apples. Therefore, 
each of our perception of an object is not completely forgotten. 
 This leads me on to ask is your apple truer than mine (in regards to the 
true nature of things)? 

In response to Matt's reply: I wish there was a way to communicate 
with children without words, without a framework that we instill in 
them, so that we can understand their thoughts as they are.
  I hope it isn't out of context for me to say that symbolism 
would not necessarily expand our thoughts of the 
world. It may somewhat hinder them because they reduce our many varied 
thoughts, perceptions, or ideas into one condensed thing.

 -m.l.

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


  No one reads Huxley's *Island* today -- but, if you're interested in
transcendental experiences evoked by psychedelics, there is a beautiful
description of the main character's trip in chapter 15. He takes the
"moksha-medicine" and describes a trip that is surely based on one of
Huxley's own. The evocation of the paradoxes of psychedelic experiences
-- the infinite ecstasy and infinite sadness than can follow on each other
in an instant -- is wonderfully set forth. A good part of the character's
trip is spent listening to music, while watching a praying mantis!
Powerful stuff.
  Which makes me wonder: has anyone ever set down memories of their
experiences while raving under the spell of E? One fellow I talked with
told me that "E is just a superficial drug. You feel good on the surface
for a few hours, then it dies away." But that may have been only his take
on it. Has anyone ever described, in a Huxleyan fashion, the experiences,
and meditations on those experiences, catalyzed by E?

Hey everybody,
 Hope u all enjoy my adventurous weekend at a glance...

*matter <--- chants in primal jarble to summon meandering thought patterns...*

Friday
 Missed Meat Beat Manifesto at the Vic (Chicago). Also missed the *nice*
getogetha Gage (mw-raves) had in Urbana. Shucks.

Saturday
 Connected with hion (mw-raves) and his friend Neringa (nice girl)! Left my
house en route to Urbana, IL (about 3 hours south of Chicago). Was hoping 2
have been joined by some other friends, but alas... :(
 Went pretty much every way, but the right one. Ended up in Urbana around
10:00p. Chilled 4 a bit. Called 4 info on Quaint and almost died rolling on
the floor, trying to keep up with the 568 m.p.h. voice mail. Finally,
consumed a ton of sugar and pumped it up and called back, able 2 keep up w/
the spastic voice recording. Left for Bloomington around 11:00p... Had 2
stop at the grocery store. Found more PEZ whistles! Lisa, I forgot to give u
one, next time. ;) Maybe no big deal; I think the numbers are increasing.
Also included a form to order any dispenser (and flavors) your little heart
desires! ;) No web site listed, tho. (hit me w/ private e-mail if interested
in this info) Anyhoo, bought 3 of those nifty gadgets and proceeded to the
space.
 Pulled up in front of the "Machinists Lodge" in Bloomington (anyone 4
bingo?). Simple Space. No hassle at the door, at all. ;) Simple audio (two
'lil blocks) and lighting (a couple of nifty lights). Very friendly folk in
these parts -> made my night. Surely, one of the *nicest* vibes (yeas,
that's right, there was indeed a VIBE!), I have felt. 
 DJs 4 the evening were: slip, appollo, earache. Other's were scheduled, but
never got a chance to spin the wheels. All were good (it's all good) and
appollo really cleared the air with his down and dirty ghetto-house
"fu**ing, su**ing, nasty, s**t" ! However, I am glad that we transgressed
beyond that mind set (was nice to get it out in the open and move on) into
some really great "techno" ;) schtuff. :D BTW, the whistlers were in 'da
house once again! We had it goin' at least 3 of us... *nice*!
 Then 3:00a... 'Da man shows up and decides the fate of the event 4 the
evening. Needless 2 say: that was it, music down, lights up -> arrrgh! I
have been in "busts" b4, but with a vibe like this going, it is a real shame
when it has to end like that. I now truly understand RAGE! Thanks 2 bliss,
;) if u see this. Why do these moron's do this? We have no power against
them, we are no threat... I guess there r great numbers of ppl, who simply
do not understand PeaceLoveUnityRespect... ;(
 Played with Fractint (fractal generator) 4 a while; fun schtuff...
 Checked e-mail in the wee hours of Sunday am. After getting all of the
codes into my dialer, so I could call w/out incurring major charges at my
friends' place, I connected and lo and behold: another strange ppl meeting
thing happenned. Well, I just subscribed to sfraves and met a girlie in
Chicago, offa 'da sfraves list? Stranger things have happenned, but not by
much... ;)
 After a nice breakfast, Sunday am, left Urbana for the outer reaches of the
dead-end zone, west of Chicago. Rolled in around 8:00p, after taking another
adventurous "detour" home...

 Champaign/Urbana/Bloomington/Normal -> y'all have 'da shit comin' togetha!
Keep it on the upside and PLUR 2 y'all!

 Hion,Neringa,MikeyD,Gage,Tom,Hannah,Lisa,slap-me-4-those-I-missed, u all
know who u r -> major PLUR to all of you...

Here's some pointers to keep 'da man outta our sheeot!:

1] Don't ever post directions to your event, internet or printed: unless of
course you have diplomatic immunity and you own a large property, somewhere,
in which case there's a ton of promoters who really want 2 meet u!

2] Use checkpoints, maybe many, send 'em all over 'da place: confusion is
the best form of security.

3] May have 2 start refusing tix 2 ppl who ain't got it goin' on: I hate 2
suggest this, but it may be the only way, other than the secret-ravah
handshake... ;)

4] Stay quiet outside of indoor events

5] If 'da man tells u 2 turn it down...seems only logical to comply :D

6] use really small flyers. Distant Planet in Chicago was advertised on
poster-sized flyers (duh). If u make them really small, perhaps they will go
unnoticed.

7] Offer 'da man some $ for his troubles. Make a charitable donation 2 your
local authorities. Or better yet -> Police Fund-Ravers! :D That's it, talk 2
your local government officials about promoting the vibrant energy of your
local city, town or village. Invest in America=par-tay! ;)

coming up 4 me: Fiasco Revisited in Jacksonville, FL and Red Alert,
somewhere around Tuscon, Arizona, I believe... *following guidline #1,
listed above* ;)

*PLUR/Rage*
                - music -

----------------------------
You know, there are many people in the country today who, through no
fault of their own, are sane.  Some of them were born sane.  Some of
them became sane later in their lives.  It is up to people like you
and me who are out of our tiny little minds to try and help these
people overcome their sanity.
                                           -- Monty Python

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Nov 24 23:51:22 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id XAA17866; Sun, 24 Nov 1996 23:51:22 -0800 (PST)
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id XAA17859; Sun, 24 Nov 1996 23:51:18 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [204.32.168.172] (ala-ca17-12.ix.netcom.com [204.32.168.172]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.6/8.6.12) with ESMTP id XAA14337; Sun, 24 Nov 1996 23:50:38 -0800 (PST)
X-Sender: ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Unverified)
Message-Id: <v03007800aebee5fe7cf7@[207.93.141.185]>
In-Reply-To: <961121142625_1816373635@emout01.mail.aol.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
X-mailer: Eudora Pro 2.1.4
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 1996 00:02:45 -0800
To: StEvEoberk@aol.com
From: David Ginsberg <ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: the Cartesian split and rave consciousness (was: Objective &
 subjective reality)
Cc: SF Raves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi StEvEo, sorry it's taken so long to get back to you...I've been sick &
I'm only getting to the last 4 1/2 days of e-mail now.  I hope you don't
mind that this reply is to the whole group, but where one person has a
question there are probably others, and maybe someone else will find
something here interesting and keep the thread going.  My comments follow
yours...

My computer tells me that at 11:26 AM -0800 11/21/96, StEvEoberk@aol.com wrote:
>>...Cartesian dualistic thinking...such thinking has become embedded in our
>language over the past 400 years and we use such language on
>
>Hate to distract from a really great thread, but in you're opinion where did
>this shift occur? I'm by no means a scholar, but I've been studying 1000
>BCE-1500CE europe and it seems to me linear thinking, (high and low-context
>cultures) volleyed for more than a millenium starting sometime around
>classical greece. Input? Also, save me a trip to the library, give me brief
>run down on cartesian (Descartes?) priciples)

>From my studies I'd agree that linear thinking in Western culture began
about the time writing became widespread in ancient Greece, some 2,500
years ago.  I think you begin to see it with the pre-Socratics, who
diverged from the poets about the time the technology of writing began to
become widespread - and I don't think the connection between writing and
linear thinking is accidental.  There's a great book by Walter Ong called
"Orality and Literacy" which addresses the introduction of writing in
ancient Greece.  Ong builds a strong case for a transformation of
consciousness with the shift from an orally-based culture to one which is
literal, and this is precisely what occurred some 2,500 years ago in
Greece.  I mean, here you had a culture with a rich history which had been
passed down orally by the town poet/storyteller for centuries.  In such a
culture, auditory ideals auch as harmony and unity are primary, and the
medium by which the story of our people is transmitted is the sound of
one's voice.  The poet's job is to tell the stories of his people in such a
manner that they're relevant to the situation his people face at that time.
Then, with the introduction of writing new possibilities emerge, and
different priorities begin to take center stage.  Suddenly technical
analysis is possible.  Facts are verifiable.  Truths are reified.  Unity
and harmony are replaced by clarity and distinction.  The word, which was
evanescent, dissapearing into the void as quickly as it was spoken,
reminding all of the way of things, is now written down to be returned to
later.  The word begins to transcend temporality.  The word itself becomes
an object for analysis.  Homer and Hesiod mark the beginning of this
period, and their poetry was already influenced by these new
possibilities/priorities.  This opened the world of philosophy, and this in
turn made possible, two milennia later, the opening of the world of
scientific inquiry.

IMHO what made this second period (the scientific age) different from the
flowering of the Greeks is partly that the originality of Greek thought
came from the truth of their experience.  Words as objects (written words)
were relatively new, and the Greeks still lived in a mythic world of
connectedness to the natural world (and that of the Gods).  They gave names
to the phenomena of their lived experience.  By the time of Descartes,
philosophy, which the scholastics rediscovered about 1,000 years ago, was
becoming more and more an analytic linguistic practice divorced from the
phenomena for which the Greeks coined the terms in the first place.
Descartes arrived at a major transition point in the development of the
Western psyche, with the decline of church authority and the rise of a new
merchant class which needed to see itself as free and autonomous.  Descarte
embodied the new subjectivism with "I think, therefor I am" and set the
stage for the next 400 years of dualistic thinking.  Dualistic thinking had
been around, to be sure, before Descartes, but with his articulation of the
world of his age it took center stage and has remained there until this
century.  Mind/body, spirit/matter, inner/outter, etc., these led to all
sorts of philosophical conundrums which have occupied thinkers since his
time.  It's this dualistic thinking that is usually referred to when
someone uses the term "Cartesian."  Cartesian thinking is VERY seductive,
we all use it every day.  It is the langauge with which we communcate about
ourselves and our bodies.  "My body" and  "out-of-body" express a supposed
relationship with the body, and where there is relationship you have (at
least) a dualism.  Post-Cartesian thinkers largely use the successes of
Cartesian scientific inquiry (where science is subjects measuring objects
and where the basis for mind/body dualism has largely been destroyed in
this century) to show that while dualism might be possible (i.e., I CAN
experience myself as a subject in a world of objects) this is based upon a
more primordial, holistic ground in which it isn't really possible to
separate subject and object and all is just meaningful interaction (I think
of this in terms of great parties or the magical drum circles that form in
the rain forest near Olympia, WA, and others liken it to rock climbing or
certain athletic experiences), where the sense of self just melts away to
the unitary wholeness from which language made it spring in the first
place.

My point is that this holistic way of being-in-the-world is both more
primordial (as pre-linguistic and in all likelihood shared with other
animals) and more meaningful (as mythic and based upon your own
enaction/embodiement of your culture's heritage) than the
subjective/objective way of being-in-the-world within which we dwell so
much of the time, and to which we grant authority over our experience just
as the early Christians did to the church.  And I think this granting of
authroity is as unnecessary and ungrounded today as it was for the early
Christians.  I don't think we should expect science to tell us much about
what gives a life meaning or how to live our lives any more than I think we
should expect the church or any other "rational" authority.  But at  the
same time, I wouldn't turn to a shaman to tell me about the nature of
quarks.  Science has its domain, and inasmuch as we recognize that its
domain is limited in scope and that what answers we get depends upon the
questions we ask and the paradigm through which we interpret the facts, I
think it is a highly useful way of knowing.  My concern lies with the
dimminution of meaningful existence which I almost invariably find
coincident with the belief that science=knowledge about reality, and the
related belief that myth stands in opposition to truth.  Falsity, or
untruth, stands in opposition to truth.  Myths, OTOH, are something like
the condensed truths of a peoples through time - a cultural heritage.  As
such, they are valuable ways of knowing in and of themselves and not
something that stands in opposition to scientific facts.  To me, it's one
of the tasks of the present age to explore the mythos of the Western psyche
and to rediscover existential meaning as the foundation both for scientific
knowledge and for individuation, and to restore existential truth to its
primary position at the center of humanity's search for meaning such that
more children are able to grow up without losing their individuality and
their passion and resigning themselves to a position within the herd.
>
>Also I'm sure I'm out of line here, but I would love to see more of these
>kind of quality threads, just with a little more personal respect and less
>"one-upping"
>-StEvEo

You're in no way out of line, and I really appreciate your candor in giving
me this feedback.  I'd worried about this myself in the last few days.  I
think perhaps the combination of a fever and far too much recent
philosophical training (at Cal=intellectual jousting), along with an issue
about which I am passionate took their collective toll in the last
exchange.  That old Cartesian ego still flares up, apparently all the more
so when its own reality is questioned by the one it thinks it is.  And
sometimes, try as I might, I find myself believing that that's who I am,
and acting in part on this basis even as I try to undermine its very
foundations.  I apologize to anyone I offended, especially Tony (who knows
where I'm coming from) and Starchild (who doesn't yet).  To quote James P.
Carse ("Finite and Infinite Games" - I highly recommend it to anyone and
everyone but most of all to all of you!), one-upping is a finite game (one
where the intent is to win) and what I really want to play is an infinite
game (one where the intent is to continue the play).  And sometimes the
infinite game is only kept going when another player reminds us that we've
slipped into playing that nasty finite game we were taught to play in
school.  Thanks, StEvEo.  And let's all play!

-Dave

David Ginsberg
ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu
www.geocities.com/athens/2001

"Attitudes are contageous.  Is yours worth catching?"

inside space, a 7-11 (just kidding), gardens, bathrooms, parking with
incentives for carpooling.  There would be no landlord or permit problems
for an owned facility.  I think our rave community is short of landholders
and real estate-minded persons, or else this problem would already have been
solved.  Is this an idle fantasy?  Maybe the rave scene is inherently too
variety-loving to settle into one permanent venue. 

Just some wild idears,  XO  RHoda

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com

That's an interesting point. In fact, ownership is the MOST important
factor in any type of cooperative or collective. Once you own land, you are
its master and are free to explore opportunities with much less impedence.
Our founding fathers (that sounds funny) knew that land equaled power and
encorporated this concept into the fundamentals of our beliefs. I went to a
conference for members of student cooperatives 2 years ago in Santa Cruz.
There was an old-timer co-op founder there. He had  list of 20 things you
could do to start a co-op and get it off the ground. Rule #1: buy the land.

I don't know, though if our 'collective' (loosley coined) likes to be tied
down as such. We are nomadic, spontaneous, resourceful, innovative,
sporatic. Part of our being is our desire to surprise and be surprised. How
long would we dance in one spot before we became tired of it and wanted to
search for new possibilities. 
-peace-

alex

>A common rave ground, if you will, where we could have some installations,
>inside space, a 7-11 (just kidding), gardens, bathrooms, parking with
>incentives for carpooling.  There would be no landlord or permit problems

I've mentioned this alooong time ago and here's what I was thinking.

We need to get enough people together and have a few fund raiser parties or
any type of fund raisers to gather money to purchase a big piece of land
and have some buildings put up on it. Here's the catch, we would have to
have some people living on the land to keep it up and what not. Which for
some of us would be a great idea. We would also need a few people to act as
the landlords of this place. If we have a big enough spread of land we can
have a few warehouse type buildings or any type of buildings for that
matter and can have 2 or 3 parties going off at the same time as long as
there not too close together.

We would need some trust worthy people to take charge of this land as well
as some people to live on the land to keep it up and watch after it. There
are a lot of people here in the SFR community with a lot of different
skills ranging from doctors, computers, food service, electricians and
construction workers. I'm sure we can do this.

Tim (knucklehead)

From: David Ginsberg <ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: Imagination without Knowledge Cannot be Creative - (RR)
Cc: SF Raves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>

Precedence: bulk

At 9:36 AM -0800 11/21/96, Thompson. Jim wrote:
>Please excuse the somewhat random structure of the following - this is
>meant as a posting to SFRaves, not a term paper!
>
>
>We think in terms of language.  Without advanced language concepts
>one is incapable (in general) of having advanced thoughts.  Why
>do we remember so little of our childhood up until the age of
>3 or 4?  It is because we do not have the language skills to
>make sense of our surroundings.  We can have vague rememberances
>of places or events but no strong recollections because we tend
>to remember (think) in terms of language concepts.  Noam Chomsky
>posits that language constructs are actually "hard-wired" into
>the human brain.  That is why children have such an amazing
>ability to acquire language skills.

I'll agree that language and "advanced thoughts" are intimately related,
but I'm afraid Chomsky and his cognitivist approach to the mind simply
can't account for things such as the birth of language or the background of
understanding upon which language is based.  In fact, if you read George
Lakoff (Chomsky's former student, now on the faculty at Cal) and Mark
Johnson's work (at the University of Oregon), they show rather convincingly
that our primary conceptual schemas are born out of our early embodied
experiences, and that we use metaphorical elaboration to build ever more
complex conceptual schemas.  As infants we learn about things such as
direction, force, blockage, building, tearing down, up, down, inside and
outside.  This is all learned prior to language.  In fact, recent work with
infants has shown that even an understanding of the continuity of objects
and gravity is held by infants at 3 mos.  This does  not come from
language.  Rather, it is the ground upon which language is built.
>
>There is a latin saying "Namen est Nomen" meaning "to name is
>to know".  It has been recognized for centuries that once you
>put a name to something (a concept, say) you are now "conscious"
>(have knowledge) of it.  A large part of learning a new subject is
>learning all the definitions ("names") that go with that subject....

It is unsurprising that the Romans would have such a saying.  The Romans
didn't create their mature language out of the phenomena of Roman culture.
Rather, they "borrowed" it all from the Greeks without care for the
phenomena which gave the Greeks to name these words in the first place.
This is the first setting-adrift of thought, the cutting off of language
from its roots which many are trying to overcome in this "postmodern" age.
Certainly a large part of learning a new subject is learning names.  This
makes sense in a system built upon the Roman educational system as handed
down through the medieval Christian church.  But I'd submit that the great
thinkers of any age are those who are paying attention to the phenomena of
their age and articulating those phenomena in such a manner that the
language is made richer.  What is poetry or literature?  It isn't the
regurgitation of remembered words - this might be what Time magazine or the
evening news do, but literature expands the language, and allows the rest
of us to see something we might never have seen before.
>
>Your imaginings are confined to the level of your knowledge.

Wow Jim, I have some trouble with this.  I think I see where you're coming
from, though I think this statement is much stronger than supported by the
evidence.  Cats paint, yet possess no conceptual knowledge of the cognitive
sort you are speaking of here.  And children are more creative than most of
us.   This statement is more appropriately limited to the domain of
conceptual knowledge such as theories.
>
>To emphasize imagination and creativity over knowledge and logic
>is a creative dead-end.  People like to make a big deal over
>"non-linear" thinking and reality, but the concept of non-linear
>systems and thinking is itself a result of advanced mathematical
>concepts.  People could not "see" the patterns of nature that
>are fractal in nature until the mathematical concepts of fractals,
>chaos and non-linearity were invented.

And of course people could never see the patterns at all if they weren't
there as phenomena to be named.  Goedel's incompleteness theorem (see Tony
on this one!) shows that logic is necessarily incomplete.  Non-linearity is
simply a correction to a couple of millenia of linear thinking and the
recognition that linear thinking isn't enough, just as Euclidian geometry
wasn't enough.  This doesn't mean that Euclidian geometry or linear
thinking are useless, or that imagination and creativity should reign
supreme over knowledge (which still needs to be defined) and logic, but it
does suggest that these limits should be recognized and taken into account.

>
>To have a higher consciousness (knowledge) one must first pass
>through lower stages of consciousness (knowledge).  What is
>consciousness but knowledge (of one's own state or of concepts
>or of reality)?

Knowledge is generally held to be justified true belief.  I doubt whether
we really want to restrict consciousness to justified true belief.  I think
perhaps what you mean to say here is awareness, not knowledge.  If that's
what you mean then I agree 100%, as would, I take it, most buddhist and
other contemplatives.


-Dave

I just posted a long-winded suggestion to the group, but I really want 
 to address an important issue and that is the legality of a venue.  
 What happens if someone od's, dies, or gets hurt?  That's the beauty 
 of Burning Man, it was man against nature w/o specific liability but 
 they had covered all possibilities in the event of any accidents.  And 
 even now, BM is going through growing pains.

If a group were to own land and not address the possibility of these 
 issues, I could easily see the government cracking down on holding 
 events while an investigation on a wrongful death, drug use, etc. is 
 conducted.  Look at some night clubs and their owners and what they 
 have to go through.

And worst of all, in California, ravers may not be sue happy but very 
 upset parents could be and that would ruin the whole spirit of the 
 _intention_ of the venue.  There needs to be a concise mission 
 statement and understanding of risks involved in a proposal before 
 investors put their money down...hence my suggestion of a 
 community-based non-profit.  Even then, there'd be a tough road to 
 pave but I also believe that it's good that we're discussing it...a 
 seed thought or astral projection has to eliminate negative blocks 
 (thoughts) to flow more easily.

Just playing the devil's advocate,
Diane
----------

Date: Mon, 25 Nov 1996 10:39:06 -0800

Well hey, it feels like wensday already....

What a wonderful weekend.  Friends, family, dancing and trancing, I'm
suprised my body can accept the punishment I put it through.

Friday-  Stompy.  Talk about HOUSE!   The SF house scene is alive and
very well.  Many clubgoers were out there, not too many scenesters,
however.  I did manage to find a few friends I thought I lost in the
past years.  Gruuving to some progressive house tunes, left @ 3:30 due
to my company not being able to "hang" @ such a late of an hour.

Saturday-  Arrived @ Ameba @ 12:00.  "GASP!" Sold Out!  well, I knew
where the local was but I didn't want to crash it.  Ended up at Acme Jr.
anyways, and,  after slipping past the guard (thanks Crusty, MAR, and
Co.)  Managed to get in becuz of some way cool door people *Smooches*,
Bless ya gals.   
The location, I've been to twice.  
The first time I thought, "What a stinky, overcrowded, deathtrap."
This time around I'd have to say...
"What a nice beautiful stinky overcrowded deathtrap!!"
The people were sooo positive despite the crowded atmosphere, I ran into
sooo many faces that I haven't seen in months to years...   But, the
music was what kept me from conversing (as usual).  Dancing and dancing
through Ethans and Deaks set.  (does anyone else think that Deaks has
mixing background from the old skool hip-hop scene, that's the last time
I remember hearing that kind of transforming...).   
I lasted until 7 am or so since I had some errands to do Sunday morning.
 Finally spun out at 11:30 for a few hours and spent the remainder of
Sunday wrekkerd shopping.  
A perfect end for a fab weekend...

C U @ Saturn-5's  Jerky Turkey"  event and  _Ubquitious_ on Friday.

---Adam
"Stay Connected..."

From: Diane_Tabellija@xn.xerox.com (Tabellija,Diane)

Jim,

As I've mentioned to many in the past, forming a collective of 
 organizers leasing/buying/renting  a legit venue on a full-time basis 
 is a viable option.  If it's a non-profit collective with a board of 
 directors, as part of the proposal/permit process the group could show 
 the city and county officials that it's supportive to the community 
 including youth and diverse cultural activities.  By being a community 
 based project, it should qualify for arts & youth grants and it could 
 actually take "raving" into a different light.  Of course, daytime 
 activities should include health, fitness, diet, and awareness of 
 alternative options of inducing trance dancing among other things and 
 perhaps art exhibits/multimedia events.

The bottom line is that to make this happen, one needs to prioritize 
 what's important for a rave/dance and emphasize these merits while 
 also acknowledging the downsides but offering solutions or alternative 
 educational activities to avoid the bad rap raves have had.  This can 
 be construed as the end of what raving represents or a sell out but 
 there will always be renegades and underground parties.  And if part 
 of the scene wants to avoid hassles, massive payoffs, etc.  then there 
 has to be a certain maturization and recognition of the need for 
 cultural "initiations" that part of the scene offers.

If one looks at some offshoots of what happened in the 60's there are 
 collectives that own land and conduct their own gigs...privately (e.g. 
 Wavy Gravy's Camp WinnaRainbow, Venture, Esalen, etc.).  If one were 
 to run a for-profit organization, then the owners would be _liable_ 
 for any mishaps or legal entanglements in a much more specific way 
 than a non-profit would, hence my suggestion for a non-profit.  Jason 
 (from ComeUnity) once told me about the Mind Gym in the UK which 
 catered to health (mental and physical) in the daytime and had parties 
 at night.  I've explored some 24-hr Nautilus-type gyms but never have 
 explored the legal aspects of running a night club.  I suspect that to 
 avoid additional hassles, one would not want an alcohol permit...but 
 one should explore the possibilities of allowing potential renters to 
 serve alcohol like many do at community centers (usually a one-day 
 liability insurance policy is required).

Lastly, I just want to add, that as part of my vision a while back, I 
 thought particular organizers would want to make up the collective and 
 each one would have XX amount of Friday nights and XX amount of 
 Saturday nights per year so there wouldn't be any question of one 
 group having too much influence in the collective.

So, yeah, if you explore this idea further, I'm interested if it were 
 run as a non-profit.  I, personally, wouldn't invest in a for-profit 
 organization that would set itself up for potential legal risks.

Diane
----------

Thank you everyone for such a wonderful weekend and such a great party.
Special thanks goes out to following for bringing thier records and gear and
creating the sounds for the weekend: SteveO, Mei-Lwun Yee, Marcus, Andy,
Toby Egan, Joseph Brown, Uncle Noah, Derek, Jonathan Mark Logan, My partner
Eric in RE:, Mark Camp from Astronout, and Troy Sheets from Artage.  These
people all gave outstanding performances, and I for one was quite pleasantly
suprised at the talent from all the dj's.  All of them are totally worth
hearing so check them out if you get a chance.  In scheduling the time slots
I only looked at the style of music they played and tried to create some
sort of continuity from that.  The whole party went smoothly, with excellent
communication among the dj's so that I never had to tell anyone to play or
stop playing.  I actually lost the list on Friday, and didn't remember who
was supposed to play when.  It was all good though cuz the dj's all knew
thier part and played it well.  Perfect perfect perfect.

Thank you sooooo much to all of the people who helped with the decorating.
The cabin was completely transformed, and completely ravable.  If only the
owners could have seen what you did to thier cabin :)   The disco ball was a
nice touch.

Thank you eveyone who donated gear: Toby, Eric, and Mark Camp. (I hope I got
everyone in there).  With out you, well it just couldn't have happened.

Thanks to Annon and Shawna for singing and reading poetry during our
set...it was beautiful.

Thank you Troy Sheets for reminding me what true minimal ambient was, and
how really cool it could be.  One analogue synth and an effects box...it was
beautiful folks.

Thank you everyone who stayed to help clean on Sunday.  

Extra super specialicious thanks to all those who helped carry gear up and
down the 500 feet of stairs and walk way.  May you all attain full
enlightenment in this lifetime.

Dinner was great as well, with everyone fixing what ever they were at
various times and just putting it on the table for everyone.

And ofcourse thank you SteveO for all your time and effort in putting this
whole thing together and coordinating the money stuff.  You da'Man.

I believe everyone had a wonderful time....especially that small group in
the upstairs bedroom ;)  That door should have had a warning sign on it.
Make a note for the next one.

This was my kinda party.

Rick

  

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape us for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

On Mon, 25 Nov 1996, knucklehead wrote:

> What does everyone think of this
> idea as a whole?

This idea was discussed some time ago on sfraves...so you might want to
search the archives as to what was discussed, problems encountered etc.

If I remember correctly the problems were who owns the land, who is
responsible for it (liability etc.), who throws parties (if one group wants
to throw a party on this date and this other group of people do to, who
gets the site).

how about making a corporation so that liability is not an issue and
ownership can be passed on.  Shares can be given to those that contribute
the money?

I am an accounting student about to graduate (spring, 97) and I work for a
CPA so I can research any issues that come up nad will attempt to help in
any way I can.

Sounds like an exciting venture!

Gioni

Gioni
pasque@isp.net
www.isp.net/~pasque

Monday Night Dinner, (always at 8:30 pm,) a different cuisine and location
each week. 

We are a haphazard collection of ravers who get together to properly wind
down their weekend; or; rev their engines for the coming week of parties.
Everyone who reads this is welcome to come.  Be there or be talked about!  

Join our happy group, (and those returning from Tahoe!!!!) next on November
25th at: 

Ar Roi              

Ethnic cuisine at 643 Post Street, in San Francisco
Telephone:   (415) 771-5146
Prices:   Inexpensive, meat entrees under $9, (veggie dishes are less than
that.)

Sleek deco setting in cool blue and gray; convenient to theater district.
The soups, and seafood salads are touted.  Ask for the SF Raves table.

Ok, here's the scoop.

I've got 14-1/2 hours of music from the Cabin.  I started recording at 
approx. 5pm on Saturday all the way till around 7am on sunday morning.  
It would take me for EVER to dub all those tapes.  So what I thought I'd 
do is take them to a Tape Duplicating place to get copies made.

Before I can figure out a price for a set of tapes, I need to know how 
many people would like copies.  The more people that order tapes, the 
cheeper it will be.

so, if you'd like the music from the cabin, please send me an Email.

thanxs!

-M

ps - anyone know of a good inexpensive tape duplicating house? :)

     ********************************************* 
     Some Theories on the Sacramento Free Party... 
     *********************************************
     
     THEORY 1
     The Great Gods of Big Mudda Parties... Cool World, have come back to 
     try to lure us into thinking they're vibe enough to spend $20 bucks on 
     for their New Years shindig...
     
     THEORY 2
     Sacramento is a great untapped Mecca of raving.  Cool World is working 
     with local Adidas, Nike and Fila vendors is a benign takeover of the 
     youth of our fair state's capital city.  At $50 for a pair of three 
     stripe pants... wow.
     
     THEORY 3
     Pete Wilson discovered some spare money floating around the finances 
     at that big domed building, and he's giving it back to the people by 
     throwing a good ol' hootenanny.
     
     THEORY 4
     Television just isn't having the same impact it used to anymore.  
     There's just so much crap going on subliminally that people are now 
     numb to sublim TV messages.  So they have to increase the ambient 
     volume to be able to increase the volume of the messages... hmmmm.
     
     THEORY 5
     Some lightbeings have gotten together and in an effort to let people 
     know that we can be good to each other without alterior motives, are 
     organizing a gathering so boys and girls of strong minds and honest 
     hearts can meet one another.  Elevate yourselves to the purity of your 
     birth, and then add your collected wisdom from the day you died...(*) 
     
     THEORY 6
     The heat will be 125 Farenheit, and the Lower Hades water booth will 
     be open all night with $15 water.
     
     THEORY 7
     This is the rave that the Road Rules people end up in... look out for 
     the MTV camera crew!
     
     THEORY 8
     Brought to you by Budweiser (There's Two E's in every BudwEisEr), 
     Pepsi (The OG smart drink), Coke (For Washing Shrooms Down, Coke is 
     it!), Sprite (Image is Nothing, But Don't We Look Cool?), Tommy 
     Pullmyfinger for the Exclusive (I spent so much money on clothes, now 
     I go to free parties exclusively), Blow Pops (Suck on this), and 
     Evian (Evian is Naive spelled backwards and that's okay).
     
     THEORY 9
     Somebody has to get rid of an awful lot of bunk E...
     
     THEORY 10
     Don't say okay if a girl asks you if you want a lapdance.  Just 
     cherish well your thoughts and keep a tight grip on your booze.
     
     THEORY 11
     The aliens keep getting their guidance systems fucked up when they try 
     to abduct near the SF area due to a highly potent "vibe" energy field. 
      So they figured Sacramento wouldn't have that problem (I live in San 
     Jose... I can joke about this , no?).
     
     THEORY 12
     Maybe sometimes those big promoters figure they can get more people into 
     the scene by throwing an occasional free party.  This probably isn't bad 
     for anybody, and it's this type of thing that makes parties work.  Go, 
     you've earned it.
     
     Honestly, if money is a factor, and there's nowhere else you'd kick 
     yourself for not going to (which it currently appears is the case), it 
     sounds like a great idea.  And I hear in a recent survey of DJ's named 
     Ghost, Ghost was picked as the number one DJ.  I'll probably end up 
     going to check out DRC and Dutch if nothing else is going on.  And 
     that communal hotel thing doesn't sound like a bad time...
     
     *****************
     Weekend in Review
     *****************
     
     Friday Night...
     Goa Goa Goa at the Ceiba Records Lunarseed party thingy.  Listened to 
     uh... Goa!.  Really burnt out from partying Thursday.  Venue was same 
     as the venue used for Wyrd, just one night earlier (I love how time so 
     often keeps two different chunks of mass from occupying the same 
     space).  Sweaty, hot, humid.  Danced for a little while.  Spoke with 
     some HELLA special people.  Yoko, you jam eternal.  Met Chin and a 
     couple other listers... Plotted with Mic*doh*.. Dan.  Finally felt 
     like my plug was unplugged... And stand back... this is GROSSSSSSS.
     
     I laid down on the phunk sweat soaked floor and slept.
     
     Caban (Kaban?  uh... the guy with the big fro from CCC) was mental.  
     Well motivated, driven, epic, beautiful, hard, scary, trippy, 
     inspiring psychadelic trance.  And I heard him play something new to 
     me... a glimpse of a brighter future... breakbeat goa (Yeah!!!!!).  A 
     lot of goa DJ's tend to play it really safe, and it was nice to hear 
     someone who had their technical shit together, and also had a 
     statement and a journey in mind.
     
     The CD was cool, despite the "known" blemish.  Way better than 
     throwing it away.
     
     Went back to the SanJosean zone with Ben and Dhiren and Loren (and the 
     other people who are regrettably in the "I really liked those nameless 
     folk" category, especially the guy with the light box)... too much killer 
     conversation.
     
     With our love, we could save the world if they only knew...
     
     Saturday:
     Slept during raving hours despite will to go to Wyrd (hella tired).  
     After spending and exhausting Friday in the Stevenson alley Acme 
     (that's a really epic observation whoever you were), didn't really 
     want to go.  And thats also where they threw CHI, the last ProSoy 
     party I went to.  Glad to hear everybody had a good time though... was 
     there a space where people could chill?  As I fell asleep around 
     2:00am I smiled thinking about you all...
     
     Sunday:
     Bought bizarre crap in back room at Ameoba after sleeping all day.
     
     This weekend, I will fill the batteries before I go out.  I have no 
     intention of having a quiet weekend.  It's time to give thanks for the 
     last year... and it's been a damn good year.
     
     Peace,
     AndyW
     
     P.S.       To those of you who think it's funny to just throw out gum 
     at a party when it's tasting stale... I sat in your gum on Friday, and 
     I think you suck and live your life without regard for others while 
     preaching love and unity.  Please fold it up in some stiff paper (like 
     those groovy flyers all over the  floor), or put it inside a spent 
     water bottle or *egads* throw it away in a trash can.
     
     
     It's so weird explaining to my roommates that I MEANT to put my cords 
     in the freezer.

 with SMTP (Apple Internet Mail Server 1.1b2d4); Mon, 25 Nov 1996 14:04:11 -0800

Date: Mon, 25 Nov 1996 14:04:43 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: peter@niles.com (Customer Service)
Subject: and this is what happened to me on saturday night <nrr>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

So it's Saturday night, and me and the boys are hanging out in this club
down in North Beach, acting like fools.  Me, I'm out on the dance floor
mackin on the ladies, cause I know that's what they like.

My boy Slider is over there in the corner swiggin whiskey straight out the
bottle, trying to keep it all low-key so the bouncers don't start trippin.
And then my man Duke, he's over there gettin goofy on the dj, cussin at him
and telling him to scratch the record.  Duke likes getting all stupid like
that on the dj's, like going up to Jeno and pronouncing his name
fonetically just to get him all riled up. Like, "Hey, ain't you dj Gino?"
That's the kind of punks we are when we go out catting on a Saturday night.


So right now Duke's hanging over by the dj booth, pushing the dj around,
callin him a softy and telling him to play something you can freak the
ladies to.  Except I'm not even paying attention to that, 'cause I'm the
kind of guy who can freak the ladies to just about anything.  I got talents
like that.  Hip-hop, trip-hop, be-bop and blues, you name it.  Which is
exactly what I'm doing where this story begins.  Course, the ladies gotta
play all coy when I start with the hip grinds; they make faces and move
away on the dance floor, but I know that's the kind of catNmouse game they
like to play when I start pulling the boomerang tricks out my sleeve.

So later on I'm in the can, and Slider slid in after me.   That's how come
we call him Slider, cause he's always sliding around like his sneakers were
made out of greased moose poop. Foaming at the mouth, eyes wild, Slider
burst in saying, "Boomerang, we gotta ship on out!  Everyone's talking
about how you've been getting fresh with this girl, and her boyfriend's a
judo expert, looking to use you as a punching bag!"

"Eep!" said I.  "Time to make like a bakery truck and haul buns outta here!"

 Duke was still dancing on top of the speakers in the main room, and Slider
dragged him down, cussin and fussin about how he wasn't ready to go yet.
Then the three of us, slick like we are, made a move toward the bar, and
ducked out the fire exit before anyone saw us.

Well, wouldn't you know it, the door slammed shut behind us, and standing
there in the rain are these three cats, these three big, nasty looking
jacks,  ready to brawl.

"Aw, shucks, fellas,"  said I with dignity.  "Looky here:  I'm a lover, not
a fighter.  Now me and the boys were just having fun in there--"

"This is between you and me, kid,"  said the big guy, the judo expert.

I remembered old Grandpa Fidget once told me that if you're gonna get
whupped,  you might as well make the first punch, because that might be the
only one you get.  And so I swung at the kid, which was pretty dumb,
because he ducked, and then kicked me in the mouth.

"Ouch!"  thought I, and the kid jumped on me.  Then he got me in one of
these super judo half charley pretzel nelson double chicken wing leg-bender
holds, the kind where there's legs and arms all over the place and you
don't know your arse from jupiter.  So we rolled around in the mud puddle,
arms and legs all twisted and wrapped up like we were in a lovers' embrace,
except I don't think this guy wanted a kiss, if you catch my drift.

So just when I was fixing to die, me and the judo guy flipped over, and I
saw this crotch in my face.   I thought, "Man, I know going for the groin
is kinda cheatin, but I don't have a choice!"

Problem was, my arms and legs were tied up all over God's creation--one leg
behind my back, the other wrapped twice around my own neck, one arm going
north and the other going south --I looked like a knot tied by a sailor on
belladonna.

So I just closed my eyes and pretended like I was sitting down to a chicken
dinner at Mama Fidget's house, and chomped my teeth down on that crotch as
hard as I could.

And then, wouldn't you know it, within a matter of seconds, I was up on my
feet, and all you heard was  Whap! Pocka-Crunch-Packa-Poof!  That's why
they call me Boomerang--I always come back atcha.  So my nemesis was
starry-eyed on the pavement, body succumbed to gravity, but mind heading
out into orbit.

Now his buddies,  I guess they saw what this old boy was made of, so they
politely stepped aside, and allowed Slider and Duke and me to exit the
alley.

Out there in the street, the boys were drop-jawed in amazement, hooting and
hollering about my victory.   "Gaw-jeez, Boomerang,"  said Duke.  "How'ja
do it?"

"Well,"  said I, a tad sheepishly.  "I guess I never realized how much
strength I had until I bit my own dinkle."

Hello sfraves,

        I have thought about how to raise some $ to either buy land or a
warehouse before. I have come to the conclusion that although it seems like
a cool idea, I feel it would not be all that benifitial to the raving
community. The land/space would get played out, and that is a big risk to take. 
        
        Right now it is so hard to throw parties. We can't get permits in
most cities, and in the cities that we can, it costs to much. I think a
better goal to raise money towards is the changing of the laws
(dancing/entertainment) in S.F. In '93 the mayor and the police chief began
to reinforce "2am" law for people under 21. This basically states that if
you are under 21 you cannot dance after 2am. This is still in effect. For
instance, who many of you went to the Chem. Bros/ Meat Beat show? I did. And
I got booted out onto the streets of S.F. at 2am. (I am only 20 yrs old)
This really pisses me off! I don't understand why if I can vote, if I can
(have to) pay taxes, and if I can have all of the responcibilities that a
21+ person can have, why I can't dance after 2am?!?!?! This idea seems absord!

        I know that at the "Unity" party mettings, a fund was discussed,
which would go towards getting the laws changed. I think this would be a
better venture than buying land or a warehouse. By buying land, all we are
doing is avoiding the current laws that are practiced. Laws are made to be
changed. We don't live in a fixed system. We need to change things, not
avoid them. If we raise enough $ together, we can change any law in the
book! All it takes is $, it's a sick thought, but it is true. We need $ and
signatures, that's all. Hmmm. If any of you, want to help with this
situation, we should have a metting, seriously! Please respond privatly.

Peace, love and harmony to all!!!

Greg =)

Mr nStuff wrote:
> 
> " Friday-  Stompy.  Talk about HOUSE!  "
> ---------
> 
> It's really funny how you say this.
>  My friend Dave Chapman (Top Ace ravEr, 5 years) went to this party. He
> said that the HOUSE music gotta little bit out of hand for awhile. He said
> it was "Glammor house" in his words there..
>  Did you have fun though?  I wanted to go, but then I didn't, then I did.
> 
>  <<I want to go,,, but I don't feel like going>>
> 
>   I am such a confused person huh.  =]:..
> 
> Jeff


Hello,

I'd like concur with Dave Chapman's sentiment regarding Stompy Stomp.  I
too attended (as I've been doing so regularly) and was disappointed not
so much in the party as a whole but in the music.  The DJ was Victor
Simonelli and as I recall, he spoiled another Stompy party for me a
couple months back with his incessant mix of glammy, gospelly, diva-ish,
light, vocal, commercialized house.  Some of his records, I felt,
weren't even good enough to receive commercial radio airplay.  I kept
wondering throughout the night, 'Doesn't this guy know the meaning of
DEEP?'  I mean, at Stompy parties I'm used to heavy, slammin' bass and
deep often jazzy grooves unlike at any other SF parties, which, for a
true House fanatic really pleased me. Unfortunetly, Markie Mark (who
ended the evening) followed with similar programming so my hopes for
good get-down boogeying to the real House music that I know and love
were never realized...
Oh well, but in defense of Stompy the party, I'd like to say that most
people I spoke to were not very satisfied with the sounds either but
were insistent on keeping up the good vibe and partying well anyway. 
I've always liked Stompy Stomp for the brand of sounds that these
parties bring to SF, not so much progressive as is the popular house
genre.  I recall reading in XLR8R something that I completely agreed
with when describing Stompy Stomp.  "Get ready to be educated in the
realm of HOUSE".  Too bad I wasn't further educated this past Friday. Oh
well, but I haven't given up hope!!  I'd still check out Stompy and
would continue to recommend to other Househeads.

Cheers,

G

I appreciate everyone's suggestions on this topic.  Here are a few more.

If there was a cooperative, we could "sell" memberships which entitle one to
admission. Admission ticket sales to non-members could be split between
event organizers and the co-op (to support expenses such as utilities, and a
mortgage).  I think an office and resident manager would be appropriate to
facilitate maintenance and scheduling.

If there was a cooperative agreement, a legal contract, it would best to
keep rave out of the name (Dance Parties Unlimited?).  Let's buy the former
site of the Ken Keysey retreat on the Peninsula, should be some good vibes
there!   

Also, you are correct in saying we have a lot of resources in terms of
people who could put it together.  Let me mention a couple of professions
which would be crutial in starting up: a lawyer and real estate type. 

More ideas, anyone?  Anyone know someone who might DONATE property (perhaps
to avoid a capital gains tax upon sale or as a charitable write-off against
other tax liabilities)

XO  RHoda>

>music and rock music. I have never heard a piece of electronic music that

>overlay political samples... but you could lay those over everything. I

Has anyone come down with mono lately?  My roommate is currently
succumbing to it, and we were wondering if we could trace its origin to
some party in the recent past.

Given the activities that transpire at raves, I wouldn't be surprised if
mono could explode in the scene if we weren't careful. 

Be warned!
	
		jon

So, have any of you received that big ol' 8 page flyer for Coolworld in the
mail yet?  

Yikes!

This is indeed the very biggest flyer I've ever seen!  Broadcast live on the
internet all over the world from the Henry J. Kaiser Convention Center.  

Yikes!

Live 105 dj's, a secret sex room, tickets $35 at Bass Tickets, 15,000
people, tickets on sale all over the state, directions to the party from
Southern California.  They even have a Travel Line to arrange hotel
accommodations if you're traveling from afar!  They even have an 800 number
to dial if you're coming in from outside California!  There's even a VIP
lounge for the really hip & with-it folks.  And a rooftop spacecraft landing
site for aliens.  

Ack.

If I could get in for free somehow, and I wouldn't be wasting New Year's Eve
to do it, and there wasn't anything better to do that night, I would
probably actually go & check this out just to see what the hell goes on.
It'd have to be a regular fucking three ring circus in there!  

Anybody here going?  If so, they tell you to bring your compass in case you
get lost!

From: Uncle Noah <napodaca@ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: ez031733@boris.ucdavis.edu
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Okay, here's what I thought...
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.961125182048.14985K-100000@boris.ucdavis.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I'm still a little tired, but I slept a little more last night, so I think
I can write a fairly coherent post here... :)

First off, I forgot to tell Troy that Dennis Barton says hello.  :)

Okay, I said this to Joe when we were driving home and it's the 100%
truth.  We walked into a house full of folks we didn't know and walked out
of a house full fo friends.  The vibe was so thick in that place that you
could almost hold it in your hands like a piece of Jell-o from a
childrens' wading pool.
I really didn't know what to expect, to tell you the truth.  I missed the
other cabin parties and I have been away from the list for so long, I
didn't even know if anyone would remember who I am.  When I found out I
was slotted for 12-2 I got really scared and decided to re-work the set...
Pretty much, I packed up and held on tight.
Saturday afternoon was so much fun, spinning random 80's electro stuff
(anyone else like the Art of Noise?) and getting to know the folks that
were around.  I didn't realize the game room was out there, or I would've
been playing air hockey... oh well...
By the time evening started setting in, I was already feeling the vibey
bonds growing stronger and stronger.  The decorations were awesome and
everyone seemd to really be in the mood for a good time.  I was really
getting into the groove with the evening sets and I had tons of fun
talking to everyone, playing games (Like Abalone and Sets!) and being
freaky in general (and sometimes getting photographed in the process...
;)....)
By about 11.40 I was totally stressed out and I didn't know if I could
make it through the set.  When the first crossfade went poorly, I really
got rattled (I apologize for that one, but the crossfade on the tape is
good :P)

So I took a deep breath and reflected, remembered a few Taoist meditations
and went back at it.  Then I noticed Joe starting to have fun ;)  That did
it for me right there.  Everyone dancing with me seemed really into the
stuff, even when I went to the new school electro, folks seemed to be
understanding my vibe.. I was really really happy.  :)
When I brought the tapes around, I was a little worried because so many
folks were over on the couches and blankets, but to my surprise, they were
almost all awake and grooving to the vibe from over there!  I was blown
away!
The rest of the evening was just amazing.  I was dead tired, and the
grooves kept my in a happy place.  The IDM set was especially interesting
to me, since I hadn't heard that stuff very much.. I liked it!  The live
stuff really got me going... I found myself awake with my eyes closed and
in a strange REM/alpha wave state where I was actively dreaming with the
music, but I wasn't actually asleep... really really fun stuff, folks.  :)

Sunday came a little too quickly, and I had to bug out to catch my plane
from Sacramento back to Orange County.  All day I have been at work
reflecting on the experience and have had this happy smile and warm spot
in my heart.  I feel bad that I won't be raving with you folks again for a
little while, but I promise that the next time I come up I will let you
know!  

Thanks to all of you who helped keep my personal vibe up, and thanks for
those who helped pamper my buddie, Joe!!!  He told me that he feels so
loved and welcome in the scene now!!  Look for him at parties in the
future!!!

Okay, lastly it's the BSP:
I'll have my new mixtape "Beyond the Process" ready in a few weeks...
sadly it won't be free, but I promise it will be fun!!!  If anyone thinks
they might be interested, let me know :)

Thanks again everybody!!!  You are all superstars to me!!!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Nov 25 19:56:09 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id TAA17986; Mon, 25 Nov 1996 19:56:09 -0800 (PST)
Received: from dfw-ix1.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id TAA17972; Mon, 25 Nov 1996 19:56:04 -0800 (PST)
Received: from wck-ca14-36.ix.netcom.com (shawna-@wck-ca14-36.ix.netcom.com [207.92.174.100]) by dfw-ix1.ix.netcom.com (8.6.13/8.6.12) with SMTP id TAA28609 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 25 Nov 1996 19:55:20 -0800
Date: Mon, 25 Nov 1996 19:55:20 -0800
Message-Id: <1.5.4.16.19961124203511.2977dab4@popd.ix.netcom.com>
X-Sender: shawna-@popd.ix.netcom.com (Unverified)
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.4 (16)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (Frisco Freaks)
From: The Laffin Happy Trip Farmer <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: Re:  Imagination without knowledge... (nrr)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>We think in terms of language.  Without advanced language concepts
>one is incapable (in general) of having advanced thoughts.  Why
>do we remember so little of our childhood up until the age of
>3 or 4?  It is because we do not have the language skills to
>make sense of our surroundings.  We can have vague rememberances
>of places or events but no strong recollections because we tend
>to remember (think) in terms of language concepts.  Noam Chomsky
>posits that language constructs are actually "hard-wired" into
>the human brain.  That is why children have such an amazing
>ability to acquire language skills.


The only reason language exists is so we can communicate with others (imo).
Language is our primary source of communication for the most part.  One does
not need language to think their thoughts, to know what I'm thinking does
not necessarily require English words. The specific need for a spoken
language only really arises when attempting to communicate those thoughts to
other people, if there was no reason to communicate with other people,
specific spoken words would not be necessary.  And I think children learn
language so quickly because they *have* to in order to survive in our world,
because they must communicate with others.  Also because there is nothing to
"unlearn" in learning your first language, unlike learning a 2nd language
after your first.  When learning spanish, I had to stop myself from thinking
english, & then start thinking in spanish, a two step process going from
translating to actual understanding.  New children have no such problem.
Anybody ever tried to learn to snow-board *after* knowing how to ski?  More
difficult than simply learning to snow-board without having skiing
experience, nothing to unlearn.


>There is a latin saying "Namen est Nomen" meaning "to name is
>to know".  It has been recognized for centuries that once you
>put a name to something (a concept, say) you are now "conscious"
>(have knowledge) of it.  A large part of learning a new subject is
>learning all the definitions ("names") that go with that subject....


Again, we only name things in order to communicate with others.  If I know a
tree produces edible fruit, I only need to understand that conceptually to
myself, I dont need to invent words to tell myself this.  I only need to
know the words for these things if I want to tell somebody else that the
fruit on the tree is edible.  I certainly understand plenty of things
conceptually, but sure as hell couldn't describe what I know using language.
Shit, even on the topic of words themselves, I understand definitions of
words correctly, but couldn't use words to describe what they meant in a
dictionary sense!


>Your imaginings are confined to the level of your knowledge.


I find the opposite to be quite true!  Aside from technical finite logical
deductions that require a certain base of factual knowledge for you start
with (how ya gonna figure out why your client's not seeing the server if you
don't even know what a mouse is, right? Gotta know something), I say
Balderdash! Foolishness! :)  Saying that my imaginings are limited to my
knowledge is pretty much the same as saying that I have no imagination at
all, that I know only facts that have been presented to me.  And I dare say
that from time to time, I've been known to have a rather vivid imagination,
much to the chagrin of my co-workers! ;)  I think creative thinking people
possibly have a broader spectrum of learning ability (more ways to intake &
assimilate information) than perhaps some of our more stodgy unimaginative
friends! :)


>To emphasize imagination and creativity over knowledge and logic
>is a creative dead-end.  


To emphasize knowledge & logic over imagination and creativity is a creative
dead-end, not the other way around.  Just look at Spock on Star Trek!  Not a
very imaginative fellow, in spite of being half-human.  And really, to
emphasize either one of these over the other is to limit your brain's
potential.  Emphasize them both!  People tend to think of these qualities as
being opposites, incompatible (left-brained people versus right-brained
people etc), but they actually complement each other, and when put to good
use together can produce phenomenal results, from whence come the true
geniuses imho.  


>People like to make a big deal over
>"non-linear" thinking and reality, but the concept of non-linear
>systems and thinking is itself a result of advanced mathematical
>concepts.  People could not "see" the patterns of nature that
>are fractal in nature until the mathematical concepts of fractals,
>chaos and non-linearity were invented.


I have to agree with Brian here, these things were discovered, not invented.
We came up with these terms to describe what it was we were experiencing, we
discovered these equations in order to better understand what it was we were
seeing.  I consider non-linear thought to be a simple fact (for me, anyway,
can't answer for the rest of you's).  My thoughts are non-linear, whether or
not we have a word or an equation for it.  I very often struggle with the
fact that I just don't have a vocabulary sufficient to describe the things I
think, experience, feel; linear strings of words to describe non-3rd
dimensional fractal expansions of thought, very inadequate.  If we didn't
think non-linearly, I don't think the concept of non-linear thought would
have been "invented" anyway, we wouldn't have been capable of it.  Just like
all other words, they were simply created to describe something we were
already seeing or experiencing, to other people.  "Oog find tree with good
fruit! Good fruit!"  "Oh yeah?  Moog find way to change subjective reality
by altering moog's perception! *grunt*"  Or whatever you want to describe.


>To have a higher conciousness (knowledge) one must first pass
>through lower stages of conciousness (knowledge).  What is
>conciousness but knowledge (of one's own state or of concepts
>or of reality)?


Consciousness and knowledge are not necessarily the same thing.  I think
that consciousness is simply awareness.  Awareness doesn't necessarily
require that you learn something, where I think that actual knowledge does.
But that's pretty debatable I guess, a semantics thingy; people will always
have different ideas of what constitutes their own consciousness.


>To separate conciousness and creativity from knowledge and empiricism
>is quite simply impossible....


This makes sense with regards to what I was saying before, the two sides of
the brain must be in balance.  Never will I try to separate them, wouldn't
be logical! ;)  


Ok, yakked enough.  See ya!

love,
Shawna

            
                   
         Do not go gentle into that good night.
       Rave! Rave into the dawning of the light!

In the search for good music in Tapei....

Someone on the list mentioned a club called KISS, although they forwarned 
me that the club was kinda on the cheesy side. But I figured what the
hell, so off I was to KISS on a Fri night. Absolutely beautiful club.
Marble, wooden dance floor, the B.S. roped off VIP areas, a killer
sound system and about $17. There was indeed a cheesy, Bobby
Brown-sounding group performing. I watched for a while, drank the beer
that was included with the price of admission, and they took a break. When
they took their break, the D.J.'s started spinning some fairly mediocre
house. But hey, it was something. Just to bother them, I went and asked if
they had any trance or techno(even though I party in S.F. I can never get
enough of it.) The told me that they were scared to play trance because
the crowd they played to wouldn't get it. I asked them if they knew of any
place in Tapei that did play trance. They gave me an address, and off I
went to club #2.

Club #2 turned out to be a place called Queens. $350 NT dollars to get
in(about $13 or $14 American), one drink included(which was an odd, but
welcome concept to me.) The setup was reminisent of 1015 Folsom. Two
floors, good lighting system, good sound, and a couple of bars. The
people were dressed up a bit(but not overly so,) which was a plesant
change of pace. 

I walked in, and was floored. The were playing some great sounding techno.
And the next song was good too. The next song was even better. They
continued to play great, wonderful, absofuckinglutely *FABULOUS* techno
and trance till 6 a.m. I could not for the life of me stop dancing, and I
rarely dance. The people were fairly friendly, looking like they were
having a good time. To say I was impressed is an understatement. 

I also hooked up with a British rave promoter who throws parties over
there and got the score of the night: The Taiwanese Rave flyer! I chatted
with him a bit about the scene over there. Parties are about $15, there
are only a couple of promoters, and even though drug-trafficking can
result in a death sentence, there are all the amEnities one would find at
home. All in all I got the impression that the scene was fairly new
over there(but the D.J.'s sure know what's up.) A very pleasant
experience. I give it two glowsticks up.

Thus concludes the international rave report for Tapei, Mon. Nov 25 1996.       

The next installment will be coming live from Seoul, Korea.

                                        Black Adder

what's wrong with cops being all over the place?
i have no problem with cops (until they start beating people up). until
then, they're just doing they job. i don't hate them for doing what they
beleive in.
besides, who cares if cops are at a party? i _like_ it when i see the cops
show up, verify that the party is safe, smile at everyone, and leave. were
it up to most cops, they wouldn't bust parties. decisions come down from
above.

maybe the cops make the e dealers by the front entrance clam up for a
while. or maybe the fool taking e in front of a cop gets busted. gee, that
would be too bad. i guess that puts a damper on all the over drug users and
pushy drug dealers out there. i don't think it will put a damper on any fun
i might have.

Date: Tue, 26 Nov 1996 00:25:08 -0800

From: Argon 99 <erase99@sirius.com>
Subject: [Newsflash]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

ok. maybe i'm a little cranky right now because i have a headache. or maybe
i'm all twitchy because i just finished a marathon 3 hour netquake session.
but anyway..
i've seen a lot of new ravers lately, and i thought it's probably time to
point out again that:

you don't need e to have a good time.

???!! yes. it's true. you can have fun at a rave without drugs. 
do you need to take e every single weekend? no. unless you are trying to
seek out some higher meaning to your life through the use of mdma, taking
it every single weekend to "have a good time" makes you no different than
the guy who goes out and gets drunk every weekend. sure, e is probably
safer than alcohol (certainly in the short term, possibly in the long term
as well), but you are doing it for the exact same purpose: to get messed up
and have fun. wow. how idyllic.

of course, you don't even have to pay attention to me. maybe i just made
myself grow up too fast. or maybe i'm trying to spare you some of the shit
i went through. my advice: go help out at a party. be a part of something
you help create. believe me, the feeling you get from that will last long
after any e hangover will. instant gratification is all fine and good, but
it's just that - don't mistake it for anything else.

maybe what i'm trying to get across is be responsible to yourself. be
responsible to your body, be responsible to your mind. do e if you enjoy
it, but don't go crazy and put a huge stress on your body. no doctor alive
would have the gall to suggest that you do e more that once every ten or
fourteen days. don't burn out your body, and don't do it to your mind, either.

raving shouldn't be about how many drugs you can stuff down your throat
(that's what adolescence is about!), it should be about discovering
yourself; finding a direction for your life, and using that knowledge to
make it better. no chemical is substitute for self-knowledge and
introspection.

oh well. i'm not writing so well tonight. i'll stop before i make some huge
blunder.

happy thanksgiving (even though REAL thanksgiving is in october)
play safe.
-brendan
