My computer tells me that on Mon, 25 Nov 1996, Advanced Technology 99
shared:

> what's wrong with cops being all over the place?
> i have no problem with cops (until they start beating people up). until
> then, they're just doing they job. i don't hate them for doing what they
> beleive in.
> besides, who cares if cops are at a party? i _like_ it when i see the cops
> show up, verify that the party is safe, smile at everyone, and leave. were
> it up to most cops, they wouldn't bust parties. decisions come down from
> above.
> 
> maybe the cops make the e dealers by the front entrance clam up for a
> while. or maybe the fool taking e in front of a cop gets busted. gee, that
> would be too bad. i guess that puts a damper on all the over drug users and
> pushy drug dealers out there. i don't think it will put a damper on any fun
> i might have.

	So seeing a friend of yours get hauled off to jail in front of you
wouldn't spoil your fun, Brendan?  Or do you not have any "fool" friends
who might accidentally do something where they could be witnessed by a
cop?
	Maybe cops take orders from above, and are "just doing their job";
so were Hitler's SS troops when they loaded the ovens.  That's not a 
stretch -- take someone who believes that if you break the law you are a
criminal who deserves whatever punishment the law dictates you should
receive, and gives little or no thought to the morality of the law in
question, and you have an SS trooper waiting to happen.  
	I've talked to many cops who think this way, and I think it is a
mindset encouraged by the institutions they belong to.
	I do not hate the police as individuals.  I'd love to see a cop
grooving to the music at a rave (people on this list have mentioned seeing
this, so I know it happens, although in my five years of semi-regular
raving I don't recall ever seeing it).  However when cops are at a party,
it usually means either the party is about to be busted, or it is a large
and often low-vibe event that is overpriced in part because the promoters
had to hire cops for security in order not to get busted.
	Given these circumstances Brendan, can you blame me or Pablo 
or anyone else for not being thrilled to see cops all over the place at a
party?

Question authority before it questions you,

				<<< Starchild >>>

On Tue, 26 Nov 1996, Argon 99 wrote:

> fourteen days. don't burn out your body, and don't do it to your mind, either.
> 
> raving shouldn't be about how many drugs you can stuff down your throat
> (that's what adolescence is about!), it should be about discovering
> yourself; finding a direction for your life, and using that knowledge to
> make it better. no chemical is substitute for self-knowledge and
> introspection.

while i am a huge fan of E, i must second some of brendan's sentiments
here.

now, i have to say, i don't agree that E is about "instant
gratification"... i have used it a number of times in ways that it has
helped me gain self-knowledge, aided introspection, and facilitated some
very real lasting friendships.

but i have noticed that with frequent use, all of these effects diminish
rapidly, leaving just the "high" (often followed by a low).

it's sometimes hard to be moderate with such a special substance, but
believe me, it will get a lot less special if you overuse it.

E is not physically addictive, but it can be psychologically addictive. if
you haven't found this out yet, consider yourself lucky-- but unless
you're very conscientious about moderation, you will someday experience
psychological withdrawal after an Experience (which will most likely seem
empty in retrospect), and you will know exactly what i'm talking about.

of course, going through that can be a learning/growing experience too, if
you deal with it in a responsible and self-aware fashion...

just my 125 milligrams--

love,

brian

Luuuuuuvleee!

Haven't checked mail to see if everyone else had a good time, but I sure did!
Big thanks to all who participated, and extra big thanks to Sound System
Wonder Workers Rick Riffle, Eric D(?) & Mark Camp, Chowmasters Kerry L, Tom
Clark & Ahnon Cross , Decor-Divas Melissa Wong, Laura Parker & Robin G, and
everyone who contributed, moved equipment, and stuck around for clean up.

As for the artists... uhh...  hmm... MARK! WHEN ARE THE TAPES GONNA BE
READY!?!? Rarely has my appetite for the funk been so satisfied as it was by
Toby Egan's, Derek's, & Mei-Lwun's Sets. Did everyone hear Mei-Lwun's band's
(Soulstice(sp?) tape on sunday? Just coincidence that one of their records
was played by another D.J. at the cabin trip last year?... I think not. And
can someone tell me where the hell Noah and his magic crate get all those
wonderful samples?!

Right down to the last drop of coffee and the last buttered nugget at Sunday
eve's Buttercup Pantry experience, twas alllllll goooood!.... well... 99.999
goood%. I kinda feel I need to say something about having liked to see more
faces involved in the clean-up on Sunday. It would've made things go much
faster and given us all time to relax & reflect. But that's about all I can
say seeing as how I ended up with a year's supply of leftover groceries.

There is a lost and found box: Day Glo Blanky, Vuarnets, Green Ski Jacket,
Army Jacket Liner, Brown Girl's Shirt, Blue Shirt, Black Ski Pants, Winery
Shirt, D.Q. Shirt, Black Makeup Bag, Letterman's Tool, Purple Flashlight
(Jon's), Contact Cleaner, BM Laminate, Bottle of Equinox, 3 C.D.s (Krishnas?)
and a Bar of Soap. Oh yeah, Pengo's missing his pipe and Dianna's missing her
toothpaste. Any clues?

As for the finances, I'm glad to say it worked out close to square (+/- $50,
depending on deposit) Minimal damages and no major injuries known.

Last year some cabin folks had a very special reunion dinner the next week,
if anyone was interested in doing that, I could certainly contribute some
groceries!

Love & Reflections,
-StEvEo

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Nov 26 09:52:41 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id JAA00767; Tue, 26 Nov 1996 09:52:41 -0800 (PST)
Received: from arkons.lmsc.lockheed.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with SMTP id JAA00743; Tue, 26 Nov 1996 09:52:16 -0800 (PST)
Received: by arkons.lmsc.lockheed.com with SMTP (Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.993.5)
	id <01BBDB7F.8BEE2430@arkons.lmsc.lockheed.com>; Tue, 26 Nov 1996 09:52:33 -0800
Message-ID: <c=US%a=_%p=LMCO%l=LMCO/LMMS/0001A895@arkons.lmsc.lockheed.com>
From: "Thompson. Jim" <jthompson@arkons.lmsc.lockheed.com>
To: sfraves - send mail to list <sfraves@hyperreal.com>,
        The Laffin Happy Trip Farmer <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: Re:  Imagination without knowledge... (nrr)
Date: Tue, 26 Nov 1996 09:52:00 -0800
X-Mailer:  Microsoft Exchange Server Internet Mail Connector Version 4.0.993.5
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I wrote:

>We think in terms of language.  Without advanced language concepts
>one is incapable (in general) of having advanced thoughts.  Why
>do we remember so little of our childhood up until the age of
>3 or 4?  It is because we do not have the language skills to
>make sense of our surroundings.  We can have vague rememberances
>of places or events but no strong recollections because we tend
>to remember (think) in terms of language concepts.  Noam Chomsky
>posits that language constructs are actually "hard-wired" into
>the human brain.  That is why children have such an amazing
>ability to acquire language skills.


Laffin Happy Trip Farmer wrote:

>> The only reason language exists is so we can communicate with others (imo).
>> Language is our primary source of communication for the most part.  One
does
>> not need language to think their thoughts, to know what I'm thinking does
>> not necessarily require English words. The specific need for a spoken
>> language only really arises when attempting to communicate those thoughts
to
>> other people, if there was no reason to communicate with other people,
>> specific spoken words would not be necessary.  And I think children learn

I reply:

Au contraire!  I think language skills are ESSENTIAL to thinking beyond
a
primitive, animalistic level!  To argue that you do not need language to
have
advanced thoughts does not (IMHO) stand up to analysis.  Look at
mathematics:
advances in mathematics often come ONLY AFTER new ways of symbolically
representing concepts are invented ("discovered").  Without a "zero"
multiplication
and division are very difficult (at best!), invention of a cartesian
coordinate system
largely made analytic geometry possible (polar coordinate system too!),
etc, etc....
Languages are merely symbols representing thoughts.  Once one has a good
set of symbols and a good set of rules for manipulating them, MUCH
higher
levels of abstraction are possible.  Why has there been such an
explosive increase
in human knowledge since the invention ("discovery") of symbolically
representing
words on paper?  Words on paper allow for thoughts to be built OVER TIME
-
to be refined, re-worked, improved.......
 ----------
From: The Laffin Happy Trip Farmer
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re:  Imagination without knowledge... (nrr)
Date: Monday, November 25, 1996 7:55PM

>We think in terms of language.  Without advanced language concepts
>one is incapable (in general) of having advanced thoughts.  Why
>do we remember so little of our childhood up until the age of
>3 or 4?  It is because we do not have the language skills to
>make sense of our surroundings.  We can have vague rememberances
>of places or events but no strong recollections because we tend
>to remember (think) in terms of language concepts.  Noam Chomsky
>posits that language constructs are actually "hard-wired" into
>the human brain.  That is why children have such an amazing
>ability to acquire language skills.


The only reason language exists is so we can communicate with others
(imo).
Language is our primary source of communication for the most part.  One
does
not need language to think their thoughts, to know what I'm thinking
does
not necessarily require English words. The specific need for a spoken
language only really arises when attempting to communicate those
thoughts to
other people, if there was no reason to communicate with other people,
specific spoken words would not be necessary.  And I think children
learn
language so quickly because they *have* to in order to survive in our
world,
because they must communicate with others.  Also because there is
nothing to
"unlearn" in learning your first language, unlike learning a 2nd
language
after your first.  When learning spanish, I had to stop myself from
thinking
english, & then start thinking in spanish, a two step process going from
translating to actual understanding.  New children have no such problem.
Anybody ever tried to learn to snow-board *after* knowing how to ski?
More
difficult than simply learning to snow-board without having skiing
experience, nothing to unlearn.


>There is a latin saying "Namen est Nomen" meaning "to name is
>to know".  It has been recognized for centuries that once you
>put a name to something (a concept, say) you are now "conscious"
>(have knowledge) of it.  A large part of learning a new subject is
>learning all the definitions ("names") that go with that subject....


Again, we only name things in order to communicate with others.  If I
know a
tree produces edible fruit, I only need to understand that conceptually
to
myself, I dont need to invent words to tell myself this.  I only need to
know the words for these things if I want to tell somebody else that the
fruit on the tree is edible.  I certainly understand plenty of things
conceptually, but sure as hell couldn't describe what I know using
language.
Shit, even on the topic of words themselves, I understand definitions of
words correctly, but couldn't use words to describe what they meant in a
dictionary sense!


>Your imaginings are confined to the level of your knowledge.


I find the opposite to be quite true!  Aside from technical finite
logical
deductions that require a certain base of factual knowledge for you
start
with (how ya gonna figure out why your client's not seeing the server if
you
don't even know what a mouse is, right? Gotta know something), I say
Balderdash! Foolishness! :)  Saying that my imaginings are limited to my
knowledge is pretty much the same as saying that I have no imagination
at
all, that I know only facts that have been presented to me.  And I dare
say
that from time to time, I've been known to have a rather vivid
imagination,
much to the chagrin of my co-workers! ;)  I think creative thinking
people
possibly have a broader spectrum of learning ability (more ways to
intake &
assimilate information) than perhaps some of our more stodgy
unimaginative
friends! :)


>To emphasize imagination and creativity over knowledge and logic
>is a creative dead-end.


To emphasize knowledge & logic over imagination and creativity is a
creative
dead-end, not the other way around.  Just look at Spock on Star Trek!
Not a
very imaginative fellow, in spite of being half-human.  And really, to
emphasize either one of these over the other is to limit your brain's
potential.  Emphasize them both!  People tend to think of these
qualities as
being opposites, incompatible (left-brained people versus right-brained
people etc), but they actually complement each other, and when put to
good
use together can produce phenomenal results, from whence come the true
geniuses imho.


>People like to make a big deal over
>"non-linear" thinking and reality, but the concept of non-linear
>systems and thinking is itself a result of advanced mathematical
>concepts.  People could not "see" the patterns of nature that
>are fractal in nature until the mathematical concepts of fractals,
>chaos and non-linearity were invented.


I have to agree with Brian here, these things were discovered, not
invented.
We came up with these terms to describe what it was we were
experiencing, we
discovered these equations in order to better understand what it was we
were
seeing.  I consider non-linear thought to be a simple fact (for me,
anyway,
can't answer for the rest of you's).  My thoughts are non-linear,
whether or
not we have a word or an equation for it.  I very often struggle with
the
fact that I just don't have a vocabulary sufficient to describe the
things I
think, experience, feel; linear strings of words to describe non-3rd
dimensional fractal expansions of thought, very inadequate.  If we
didn't
think non-linearly, I don't think the concept of non-linear thought
would
have been "invented" anyway, we wouldn't have been capable of it.  Just
like
all other words, they were simply created to describe something we were
already seeing or experiencing, to other people.  "Oog find tree with
good
fruit! Good fruit!"  "Oh yeah?  Moog find way to change subjective
reality
by altering moog's perception! *grunt*"  Or whatever you want to
describe.


>To have a higher conciousness (knowledge) one must first pass
>through lower stages of conciousness (knowledge).  What is
>conciousness but knowledge (of one's own state or of concepts
>or of reality)?


Consciousness and knowledge are not necessarily the same thing.  I think
that consciousness is simply awareness.  Awareness doesn't necessarily
require that you learn something, where I think that actual knowledge
does.
But that's pretty debatable I guess, a semantics thingy; people will
always
have different ideas of what constitutes their own consciousness.


>To separate conciousness and creativity from knowledge and empiricism
>is quite simply impossible....


This makes sense with regards to what I was saying before, the two sides
of
the brain must be in balance.  Never will I try to separate them,
wouldn't
be logical! ;)


Ok, yakked enough.  See ya!

love,
Shawna



         Do not go gentle into that good night.
       Rave! Rave into the dawning of the light!

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hi everyone!  i need your help! (******ATTENTION*********THIS IS COMPLETELY
NON-RAVE RELATED)
My apologies for posting this here.  i am working against time and well,
desperate times call for desperate measures....thank you for your time in
advance.
>
>i am taking a human factors class, referred to as ergonomics. the science
>that explores human capibilities and behavior and how these characteristics
>are incorporated into the design, evaluation, operation and maintance of
>products. (yes, that was a definition)
>
>for my final project, we are designing a universal remote control.
>in order for us to design a remote, we need input from people who use remote
>controls!
>ideally we need a sample size of about 50 people, so your answers will not
>only be greatly appreciated but will make a large impact on our final design.
>*a side note here: all of my responses up til now, except one, have been
>from men.  although i need as many responses as i can get my hands on, i
>would love to hear from more women!*
>
>if you are interested, please answer the following questions and return to
>me as soon as possible.
>if you would like to see the end result, please do not hesitate to let me
>know.  we should have our project done by early december (if we are lucky)
>
>on behalf of my group: natalie, tofoy, noell, tristan and myself, we thank
>you for your time!
>***************************************************************************
*****************
>
>your age:
>gender:
>
>how many people in your house use the t.v?.:
>
>how many remotes do you have? (i.e. tv, vcr, converter, stereo):
>
>do you have a universal remote control?:
>
>if no, why not?:
>
>how do you use your remote when changing channels? (i.e. hold it in your
>hand, leave it on the table, carry it with you around the house, etc...):
>
>what do you like about your remotes? (size of buttons, options):
>
>what do you dislike about your remote?:
>
>how many tv's do you have?:
>
>where is the t.v. you use the most?:
>
>are there particular channels you watch the most?:
>
>do you have a picture-in-picture t.v.?:
>
>do you find you watch more than 1 program at a time?:
>
>if you were able to design a universal remote that would best fit your
>needs, what would it be like?: (take into consideration size, shape, would
>the buttons be illuminated, if you watch t.v. in the dark, would it work
>with on screen programming, waterproof - children in mind here, able to work
>more than 1 t.v.):
>
>
>***************************************************************************
******************
>
>
>thanks again for your help!

As you read, Audio Impact has lost its space, but maybe this is a blessing
is disguise. Though the club had a good vibe last week, the management was
a real downer. The bartenders and security were big dicks. I can't remember
the last club I went to that had big goons like that doing THOROUGH
body searches. I saw a few people get bumped around by them, and got tired
of seeing them shine flashlights onto people's faces to make sure they
weren't up to no good. Chill out, already. It'll be a good club no matter
where it's moved to, and I know we can do better than that.

At 9:54 AM -0800 11/26/96, Thompson. Jim wrote:
<snip>
>Au contraire!  I think language skills are ESSENTIAL to thinking beyond a
>primitive, animalistic level!
I have difficulty with such anthropocentric langauge.  "Man is the
highest", "the center", "has dominion over the beasts", etc.  Reminds me of
Sunday school.  What have the cognitive changes in the human psyche wrought
over the past 5 millenia?  High tech wars which require the courage to puch
a button while safely out of range, television, coca-cola and breast
implants.  Human history is filled with cases of genocide and forgive me if
I'm just unaware but I don't recall hearing of such mass slaughterings
among "primitive" animals.  IMHO many of the greatest advances in the human
condition are the result of getting back in tune with such "primitive" and
"lower" functions as compassion, love, and other emotions.  My cat feels
love, feels like it belongs, and loves me.  What "advances" could be more
important than that?

Figured I'd send this out for all those computer types like myself.  Might
as well find things to send you all while I sit around waiting for code to
compile.


> > Subject: Microsoft Buys Catholic Church
> >      
> > VATICAN CITY (AP) -- In a joint press conference in St. Peter's Square this 
> > morning, MICROSOFT Corp. and the Vatican announced that the Redmond software 
> > giant will acquire the Roman Catholic Church in exchange for an unspecified 
> > number of shares of MICROSOFT common stock. If the deal goes through, it 
> > will be the first time a computer software company has acquired a major 
> > world religion.
> >      
> > With the acquisition, Pope John Paul II will become the senior 
> > vice-president of the combined company's new Religious Software Division, 
> > while MICROSOFT senior vice-presidents Michael Maples and Steven Ballmer 
> > will be invested in the College of Cardinals, said MICROSOFT Chairman Bill 
> > Gates.
> >      
> > "We expect a lot of growth in the religious market in the next five to ten 
> > years," said Gates. "The combined resources of MICROSOFT and the Catholic 
> > Church will allow us to make religion easier and more fun for a broader 
> > range of people."
> >      
> > Through the MICROSOFT Network, the company's new on-line service, "we will 
> > make the sacraments available on-line for the first time" and revive the 
> > popular pre-Counter-Reformation practice of selling indulgences, said Gates. 
> > "You can get Communion, confess your sins, receive absolution -- even reduce 
> > your time in Purgatory -- all without leaving your home."
> >      
> > A new software application, MICROSOFT Church, will include a macro language 
> > which you can program to download heavenly graces automatically while you 
> > are away from your computer.
> >      
> > An estimated 17,000 people attended the announcement in St Peter's Square, 
> > watching on a 60-foot screen as comedian Don Novello -- in character as 
> > Father Guido Sarducci -- hosted the event, which was broadcast by satellite 
> > to 700 sites worldwide.
> >      
> > Pope John Paul II said little during the announcement. When Novello chided 
> > Gates, "Now I guess you get to wear one of these pointy hats," the crowd 
> > roared, but the pontiff's smile seemed strained.
> >      
> > The deal grants MICROSOFT exclusive electronic rights to the Bible and the 
> > Vatican's prized art collection, which includes works by such masters as 
> > Michelangelo and Da Vinci. But critics say MICROSOFT will face stiff 
> > challenges if it attempts to limit competitors' access to these key 
> > intellectual properties.
> >      
> > "The Jewish people invented the look and feel of the holy scriptures," said 
> > Rabbi David Gottschalk of Philadelphia. "You take the parting of the Red Sea
> >  -- we had that thousands of years before the Catholics came on the scene."
> >      
> > But others argue that the Catholic and Jewish faiths both draw on a common 
> > Abrahamic heritage. "The Catholic Church has just been more successful in 
> > marketing it to a larger audience," notes Notre Dame theologian Father 
> > Kenneth Madigan. Over the last 2,000 years, the Catholic Church's market 
> > share has increased dramatically, while Judaism, which was the first to 
> > offer many of the concepts now touted by Christianity, lags behind.
> >      
> > Historically, the Church has a reputation as an aggressive competitor, 
> > leading crusades to pressure people to upgrade to Catholicism, and entering 
> > into exclusive licensing arrangements in various kingdoms whereby all 
> > subjects were instilled with Catholicism, whether or not they planned to use 
> > it. Today Christianity is available from several denominations, but the 
> > Catholic version is still the most widely used. The Church's mission is to 
> > reach "the four corners of the earth," echoing MICROSOFT's vision of "a 
> > computer on every desktop and in every home".
> >      
> > Gates described MICROSOFT's long-term strategy to develop a scalable 
> > religious architecture that will support all religions through emulation. A 
> > single core religion will be offered with a choice of interfaces according 
> > to the religion desired -- "One religion, a couple of different 
> > implementations," said Gates.
> >      
> > The MICROSOFT move could spark a wave of mergers and acquisitions, according 
> > to Herb Peters, a spokesman for the U.S. Southern Baptist Conference, as 
> > other churches scramble to strengthen their position in the increasingly 
> > competitive religious market.
> > 
> > 
> 
>

can party before Ubiquitous and then have alittle after-party as well. For
some of us we can party all day Sat. since we will have the room until

that are adjacent.

From: Thompson. Jim
To: Starchild
Subject: NRR: It takes a GOVERNMENT to Raze a Village

Starchild wrote:

>> 	Maybe cops take orders from above, and are "just doing their job";
>> so were Hitler's SS troops when they loaded the ovens.  That's not a
>> stretch -- take someone who believes that if you break the law you are a
>> criminal who deserves whatever punishment the law dictates you should
>> receive, and gives little or no thought to the morality of the law in
>> question, and you have an SS trooper waiting to happen.



If one looks at all the horrors of the 20th century one thing stands in
common - government power.   Whether the powerful government
is left or right the body counts are the same:

	Russian Communists        10 - 20 million dead (starvation of Kulaks,
Gulag)
	German Fascists	            10 - 20 million dead (concentration camps,
war )
	Chinese Communists       20 - 30 million dead (starvation, work camps)
	Kmer Rouge	            1- 2  million (killing fields, work camps)
	Etc, Etc, Etc	            millions and millions......


The above counts aren't even considering (well, only partially) the
deaths
in this century due to (government led) armed conflicts.  The amount of
damage we humans as INDIVIDUALS can do is considerable, as organized
groups collected into governmental bodies, it is astronomical.....

From: Starchild
To: Advanced Technology 99
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Why the boys in blue make us blue

My computer tells me that on Mon, 25 Nov 1996, Advanced Technology 99
shared:

        jim thompson - cube root fact axon info grid data fate
        ::: ..::.  ....:  ::::.::::::     .       ....::... ::
        .:..:::::  ....:::.....::.:::::::::..     .. :..:::::

        :::..:::....:: .:......::..   :::::.::         ::.....
> beleive in.
> besides, who cares if cops are at a party? i _like_ it when i see the cops
> show up, verify that the party is safe, smile at everyone, and leave. were
> it up to most cops, they wouldn't bust parties. decisions come down from
> above.
>
> maybe the cops make the e dealers by the front entrance clam up for a
> while. or maybe the fool taking e in front of a cop gets busted. gee, that
> would be too bad. i guess that puts a damper on all the over drug users and
> pushy drug dealers out there. i don't think it will put a damper on any fun
> i might have.

	So seeing a friend of yours get hauled off to jail in front of you
wouldn't spoil your fun, Brendan?  Or do you not have any "fool" friends
who might accidentally do something where they could be witnessed by a
cop?
	Maybe cops take orders from above, and are "just doing their job";
so were Hitler's SS troops when they loaded the ovens.  That's not a
stretch -- take someone who believes that if you break the law you are a
criminal who deserves whatever punishment the law dictates you should
receive, and gives little or no thought to the morality of the law in
question, and you have an SS trooper waiting to happen.
	I've talked to many cops who think this way, and I think it is a
mindset encouraged by the institutions they belong to.
	I do not hate the police as individuals.  I'd love to see a cop
grooving to the music at a rave (people on this list have mentioned
seeing
this, so I know it happens, although in my five years of semi-regular
raving I don't recall ever seeing it).  However when cops are at a
party,
it usually means either the party is about to be busted, or it is a
large
and often low-vibe event that is overpriced in part because the
promoters
had to hire cops for security in order not to get busted.
	Given these circumstances Brendan, can you blame me or Pablo
or anyone else for not being thrilled to see cops all over the place at
a
party?

Question authority before it questions you,

				<<< Starchild >>>


> [late night headache/feverish rantings - a little incoherent, sorry. i'll
> try and get better. <g>]
> -brendan

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Subject: Rave Lecture at SFSU
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.961126121109.11961A-100000@pluto>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



  A couple of folks asked me to take notes and report on Dr. Rietveld's
lecture, so here's a selection of ideas and topics that she covered:

1) House music began in Chicago in venues for gay Latinos and
African-Americans
2) Techno began in the mid-80s in Detroit
3) Raves started in England
4) All the above, plus other influences and confluences, make it difficult
to trace the evolution of dance music today. The process is more like a
web than a linear development.
5) The purpose of house music is TO DISAPPEAR -- disappear from the
critical gaze of conventional society, and to take a "vacation" from your
ordinary self, to lose yourself in the music and dance.
6) "In house, you don't dance to the music you like: you like the music
you dance to."
7) House music is "interactive consumption."
8) A rave is a temporary cult, where the DJs/shamen can shape the
emotional
terrain of their dancer/congregation.
9) At a rave, the crowds are as much responsible as the djs and
technicians for what happens.
10) Every good rave should end with an "anthem" rather than just come to
an abrupt halt.
11) A rave is a festival, not a spectacle. 
    spectacle = regimented and choreographed
    festival = spontaneous and interactive
12) Susie K brought up the significance of raves taking place in old
warehouses. Dr. Rietveld commented on the McLuhanesque fitness of a
digital, postmodern phenomenon (raves) taking place in the shell of an
abandoned modern institution (the warehouse and factory).

  All in all, a very good talk. Whether you agree or disagree with any
point, the whole presentation was very thoughtful and serious.

On Tue, 26 Nov 1996, Argon 99 wrote:

> ok. maybe i'm a little cranky right now because i have a headache. or maybe
> i'm all twitchy because i just finished a marathon 3 hour netquake session.
> but anyway..
> i've seen a lot of new ravers lately, and i thought it's probably time to
> point out again that:
> 
> you don't need e to have a good time.
> 
> ???!! yes. it's true. you can have fun at a rave without drugs. 
> do you need to take e every single weekend? no. unless you are trying to
> seek out some higher meaning to your life through the use of mdma, taking
> it every single weekend to "have a good time" makes you no different than
> the guy who goes out and gets drunk every weekend. sure, e is probably
> safer than alcohol (certainly in the short term, possibly in the long term
> as well), but you are doing it for the exact same purpose: to get messed up
> and have fun. wow. how idyllic.
> 
> of course, you don't even have to pay attention to me. maybe i just made
> myself grow up too fast. or maybe i'm trying to spare you some of the shit
> i went through. my advice: go help out at a party. be a part of something
> you help create. believe me, the feeling you get from that will last long
> after any e hangover will. instant gratification is all fine and good, but
> it's just that - don't mistake it for anything else.
> 
> maybe what i'm trying to get across is be responsible to yourself. be
> responsible to your body, be responsible to your mind. do e if you enjoy
> it, but don't go crazy and put a huge stress on your body. no doctor alive
> would have the gall to suggest that you do e more that once every ten or
> fourteen days. don't burn out your body, and don't do it to your mind, either.
> 
> raving shouldn't be about how many drugs you can stuff down your throat
> (that's what adolescence is about!), it should be about discovering
> yourself; finding a direction for your life, and using that knowledge to
> make it better. no chemical is substitute for self-knowledge and
> introspection.
> 
> oh well. i'm not writing so well tonight. i'll stop before i make some huge
> blunder.
> 
> happy thanksgiving (even though REAL thanksgiving is in october)
> play safe.
> -brendan
>

I will probably get flamed for this, but what the hell:

I would add marijuana to this statement. It is rather interesting just how
socially acceptable it is within the scene. I am by no means against it
in any way shape or form, but I question the need to be constantly using
it to have a good time. I can't count the number of times I have asked
someone what they have been doing and heard "Smoking lots of ganja."
Really, if you walked up to someone and asked them what they had been 
doing lately and they said "Getting drunk every night," or "Doing lots of
speed," I think many people would feel that they had a problem. But for
some odd reason, this view does not seem to extend to pot. Just a random
thought I had.....


                                          Black Adder

> I will probably get flamed for this, but what the hell:
> 
> I would add marijuana to this statement. It is rather interesting just how
> socially acceptable it is within the scene. I am by no means against it
> in any way shape or form, but I question the need to be constantly using
> it to have a good time. I can't count the number of times I have asked
> someone what they have been doing and heard "Smoking lots of ganja."
> Really, if you walked up to someone and asked them what they had been
> doing lately and they said "Getting drunk every night," or "Doing lots of
> speed," I think many people would feel that they had a problem. But for
> some odd reason, this view does not seem to extend to pot. Just a random
> thought I had.....
> 
>                                           Black Adder
> 
> hmmm. ok. insert blowtorch sound here.  just kidding. 

I see use of substances as ok - if you can apply it towards something 
(art, music, general creation, etc..) 

As far as marijuana - it is a very natural substance, nothing artificial, 
been with us for thousands of years (so has alchohol, but the behaviral 
effects are quite different, not to mention the buzz from alchohol is 
aquired when your brain is getting poisoned).  True - too much marijuana 
can be bad for you (and expensive!) but the side effects are slim - 
usually limited to a scratchy throat and a severe case of the munchies 
and the need to go to sleep. :)  Some studies say that it can be cancer 
causing but the method of research seemed a bit invalid to me... no 
cancer cases have been documented as being caused by gettin' irie too 
often.

On Tue, 26 Nov 1996, Courtney Nielsen wrote:

> I see use of substances as ok - if you can apply it towards something 
> (art, music, general creation, etc..) 

I see those as valid uses. I also see using substances just to have a
great time as valid, *in moderation*. I make no excuses for my activities,
and feel no need to ascribe my uses to "intellectual stimulation"(although
at times they have been.)

> As far as marijuana - it is a very natural substance, nothing artificial, 
> been with us for thousands of years (so has alchohol, but the behaviral 
> effects are quite different, not to mention the buzz from alchohol is 
> aquired when your brain is getting poisoned).  True - too much marijuana 
> can be bad for you (and expensive!) but the side effects are slim - 
> usually limited to a scratchy throat and a severe case of the munchies 
> and the need to go to sleep. :)  Some studies say that it can be cancer 
> causing but the method of research seemed a bit invalid to me... no 
> cancer cases have been documented as being caused by gettin' irie too 
> often.

I am not speaking from a physiological standpoint, but rather from a
psychological one. Alcohol, pot, E, LSD, etc. all alter your perception of
reality to varying degrees. I just question why it seems to be acceptable
to use one certain type of mind-altering substance in great quantity,
whereas if you to use some of the others, you would be labeled an
alcoholic or an addict. I am not trying to condemn anyone at all, just
musing on the disparity in how certain substance are viewed.

                                      Black Adder

On Tue, 26 Nov 1996, Arthur Chandler wrote:

> 12) Susie K brought up the significance of raves taking place in old
> warehouses. Dr. Rietveld commented on the McLuhanesque fitness of a
> digital, postmodern phenomenon (raves) taking place in the shell of an
> abandoned modern institution (the warehouse and factory).

Thanks for the notes. The above struck me as very amusing, as it
obfusicates a very simple reality: Warehouses are used because they are
big, usually empty, and cheap. I don't think this needs to be viewed from
an anything-esque perspective to get to the root of it.... ;-)

> As far as marijuana - it is a very natural substance, nothing artificial, 
> been with us for thousands of years (so has alchohol, but the behaviral 
> effects are quite different, not to mention the buzz from alchohol is 
> aquired when your brain is getting poisoned).  True - too much marijuana 
> can be bad for you (and expensive!) but the side effects are slim - 
> usually limited to a scratchy throat and a severe case of the munchies 
> and the need to go to sleep. :)  Some studies say that it can be cancer 
> causing but the method of research seemed a bit invalid to me... no 
> cancer cases have been documented as being caused by gettin' irie too 
> often.
> 
You know...I would be one of the last people to diss pot as a huge societal
evil. Anyone who knows me can attest to that fact. But please, let's be
real, ok? We didn't need a scientific study to know that cigarettes get
people hooked and that these people happen to develop bad coughs and many
of them died prematurely. right? I'm not comparing the ill effects of
smokes to pot, I'm saying that these things were evident before the
president classified nicotine as an addictive substance.

Among the side effects of pot that I or friends have expereinced are: panic
attacks, double vision, depression, lethargy, and the beforementioned
scratchy throats (and tattered lungs). I don't understand how cigarettes
could cause lung cancer, but that pot smoke, which is harsher, somehow
would not. *shrug*

 I have also had many many special experiences... with friends and
alone. It can be very theraputic on several different levels. 

But to ignore the obvious: That is can be damaging to certain individuals,
and to believe that 'the lack of scientific studies' somehow makes these
side effects invalid is silly. 
-peace- 
alex

ps- I've noticed a lot of responses copying the entire thread. It's a real
pain sometimes, not to mention a waste of space, so let's be more careful:)

CoolWorld will have 40W lasers, Mega Watt sound systems, and more.  Lots
more.  Sure, it won't have the same look and feel of a little F8 party.
And there will be people from LA, gangster types, drunks, narcs, and
everything else.  So what.

Hide what you don't want taken away in your pants (like high school) at
the entrance.

Use some discretion when smoking.  

Don't EVER look into the eyes of a gangster type.  You can spot them
easily, just don't look at them, especially up close.  They will leave
you alone, they are looking for a fight, not a dance.  You know the
clothes, the hat, the look, even the 'tuff' expression on the face.
They will mostly grow up to go to jail or be killed by another.  Leave
them alone.  

Life is full of dangers:  Ski within boundaries.  Avoid jelly fish.
Don't look into a laser.

If you know how to avoid problems, you can have a good time.  15,000
people.  I intend to go, and I believe I will have a good, safe,  time.

On Tue, 26 Nov 1996, Courtney Nielsen wrote:

> blkadder@value.net wrote:
> > 
> > 
> 
> I see use of substances as ok - if you can apply it towards something 
> (art, music, general creation, etc..) 
> 
> As far as marijuana - it is a very natural substance, nothing artificial, 
> been with us for thousands of years (so has alchohol, but the behaviral 
> effects are quite different, not to mention the buzz from alchohol is 
> aquired when your brain is getting poisoned).  True - too much marijuana 
> can be bad for you (and expensive!) but the side effects are slim - 
> usually limited to a scratchy throat and a severe case of the munchies 
> and the need to go to sleep. :)  Some studies say that it can be cancer 
> causing but the method of research seemed a bit invalid to me... no 
> cancer cases have been documented as being caused by gettin' irie too 
> often.
> 

Ummm...you sound a bit like Philip Morris.  Tobacco companies are
*still* claiming the research doesn't prove anything.  Do you actually 
believe that??  Just because the research
isn't there does NOT mean it doesn't cause cancer.  What about that black
tar shit that coats your pipe and almost the entire length of your bong.
If that shit coats your bong, don't you just wonder what it does to your
lungs?? I personally don't want to be the first statistic.

Oh yeah, and I'm really sick of the "marijuana is natural" bullshit.  A
drug is a drug.  Whether or not it is synthesized in a lab or grown from a
plant.  THC is a secondary plant chemical that helps the plant fight
herbivores such as insects. (btw, there are studies about caterpillar
"addiction" to THC as a way of making the larvae continue feeding--thereby
a more effective pesticide--ask me about it sometime)  Strychnine is also
a natural occuring compound that comes from plants of the genus
_Strychnus_, and it will kill you.  Other compounds are tannins from oaks,
solanine from potatoes--these will also do very bad things to you.  AND
they are natural.  Many, if not most, of our drugs hail from plants.  I
just don't buy the "it's more natural" agenda.  It's seeing things through
rose-tinted glasses.

BTW, I am not down on using drugs, I'm down on abusing drugs.
Personally, I support full legalization of all drugs.  I dislike
categorizing drugs as "good" and "bad" and "good" and "better."  Drug use
is a very multi-faceted topic and I encourage everyone to understand *all*
implications of drug use.  We are a drug culture and there is no
getting away from that.  Denial and hypocrisy are very strong human
characteristics and often thwart the most informed people.

Enough of my public service message here...

-kaySEE

Hello!!!  Hope everyone is having a groovey day.

So far, I've recieved 21 orders for tapes.  I plan on calling around next 
week to see what kind of pricing I can get.  Please let me know by Monday 
if you'd like a copy of the tapes.  

I've had a couple of suggestion for Art Work, etc...  What I thought 
might me cool, is to have anyone who feels like it do some cool art work 
and send it to me.  And rather than have a 'contest' for the best 
artwork, I thought I'd use everything that is submitted.  So that every 
tape is different (or at least a good portion of them).  Does this sound 
cool with everyone???  If you wanna do this, please send it to me as a 
Mac pict. file.

I've also had a couple of requests for individual DJ sets.  This may be 
kind of hard as I was not really paying attention to who was playing 
when.  I'm not even sure if there was a set DJ schedule.  Anyways, if 
there are enough people who want individual DJ sets, I can probably go in 
and try to figure it out.  DJ'S!!!! - Do you all remember what time your 
were playing on Saturday eve/Sunday Morn??   If you do, please send me 
the aprox. times of your sets.

um...ok, I think thats it.  I listened to portions of the tapes last 
night and they all sound GREAT!!!!  Especially the Poetry and Vocals from 
Shawna and Ahnon during the Re: and Astronout sets.  Wow!!!  You two have 
brought new meaning to our music!!!  It sounds absolutly wonderfull!!!!!

KaySEE wrote:
> 
> On Tue, 26 Nov 1996, Courtney Nielsen wrote:
> 
> > blkadder@value.net wrote:
> > >
> > >
> >
> > I see use of substances as ok - if you can apply it towards something
> > (art, music, general creation, etc..)
> >
> > As far as marijuana - it is a very natural substance, nothing artificial,
> > been with us for thousands of years (so has alchohol, but the behaviral
> > effects are quite different, not to mention the buzz from alchohol is
> > aquired when your brain is getting poisoned).  True - too much marijuana
> > can be bad for you (and expensive!) but the side effects are slim -
> > usually limited to a scratchy throat and a severe case of the munchies
> > and the need to go to sleep. :)  Some studies say that it can be cancer
> > causing but the method of research seemed a bit invalid to me... no
> > cancer cases have been documented as being caused by gettin' irie too
> > often.
> >
> 
> Ummm...you sound a bit like Philip Morris. 

Used to smoke 'em.

> Tobacco companies are
> *still* claiming the research doesn't prove anything.  Do you actually
> believe that??  Just because the research
> isn't there does NOT mean it doesn't cause cancer.  What about that black
> tar shit that coats your pipe and almost the entire length of your bong.
> If that shit coats your bong, don't you just wonder what it does to your
> lungs?? I personally don't want to be the first statistic.
> 

Ahem. I did not say that too much marijuana was not bad for you. I was just trying to explain why marijuana is 
seen as separate from other substances. Sorry if I offended you. 

> Oh yeah, and I'm really sick of the "marijuana is natural" bullshit.  
> A drug is a drug.  

I agree. And natural can be just as deadly as artificial. I guess the point that I meant to bring up is that 
when you buy a bag of ganja, you can see what your getting, you can smell it, you can hold it and find out how 
good it is, meaning less chance of buying something poisonus or bunk like other manufactured substances.

>Whether or not it is synthesized in a lab or grown from a
> plant.  THC is a secondary plant chemical that helps the plant fight
> herbivores such as insects. (btw, there are studies about caterpillar
> "addiction" to THC as a way of making the larvae continue feeding--thereby
> a more effective pesticide--ask me about it sometime) 

Sounds interesting. I would like to know more. Marijuana farmers in the country surround the base of their 
plants with dogshit to keep deer away (deer are major stoners) - the carnivourous smell of the dogshit keeps a 
deer away as good as an electric fence would. 

 Strychnine is also a natural occuring compound that comes from plants of the genus
> _Strychnus_, and it will kill you.  Other compounds are tannins from oaks,
> solanine from potatoes--these will also do very bad things to you.  AND
> they are natural.  Many, if not most, of our drugs hail from plants.  I
> just don't buy the "it's more natural" agenda.  It's seeing things through
> rose-tinted glasses.
> 

The small amounts of alkaloids such as strychnine in plants, etc have to be taken in immense quantities in 
order to kill you though.  Otherwise we would all drop dead from eating an apple.  

> BTW, I am not down on using drugs, I'm down on abusing drugs.
> Personally, I support full legalization of all drugs.  I dislike
> categorizing drugs as "good" and "bad" and "good" and "better."  Drug use
> is a very multi-faceted topic and I encourage everyone to understand *all*
> implications of drug use.  We are a drug culture and there is no
> getting away from that.  Denial and hypocrisy are very strong human
> characteristics and often thwart the most informed people.
> 
> Enough of my public service message here...
> 
> -kaySEE

HEY! I'm not trying to start a fight with anyone here!!! A person was curious as to why marijuana was not 
considered to be in the same family as something like MDMA or speed and I simply came up with my own possible 
explanations.  Geez...

-Courtney

> On Tue, 26 Nov 1996, Arthur Chandler wrote:
> 
> > 12) Susie K brought up the significance of raves taking place in old
> > warehouses. Dr. Rietveld commented on the McLuhanesque fitness of a
> > digital, postmodern phenomenon (raves) taking place in the shell of an
> > abandoned modern institution (the warehouse and factory).
> 
> Thanks for the notes. The above struck me as very amusing, as it
> obfusicates a very simple reality: Warehouses are used because they are
> big, usually empty, and cheap. I don't think this needs to be viewed from
> an anything-esque perspective to get to the root of it.... ;-)

But they are usually empty and cheap because they are no longer in major use.
They have become "obsolete", If EDI and just in time manufacturing comes into
full swing then you will see even more empty wharehouses.

>     anyone heard of that new pipe that only heats the bud up enough to 
>     vaporize the fumes without turning it into smoke?  That sounds like it 
>     would take care of the tar problem...

the idea being to increase the temperature enough to vaporize the thc, but
not high enough to ignite the rest of the plant. as has been pointed out,
it's not a new idea.
i've seen plans for the DIYer in ascii format on bbs's over the years. i'm
sure they've made their way onto the net by now. 
-brendan

To: I_wanna_Dance! <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Cc: Austin Woffington <exodus@earthlink.com>
Subject: My weekend:  the itals (nrr) and FM
Message-Id: <Pine.A32.3.91.961126202914.69331A-100000@tuba.aix.calpoly.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi all!

Well despite the fact that I had 2 midterms on friday and worked 20 hours 
this weekend I had a lot of fun.  
  Friday I set up for the reagge concert the Itals and Andrew Bees.  And 
then stayed to watch them.  WOW.  These guys were great.  If you love 
reagge check them out.  They played a few Black Uhura songs and a ziggy 
Marley song I noticed too.  The vibe at this show was comparable to a 
rave.  Everyone dancing to the music rather than to each other, friendly 
smiles everywere and the Itals had some bomb -lemme tell ya!
   There was also an intermission show = Raks al Beledi - dance of the 
people.  A very beautiful show of traditional "belly dancing"(is ther 
another name for it?) in not so traditional clothing (I mean they weren't 
clothed from head to toe with only thier eyes showing, but they were 
wereing indinan dress).  

Saturday mi amigo Mike decided to throw a party(about a week and a half 
of planning) on Saturday.  It just so happend to be a Full Moon gig on 
the beach.  It was great! Perfect weather -wasn't cold at all.  Great 
people and great music.  This was only the second party I had ever stayed 
at till the last trash was picked up, the last cord rapped and the last 
person to leave.  It takes alot out of ya haulin' 4 boxes and a generator 
up a beach.  I'm sure some of you have had this pleasure and I definately
 have a greater respect for all the work that goes into a good party.
   I met this girl at the party - very smart- who designes lighting boards
 and light racks.  Well she's still beginning but she says she's working on a 
project to design lighting controled by hand movement.  She will be 
moving up to SF this June to sell and promot here equipment and hopefully 
make some contacts to improve her work.

Happy Turkey Day and I might see some of ya at Ubiquatious!

PLUR,

       Austin

        ------------------(   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )-----------------

HI all,

I had a few questions for the list and was hoping some of you could respond.

I love the art work I see at many of the parties like Harmony, The Goa 
Gill party, Gateway etc. and was wondering who are the artists who design 
and do all this beautiful work.  Are they affiliated with the party or is 
the work recycled between crews?  Are the artists paid for there work or 
is done in the spirit of rave and for the community?
   The reason I was asking is because I'm getting together with a few 
people in SLo to throw a party and I would love to get some great 
decor for the space.  I'm not a very good artist but I can do technical 
design.  I know a few artists but they don't do the style of art I am 
interested in displaying.  I also am looking for ideas I 
have a few of my own and the rest come from experience in the scene.  
	Aside from that, I would like your Opinion.  I know that the 
party we throw will be small but i'm contemplating on using a legal venue 
till which can only be utilized till 4am or confirming a warehouse 
(hopefully with permits) till when ever - 6 or 7.We all have alot of 
support from the local djs and those that want to go - it's just a matter 
of putting forth the enrgy to create the party we want to create.

I've helped with parties and concerts before but have never been involved 
with all aspects of the creation.  It's very exciting and I hope it all 
pays of.
Any advice is welcome, Thanks.

PLUR,

       Austin

>>>Online computer users often engage in what is affectionately known as
>>>"cybersex". Often the fantasies typed into keyboards and shared through
>>>Internet phone lines get pretty raunchy. However, as you'll see below, one
>>>of the two cyber-surfers in the following transcript of an online chat
>>>doesn't seem to quite get the point of cyber sex. Then again, maybe he
does...
>>>Wellhung: Hello, Sweetheart. What do you look like?
>>>Sweetheart: I am wearing a red silk blouse, a miniskirt and high heels.  I
>>>work out every day, I'm toned and perfect. My measurements are 36-24-36.
>>>What do you look like?
>>>Wellhung: I'm 6'3" and about 250 pounds.I wear glasses and I have on a pair
>>>of blue sweat pants I just bought from Walmart.I'm also wearing a T-shirt
>>>with a few spots of barbecue sauce on it from dinner...it smells funny.
>>>Sweetheart: I want you.Would you like to screw me?
>>>Wellhung: OK.
>>>Sweetheart: We're in my bedroom.There's soft music playing on the stereo and
>>>candles on my dresser and night table.I'm looking up into your eyes,

>>>Wellhung: I'm gulping, I'm beginning to sweat.
>>>Sweetheart: I'm pulling up your shirt and kissing your chest.
>>>Wellhung: Now I'm unbuttoning your blouse.My hands are trembling.
>>>Sweetheart: I'm moaning softly.
>>>Wellhung: I'm taking hold of your blouse and sliding it off slowly.
>>>Sweetheart: I'm throwing my head back in pleasure.The cool silk slides off

blouse.

>>>Sweetheart: OK. I'm pulling your sweat pants down and rubbing your hard tool.
>>>Wellhung: I'm screaming like a woman. Your hands are cold! Yeeee!

>>>out nibbling on you...umm... wait a minute.

>>>Wellhung: I'm having a coughing fit. I'm turning all red.
>>>Sweetheart: Can I help?

>>>the cabinets, looking for a cup. Where do you keep your cups?
>>>Sweetheart: In the cabinet to the right of the sink.
>>>Wellhung: I'm drinking a cup of water. There, that's better.
>>>Sweetheart: Come back to me, lover.
>>>Wellhung: I'm washing the cup now.
>>>Sweetheart: I'm on the bed arching for you.
>>>Wellhung: I'm drying the cup. Now I'm putting it back in the cabinet.  And

>>>Sweetheart: Last door on the left at the end of the hall.
>>>Wellhung: I found it.

>>>Sweetheart: Your pants are off. I kiss you passionately-our naked bodies

>>>the night table.

>>>Wellhung: I have to pee. I'm fumbling my way blindly across the room and

>>>Wellhung: Now the carpet is on fire! Oh noooo!
>>>Sweetheart: <logged off>

Precedence: bulk

hey everybody.

On Tue, 26 Nov 1996 blkadder@value.net wrote:
> Warehouses are used because they are
> big, usually empty, and cheap. I don't think this needs to be viewed from
> an anything-esque perspective to get to the root of it.... ;-)

Maybe this doesn't _have_ to be viewed with an anything-esque perspective 
to understand _why_ ravers choose to hold raves in warehouses (on the 
micro level), but I think it's really fun and satisfying all the same... 

The re-appropriation of physical artifacts by the scene  for 
purposes other than they were originally intended is really fascinating. 
What was originally intended as a high-end stereo component 
(technics 1200s) becomes a musical and percussive instrument extraordinaire 
in the hands of talented djs. What was originally intended as a cheap 
bass-synthesizer/minikeyborad (tb303)  becomes the progenitor of the 
acid-bass-line. Cold medicine (vicks vaporub) becomes instrument of 
pleasure. Kids stuff (pixie sticks, glowsticks, glitter, etc.) become major 
social signifiers for a generation of young adults. Link in chain of 
capitalist distribution of commercial goods (warehouses) becomes locale 
for underground, subversive (?) counter-culture.

I'm sure there are plenty more that y'all could come up with. Point is, 
it's a very worthwhile pursuit for people (like the SFSU prof) to think 
about why things like this happen and what the implications are on 
"culture" and "society".

-dj radon

Harmony!!! wrote:
> 
> Hello sfraves,
> 
>         I have thought about how to raise some $ to either buy land or a
> warehouse before. I have come to the conclusion that although it seems like
> a cool idea, I feel it would not be all that benifitial to the raving
> community. The land/space would get played out, and that is a big risk to take. 
>         Right now it is so hard to throw parties. We can't get permits in
> most cities, and in the cities that we can, it costs to much. I think a
> better goal to raise money towards is the changing of the laws
> (dancing/entertainment) in S.F. In '93 the mayor and the police chief began
> to reinforce "2am" law for people under 21. This basically states that if
> you are under 21 you cannot dance after 2am. We don't live in a fixed system. We need to change things, not
> avoid them. If we raise enough $ together, we can change any law in the
> book! All it takes is $, it's a sick thought, but it is true. We need $ and
> signatures, that's all..
> 
> Peace, love and harmony to all!!!
> 
> Greg =) 

Okay folks, this is a serious situation and a calling to arms!!!

All of you that know Greg know when he says something he's not blowing
shit!

The proposition of buying land has been considered and executed in
southern California. A large plot of land was purchased in the Santa Ana 
hills for the purpose of throwing raves. A road was even built leading
to the space. To the best of my knowledge this effort was unsuccessful.
(anyone with details please fill us in.)

The concept of raising money to change the 2am dance curfew law does not
seem to me to be a completely unattainable goal. Any law on the books
can be changed with enough support, signatures, and donated time and
effort. Take Prop. 215 for example, sure it's a stretch. But I'm sure
all of you at least once were approached by someone at a supermarket to
sign the 215 ballot many months ago.

We have the technology to make change...we have the incentive to make
change...DO WE HAVE THE SPIRIT TO MAKE CHANGE????!???

Sometimes I wonder, Shit gets thrown around the list. People say stuff
but many times nothing happens. I'm not blaming anyone, but if something
*obviously* needs attention should we continue to ignore it?????

This is our scene....this is our time......this is our life...Let's make
it the best we can!

We have made a difference already! Proof postive...Friends and Family,
Harmony, Famtasia, BBQ 'n' Beats, ODP, Elevation, and many other
net-related parties are on the horizon. The CA underground rave scene is
about to explode! Let's give it the resources to prosper.

We have a small group willing to make a difference. We have so many
successful business-minded people on list. Let yourself be known! Let's
not let such an important movement fade away into the abyss of the list.

Anyone interested in this crazy notion please respond and let yourself
be known. Hopefully with enough of us we'll be able to actually make
things happen for a change. 

Crazy thoughts invading my mind,

Terry

(responses for those computerly-challenged:408.486.9591 or 619.214.7499)

P.S. If you believe in this and are on another list please forward or
     paraphrase this message to the appropriate channels.
     (HINT HINT AUSTIN, CRUNCHMAN, & JBONDY!!!!)

Dear SFRavefriends,

	Indeed!  8)  And the neglected subject of a German pharmaceutical
company's 1914 patent becomes the drug of choice for ravers worldwide in
the 1990s...  

Much love,
				<<< Starchild >>>

My computer tells me that on Tue, 26 Nov 1996, dj radon shared:

> hey everybody.
> 
> On Tue, 26 Nov 1996 blkadder@value.net wrote:
> > Warehouses are used because they are
> > big, usually empty, and cheap. I don't think this needs to be viewed from
> > an anything-esque perspective to get to the root of it.... ;-)
> 
> Maybe this doesn't _have_ to be viewed with an anything-esque perspective 
> to understand _why_ ravers choose to hold raves in warehouses (on the 
> micro level), but I think it's really fun and satisfying all the same... 
> 
> The re-appropriation of physical artifacts by the scene  for 
> purposes other than they were originally intended is really fascinating. 
> What was originally intended as a high-end stereo component 
> (technics 1200s) becomes a musical and percussive instrument extraordinaire 
> in the hands of talented djs. What was originally intended as a cheap 
> bass-synthesizer/minikeyborad (tb303)  becomes the progenitor of the 
> acid-bass-line. Cold medicine (vicks vaporub) becomes instrument of 
> pleasure. Kids stuff (pixie sticks, glowsticks, glitter, etc.) become major 
> social signifiers for a generation of young adults. Link in chain of 
> capitalist distribution of commercial goods (warehouses) becomes locale 
> for underground, subversive (?) counter-culture.
> 
> I'm sure there are plenty more that y'all could come up with. Point is, 
> it's a very worthwhile pursuit for people (like the SFSU prof) to think 
> about why things like this happen and what the implications are on 
> "culture" and "society".
> 
> -dj radon
>

Thanks, Dave! ;) I keep forgetting to bring these and seriously regretting it.

Everybody else, these ear plugs are about $15.00 and taper off the high-mid and hi 
frequencies still allowing u 2 hear w/out frying your ears! A worthwhile investement, 
you can pick up at any good music store! :D

--- On Tue, 26 Nov 96 22:11:09 UT  Davis Bassan <MaXXimum@msn.com> wrote:

>Just a little note to ear plugs.
>
>The Ideal is to find plug that reduce upper mids more than anything else. If 
>you look at a table of "damage risk contours for 1 exposure pure day" you will 
>notice that your ears are 30 db more sensitive at 2000 hz than at 150 hz, or 
>21 db more sensitive at 2000 hz than at 10 000 hz. Basically, your hearing 
>will get damaged after only 3 minutes of exposition to a 2000 hz tone, but at 
>150 hz of pure tone, your ears can withstand 130 db for 3 minutes before 
>damage start. It is easy to loose your hearing with a system that is "colored" 
>. Colored means that emphasis has been put on the weak frequencies. Example, 
>the famous EV MTH4 uses 4 10" drivers on manifold horn for the mid range 
>section (800 hz to 3 khz). this is why they seem extremely loud and they hurt 
>your ears. Most raves run the sound between 120 db at 1 meter to 140 db at 1 
>meter (which is stupid). At 130 db at 1 meter (3 ft) at 2000 hz, damage to 
>your hearing is done within 0.03 seconds compare to 3 minutes with a 150 hz 
>tone (upper bass kick). Other type of speakers might not seam that load (or 
>won't hurt your hearing so much) because the speaker builder or the sound 
>engineer has lowered the mids output to a more ear pleasing level. It is 
>easier to make it seem loud by pushing the 1 - 3 khz section than to keep the 
>levels at a more pleasing level. Do you go to raves to enjoy the music or to 
>destroy your hearing (hearing loss is PERMANENT and IRRESVERSIBLE) ?
>
>Moral : put fucking plugs in your ears ( you can get the yellow or orange foam 
>one for $1.50 at any hardware store/music store) , and if you spend about $150 
>you can get customized ear plug that will attenute the mids and low high a lot 
>more than the highs and bass. If you don't, YOU will regret it later.          
>  
>
>French E
>Maxximum Sound and Lights                   
>
>----------
>From: 	mw-raves-owner@hyperreal.com on behalf of Ed Jones
>Sent: 	Tuesday, November 26, 1996 3:22 PM
>To: 	Davis J. Bassan B.S.
>Cc: 	Adam Tyr Dorfman; mw-raves@hyperreal.com
>Subject: 	Re: Blessings anyone?
>
>On Tue, 26 Nov 1996, Davis J. Bassan B.S. wrote:
>
>> at most drug store you can get 29db plugs that work great.  I highly
>> recommend getting a pair of these and humping a few speakers :).
>> btw even 11db is going to do you a lot of good.  much better than nothing
>> certainly but at the volumes and durations at parties you really need over
>> 20 db protection.
>
>These are cheap, and definitly worthwhile. But they roll off pretty steeply
>at higher frequencies. I like more than just bass so that's where the
>musician earplugs come in. They try to be flatter across the band. By
>this I mean, they try to attenuate the signal equally across frequencies.
>Actually, they arent super flat, but it's better than no high frequencies
>at all :-P
>
>For budget ear plugs, I highly recommend the E.A.R. brand of squishy
>ear plugs (typically 29db) that they sell in the drug stores. You can
>buy more or less as well, but I think 29 is what I see the most. 
>
>Ed Jones

[ to sfraves list ]
[ Humorously Rave-Related : Do not take too seriously! ]

 Well, the doctor at Kaiser told me that the ache in my heel is due to
something called plantar fasciatis (sic). I don't know if anyone else
here in SFRaves has had this - it feels like there's a pebble between
my heel and my shoe. It's cut down on my dancefloor endurance for sure.

 Anyway, the doctor told me that it takes time and care, and it'll heal
itself. He perscribed ice packs, regular doses of ibuprofen,
and to get the weight off the back of my foot and more onto the front
pads - ie, heels!
 
 So, if anyone can recommend any places that sell 9-1/2 long E-width 
shoes w/high heels that can be danced in, just drop me a line...I'm 
short of the rest of the ensemble too, so any recommendations along those 
lines would be appreciated...

  Larry "I have a perscription for this baby-T !!!" Ching

 Oh...if anyone actually has any advice they want to give me about curing
this plantar faciatis thing, please send it along.

PS - Have a great Thanksgiving, y'all!

Ok, I think I've said this before but...

The scene is what you perceive it to be... We all create our own scene.
Some consider the scene a babe market, figuring out how-to and how many
babes, or dolls (i.e. guys) they can "bag and tag"...  I know several of
these type people from both gender sides.
Some see the scene as a profitability market to sell drugs.  Some see
the scene to buy "stuff"(I've heard people discuss about how "dry" blah
blah blah's party was, Or sooo many people would be whispering "E, E, E"
that I thought it was part of the song.).
Some go out to escape reality, some are running away from something (and
still running), some go out to have a good time, Dance, trance,
excersise, whatever. Some are looking for family, and found it here.
All I can say is from my own experiences, and from those that wish to
share their experiences with me.  I was attracted to the promoter aspect
at one time, and at another I was allured to the controlled substances
that were readily available. 
There are some that will never "get it" in this cycle.  So yes, the
scene will always be sex, drugs, defiance against the MAN. Whatever... 

Now I feel that it's the acceptance of oneness that pulls me to the
scene. The ability to see all these perspectives at once and at the same
time keep my agenda and "spread that vibe".  Im in the scene for love,
no, not physical, but real love.  I choose techno, and I choose dancing
as a medium.  Others have chosen dance music, blues, rap, art, writing
to convey a message.  This is my choice.  This is my message.  And soon,
hopefully when I get away from the binds of this corporate society, I'll
be able to spread my message thru better medium, be it DJing, making
music. Something. It is on the horizon.
---Adam
"Stay Connected"

wayne- ( and others silly enough to be on sfraves when they should be
traveling to their thanksgiving destinations, or else planning for saturn 5)

[note bene - i'm not sure if this should be addressed to wayne, or if he is
just playing devil's advocate.  i'll address it to him, cause that's more
fun =p  )

>"Too bad there are people in our scene that try to coveniently replace
>alcohol with e and then try to get with everybody."

throughout my meager 21 years of existence, i have noticed that, in every
scene with which i have been involved, there have been people who "try to
get with everybody."  i have noticed this in the rave scene, in the small
facets of the industrial scene with which i have had acquantence, in the san
francisco music choral scene (in which i am very involved), in various
occupational scenes (both large and small companies), and in the academic scene.

throughout these various scenes, there are very few commonalities; in fact,
the only commonalities that i can see is that they are comprised of humans
who desire intimate contact with other humans and who are looking to their
environment for that contact.

different people choose to express their sexuality in different ways,
influences by a whole host of factors that i shall not try to discuss over
e-mail.  suffice it to say, to cut with a rather dull philosophical knife,
there are many people who choose to express their sexuality openly, and
there are those who choose to not express their sexuality openly.  these two
groups of people reside within every scene with which i have had
involvement, and they have used various means for that expression.

wayne, the people who you see "replacing alcohol with e and getting on
everybody" are the same people who would be doing that in any other scene in
which they are involved.  it is not unique to the rave scene.  they are
doing it because they are human, and humans have this wonderful tendency of
loving each other and trying to be intimate with each other.  we can be
idealistic about the rave scene and try to make it this pan/asexual mecca,
but we would be denying the sexual nature of our humanity at the same time.

i have no problem with people getting on each other in the rave scene.  if
they want to do that, that's great for them!  sometimes i want to do that,
sometimes i don't.  here's the question i think we SHOULD be addressing:

"how do we handle individuals under the influence of chemically induced love
who try to impose that love upon others who may not want to receive it?
i.e., how do we handle the influx of e-heads who feel love while under the
influence, but act like jerks the rest of the time? (i find those two groups
of people to be the same!)"

DISCUSS!

love to you all-

matt
matthew d. p. k. lanier
professional hugger and empath

415-752-3218

pager  mailto:lanima00@usfca.edu (up to 240 characters)

use 'E'  to take advantage of the cituation. They know what it does and
fully use that in there favor just to get alittle action. They may or may
not take it themselves, but are aware of the females that are on it and go
in for the kill. Play on them and get them aroused just to have sex with
them for there own pleasure. Then when they find someone new the do it all
over again.

they pretend to understand everything and use the scene for there own
personal pleasures (ie..sex). this is not cool at all.  The kissey, touchey
things that goes on at "raves" while on 'E' are one thing, but using it to
ones own advantage is another. They try to use others to get into the scene
deeper just to meet more people for them to use and abuse. These types of
people should be pointed out and hopefully they will leave. I've seen it
happen and have actually tried to tell some women that they should be
careful if I see them with these types of people, there actually pretty
easy to spot even if you yourself are on 'E'. Whether they take that advice
to heart or not is up to them, but at least I have warned them.

Date: Wed, 27 Nov 1996 12:27:32 -0800
To: "GrumpCo(tm)" <wayne@club.net>
From: bri@value.net (Brian Denny)
Subject: Re: the rave scene is not about sex.
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

DJ Grumpy wrote:

>"Too bad there are people in our scene that try to coveniently replace
>alcohol with e and then try to get with everybody."

indeed, too bad. too bad there are people in the club scene, or the
business world, who do not respect other peoples boundaries, or use
intoxicants, power, or any other form of leverage to take advantage of
others.

i guess i would say that, if the rave scene is not about sex, neither is
your discussion topic. respect seems to be a more relevant idea.

but since you mentioned it ;)

as far as sex and E-- well, apparently it's different for everybody, but
most of the people i've talked to wouldn't want to actually have sex on
E... but the same people (including myself) have on occasion had positive
experiences with getting naked and exploring the sensual aspects of the
drug in a somewhat sexual way.

a question which really had me boggled for a while was, "what is the
difference between sensuality and sexuality." i started wondering this when
i had an experience with a good friend at a party in which she and i got
pretty intimate-- a sober observer would have said we were "making out"--
but neither of us felt that it was a sexual experience.

the question was answered for me when i had a similar experience a couple
months later with someone else, in which our hypothetical sober observer
would have noticed little difference, but we both felt a degree of sexual
energy there that usually isn't present in e-kisses.

so i guess the answer to "what is the difference between sexuality and
sensuality" for me is simply intuitive. i know it when i feel it.


and once again, there's a difference-- a BIG difference-- between having
mutual physical experiences with people and trying to push your sexuality
onto people who don't care to receive it.

finally, to answer the original discussion topic, yes, it's a shame there
are people like that in our scene. i had an experience a few weeks ago at a
rave, where i put my arm around somebody i was talking with, and she
thought i was trying to pick up on her (i was on e, and meant nothing by it
other than innocent affection)... that is the first time anyone has _ever_
thought i was trying to pick up on them, and the first time i have ever
crossed someone's physical boundaries. it was a sobering experience, and i
have to think that if there weren't so many disrespectful people in the
world, maybe she wouldn't have misinterpreted my intent. who knows.

love,

brian

        sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>>"how do we handle individuals under the influence of chemically induced love
>>who try to impose that love upon others who may not want to receive it?
>>i.e., how do we handle the influx of e-heads who feel love while under the
>>influence, but act like jerks the rest of the time? (i find those two groups
>>of people to be the same!)"
>
>Thank you! *That* is more in line with what I was hoping for in this
>discussion.

or, as Tim said, people who maybe are not on E but know how to use and
abuse people who are?

ok, lets start by dividing this into two categories: (1) situations in
which Guy tries to get physical with Girl and Girl is aware of it and
doesn't like it, and (2) situations in which Guy uses his "smoothness" and
knowledge of E in order to make Girl think he's acting innocently when in
fact he has ulterior designs.

situation 1 happens a lot, i've seen it many times. i've had female friends
come to me and say "so-and-so was getting a little closer to me than i felt
comfortable with...", and the question i always want to ask is, "did you
tell him to go away?" of course, when you're feeling all lovEy, the last
thing you want to do is hurt someone's feelings, but i really feel that if
someone is a jerk they should be treated accordingly.

situation 2, in which Guy is being really sneaky and manipulative, is
somewhat more difficult to handle. Tim noted that he can try to warn Girl,
but Girl is not always receptive to such warnings.

if i am a friend of Girl, i might try inviting her to spend some time
talking with me, thus distracting her from Guy. not always effective.

or i might try confronting Guy directly, risking open animosity between us.
this gets pretty touchy if Guy and i share a circle of friends...


hmm... no answers, but some thoughts.

love,

brian
