Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday morning 9am-11am - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Tuesday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench. Varied techno sub-genres, noise, spoken word, world
       music. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

From: Jessica Robin Berkson <berky@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: Re: mono going around?
To: Jonathan Mark Logan <gonzo@leland.stanford.edu>
cc: friends&family <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.3.95.961125163226.12136A-100000@epic5.Stanford.EDU>

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



YES MONO IS AROUND!!!  My SO is just getting over the worst of it, and as 
far as we can figure out, I gave it to him, unknowingly- it seems that 
you can carry it and never get sick from it, or only get a very mild 
case- according to the doctor you can carry it and pass it around for as 
long as 18 months....

I'm pretty sure I got it at a party....all those 
water bottles you share in those sweaty moments when you just don't 
care....I'm super careful now, and won't share a bottle- for everybody 
else's health, not just mine....

be careful you guys- mono is a nasty little disease, and I've heard from 
a number of people that the virus that causes it (EBV) is also suspected 
in chronic fatigue syndrome....It strikes when you are worn down and 
super tired from too much partying, studying working, whatever...ravers 
are a perfect target.

xox
jess

On Mon, 25 Nov 1996, Jonathan Mark Logan wrote:

> 		
> 
> Has anyone come down with mono lately?  My roommate is currently
> succumbing to it, and we were wondering if we could trace its origin to
> some party in the recent past.
> 
> Given the activities that transpire at raves, I wouldn't be surprised if
> mono could explode in the scene if we weren't careful. 
> 
> Be warned!
> 	
> 		jon

brian ( and all) -

>ok, lets start by dividing this into two categories: (1) situations in
>which Guy tries to get physical with Girl and Girl is aware of it and
>doesn't like it, and (2) situations in which Guy uses his "smoothness" and
>knowledge of E in order to make Girl think he's acting innocently when in
>fact he has ulterior designs.

there are women who have used e to get a guy, also.  let's be a little more
careful about our use of pronouns.  i think some of the unspoken assumptions
like this can be just as dangerous.

love to you all!-

matt l
matthew d. p. k. lanier
professional hugger and empath

415-752-3218

dear diana (and all)-

>I suddenly remember what happened 
> and the horror struck.  Oh my god!  I led him on and then dissed him 
> 'cause I was too blitzed to recall his face, his name, etc.
>
>Okay, so now I'm marred for "hitting" on two guys at one party and not 
> being able to connect back with one of them to explain things.  Pretty sad...
>
>Comments?

raves are a wonderful place to appreciate people for what and when they are.
if you connect with someone for a period of time, that's when you connected
with them - not before, not after.  appreciate it for exactly what it was -
a connection.

i've been in that situation before, on both sides.  don't stress about it -
you may bump into him again, and you may not. and you know what?  both are cool!

love to you all-

matt
matthew d. p. k. lanier
professional hugger and empath

hey all
I never posted anything to SFRaves about this thread previously but I
thought I'd take a second to say that I agree with all of you (esp
Brian)and have experienced/witnessed the same thing.  My girlfriend
raves and does E with me, and although we do spend +some+ time being
touchey and somewhat intimate while dancing...we usually dance in our
own worlds-to the music and enjoy our own space.  She knows alot more
people in the scene than I do, seems like they are mostly guys too. It
never bothers me and I always dig meeting other guys...but it is very
clear to me when her personal space becomes compromised by someone who
thinks that an ekiss or a hug means they have a green light to put the
moves on.  Some people just don't get it.  The positive vibe and good,
warm fuzzy feelings are about love and respect, not about horniness. 
oh, Happy Turkey Day.....

Hey, I stopped sharing bottles too. I feel bad refusing people, and
sometimes people can get a bit pushy (yes, even "ravers"). But it's MY
saliva, and I have the RIGHT to keep it to myself! :) And the right
not to have anyone else's.

I've been sick since the Harmony 3 year (I'm _finally_ getting
better), and I blame (among other things) being unconcerned about
other people's sicknesses entering my body.  Not everyone is as
careful with their health as I am...and sometimes all it takes is
sharing a little warm, murky water to get what they have.

So I have officially stopped sharing water bottles. If you ask me, and
I say 'no', it's not because I don't love you. On the contrary, it's
because I love us both. :)

health and happiness,
Steve

On Wed, 27 Nov 1996, Tony Rose wrote:

> On Wed, 27 Nov 1996, Brian Denny wrote:
> 
> > 
> > situation 1 happens a lot, i've seen it many times. i've had female friends
> > come to me and say "so-and-so was getting a little closer to me than i felt
> > comfortable with...", and the question i always want to ask is, "did you
> > tell him to go away?" of course, when you're feeling all lovEy, the last
> > thing you want to do is hurt someone's feelings, but i really feel that if
> > someone is a jerk they should be treated accordingly.
> >

> > somewhat more difficult to handle. Tim noted that he can try to warn Girl,
> > but Girl is not always receptive to such warnings.
> 
> maybe girl should take a little responsibility for herself...she cant be
> totally helpless(come on girls!)

Great topic.  Thanks for bringing it up, Wayne!

I'm glad Tony made the point about girls not being helpless.  I think that
is a good point.  Although women can be put in really sticky situations
out of their control, there is such a thing as free will.  Women do, can,
and should make their own decisions.  However, there is some concern when
these decisions are faulty.  Many women have a hard time asserting
themselves because they are taught that come-ons are flattering.  My own
mother always told me to say thank you to flattery, not really
discriminating between wanted and unwanted.  Of course I don't think that
way today, but totally overcoming your baggage is difficult.  It's hard
to say "go away", when saying so means that you are then a bitch.  I don't
really feel that way nowadays and have no problem telling someone that I'm
not interested.  And I don't really care anymore if someone thinks I'm a
bitch for chrissake.  I really frown upon unwelcome come-ons and actually
feel a bit sorry for the individual involved because I can't believe
that's the only way he can relate to a woman.  My way of dealing with it
is sheer avoidance.  I really try to avoid scenes that are high in the
meat market factor. And I am really careful about how I dress, which
pisses me off on one hand because i am changing my appearance based on
another's opinions.  But, at the same time I know certain clothes have
certain connotations and I need to be careful at times about that.  I'm
still trying to figure this dichotomy out and find some middle ground.
That's why raves are so special to me because it is like this little piece
of utopia (sometimes).

I really feel like I can dress in a certain way and not worry about it too
much.  And, my MOST favorite thing, I can talk to a guy, actually be
friendly and not worry that he is interested or thinks the same of me.  We
can actually talk as two human beings.  I can feel attractive or attracted
to individuals *without* being either predator or prey.  It's lovely.

Once at a party, albeit a bit shady (in my early days of raving where I
didn't know any better), I was sitting in the chill room with two female
friends.  We were talking, hugging, and having a wonderful time.  Guys
kept coming up to us and trying to "chat" with us, so to speak.  We really
were not into this and made sure our body language indicated that.  Most
of the guys got the hint, but this one dude just didn't have a clue.  He
came back THREE times to see if we had softened up sufficiently to let him
into our little circle.  We bluntly said "GO AWAY" and various other
sundry comments.  But, he kept coming back.  I just could not believe it.  
This guy had audacity.  I've encountered other men like that, but it
really is obvious and I'm getting pretty good at saying go away.  I
try to rely on myself to judge this and that's where I think free-will
comes in.  It's nice if you have a male friend there to help you out, but
women really should learn how to take care of themselves.

One more thing, women, in their own way, can certainly take advantage of
a situation.  It must feel pretty lame to have some cute girl get all
friEndly with you while high and then dis you when not.  
Girls have their own agendas and it's certainly not specifically guys who
take advantage of a situation.  I just think it's in a different way and
for slightly different reasons.

--KaySEE

At 12:25 AM 11/26/96 -0800, you wrote:
>ok. maybe i'm a little cranky right now because i have a headache. or maybe
>i'm all twitchy because i just finished a marathon 3 hour netquake session.
>but anyway..
>i've seen a lot of new ravers lately, and i thought it's probably time to
>point out again that:
>
>you don't need e to have a good time.
>
>???!! yes. it's true. you can have fun at a rave without drugs. 
>do you need to take e every single weekend? no. unless you are trying to
>seek out some higher meaning to your life through the use of mdma, taking
>it every single weekend to "have a good time" makes you no different than
>the guy who goes out and gets drunk every weekend. sure, e is probably
>safer than alcohol (certainly in the short term, possibly in the long term
>as well), but you are doing it for the exact same purpose: to get messed up
>and have fun. wow. how idyllic.
>
>of course, you don't even have to pay attention to me. maybe i just made
>myself grow up too fast. or maybe i'm trying to spare you some of the shit
>i went through. my advice: go help out at a party. be a part of something
>you help create. believe me, the feeling you get from that will last long
>after any e hangover will. instant gratification is all fine and good, but
>it's just that - don't mistake it for anything else.
>
>maybe what i'm trying to get across is be responsible to yourself. be
>responsible to your body, be responsible to your mind. do e if you enjoy
>it, but don't go crazy and put a huge stress on your body. no doctor alive
>would have the gall to suggest that you do e more that once every ten or
>fourteen days. don't burn out your body, and don't do it to your mind, either.
>
>raving shouldn't be about how many drugs you can stuff down your throat
>(that's what adolescence is about!), it should be about discovering
>yourself; finding a direction for your life, and using that knowledge to
>make it better. no chemical is substitute for self-knowledge and
>introspection.
>
>oh well. i'm not writing so well tonight. i'll stop before i make some huge
>blunder.
>
>happy thanksgiving (even though REAL thanksgiving is in october)
>play safe.
>-brendan
>
>

        You are soooooooooooo f***** cool I just can't believe it.
FINALLY!!!! Someone who's not into that E is good for you shit. Damn, it's
about time. Go get'em man, kick some sense into their happy little butts. So
many people are stuck into believing that E is the greatest creation in the
universe. . . anyone ever think that maybe being on E, makes you think that
E is good, you think everything else is better, why wouldn't you think that
the drug that made you this way was good too? I think that E can mask the
idea that you've actually taken a drug, and the peak n all from the E make
you love E. Isn't that why so many people are protective of it? If you like
it, you think that it's harmless, if you don't like it, you realize how
harmful it can actually be. Those who haven't tried it, only know the facts.
. . maybe we should find one of them and listen to what they have to say. . . 

But don't talk to the person about how good or bad it is before they make
their own decision.

Aryck

A
>
>	So seeing a friend of yours get hauled off to jail in front of you
>wouldn't spoil your fun, Brendan?  Or do you not have any "fool" friends
>who might accidentally do something where they could be witnessed by a
>cop?
>	Maybe cops take orders from above, and are "just doing their job";
>so were Hitler's SS troops when they loaded the ovens.  That's not a 
>stretch -- take someone who believes that if you break the law you are a
>criminal who deserves whatever punishment the law dictates you should
>receive, and gives little or no thought to the morality of the law in
>question, and you have an SS trooper waiting to happen.  
>	I've talked to many cops who think this way, and I think it is a
>mindset encouraged by the institutions they belong to.
>	I do not hate the police as individuals.  I'd love to see a cop
>grooving to the music at a rave (people on this list have mentioned seeing
>this, so I know it happens, although in my five years of semi-regular
>raving I don't recall ever seeing it).  However when cops are at a party,
>it usually means either the party is about to be busted, or it is a large
>and often low-vibe event that is overpriced in part because the promoters
>had to hire cops for security in order not to get busted.
>	Given these circumstances Brendan, can you blame me or Pablo 
>or anyone else for not being thrilled to see cops all over the place at a
>party?
>
>Question authority before it questions you,
>
>				<<< Starchild >>>
>
>

        Y'know, I'm not afraid of police unless I'm doing something I
believe is wrong. They're there to serve and protect. I've seen a lot of
police at raves, I've never been to a busted party. My girlfriends friend's
boyfriend was an officer at GAIA (or wherever). Everyone was cool, and you
could talk to the cops if you wanted because they knew what to expect at
raves, and it wasn't much of a big deal to see stoned or fucked or wired
teens dancing to death. They were there to protect us from violence, or
getting hurt, and that's all. Sure they may arrest a drug dealer, but only
if you really should be arrested. It's just another kid to them. It's not
like that kid selling E will fess up to all the E dealers in the city and
lead a state-wide drug bust or anything. Shit, sooo many police are used to
seeing kids on drugs that they rarely do much at all anymore unless you're
doing something ELSE wrong. If they busted one guy, they'd have to bust a
thousand others.

        Starchild and Pablo are like those hippies that "Didn't trust anyone
over 30".
Not all authority is bad. . . I mean, they're main purpose in life is to
make sure that the good people in the world are safe and comfortable, and
the bad people are where they should be. Times are changing. . . 

Aryck

Hi kids,

My friends and I are throwing a party in mid January, and I'm looking to
book dj's..talented novices encouraged.  This is not a rave.  It will be a
collective bunch of folks at a house in SF...Burning Man people, artists,
weirdos.

I'm looking for new talents to melt the wax.  Not necessarily techno,
though I will book at least one techno dj.  (to my dismay, I've recently
found that some "normal" people get wigged out by techno) I'm looking for
dj's who spin house, flam house,  hip hop, trip-hop, funk, reggae,  etc.
Enough to keep everybody happy.

We're not necessarily looking for Jeno/Garth style perfect beatmatching.
I'm more interested in finding unique & innovative dj's who've been hanging
out in their bedrooms for too long.

There will be alcohol at the party, so expect an eclectic bunch.  But don't
worry, Slider and Duke won't be there drinking whiskey and freaking on the
speakers.  (mainly because Slider & Duke don't exist.)

There will be no money involved, but it's a great chance for you to show
off in front of your friends and mine.  Depending on the number of
responses, sets will be probably 45 min to an hour.

Send tapes to:

Boomerang Fidget
Elevator Pop Gallery
2414 Dwight Way
Berkeley CA 94704

or call eves 510-845-3566.

If you send a tape, please email me when you do and let me know so I can
keep an eye out for it.  And if the tape isn't perfect, don't freak out,
we're not performance nazis.  Just send your best.

Thanks.

love ya.  mean it.

b))merang

Hi Aryck,

>
> . . maybe we should find one of them and listen to what they have to say. . .
>
	I have NEVER taken E and have NO history of chemical abuse (however I do
	like a bevvy now & again). I've only been to a couple of raves in SF and
	have only recently seen for myself what E seems to do for people as a
	(passive) observer of others and friends. Apart from the physiological
	effects such as pupils like saucers (no wonder this list has many references
	to aliens) and innane grins [which I have constantly - the original smilee :) ]
	I wonder how much E actually contributes to individual and mass enjoyment. I'm still
	trying to determine whether the vibe at an event has anything to do with E or
	just the fact that most people there are just cool and would set the same vibe E or
	no E.

	I really have no problem with people on E, everybody has their poison, mine just
	happens to be the more old-fashioned beer & scotch!

	As for having somebody "offer" sexual favours for your drugs, just make sure you
	get yours first!

 - Da FunkE Scotsman -

> 
> 
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Nov 27 17:28:50 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id RAA01588; Wed, 27 Nov 1996 17:28:50 -0800 (PST)
Received: from acergw3.acer.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id RAA01581; Wed, 27 Nov 1996 17:28:46 -0800 (PST)
Received: from smtplink.acer.com ([204.160.139.137]) by acergw3.acer.com (8.7.3/8.7.3) with SMTP id RAA29312; Wed, 27 Nov 1996 17:24:42 -0800 (PST)
Received: from ccMail by smtplink.acer.com (SMTPLINK V2.11.01)
	id AA849144848; Wed, 27 Nov 96 17:25:58 pst
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 96 17:25:58 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9610278491.AA849144848@smtplink.acer.com>
To: star@sfsu.edu, Aryck <mxman@illuminati.heald.edu>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Why the boys in blue make us black n' blue
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     Aryck,
     
     I think we're both alright people... it was a pleasure to meet you.
     
     But I have a slightly different viewpoint on the "responsible 
     officer..."
     
     Police are currently under too much stress with too little supervision 
     and not enough checks and balances to keep things safe for everybody.  
     I have heard too many racist slurs, and too many rushed justifications 
     from members of law enforcement to make them the catch all end all 
     cure for crime.
     
     My friend and I were crossing a bridge at night when I was fifteen.  
     We'd had a couple beers, and we were walking home.  My friend had 
     found a fire extinguisher on a lawn in front of some apartment 
     buildings, and put it in his coat.
     
     As we crossed this overpass (over the 405 in Irvine), we were stopped 
     by two police officers in a marked car.  They shined the car lights on 
     us and asked us to put our hands up.  Frank put one hand up, I put 
     both up.  The cop yell's "Fatso, put your hands up".  Frank looks at 
     me nervously and indicated towards the fire extinguisher which is 
     being held in his jacket by the other hand.  The cop yells again, and 
     he raises the other hand.  The fire extinguisher drops to the ground 
     and I suddenly realize that the police officers have their weapons 
     drawn.
     
     They inform us to turn around, while keeping our hands up in the air.
     
     I turn around, as does Frank.  They then tell us to step against the 
     barrier (about two-three feet high at the edge of the overpass...).  I 
     am somewhat afraid of heights, and not exactly excited about this, so 
     I announce that I'm not going anywhere, if that's okay with them.
     
     One of the officers runs up and pushes me towards the barrier, which 
     has trucks and cars and a 40 foot drop on the other side... I step 
     back, at which point I feels my knees get blown out.
     
     The cop had taken my knees out with his baton.  I yelled that I am 
     afraid of heights, and that I'm not out cause problems.  He asks me if 
     I'm a smart ass with my parents too.  They then ask for my id.  I 
     slowly remove it, and they review it.
     
     "Is that a Polish last name?"
     
     yes.
     
     "Well that makes sense"
     
     Huh?
     
     "Shut up"
     
     ....
     
     "I see you're under 18 here"
     
     Yes.  I'm 15.
     
     "Little late to be out... Stand up".
     
     I stand up and face them.  As I stand, I lose my balance a little bit, 
     and feel myself falling backwards (toward the barricade).  I lurch 
     forward a couple inches.  The police push me on the ground and both 
     officers (I think) hit me several times across the body and legs.  I 
     am in severe pain, but not reacting out of fear short of a few yelps.  
     I estimate I was hit some 10-15 times while in the fetal position on 
     the ground.
     
     As the second unit pulls up a couple minutes later, the first unit 
     tells them they had just broken up a fight, that they are almost done 
     with the report, and that the situation is contained.
     
     I am taken into custody, and released to my parents.  My mother never 
     believed me about that night.  I got two broken ribs and a black eye 
     in the incident.  I couldn't file a complaint without my mother.
     
     The police have never taken my cat out of a tree, never caught the 
     person who stole my first guitar and amplifier, never caught the 
     person who stole my car, have forced a girl to give them each a kiss 
     to avoid being taken in for under age drinking, have cost me $1300 in 
     warrants over a car parked for over a year with expired registration 
     on my father's property, have called me a faggot, a pussy, a rich 
     white piece of shit, and have broken up small private parties where 
     people of voting age quietly gather and enjoy films and music.  They 
     have never saved me while I was being beaten up, they didn't keep my 
     sister from being assaulted, and they gladly accepted money from a 
     shopowner who was about to be looted for taking the possible offenders 
     away after the LA quake.  They didn't even fingerprint my house after 
     it was broken into (with about $500 worth of stuff missing) and I even 
     told them what house the perp ran into.
     
     Cops have caused me more grief than good that I can see from here.  I 
     am very uncomfortable around police officers sometimes.
     
     I don't mind a point of view, but based on my life experience, I don't 
     want to pay into the cop monopoly to have my party stay "safe".  
     Offering to keep a party secure and unbustable by off hours police 
     officers and only off hours police officers is extortion/bribery of 
     the lowest calibre.
     
     The Officer Mike is a Good Man point doesn't really hit me as valid 
     100% of the time.
     
     Have I met good cops? Of course.  Do we need law enforcement?  Of 
     course.  Do I want to explore alternatives to having cops twist my arm 
     into paying them money to keep my party going?  Definitely.
     
     But nobody should be above the law, and currently, it seems they often 
     are.
     
     Peace,
     AndyW
     
     P.S.       I'm glad you know what kind of hippies Pablo and Starchild 
     are... but I'm going to wait until I meet them to determine what 
     they're like.
     
     P.P.S.     After talking about this, I probably do need a hug Ran...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Nov 27 18:55:46 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) id SAA08259; Wed, 27 Nov 1996 18:55:46 -0800 (PST)
Received: from host.domain.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.8.3/V2.0) with ESMTP id SAA08248; Wed, 27 Nov 1996 18:55:41 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [204.253.162.77] (wayne.eff.org [204.253.162.77]) by host.domain.net (8.7.5/8.6.12) with ESMTP id SAA23082 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 27 Nov 1996 18:55:34 -0800 (PST)
Message-Id: <v0300780caec29e42fbcd@[204.253.162.77]>
In-Reply-To: <9610278491.AA849144848@smtplink.acer.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 27 Nov 1996 18:55:11 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Irvine Police Suck" <wayne@club.net>
Subject: Re: Why the boys in blue make us black n' blue
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'm glad that Andy wrote about the Irvine Police. I was another
pre-adolescent and adolescent victim of that greenbelt-lined police state,
and I am absolutely positive that my experiences, interactions and
observations with that city's police force have forever instilled in me a
deeply anarchistic establishment resentment for that fucked up place and
the people that run it.

Irvine has a special stigma placed upon it by "people who know." When you
tell then you're from Irvine, most people just nervously reply "oh." If you
then immediately explain that you'd ba happy if the place were burned to
the ground, they under stand that *you* get it. Get it? Let's just say that
it's a place you are very glad "you *used* to live if you are any kind of
free-thinker who no longer (or never did) find salvation by participation
in mindless neighbor-neighbor competitions to see who could buy the latest
3-series BMW first.

The Irvine PD, as a group (yea, group!) were the most arrogant,
boundary-overstepping piece of fucking shit organization I have ever dealt
with. They are are collectively all corrupt bastards with badges.

The story Andy told is just one of many, many stories to tell.

Andy and I both grew up there in the brown-shirt and black arm-band wearing
"kkkommunity of Irvine", and it sucked. Irvine is a special "artifical
reality" community where everybody's supposed to be at home when they roll
up the streets when the street lights go on. If you aren't, or if you are
any minority (asian doesn't count!) inside the city limits, you *will* be
stopped by the police and interrogated as to what you are doing inside city
limits. This is *no joke*.

Here's a very, very small glimpse into the Irvine Police:

The Irvine police were expecially good as "busting" skateboarders and
bicyclists and sending them to "bicycle school". I think that this was
their "most positive" (read: least oppressive) contribution to the
community as most of their other hijinks went downhill from there.

There was an officer named S.M. Soto, this chubby little hispanic guy that
looked like he could have been straight out of the movie "The Good, The Bad
and the Ugly". The problem was, he wasn't dressed like a bandito. He was a
cop. And he -personally- had ticketed each and every person I knew at least
once. He prided himself in setting traffic ticketing records every month
and every year he was an officer there, and many, many of those tickets
were bad ones -- i.e. "Tell it to the judge! I'll be there -- I get
overtime for court pay!"

He even got me once.

Everybody that I new in Irvine had their own "Soto" story to tell. Repeated
complaints to the IPD resulted in nothing more than a later promotion of
him to a motorcycle officer. I won't even get into all the stories that I
have been told about this officer -from the people it happened to-, but
there are two in particular that were amazing boundary-overstepping tales
I'll save for a party since my fingers would tire if I wrote them all.

Then there was the "Captain" of the Irvine Police Explorers. He was quite a
guy. The kind of mid-thirties type that you would see running a "boys
club", except he was a senior officer on the IPD, and, of course, had a
badge. And guns, and cop cars and cool radio equipment. All the stuff to
impress the boys.

This was probably my freshman year of high school... Well, I had a couple
friends that were explorers, and they told me they were having a good time
doing that, so I approached the explorers about helping with a couple 5k or
10r runs or something. The first thing I noticed is that this captain guy
kinda gave me the creeps. Then he tells me "Your father's not a cop, he's
nothing more than a glorified tow truck driver with a gun and a badge. I'm
a real cop." -- Well, that kinda put me (and my father, who was still an
active CHP officer at the time) off, so I quit the explorers before I even
really had a chance to join and forgot all about it.

Well, wouldn't you know, that bastard was secretly taking all the explorer
boys up to his ranch in Riverside and sodomizing them in his spare time --
and he finally got caught! I don't think he was ever prosecuted for those
awful crimes but they did ask him for his gun and his badge before they
played down the case. Oh well, how will he pick up all those unsuspecting
boys without the cool cop car and guns to impress em?! I'm sure he figured
it out since he surely got another chance.

We once had a locker inspection for 100% of the lockers in our school
because *one* student was caught with a joint. The IPD personally searched
all of our belongings and our lockers as a result of it. I don't know if
this was a violation of civil liberties, but in Irvine, this kind of
frenzied harrassment was quite the norm.

We had a really nice guy at my high school that got pulled over one day in
his VW bug for an unspecified reason. (i.e. a typical "he's young, let's
randomly detain and search him" opportunity.) He was one of those really
positive, really together student-council type people -- liked by all,
accomplished, etc... Well, he had one of those Wink mirrors in his car (one
frame that comprises many small rear-view mirrors angled to give you really
good visibility.) Well, one of the mirrors had fallen out of his Wink
mirror, and was on his seat or in his glove box or something, and the cop
noticed it. So, of course, the cop decided that this guy must be a coke
fiend, having this loose small mirror and all, and immediately arrested him
and searched his car for "more evidence of wrongdoing" I suppose.

Well, this guy happened to be a martial arts student and had his dojo bag
in his car with a pair of nun-chaku (spelling?) in the bag. Well, posession
of those as a weapon (i.e. non martial arts training and use) is a FELONY
-- and even though this guy was a martial arts student the cop didn't care
so he was immediatly handcuffed, thrown on the ground face down with a
cop's boot holding him to the ground by his throat, then taken to jail, car
towed, etc. Our student friend later remarked it was too bad he wasn't
carring a gun in his car since that's only a misdemeanor.

Another person at my high school was stopped for "a traffic violation." The
police officer decided that since he was young, he probably didn't
legitimately own the nice stereo in the dash of his car. So the police
officer detained him and insisted that he disassemble and remove the stereo
receiver "so that he could run a serial number check." Well, he did remove
it under the threat of arrest if he didn't comply and, of course, the cop
found "nothing comes up in our database." So there this guy is on the side
of the road with his dash totally disassembled, etc. You get the point.

Another friend was pulled over *twice* in one day for simply driving around
town in a late 70's Checy 4x4. Typical IPD harassment.

Oh, and to top things off, our mayor, a Viet Nam vet, watched Apocalypse
Now one night on cable TV and decided to shoot his wife in the head with
his .45 auto. He was politely asked to step down from the office of the
mayor but on the next elections he quickly won a city council seat after
that and, of course, was never charged with a crime. He later ran again for
Mayor but I was so disinterested in the "superficially beautiful utopia"
that was Irvine that I merely reduced my exposure to that community to just
sleeping there until I finally moved out of the city when I was 19.

Basically the rule was: If you were young (i.e. under 25) expect to be
pulled over somewhere between once a week and once a month, just to be
interrogated and/or intimadated. If you were of any age but not driving a
late model car, expect to be pulled over - period. If you "look bad" expect
to be arrested for some trumped up reason "to be sent a message". The
fundamantal principals of Irvine and it's willing participants are that
everybody strives for Nuvo riche, upper middle class working professional
keep-up-with-the-Jones'-sameness. If you don't fit in that mold and you
don't aspire to be that, and the "community" realizes, expect to be
stopped, harrassed, and ticketed/arrested until you leave their beautiful
greenbelt-lined utopian world.

I did enjoy some "revenge" though. When I was watching Independence Day, I
was much amused when they went to "El Toro Marine Base" (in Irvine) only to
find the whole fucking town leveled to the ground. There is justice.

Even to this day when I go back inside city limits (less than once a year,
thank god) I feel like somebody is choking me. The police oppression there
is really that chilling.

Mmmm..the comment about hearing the Jaws theme was funny ...
I think u prolly only got to check the European charts to see what'll
happen , the good stuff remains underground and the cheesy
versions sell to the massives proving very little indeed . I mean ,
we already had " I wanna be a hippy " at number 1 , a dutch
happy gabba tune with " Maroo Marooana...wanna be a hippy
, i wanna get stoned " as the lyrics...altho they just sang
maroo maroo maroo on tv , so I'm kind of unmoved by the 
possibility of main stream stuff . Right now , the underground
scene globally just survives , vinyl is largely bought only
by dj's / bedroom dj's and its hard to promote instrumental music .
If this exposure can , ( god forbid ) , get some decent music
into the ears of the MTV crowd , then it could be a good thing .
I say could , cos there is the beer boy rave crowd in Europe too ,
but really , those with taste stick together and altho u;d see more
events , switched on folk like the SFRavers would know whats
cool and whats not . It'll be interested to see if the big labels take
the bait and start signing up some REAL acid bands .

I am going to get yelled at for this by one of a few people but that's ok, 
we will sort it out....

>   And I am really careful about how I dress, which
> pisses me off on one hand because i am changing my appearance based on
> another's opinions.  But, at the same time I know certain clothes have
> certain connotations and I need to be careful at times about that.  I'm
> still trying to figure this dichotomy out and find some middle ground.

	My question here is why do things that are dangerous to wear make
people want to wear them. I am not defending anyone in this case, I do not
mean to, male people types need to keep their hormones and power trips at
bay. But I have wondered this - what is the reason women what to wear
certain clothes which from the outside look ridiculously uncomfortable.
There seems to be this thing that "pretty" clothes make women feel good,
but I cannot see where that feel good is coming from...  Except from
either a pre-programmed baggage of these clothes = feel good or (and this
is where people will jump on me) from the flaunting of sexuality with a
release from responsiblity that may come from it. Ok, let's get one thing
striaght here, I have no experience as a woman dressing up in "clothes
that one might avoid" (I assume these to be alluring or something like
that) so I am in the dark on why women like wearing them.  I understand
how some clothes can be feel really nice, but then there are clothes that
just look fucking uncomfortable and do nothing but accentuate those 
things that are supposed to be sexy by boosting and cramming and creating 
more and tucking here or whatever other ways clothes are suppose to make 
the female human body more attractive...
	So maybe I am way off base and all alluring clothes have a silky
caressing feel and that is why people like them - I just do not understand
where the these alluring clothes make me feel good comes from, and the
only conclusions I can see are either women being duped into wearing them
through advertising and societial pressures (and if that is the case, then
why do women expect to be treated any differently then how they behave? I
do not see how women can expect men to break their societial conditions
that women must be possessed and that body type A is the only attractive
body type, when those same women cannot decide for themselves what they
want to buy and wear. Fuck, it isn't easy but it is what has to be done.)
or because they want the attention or maybe the power of being alluring
(is there something else I am missing here). In either case, the attention
has its responsibilities associated with it and the power trip will
hopefully be met with an equal power trip to balance things out... 
	Now does this make women evil? What about guys who think they are
just being friendly when in fact they are pestering some girl or passing
her boundaries under the guise of showing affection (well, as a guise to
the guy himself) such as a tight warm hug. Do that make guys evil too?
	My response to both is - without the realization of what they are
really doing, or what the underlying motive is, there is something missing
to be really evil because with the knowledge of an evil intent they are
trampling over other people's feelings or bouindaries (without that
knowledge they are ignorant creatures which will hopefully one day stop
troding on other peoples experinces). I believe that such a trampling will
be repaid at some point with an equal or greater trampling (another ramble
for later maybe) unless people start paying attention to what they are
doing while they are doing it. Because after the fact, you can send a
million years analyzing the situation and see it through millions of
perspectives. At the end of the day, one is most likely to use some other
perspective than the one that applied at the moment the action was
happening... Is this what people mean by living in the moment? I suppose
that is a topic for another ramble... 

dave

Well, after a long absence due to a lot of things not worth going into
here, I've got time again to get back on the list.  Hello and a virtual
hug to everyone, especially those who have given me rides when my car
was dead (and you know who you are).

The following statement kind of struck me, especially after my
experience at Wyrd, which was bouncy, sweaty, energetic, and a great
deal of fun except for one niggly detail that bugged me (and no, it
wasn't the line for the bathroom >%^)

> >you don't need e to have a good time.
> >
> >???!! yes. it's true. you can have fun at a rave without drugs.

The *ONLY* person who I didn't already sort of know who said anything to
me all night said, and I quote, "Do you have any E?"  Now I admit to
giving and receiving my fair share of grins and goofy looks all night,
but the fact that this was the _only_ thing anyone decided to actually
ask me was kind of disheartening.

The new Wired (spare me, I know, but I do read it) has an interesting
article about how Federal Express represents the dissolving of the
traditional manufacturing-distribution-retail three layer system into
direct manufacturer-customer commerce.  

Warehouse and light industrial space doesn't stay empty for long --
a decade at most.  Then it's converted into offices and lofts.  What
happened next door to 1015 Folsom is indicative of the future of SOMA.
I expect the number of venues there suitable for loud all-night events
to diminish quickly in the next few years as the old spaces are 
reoccupied by long-term office and residential tenants.  Those of you
who work in high tech/net stuff there are already part of that.  This
isn't necessarily bad, but the lesson it teaches is that our scene,
when it's healthy, thrives at the margins, picking up the detritus of
industrial/high tech capitalism and turning it into ART :)

phred

Dear SFRavefriends,

My computer tells me that on Wed, 27 Nov 1996, Aryck shared:

>         Y'know, I'm not afraid of police unless I'm doing something I
> believe is wrong. They're there to serve and protect. I've seen a lot of
> police at raves, I've never been to a busted party. My girlfriends friend's
> boyfriend was an officer at GAIA (or wherever). Everyone was cool, and you
> could talk to the cops if you wanted because they knew what to expect at
> raves, and it wasn't much of a big deal to see stoned or fucked or wired
> teens dancing to death. They were there to protect us from violence, or
> getting hurt, and that's all. Sure they may arrest a drug dealer, but only
> if you really should be arrested. 

	When "should" someone be arrested for the nonviolent act of
selling a drug?  Never, in my opinion.  Even if you disagree Aryck, what
makes you think cops only arrest those who deserve it?  How the hell can
they tell the difference?  Like you say below, isn't it often just another
kid to them, or just another juvenile delinquent?

It's just another kid to them. It's not
> like that kid selling E will fess up to all the E dealers in the city and
> lead a state-wide drug bust or anything. Shit, sooo many police are used to
> seeing kids on drugs that they rarely do much at all anymore unless you're
> doing something ELSE wrong. If they busted one guy, they'd have to bust a
> thousand others.

	No, unfortunately the way the game is played now, they don't.
They can pick and choose. They are under no obligation to enforce the laws
fairly.  They can bust you for driving 70 in a 65 zone, and ignore the guy
that goes speeding by at 80, and there's not a damn thing you can do about
it.
	Furthermore, many laws are *meant* to be arbitrarily enforced;
they are written with the expectation that cops will routinely look the
other way when they are broken -- unless they don't like the way you look
or something.  Where do you think we get the term "throwing the book" at
someone?  It means to charge someone with all the infractions that are
normally ignored.  This kind of power in the hands of the police leads
naturally to corruption of the type seen in many countries where bribery
is a way of life.

>         Starchild and Pablo are like those hippies that "Didn't trust anyone
> over 30".

	I'm not sure that slogan was ever meant to be taken literally,
however in any case I believe that mistrust of government power is a bit
more well-earned.

> Not all authority is bad. . . I mean, they're main purpose in life is to
> make sure that the good people in the world are safe and comfortable, and
> the bad people are where they should be. Times are changing. . . 

	... and so are laws, thousands are passed by our elected and
unelected leaders every year.  Do you know what they all say?  Do you know
that you're not breaking the law right now, that you haven't become,
unbeknownst to you, one of the "bad people"?

Rotten to the core,   ;)
				<<< Starchild >>>

warning: this post not for the meek or those with short attention spans!

hrmf. adam deleted the original message, but the subject line caught my
attention, being something i've pondered heavily in the past few
weeks...

the sex-hippies-raves-capitalism-society connection is complex
relationship that could easily be a 10 pound book if put into print.
seems that most of the people in RaverLand (as is the case with most of
the U.S. population) have a nagging aversion to sexual expression.
what's going on here?

this summer, I finally made it to the Burning Man festival. one of the
greatest things about Burning Man was the lack of "lifestyle police."
Left to their own devices, most of the participants let loose, but kept
to the one rule that was as much a part of the festival as the Man
itself: Do whatever you want, however you want, as long as it doesn't
infringe upon the enjoyment of the festival by someone else. This seemed
like such a simple, enjoyable way to live. Though far from being Utopia,
the festival really inspired me, and made me look at the society i live
in from a completely different point of view.

At the dawning of the Age of Aquarius, sex was viewed in a very
uncomfortable light by the american public. Ricky and Lucy Ricardo slept
in different beds! IT (read: sex) was something that everyone knew was
around, but nobody talked about. The hippies saw how it was, and
countered with their own view of sexuality. Free Love! This went against
what was "normal" at the time, but again, the emphasis was on freedom of
expression, so long as your means of expression didn't harm others.

but, you see, Capitalism has a funny way of taking its worst enemies and
using them to its advantage. I mean, you can BUY a piece of the Berlin
Wall! jeez! And those advertising agents on Madison Ave...they know and
realize now that SEX SELLS.

...which brings us back to the ravers.

Raves are meant to be a sanctuary in a world gone mad. People come to
have fun and express themselves in a setting that was created for that
very purpose. But what if (consenting) people wanted to express their
sexuality in that setting? It would evoke extreme criticism from most
Ravers. But why?

Well, sexuality seems to be viewed by Ravers, who for the most part,
were raised in the American Consumer Culture, as a tool of Domination
and Sales. The natural reaction to that view would be an abandonment
(supression?) of sexual expression. Ever notice the unofficial "uniform"
of the scene seems to be overalls? -- practical, non gender-specific
clothing.

But all this supression of sexuality seems rather artificial to many. It
looks as though after the dust from the rebellion against (or secession
from) American Consumer Society settles, Ravers are going to realize
that they've abandoned, or maybe just forgot, a major part of the human
experience. Sexuality doesn't have to be used to sell commercial time on
daytime talk shows! It can be a powerful ally and friend, and a
wonderful way to express love for another person. Don't let anyone take
it away or tell you that it's wrong or dirty.

Now, many people seem to think that Raves and the Rave Culture will
point western civilization in a new direction, away from the cold,
social Darwinist Cult of the Consumer, and towards a more open,
accepting, and compassionate future existance. Possibly, but the
Lifestyle Police are in the Rave Culture too. There are those who
haven't learned to accept their own nature, and attempt to impose their
values (and insecurities) upon others. This runs contrary to the nature
of our Scene, and only serves to hinder the progress of our Culture.

To the Lifestyle Police:
Try to have some faith! Let people decide how to express themselves. As
long as the underlying "don't ruin someone else's enjoyment" rule is
adhered to, i don't see how this could be a problem. I realize that most
people aren't comfortable with the images this might invoke, but
remember: if you don't agree with what you see, you can always go (or
look) elsewhere.

No. I guess the Rave Scene ISN'T about sex.
But should it be completely DEVOID of it?

Subject: Rave Spaces and SOMA
In-Reply-To: <9611272104.ZM13206@well.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.961128081909.23461A-100000@pluto>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


  I've been doing research on SOMA, and agree completely with Fred's
observations. The derelict warehouse spaces are being snapped up at a
dizzying rate and converted into lofts and offices, or else torn down
completely and made over into high-revenue spaces (condos, upscale
corporate satellites, etc.). 
  The president of one company in the 600 block of 3rd Street said that
the rates in his building had gone from 45 cents a foot a year ago, to 80
cents a foot when he signed his lease 6 months ago, to $1.05 now --
expensive, but still a bargain compared to the $2 a square foot in Silicon
Valley.
  I looked at some lofts on Tehama Street last week that were pretty raw,
but still going for $240,000-$280,000 -- and they are selling.
  According to USA Today (if Phred can read Wired, I can confess to USA
Today), there are around 400 multimedia companies in SOMA right now, and
the numbers are on the way up -- as are the numbers of services that
support the folks who work there (copy shops, cafes, etc.).
  So... if the nighttime warehouse rave scene is going to stay alive in
SF, it looks to me like it will have to migrate further south into China
basin, and come up against Portrero Hill and Hunter's Point.
  Anyone with other ideas on this movement?
 

On Wed, 27 Nov 1996, Fred Heutte wrote:

> Warehouse and light industrial space doesn't stay empty for long --
> a decade at most.  Then it's converted into offices and lofts.  What
> happened next door to 1015 Folsom is indicative of the future of SOMA.
> I expect the number of venues there suitable for loud all-night events
> to diminish quickly in the next few years as the old spaces are 
> reoccupied by long-term office and residential tenants.  Those of you
> who work in high tech/net stuff there are already part of that.  This
> isn't necessarily bad, but the lesson it teaches is that our scene,
> when it's healthy, thrives at the margins, picking up the detritus of
> industrial/high tech capitalism and turning it into ART :)
> 
> phred
>

Subject: Sex and E, etc.

One thing that I observe in many people who use drugs and/or alcohol ... is
that they are using them as a tool to alter their behavior....

I often see people who are drunk or high allowing themselves to do the
things they wish they could do all the time (albeit often more sloppily)
... you know, the drunk who is more outgoing and friendly, or is saying the
things they were too chicken to say when they were sober, or the e-head who
is hugging and touching and expressing their sexuality, or telling people
their real feelings when they'd never do that in a sober state (one of my
boyfriends calls e the "truth serum").

If you are someone whose behavior changes a lot when in an altered state,
take a look at it.  Why?  What is it that you aren't expressing in your
daily unaltered state that is trying to be let out? What are you
repressing?

If you wait until you're high on e to express your sensual/sexual side, you
MUST find a way to learn to express that part of yourself when you're
sober.  If you need a few beers to get out on a dancefloor and dance, or to
talk to people you want to talk to ... you MUST learn to do that without
the chemical assistance.

This is all a learning experience ... and if you take a look at what you do
when you're inhibitions have been lessened by chemicals, you'll see the
part of you that needs expressing ... learn to do it!

Every time you alter your state, look back later and ask, how did I behave
differently than I would have if I were sober?  Think about why.

And once you learn to express yourself more consistently in your life, you
won't have those ridiculous "I can't believe I did that!" blowouts that
result from what you've been holding back exploding when you finally lift
the cover on it!

Be yourself, all the time.

Love, Leslie

>>Au contraire!  I think language skills are ESSENTIAL to thinking beyond a
>>primitive, animalistic level!

At 6:55 PM 11/26/96, David Ginsberg, ginsberg@uclink4.berkeley.edu
wrote:
>I have difficulty with such anthropocentric langauge.  "Man is the
>highest", "the center", "has dominion over the beasts", etc.  Reminds me of
>Sunday school.  What have the cognitive changes in the human psyche 
>wrought over the past 5 millenia?  High tech wars which require the
>courage to push a button while safely out of range, television, coca-cola and 
>breast implants.  Human history is filled with cases of genocide and forgive 
>me if I'm just unaware but I don't recall hearing of such mass slaughterings
>among "primitive" animals.  IMHO many of the greatest advances in the 
>human condition are the result of getting back in tune with such "primitive" 
>and "lower" functions as compassion, love, and other emotions.  My cat feels
>love, feels like it belongs, and loves me.  What "advances" could be more
>important than that?
  The issue isn't to what ends man has applied its knowledge.  The fact
that the advances we have made, and we _have_ made advances, required
language is the point.
  Animals, like the _domesticated_ house cat, are not the best example,
I'm sure you'd agree.  Some animals live brutal lives based on those
"lower functions."  

  And language skills are essential to _avoid_ the problems you
mentioned.
Here is a Hawkings quote which I think is right on target...

For millions of years, mankind livd just like animals.
Then something happened which unleashed the power of our imagination.
We learned too talk.
And we learned to listen.
Speech has allowed the cuhmunication of ideas, enabling human beings to
   work together.
To build the impossible.
Mankind's greatest achievements have come about by talking.
And it's greatest failures by NOT talking.
IT DOESN'T HAVE TO BE LIKE THIS!
Our greatest hopes could become reality in the future.
With the technology at our disposal, the possibilities are unbounded.
All we need to do is ...
  make sure ...
    we keep...
      talking .

parties (at least undergrounds), were throwm in Hunters Point you would
have a better chance at success.  The REAL problem with hunters point and
"ravers" is turf respect.  You have GOT to have buy-in from the locals,
otherwise you are nothing more than an interloper and trespasser.

Equinox & Vortex parties were thrown in HP with great success.  The real
issue however is getting protection from, er, break-in that WILL OCCUR IF
YOU DON'T PAY THE PROPER RESPECT TO THE NEIGHBORHOOD!  It can be done, you
just have got to know who to go to and who to trust.  Even the cops in HP
can be cool (an undercover cop came into a Vortex, checked it out, wished
us good luck, then left.  It as all good.)  No problem from the locals from
what I recall.

But then again, nothing is supposed to last forever.  The rave/dance
community is so fractured, and is such a loose collection of people ,
everyone with different goals, that establishing a presence is next to
impossible.  As I have said in the past, if people were to present a
unified front, we wouldn't have to scramble for places, permits could be
obtained much easier, and there could be more frequent events.  If there
weren't the animosity between promoters, DJ's, and other elements, and if
people acted in concert for the common good of dance culture, the scene
would be a bit more viable.  Since no such coalition exists, we, like other
fringe movements, will always be pushed farther and farther to the
edges...always near the brink of becoming obsolete (the numbers in
attendance are proof.  It is about 1/3 of what it was in '92).  Compare
this to the clout the gay community has in SF.  Cops DARE NOT bust up a gay
event, or come down to hard on them (do you think the Townsend security are
as hard on the gay patrons using drugs as they are on the straight patrons?
No, the treatment is much, much heavier with 'straight' parties...I don't
even think they try to search the gay bros & sistahs).  Why?  Becuase gays
in this city are organized, have political and economic clout, and have a
definitive presence in the community....unlike 'ravers' who generally party
during the weekend exclusively. I am not sure whether 'dance culture' is
really viable, even after 6 years I have a tendency to think all of this is
a phase, and will be replaced.  Sex clubs have lasted despite AIDS, I do
not think dance culture has such resilience.  Especially with all the
forces against it:  'legit' club owners, promoters underhanded tactics,
'legit' owners in cohoots with the cops in payola schemes, 'legit' club
owners making sure UG's don't happen and employing the cops as their droogs
to shut down UG's, and suspicious fire-marshall activity.  Nope, since the
dance community (i.e. ravers) are not organized, I am afraid that it will
always have to deal with the push and pull of other forces who have a
vested interest in the culture not thriving, or thriving in a more profit
alcohol driven dynamic that involves the govt. & the police.

As I said years ago, the political inactivity of ravers will be thier
demise For n F,ony he loud nd oganed get he ods  Althrsare kcke t theurb,an eenualy pushe ot (Look atth FillreHayesaleyHutesint hMisi, asoon, he
Tnderlin..getriion 10  ovt.' mot efiietus fiuidpapr(tm t date) Lok an earn

eac ut
hn

Subject: I'm back [cue ominous chord]
Author:  grigsby@netgate.net at atlas
Date:    11/27/96 8:54 PM


Well, after a long absence due to a lot of things not worth going into 
here, I've got time again to get back on the list.  Hello and a virtual 
hug to everyone, especially those who have given me rides when my car 
was dead (and you know who you are).
     
The following statement kind of struck me, especially after my 
experience at Wyrd, which was bouncy, sweaty, energetic, and a great 
deal of fun except for one niggly detail that bugged me (and no, it 
wasn't the line for the bathroom >%^)
     
> >you don't need e to have a good time. 
> >
> >???!! yes. it's true. you can have fun at a rave without drugs.
     
The *ONLY* person who I didn't already sort of know who said anything to 
me all night said, and I quote, "Do you have any E?"  Now I admit to 
giving and receiving my fair share of grins and goofy looks all night, 
but the fact that this was the _only_ thing anyone decided to actually 
ask me was kind of disheartening.
     
// grigsbeast

Precedence: bulk


Dear SFRavers,

My computer tells me that on Thu, 28 Nov 1996, Argon 99 shared:

> >	When "should" someone be arrested for the nonviolent act of
> >selling a drug?  Never, in my opinion.  Even if you disagree Aryck, what
> 
> nonviolent? i suppose so in a phsyical sense. but there are certain kinds
> of drug dealers who _should_ be busted.  the ones who cut their shit and
> don't tell you, the ones who have no idea what exactly they are selling you
> or lie when they tell you their mdoh is mdma, the ones who don't really
> give a fuck about you past your $20. those are drug dealers who should be
> busted.

	I guess I was a bit too general in saying no drug dealer should
ever be busted.  What I meant was, no honest drug dealer should have to
worry about it.  Any merchant intentionally misrepresenting their product
or telling you something about it they don't know to be true should face
legal repercussions.
	If your drug dealer doesn't love you as a person, on the other
hand, I agree that this is too bad, but do they deserve to go to jail for
it?

> "no brain, no pain"
> use common sense. you wouldn't walk down a dark street in a high crime area
> wearing an expensive coat and carrying $1000, why would you smoke a joint
> or shoot up in front of a cop?
> -brendan

	Isn't this called blaming the victim?  We already know that not
everyone exhibits common sense all the time, and common sense tells us
that people who don't use it are already going to have a tough time in
many situations.  
	It's easy to say "tough shit, shoulda known better" to people
lacking street smarts, but shouldn't we as a society strive for a
higher standard than that?  Shouldn't we have a goal of a world free from
crime, both the kind committed by hoodlums in dark alleys who feel no need
to justify their actions and the kind committed by hoodlums with badges
who use the law as their justification?

For liberty,
				<<< Starchild >>>

Hey everybody! ;)

I just found this book in the bathroom at my mom and dad's house outside of Detroit... 

I am such a sap! I must have cried through reading pretty much the whole thing and a 
good few minutes afterwards. I suggest picking this book up if you are into what it's 
talking about (as if it really makes a difference what I think, :D). There are some 
very nice illustrations. :D

This goes out to all of you, like it or not! ;)


About Friendship
Thoughts, Hopes, Reflections

Written (and illustrated) by Lynne Gerard
published by C.R. Gibson Company

-
Dedicated to friends who come & friends who go... wherever the winds may take us, fond 
memories of times shared will forever remain.
-

There is something exceptional about friendship, which is life-giving to the soul.

Without, or from within, a divine destiny shapes our lives and impresses upon us the 
importance of good friendships.

The people we meet, especially the friends we keep, are sent to us... and we are sent 
to them, for the mutual purpose of support and discovery.

This means that our friendship is not a chance occurrence...

....our paths have crossed for a special reason.

You and I have been given the oppurtunity to consider life through each other's 
personal perceptions.

I take notice of things you feel are important...

...and you are aware of things I hold dear.

Friendship helps us develop greater sensitivity and empathy,

as we learn to respect a different point of view.

The bond of friendship gives us a better understanding of ourselves and our place in 
the circle of life.

Each of us is an important part of all that is.

You are unique and I am unique...

...each of us possess special God-given apptitudes.

Friendship is like the rain that nourishes, and the sun that encourages growth.

Through friendship we help each other recognize and develop our inner potentials.

We share each other's sorrows and joys.

We uplift each other when apprehension tries to overcome hope.

We give each other the courage to use the strength within to preserve and triumph.

Like the chickadee sings a song of praise, like the tides embrace the shore, my spirit 
rejoices in the magic of you and me.

Life is much more than what is seems, and much more than what we know...

...for each day is a new discovery, and we cannot say what tommorrow's wind may bring.

Yet, of this I am certain; knowing you has made me a better person,

and I will forever hold a part of you within me.

-
Friendships help develop awareness and understanding.
-


PLUR -> Rage,
  matter

"I'm a Sagitarrius, the most philosophical of all of the signs, but I don't believe in 
it. I think it's a buncha bullshit, myself." - James Douglas Morrison

                - music -

http://www.mcs.net/~arduous/

Hi agin! ;)
 Following is another little dittee from yours truly...

Wednesday, Outside Chicago: missed connecting with hion, he must have had to do some 
laundry or something. his friend Ericka and I hooked up and went down to the funky 
little ticket place and picked up our $10 (oops, forgot our canned goods!) tix to this 
vibeonauts/mushgroove par-tay "Blessings"... Followed the direx to the Maywood Civic 
Center. hmmm, party in a public space, interesting. Once, inside (12:30a) found a very 
happy and friendly crowd, some familiar faces (Alex and Eric), but more than anything a 
DAMN vibe, waiting to blow! [matter side steps here, to inflate the 'frisco scene; some
fellow par-tayers have informed me that the par-tay I am describing here ain't nuthin' 
compared to 'frisco -> I can't wait!] After phantom 45 ended his set (nice junglism 
[has a small place in my heart]), not sure who was up next, but that's when it started 
to happen... MINGLING! That's right! Phuckin' mingling at a CHICAGO par-tay. I didn't 
believe it! Now, granted, there were still a handfull (5% or less) of ppl who were just 
not with it, but that's kewl, whatever. Everybody else made up for it, WOOOOOO! I gave 
some very *nice"* folk some goodies (PEZ whistle, cassette of me/my bro) and got some 
great stuff back (kewl x-mas pencil and KERMIT PEZ container), but more than the stuff, 
I met some really great folk at this one! I know, you're prolly thinking, oh that 
matter, he's always happy and saize every par-tay is the best yet, etc. BUT REALLY, 
this was the best yet! I love you all and I hope it jus' keeps gettin' better, forever! 
;)

Finally, I am going to get to sleep! Get this: I drove to Detroit immediately after 
takin' Ericka home (left nw-chicago burbs at 8:00a), arrived in Detroit around 3:00p. 
Always a joy driving by the world' largest trash incinerator (ackkkk, cough!) I must 
admit, I got a few hours of zzzz's b4 going out with a friend to the Grosse Pointe 
hangout "Tap Room", where they were playing Underworld! ;)

PLUR -> Rage,
  matter

"I'm a Sagitarrius, the most philosophical of all of the signs, but I don't believe in 
it. I think it's a buncha bullshit, myself." - James Douglas Morrison

The only problem is rave is nota religion, and there is no sacred texts
regarding rave/dance culture.

As for what is important, I think if you ask 100 participants of dance
culture what is important, you would have 1,000,000 different answers.
Mathwise:  You know how ravers/partyers go on and on about the unity, the
love, the so on and so forth ad infinitum.  So I have averaged it out to
1000 things a person could find or babble on about.

Given my expertise in the subject, I *am* the undisputed expert in all of
this (if you dare not believe me, just ask me), I have reduced it to the
ultimate denominator:  "It's just a party."

Now if that is what is important, then so be it.  But why do we have to
remind ourselves of it every so often. I have an answer to that too; it is
because we go on an on about the other tired ass subjects that are a part
of the community.  Hmmm cyclical?  Perhaps.  Rambling?  Always. ;)

I'm out,
John

P.S.  Happy Holidays and many ;)

>> "no brain, no pain"
>> use common sense. you wouldn't walk down a dark street in a high crime area
>> wearing an expensive coat and carrying $1000, why would you smoke a joint
>> or shoot up in front of a cop?
>	Isn't this called blaming the victim?  We already know that not

the victim. victim of stupidity perhaps. is someone a victim when they
drive drunk and crash their car? are they a victim when they are playing
with a handgun and shoot someone in the head accidently? and even if
someone can't exihibit common sense 100% of the time, that's what their
friends should be there for. i certainly can blame the victim. if you know
the consequences of your actions, then you should be responsible for them.
responsibility, for yourself and others.

>everyone exhibits common sense all the time, and common sense tells us
>that people who don't use it are already going to have a tough time in
>many situations.  

and judges frequently realize this when they pass sentance.

>	It's easy to say "tough shit, shoulda known better" to people
>lacking street smarts, but shouldn't we as a society strive for a
>higher standard than that?  Shouldn't we have a goal of a world free from
certainly we should. but the onus is not on my shoulders to help people
avoid responsibilty. more, i think my responsibilty is to help educate
people. i never let any of my friends drive drunk, i make an attempt to
keep\ my friends away from police eyes, but there comes a point where
people have to do something on their own. if they chose to leave the shield
of their friends, or should their friends lack the same common sense, then
they should be prepared to face the consequences of their actions. and if
they get caught, or crash their car, or run over someone while drunk, then
live and learn.

a lapse in common sense does not abdicate someone of responsibility.
-brendan

Mime-Version: 1.0

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com

>>let's not forget that e was originally used as a psychotheraputic drug to
>>help people realize that expressing their emotions and desires is okay...
>>Some people (even some ravers) use E in a constructive way to try to get
>>in touch (no pun intended) with parts of themselves that they are scared
>>to explore otherwise...
>"I'm learning to ride the bicycle of happiness, and drugs are my training 
>wheels"

and that's an excellent metaphor, and i hope that was part of the idea that
people got out of the original post.

drugs are just that: training wheels. they can be used as a tool in aiding
you to find your "inner self" or whatever you may be seeking, but there
comes a point where you can have the same insight, without drugs. when you
can do that, then you don't need to use drugs all the time to explore
yourself.

not that drugs are the only path to that spot, but it is an option there
for people to *choose*. with that choice there is greater responsibility,
never forget that.

take care. hope everyone had a good time gutting the bird.
-brendan

Greetings all!
Just thought I'd add this to the discussion. Both of these quotes speak 
volumes to me. 

	"Psychedelics are like a boat one uses to cross a river, but 
once on the opposite bank the journey continues on foot."
			Alan Watts

	"It's a bit embarrassing to have been concerned with the human 
problem all one's life and find at the end one has no more to offer by 
way of advice than - try to be a little kinder."
			Aldous Huxley
Peace
Dhiren

Hey all,
I'd like to ask a favor of my fellow ravers.....
I'm doing a paper on raving and E. Why people rave, why they take e, and
why there is such a close connection between taking e and raving. 
Although I have textbook sources and enough personal experience to write
this paper, I am interested in hearing/reading other people's personal
insights also.  Everyone out there articulates their feelings
differently and I'd like to see what a few different perspectives are. 
Of course, total anonimity can be garanteed if so requested.  I'd be
willing to send anyone a copy of my paper when I'm done if so
interested. Cheers! 
-- 
Ari Newman
newmana@colorado.edu
http://beagle.colorado.edu/~newmana/Home.html

"Not one shred of evidence supports the notion that life is serious."

I rave for a variety of reasons.  First of all, it's just a total relief
from the everyday world for me.  When i'm at school or working, there are
like so many obligations and duties to fufill and when i'm out raving and
just dancing away, it's like i'm in my own world with all my fellow
ravers.  We are just like one big family.  I, personally don't do E
because i would so fucken messed up that i don't think that i'd be able
to function normally again.  I did E once or twice a while ago, i felt so
unlike me, that it was just such a bad experience.  And besides when
you're with a whole bunch of people on E, its like one big orgy.

I also rave because it's fun.  and i love meeting new people.  I'm really
friendly and when i go to raves i just try to make new friends all the
time.  And i  also love the music.  I just in a total state of trance
when i'm dancing for like 6 hours straight.

******sorry for using "like" so much**********

lunarchic

MIME-Version: 1.0

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

About your paper on raving: 
For the record, I am extrememly new to the scene (but maybe that means
I'll have a fresh perspective; who knows?), but there seem to be two major
influences drawing me more and more into rave settings:  first is the
music.  I love (and write) electronic music, and it's nice to hear so
many people doing *sooo much* with it!  Also, (for me, at least), my first
Exceptionally altered state induced a new appreciation and realization for
certain aspects of the music (i.e. the builds that disassemble the
beat suddenly, then gradually reassemble it to the rhythm of a building
acid bassline) that  I've been able to hang onto and recognize even in
complete sobriety.  I wish I could explain this better, but I fear I
would only talk in circles on this, or get overly technical with music
theory (which I'd be happy to discuss ad nauseum, if I thought you
might be interested; alas, I drift off-topic already...).  The second,
undoubtedly, is the caliber of open-minded people one can find in the
environment.  I know it's been said before, but I can't emphasize
enough what a massive relief it is to have the socially oppressive
norms of the outside world slowly evaporate in such a positive
environment.  Even with my limited exposure to date, I can already see
that I am not alone in this belief.  A great many folk also seem to share
the common goal of the enjoyment of life, even if for no other the purpose
of creating happiness itself.  Anyways, that's my $.02, let me know if I
can help you out any more than that.
(BTW, please send me a copy of the paper when you're done; I'd be very
interested in reading it; thanx!)

Enjoy life-
<,+= joe =+'>

I have been told that the manufacture of "E" creates toxic waste on par 
with the manufacture of speed.  I don't know any hard facts about this 
but wondered why this was never a discussion topic among ravers (being so 
Eco-conscience and such [pun intended]).  Where is all of this waste 
going?  Do we care?  Does anyone know the facts about the 
destructiveness/potency of such waste?

Dear SFRavefriends,

	I've taken the discussion to private mail... unfortunately I
forgot to make a copy of my response before sending it off.  Perhaps Argon
will be kind enough to share it with anyone who wants to hear my response.

				<<< Starchild >>>

My computer tells me that on Fri, 29 Nov 1996, Argon 99 shared:

> >> "no brain, no pain"
> >> use common sense. you wouldn't walk down a dark street in a high crime area
> >> wearing an expensive coat and carrying $1000, why would you smoke a joint
> >> or shoot up in front of a cop?
> >	Isn't this called blaming the victim?  We already know that not
> 
> the victim. victim of stupidity perhaps. is someone a victim when they
> drive drunk and crash their car? are they a victim when they are playing
> with a handgun and shoot someone in the head accidently? and even if
> someone can't exihibit common sense 100% of the time, that's what their
> friends should be there for. i certainly can blame the victim. if you know
> the consequences of your actions, then you should be responsible for them.
> responsibility, for yourself and others.
> 
> >everyone exhibits common sense all the time, and common sense tells us
> >that people who don't use it are already going to have a tough time in
> >many situations.  
> 
> and judges frequently realize this when they pass sentance.
> 
> >	It's easy to say "tough shit, shoulda known better" to people
> >lacking street smarts, but shouldn't we as a society strive for a
> >higher standard than that?  Shouldn't we have a goal of a world free from
> certainly we should. but the onus is not on my shoulders to help people
> avoid responsibilty. more, i think my responsibilty is to help educate
> people. i never let any of my friends drive drunk, i make an attempt to
> keep\ my friends away from police eyes, but there comes a point where
> people have to do something on their own. if they chose to leave the shield
> of their friends, or should their friends lack the same common sense, then
> they should be prepared to face the consequences of their actions. and if
> they get caught, or crash their car, or run over someone while drunk, then
> live and learn.
> 
> a lapse in common sense does not abdicate someone of responsibility.
> -brendan
>

Hi All,

just had to tell ya about our friday night.  Started out with our 
mother's great turkey dinner (yum!) but the night quickly went wacky...

Started things out at a friends house waiting for the entire group to 
collect.

Drove all the way from simi valley to fullerton for the F.A.M.I.L.Y. 
party, straight thru the door, started a little entertainment and groovin 
into the funky breakbeats blaring from the wall of the speakers, when 
suddenly...

the lights come up!   The party is busted!  DOH!  So OK, not the best 
time to be on the move, but we head up to LA proper.  Apparently the 
promoter is going to get all 1000 of us into another party for free :-)

So we get up there, park, chill for a bit, then hit the door.  Sorry, 
gotta pay (again), AND we hear that the FAMILY party has started up 
again!  Aaaarrrrrggg!

So we chill out at Jerry's Famous Deli for a bit, hoping for the late 
night crowd, but surprisingly, few people were there.  Then finally made 
our way back to the folks house.

So, all in all, I am missing you all, wishing I could be at a San Jose 
shindig instead of partying at zero decibels in my old room at the folks 
house :-)

peace

deeje
