was a hella bum party.  Welcome to Club X is what the name should have
been.  The ravers were out numbered to the clubbies.  It was overly packed,
you had to pay $5 to go, and worst of all the party stopped at 2:00a.m. and
the promoters knew this was going to happen (from what I have heard)  There
were total non-raver vibes in the place, not all of the DJ's spun last
night, and if you didn't go YOU DIDN'T MISS ANYTHING!!! They continued to
sell tickets for the party it seemed for a long time, and most of the
people who showed up late had to stay outside and not go in.  So they paid
for their ticket to stand outside and do nothing.  They played a lot of
house club crap. And it was a very disappointing party (club would be more
of the word here)  Anyway I think you all get the point that the promoters
just need to be shot or something.  Hope to see all of the true ravers
tonight at Be Here Now/Tribal Funk!!!!!  Peace, love, and harmony,
Eric

From: Karen Hardie <pounce@vcn.bc.ca>
Subject: Re: Why you Rave
To: Ari Newman <newmana@colorado.edu>
cc: sfRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>, MTN Raves <mtn-raves@hyperreal.com>
In-Reply-To: <329FADD6.4A1B@colorado.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9611292009.A25767-0100000@opus.vcn.bc.ca>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I rave because rave is the first thing in YEARS that has made me feel 
truly part of a community.  I love almost everything about raving - the 
music, the lights, the strangers, the scents, the clothes, the toys, and 
the amazing friends i have made through this scene.  Nearly everyone i 
have met through raving has been cool in their own weird, funky way.  
(there have been a few REALLY FUCKING ODD exceptions - but i don't dwell 
on them much. *grin*)

As for e ... i enjoy that sensation of light floaty vibrating sensual 
pounding energy that seems to fill my heart and body all night long :)  
but i save it for special occasions.  once a month or less.  I enjoy it 
too much to want the feeling to get stale, besides the fact that taking 
it often is hard on your system and wallet.

But most of my closest rave friends were NOT first encountered in an 
e-induced stupor ... if that's significant :) as a matter of fact, 80% of 
my buddies i owe to the Internet!

pounce
----------------------------
As she lay there dozing mext to me, one voice inside my head kept
saying, "Relax ... you're not the first doctor who's ever slept with
one of his patients," but another kept reminding me, "Howard, you're
a veterinarian."
                                       - Dick Wilson, Orlando, FL

From: Randy C Cone <randream@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: Saturn5 review (San Francisco) 
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>, Is it Trance? <604@party.net>,
        Know 1 <knowoneness-l@teleport.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9611301822.A1683-0100000@ese.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hi all!  =)

 Sorry for the spamming, but I thought there may be people scattered 
throughout these three lists who would like to read this.

 Saturn5 was the first party thrown by Steve S. I think he did a damn 
fine job of it!! We had the amazing Gateway sound system (and equally 
amazing crew!!), Greg Sandler (of Harmony) provided the brain numbing 
robotic lighting, Nub Chai provided the ever needed and delicious chai 
that only THEY can provide!
 
 The DJ's were wonderful also. Jon Logan (of ambience at dinner  ;) 
provided some tasty tunes at dinner/snacking time. Jon Carel (of Gateway) 
was next. Jon had to overcome some big bellys that were keeping some 
folks off the dance floor but by the time he was done the floor was 
equally full.

 Mystr-E (Frequency 8) was next and he really started to get the place 
rockin'. Then the cops showed up! NNNNNNNNNNNNN!!!!!!

      !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!Huge Props To Thomas Trouble!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

 Tom got us a back-up site in no time. The sound system was moved over 
to the Berkley location and we were off!

 Mystr-E continued onward with a great sounding set despite some 
technical flubs.

 The ever wonderful Anon was next. Her set was REALLY good but was very 
short. Wanh!

 The surprise of the evening was the last set by Warren Logan (of one 
track mind). This guy was GOOD!!! He had some really tasty songs and 
technically he sounded super! I can't wait to hear more from this guy!!

 I felt that (back at the original site) we had a good visual show going. 
It was a blend of Greg's robot lights, Dimension 7's video work and my 
slides/lights/decorations. I think we all blended well together and 
really produced a fine looking party.

 Thanks to all the super wonderful volunteers, without whom we never 
would have had such a good time; David Lowe, Terry (of CT Design), Matt 
Lanier, Andy W., Sarah, and a ton of other people whose names I missed or 
forgotten. Thanks also to the Dimension 7 crew!  :)

 Again; Thanks to Steve for an amazing party and for going way beyond 
what most promoters will do for their partys. With people like Steve in 
the scene, things can only get better.


   !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!STEVE ROCKS!!!!SATURN5 RULES!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!


Happy Holidaze to everyone!





Ran @ Dionysus Dreams
                                       (Namasate)

                                     -=*=-/

Hey everyone. In case you don't know by now. Space Children and Tribal
Funk are combining parties at the Home Base Warehouse. (usual place,
boring, unimaginative).Yet anything is better than what happend
yesterday. I give props to any raver that survived the horro at
Ubiquitous. The so called FREE party that with a cost of $5 per ticket.
Thats incredibly cheap, but many of us didn't bring money because it was
a ahh,err, FREE party. Right?
If you called the voicemail, it said, "we as a people have been banished
from Sacramento." blah blah blah.
I wonder why they were banished?
So they decide to have it at some bunk ity bity place. If you got to F8
early in time to receive directions (before midnight) since the place was
over max occupancy?
What is this max occupancy? I've been to parties where they cram as many
people in as possible.
Not only did they refuse to stop giving directions. They didn't even
announce it on the voice mail. I feel sorry for all the people driving
from the farthest reaches from the gallexy to go to this to find out they
only that they need to go back because they decided to not let anymore
people in. Super Cool? Hu?
And Then there was some rumor of it being on the street Duboce. This is a
residential area. I highly doubt it was there.
This might have been almost enough to tick people off. So then it is time
to annoy all the people lucky enough to get in.The party was incredibly
clubbby. More like Planet X. The music was like listening to the radio
with Jose Melendez's mix on Wild 107.7  It got broken up at around 2:00
am. Not really since they had decided to kick evreyone out at that time
and they had planned on it in advance.
Then there was the talk about an after party in Fremont. Yeah as soon as
you got there they told you to leave. Some party hu?

I don't understand these people. If you say its a free rave than its
free. if you say its in Sac, its in sac. Don't misadvertise a rave its
not cool.
I hope to see everyone at Space Children Tribal Funk.
PLUR

At 02:04 AM 11/30/96 -0800, Christina Hurley wrote:
>
>I have been told that the manufacture of "E" creates toxic waste on par 
>with the manufacture of speed.  I don't know any hard facts about this 
>but wondered why this was never a discussion topic among ravers (being so 
>Eco-conscience and such [pun intended]).  Where is all of this waste 
>going?  Do we care?  Does anyone know the facts about the 
>destructiveness/potency of such waste?

Undoubtably many illicit amphetamine manufacturers just pour their
solvents down the drain. (Someone with a bit more knowledge can describe
what they are - presumably chlorocarbons and other nasties.) Others
may be more careful about disposal, but legal disposal may be tricky
due to licensing requirements.

This "amphetamines are bad for the environment" line strikes me as a cheap
attempt by the powers that be to co-opt environmentalists' support for
their propaganda. If the powers that be were really that concerned about
the environmental effects of illicit drug manufacture, they could easily fix
the problem: legalise and regulate the manufacture of the drugs. But
somehow it seems they're crying crocadile tears over this one.

As for the destructiveness: at a guess, the solvent for a few hundred Es
is comparable to the vinyl in a car, for example.

Jeremy
